components.text: COVID-19: Managing Your Mental Health
Here at Headspace Care we recognize you might be feeling anxious or stressed about how COVID-19 could affect you and your family's physical health.
We've put together a few tips to help you manage your stress and stay resilient during this difficult time:
(1) Avoid overexposure to the news

While it’s important to stay informed, information overload can lead to extreme behavior in one of two ways. — 1) It can cause you to become anxious and even obsessive. Or, 2) it can make you numb and desensitized. Taking media breaks is important.
Positive ways to use those breaks:

items: Pick up a new hobby that can be done at home.
Make a cup of tea.
Go for walk in nature.
Do some light stretching.
Create a productivity list.
Listen to music.
Enjoy a podcast.
Meditate or develop a new mindfulness practice.

components.text: (2) Seek information from credible sources

False and confusing information about COVID-19 can cause even more anxiety. Unfortunately, there’s a lot of misinformation out there. We recommend the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the World Health Organization, and your official state and local government websites, which offer accurate and up-to-date information on the virus.
Consider sharing these sites with your loved ones to help them get accurate information, too.
(3) Seek out support

Instead of scrolling through the news, find ways to express gratitude and appreciation for your loved ones. If you’re unable to be together, pick up the phone, send a text to say “I’m thinking of you,” or set up a FaceTime or Skype date. Using technology can help you stay close. Just as you may be seeking out comfort and connection, friends and family may be, too.
Find ways to make each other laugh and limit conversations that increase anxiety.
(4) Do something that makes you happy
When we’re stressed, we tend to get into cycles of gloomy thinking and negative self-talk. Break that cycle by introducing humor into your day.

items: Have fun with dad jokes.
Play a silly game.
Watch a funny movie.
Find funny and comforting videos online. (Love cats? Search youtube for 'adorable kittens' and see what comes up!)

components.text: Laughter decreases stress by releasing endorphins, which are the hormones in your body that make you feel good!
Coping with Financial Anxiety

Millions of people across the globe are facing financial distress due to COVID-19 pandemic. If you’re feeling anxious about your financial security, know that you’re not alone and that there are ways to reduce your anxiety. We’ve put together a few of our favorite tips:
(1) Accept that it’s completely normal to feel anxious over your financial situation.

Recognizing that you don’t have control over it right now may help you pay attention to things you can control that may affect your mental health, such as your media intake and your self-care. Focusing on your strengths and your past experience with other difficult situations can help, too.
(2) Prioritize your mental health.

Continue doing activities that make you feel calm. If you no longer can attend in-person yoga classes, take classes online. If you talk to a therapist regularly and you can afford to do so, prioritize spending money on that over other expenditures.
(3) Talk to a trusted friend or family member about your financial concerns.

You don’t need to go into detail, but if you keep your worry to yourself, you could end up feeling more isolated and  anxious. Whomever you talk to may be able to offer some perspective or advice you hadn’t thought about.

properties.name: Helping Sick Loved Ones From Afar
properties.image_path: https://content-repository.ginger.dev/audio/images/ActivityCard_COVID_How Best to Support People Who Are Sick.png

components.text: Helping Sick Loved Ones From Afar

The number of COVID-19 cases is growing and most people will know someone who has it. While the majority of people who have it will not develop symptoms, there may come a time when someone you love gets sick. When you can’t physically care for someone, there are still ways to help.
Keeping reading for three tips...
(1) Send them a get well card or care package.
Since it’s best not to go to the store except for necessities, get creative with items around your house.
(2) Set up a grocery or meal delivery for them.

Ask them to send you a list of items they want, or surprise them with something you think they’ll want. (Setting up deliveries can be time consuming. A little effort on your part can make a big difference).
(3) Take care of yourself.

Having a loved one or friend who is sick can cause worry and anxiety. Make sure to get plenty of rest and take time to manage your stress. Do deep breathing, take walks, watch something that makes you laugh.

properties.thumbnail_url: https://content-repository.ginger.dev/audio/thumbnails/ActivityCard_COVID_How Best to Support People Who Are Sick.png

properties.name: Tips on How to Thrive While Homeschooling

components.text: Tips on How to Thrive While Homeschooling

Up until the COVID-19 pandemic, homeschooling has been an educational choice for some families. Today, homeschooling is the norm for families across the world. Families are now finding themselves in very unfamiliar territory-- working and schooling from home. This can bring feelings of anxiousness, and thoughts of, “I’m not qualified to do this.” These feelings are normal whether you’ve been choosing to homeschool your children for years, or you’ve been unexpectedly thrust into it.
This activity will share a few fun ideas that have helped homeschooling veterans not only “survive” home education, but actually have fun and enjoy it!
1) Start a “Question Book”

items: Use an inexpensive notebook and let your children decorate it.
Vadiate and hold space for the questions that come up by writing it in the Question Book.
Set aside time each week to explore the answers together online.

components.text: 2) Take a Virtual Field Trip

items: Take a “trip” to Le Louvre in Paris, visit an aquarium, explore space, or visit Yosemite National Park through a simple Google search.
Download Google Earth to explore different landmarks of the world.
Do an eye-spy activity or scavenger hunt. Talk with your kids about what they found interesting, strange or exciting.

components.text: 3) Learn Together in the Kitchen

items: Explore subjects like science, math and art by cooking and baking a family recipe.
Let your children learn about budgeting by planning a meal and making the grocery list.
Learn about other cultures by finding recipes online.
Make lasting memories and laugh about those recipes that “fail.”

components.text: 4) Be Creative
Being creative can enhance your child’s learning, and it is a great stress reliever for kids and the adults working hard to keep it all together.

items: Make art, color, paint, find a simple recipe for homemade playdough, or try origami.
Print free coloring pages. There are many online.

components.text: 5) Dust Off The Classics
There are so many classic reads that we can expose our children to, like The Call of the Wild by Jack London and The Lion the Witch and The Wardrobe by C.S. Lewis.

items: Access the classics on a Kindle or other device.
Get simple lesson plans and printable activities from sites like Scholastic.com.

components.text: 6) Take Time for You
Your kids’ teachers take breaks during the day, and you can too!

items: Read a book, meditate, FaceTime with another parent, take a walk alone or take a good long nap.
Let your kids learn through free play time, or call a “quiet time” for the whole family if you need to.

components.text: While you work hard to keep your child’s education going through these unpredictable and unique times, remember that the only qualifications you need to do this well are love and curiosity.
Do your best, breathe and be well.

properties.name: Take a Mental Health Break From the News

components.text: Take a Mental Health Break From the News

News about COVID-19 is hard to look away from these days. Updates and alerts seem to be on rapid fire, and unfortunately the news can feel scary and overwhelming. Too much bad news can be detrimental to our sleep, our mood, and our overall mental health. We’ve got ways to help you cut back on spending too much time immersed in the news.
We’ve put together a few tips that will:

items: Help you reduce the amount of negative news you consume
Give you tips and ideas for alternatives to the news
Find ways to relax when the news causes you stress

components.text: (1) Pay attention to how the news makes you feel as you engage with it, and afterward.

After you read, listen or watch a news story about COVID-19, how do you feel? It’s common to feel stressed, anxious, and sad. If you’re feeling that way, you could benefit from limiting your news consumption so you don’t get stuck in those emotions. Noticing how you feel can help you make that change.
Which leads to the next tip...
(2) Limit the number of times a day you look at the news.

items: Choose one or two times a day when you’ll look at the news (and not before bed). Limit the amount of time you look at it. If it’s helpful, set an alarm for when you’ll look at the news. Then set a timer for 10 minutes and stop looking at the news when the timer rings.

Turn off your notifications. Notifications on your phone not only can bring up those unpleasant feelings, they distract you from what you’re doing and tempt you into reading the full news story. Instead of news notifications, sign up for alerts from your city or town to find out crucial information.
Only read news from trusted sources. Local or national news organizations are your best bet. There can be a lot of misinformation on social media, which can cause more anxiety.

components.text: (3) Find pleasant distractions.

items: If every time you pick up your phone, you’re tempted to check the news, choose another app instead. Open a meditation app, look at your photos, search for funny gifs to send to friends. Whatever it is, make sure it lifts your mood.
Or, put your phone down and engage in an activity that calms you down. Go for a walk, take a deep breath, stretch.

components.text: Sharing Space, Giving Space
Sheltering in place can mean spending more time than usual in the same space as your loved ones. In this new reality, we need to manage disruptions to both our personal and professional lives.
This activity will share seven tips to help you feel grounded, improve connections, create autonomy and perhaps even make some moments of magic in this time.

One of the hardest things about being with our partner 24/7 is that while it can be comforting during a stressful time, it can also be a source of stress itself. Your similarities and differences become amplified. You learn when it’s easy to collaborate and... when you’re just baffled by your partner’s choices and tendencies! Read on for seven tips to manage...
1. Create a schedule and let each other know what you are up to
Structure can feel hard to find if you don’t make an effort to create it. Carve out time and space for work and play.
2. Create physical, emotional and psychological boundaries.

Just because you’re together 24/7 doesn’t mean you’re both accessible 24/7. Create times when you or your partner are able to dedicate time to work, movement or any other kind of time that will be your very own. Perhaps even choose a word or a gesture (keep it nice!) that will let the other person know you are in the middle of something and that you would rather not be interrupted.
3. Agree on how to split household duties.
You’re likely to be eating together and cleaning up after each other. Discuss the best way to manage chores and how you can make each other feel respected and cared for.
4. Engage in judgement-free listening.

We are going through a uniquely stressful time with many unknowns. Everyone reacts to this situation differently, and emotions can frequently change. Try to be present for your partner in their process and set the expectation that they will do the same for you.
5. Work on something together, whether it is a home improvement project or managing your kid’s school.
Take the time to work together and recognize yourselves as a team.
6. Create moments to intentionally connect.

Get creative. Don’t take each other for granted physically, emotionally or psychologically. Talk about hopes and dreams. And, because changing locations isn’t possible, find a way to create a little magic at home.
Staying Connected

Social connections are crucial for mental health. Feeling connected to others has been shown to reduce stress, increase happiness, and give us a sense of purpose. Studies have also shown that people who feel connected have lower rates of anxiety and depression.
That said, it’s hard to stay connected while social distancing, but maintaining relationships is perhaps more important now, during COVID-19, than ever.
This activity will share some tips to help you stay connected during this time.
Be intentional
Texting is a  great way to stay in touch, but we’re often not fully engaged during a text conversation as we are when we’re talking to someone.
Schedule a time to chat in real time either on video or phone so that you can be fully present.
Get creative
Use technology to create new experiences.

items: Have a happy hour or dinner date through video chat.
Use apps to play games, watch shows, and stay connected. (More and more apps are coming all the time to help you share experiences and activities.)
Schedule a time to watch livestreams of your favorite events and activities, such as gym classes, book clubs, and concerts.

components.text: Take the lead
Don’t wait for someone else to schedule activities. Make an effort to reach out to friends and family and get something on the calendar.

items: Schedule a virtual game night, family video chat, or invite someone to take a live morning workout class with you.
Create new and fun ways to connect and enjoy experiences together through the use of video chat, screen sharing, and the endless amount of new apps.

properties.name: Surviving Social Distancing When Working from Home

components.text: Surviving Social Distancing When Working from Home
Working from home can be an uncomfortable change in lifestyle, so it’s important you don’t neglect your mental health as you adjust to your new routine.
Here are a few ways to stay healthy and focused when working remotely:
(1) Actually get dressed

Our daily attire impacts how we act, speak and think. In fact, there have been studies showing that dressing up, or putting on work clothes, can make you feel more in control of your surroundings. How we treat ourselves (and how we treat ourselves in our home environment) can have a subtle, yet powerful, impact on our self-esteem.
(2) Soak up that fresh air

Rain or shine, spending time outdoors can lower stress, anxiety and even blood pressure! Try getting outside first thing in the morning and take frequent breaks throughout your day. If you can, leave your phone inside your home, or at least in your pocket to get away from the news and focus on your self-care instead.
(3) Plan and prep
Just as if you were going to the office, plan and prepare for your day.

items: Pack a lunch.
Take coffee breaks.
If you normally exercise during the day, set out work-out clothes and block out time for it.
Think of energizing ways to spend the extra time you might’ve spent commuting, such as doing a calming breathing exercise or 5-10 minute meditation.

components.text: (4) Create boundaries
Boundaries give you the ability to balance work and home, creating necessary distance between the two.

items: Designate a working area in your home.
Clear that working space at the end of the day, every day.
Take your lunch break away from your desk.
Identify and announce your working hours, and let your coworkers know when you are “signing off” for the day.
Save household chores for “after hours” — avoid multitasking!

components.text: (5) Give that brain a break
If you find yourself feeling overwhelmed and unproductive, try adopting brain breaks.
Brain breaks increase creativity by increasing oxygen flow to the brain during the day. To do this:

items: Designate a working area in your home.
Make a list of tasks you can complete in an hour, even if it’s just one.
Once you complete that task, reward yourself with a short break.
Consider doing something enjoyable or active to get that oxygen pumping, such as taking a walk!
Resume the following hour with a new task and a new reward.

components.text: (6) Connect from afar
Do not let distance keep you from connecting with your coworkers. Find ways to create your own virtual watercooler!

items: Call and check in with a coworker in the morning.
Set up informal meetings to catch up as you would in the office.
Try virtual walking meetings by phone or Facetime.

components.text: Plan, prioritize and recognize

Knowing how much time we spend at work, it is no surprise that a sudden shift to a new working environment may feel like a drastic life change. Planning ahead, prioritizing and recognizing your mental health needs will help to find better work (from home)-life balance, regardless of where you are.

properties.name: Talking to Your Family - Young and Old - About COVID-19

components.text: Talking to Your Family - Young and Old - About COVID-19

The COVID-19 crisis affects people in so many different ways. Figuring out what to say to loved ones can feel challenging, especially since this is a new situation for everyone. If you find yourself needing to explain the crisis to kids or discuss it with seniors, but you aren’t sure what to say --  this activity can help.
First, who do you want to talk to about COVID-19? (Choose one).
Talking to Kids About COVID-19
There is a lot of useful information out there about how to talk to kids about COVID-19. Here are a few of our favorite tips from a mental health perspective:

items: Find out how much your child knows about the virus. For kids six years and older, ask them what they know before you start talking to them about it. For kids under six, if they haven’t heard about it and aren’t asking, it may be unnecessary to bring it up.

Speak to them in a calm and reassuring way. Kids are good at knowing how you’re feeling, regardless of what you say. Also, pay attention to what you say to other adults when kids are around. If your kids are within earshot, they may be listening.

If your child is worried s/he might get sick, or that you might get sick, let them know that doctors and scientists are working hard to find ways to help people stay healthy. Reassure them that most people, especially kids, who get the virus will be OK, although some people will get very sick.
Enjoy this time with your kids. Don’t dismiss their fears, and make sure they feel loved.

components.text: Older Adults
If there’s an older adult you know who’s isolated due to stay-at-home orders, here are a few tips for how you can be supportive:

items: Check in on them regularly. Call and video chat just to say “I’m thinking of you” (and teach them how to video chat if they’re not familiar with it).
Encourage them to do activities that they find enjoyable and that may be helpful, such as taking walks, stretching, listening to music, doing puzzles, reading.
Offer to run an errand for them or bring them a meal.
Send them a list of virtual events they might enjoy: live concerts, readings, museum tours.
Tap into their experience and ask them for advice about getting through difficult times.
Most importantly, let them know you care about them and are there for them. Express gratitude to them for being a part of your life.

properties.name: Shaping a Virtual School Experience that Works for Your Family

components.text: Shaping a Virtual School Experience that Works for Your Family

Virtual school may not be ideal for most kids and parents. But, if you reframe how you look at the situation, virtual school—whether fully virtual or hybrid—can be an opportunity for all of us facing this collective challenge. Yes, it’s possible to be optimistic, and even excited about virtual learning. Here are some strategies from a Headspace Care coach and former homeschooler to survive—and thrive—this school year.
This activity will:

items: Give you five tangible strategies to help you make virtual school a success
Help you think about the specific needs of your family to manage this year

components.text: Try out some or all of these tips to help your family make the most out of virtual school.
1. Set Your Expectations

Set expectations that suit your reality, not your ideal situation and be flexible with your expectations. The following method called “Post-it: Sort it” can help you see your expectations for yourself and your child, and from there you can assess whether they’re reasonable.
Post-it: Sort it

Write down everything that needs to be done in a day on a sticky note. Be sure to include activities that you or your child want to do. Then with your child, sort the stickies into three groups: Fun, Should Do and Non-Negotiable. Look at the categories. Are you allowing them to have fun at all? Or is everything a non-negotiable? Are all the activities realistic? Get input from your child. What might be considered fun for you may not be for your child.
2. Get organized
There are two pieces to this one: organizing your space and organizing your time.
Space

If possible, dedicate a space for your child to work. If there isn’t a separate space, try to designate a place where your child can put their laptop and work away at the end of the day. Make sure all of the passwords and logins are easily accessible and visible. It’s also useful to have a calm-down space where kids can take some time to settle their emotions away from stimulus.
Time

It helps having a routine for both you and your children. Try a time-management strategy called “chunking.” WIth chunking, you choose a designated time for “recess,” for example, when you’ll all close your laptops and go out and kick a soccer ball together. Commit to a specific action that will signal specific events in your and your child’s day and try to stick with it, allowing for some flexibility, too.
3. Understand your thoughts

How you think and feel determines how you behave and take action. This can especially affect how you handle the challenge of this school year. For example, if you’re feeling anxious, you may blame your anxiety on your child’s school situation. But that may not get to the root of your anxiety. Maybe you’re actually anxious about not having time to help your child, or that your child won’t listen to you. Once you figure out your thoughts behind your feelings, you’re better able to manage those feelings and work on the root cause. And, you’ll be better able to support your child.
1. Communicate!

Your ability to communicate effectively can set the foundation for a good relationship, whether it’s with your partner, children, or coworkers. If you have a big meeting at work, talk to your children ahead of time. Explain to them that you won’t be available during a certain time, and come up with ideas of how they can work through issues if they arise. Celebrate your children if they’re able to honor that time. Similarly, if you have family commitments, give your manager and coworkers a heads-up, or mark your calendar.
2. Set your family vision & values

A family vision is a statement about what your family wants and how you’d like to achieve it. A family vision can ground you and your family. In order to be effective, though, your family vision must actually represent and reflect your family, not just some aspiration.

Involve your kids in creating a family vision! Ask questions like: What does family mean to me? What are some great characteristics of our family? What are some qualities we need to work on? What do we need to do differently to achieve this? What makes us unique? Then, refer to the statement regularly. At the dinner table, have your kids share what they did that day to embody one of the values on the vision statement.

Figuring out what works for your family will take time. Be open to making mistakes along the way. And remember to take care of yourself, too. You’ve got this! And remember, you’re part of a larger community of parents and caregivers all in similar situations, all doing the best we can for our kids.

properties.name: How Ready Are You to Change?
properties.description: How Ready Are You to Change?

components.text: How Ready Are You to Change?

One of the goals of Headspace Care coaching is to help members make a lasting change in their lives. Making a change can be difficult, so in order to create sustainable change, it helps to be ready. There are several stages of being ready for change, including wanting to change, having the confidence to change, and understanding the benefits of change. Determining which stage you’re in can help you and your coach have a better idea of where to start.
This activity will:

items: Explain the five stages of readiness;
Help you determine which stage of readiness to change you’re in.

components.text: Five stages of readiness
Research shows that there are five stages of readiness that a person tends to go through to make a lasting change.

items: Pre-contemplation: Someone in this stage is not yet considering making a change. They may be in denial that there’s anything to change at all. They might be unaware that their behavior, like not eating healthy foods, may be problematic. Or they may underestimate the pros of changing and place more emphasis on the cons.

Contemplation: In this stage, someone is weighing the pros and cons of making a change and may see the pros and cons as equal. They might not be ready to act immediately to make a change. Someone in this stage might think, “I know exercise and eating healthier might help me feel better, but starting an exercise routine would be hard with my schedule and I don’t want to stop eating my favorite foods.”

Preparation: Here, someone is deciding to make a change and making plans to make a change in the near future. They might think, “I’m going to research exercise routines and buy a book with healthy recipes.”

Action: This is the stage where someone is taking concrete action and developing goals for change. They’re ready to make a change now. They might say to themselves, “I’m going to take a 30-minute walk once daily, and I’ll prep healthy meals for the week.”

Maintenance: Someone in this stage is successfully, actively making a positive change and sticking with it. They’re experiencing the benefits of change and might think, “I feel good about my progress with taking daily walks and eating healthy meals, and I’ll keep it up.”

components.text: Consider the changes you’d like to make
Grab your journal or a piece of paper and reflect on the changes you would like to make in your life. Then answer questions 1-5 below:

items: The goal or behavior I want to work on first is: _______
My reasons for wanting to change this behavior are: _______
The obstacles standing in the way of my changing this behavior are: _______
My strategies to overcome the main obstacles are: _______
My goal for next week with respect to this behavior is: _______

components.text: Check-in
Based on your answers to the questions, and the explanations of the stages of readiness, how ready are you to make a change?

While you might not be sure you are ready to make changes now, you’ve taken a positive step by beginning to consider setting goals. A coach can help you to put these together and create SMART goals to assist you in making this manageable in your daily life.

Talk to your coach about strategies to help move you through these stages so you can feel confident and ready to create sustainable and positive change. If you are feeling stuck on the questions, fill it out as best you can. Your coach can help you figure out the next steps towards making a change.

Maybe you feel stuck right now. You might know you have a problem, but aren’t sure how to solve it. Or, you’re almost ready to make some changes but not sure how to move forward. A coach can either help you work through any limiting beliefs or collaborate on a plan to create positive change.

Talk to your coach about strategies to help move you through these stages so you can feel confident and ready to create sustainable and positive change. If you are feeling stuck on the questions, fill it out as best you can. Your coach can help you figure out the next steps towards making a change.

This is a busy time of trying out new routines and discarding old habits. Perhaps you’ve already achieved your goal, but you want to stay on track to make sure you don’t have relapses or fall into old habits. A coach can help hold you accountable to maintain your focus on what you’d like to achieve.

Talk to your coach about strategies to help move you through these stages so you can feel confident and ready to create sustainable and positive change. If you are feeling stuck on the questions, fill it out as best you can. Your coach can help you figure out the next steps towards making a change.
Strategies for Better Sleep

Have you experienced this? You’re lying in bed and exhausted, but you can’t fall asleep. As the clock ticks, you get more and more anxious because you’re anticipating how tired you’ll be the next day. This, frustratingly, keeps you up more. By learning how to set yourself up for a good night’s sleep, you can work on breaking the cycle so that you get the z’s you need.
This activity will:

items: Give you hands-on strategies for getting a better night of sleep;
Help ease your anxiety around your sleep.

components.text: Try one or all of these tips for a better night’s sleep:
Set a “sleep alarm”

Set an alarm for an hour before you want to fall asleep. When the alarm rings, start getting ready for bed. Take the hour to wind down, brush your teeth, read a book, or write down three good things from your day. Winding down earlier and keeping to a scheduled bedtime will help you feel more relaxed as you tuck yourself in.
Have a bedtime routine for your phone

Seeing the blue light from your phone right before bed can disrupt your sleep cycle. An hour before you get in bed, put your phone away. Plug it in out of your reach, or better yet in a different room. Try to make this a regular practice so that it becomes a part of your winding down process.
Write down your worries

Once you’re in bed with the lights out, you may sometimes find that your brain goes straight to worrying. Before you start listing out all your worries in your head, turn the light back on and quickly write down all the things you’re worried about. That will help you free up your mind for sleep, and you can rest assured knowing that the list will be there in the future for you to tackle.
Have a good contingency plan

To prepare for the possibility that you’ll wake up in the middle of the night and have a hard time going back to sleep, keep a funny, lighthearted book or magazine nearby. If you find yourself awake for an hour or more, get out of bed and read your book or magazine (not your phone!). If you start worrying about how tired you’ll feel tomorrow, take a deep breath and tell yourself, “It's OK if I'm up right now. Tomorrow I'll be OK.” Spending your time awake reading rather than ruminating may help you fall asleep faster, too. By having a good contingency plan, you’ll likely to be more successful in getting back to sleep.

Changing bedtime habits may not happen, well, overnight. Start with one or two of these strategies for one night and see how it goes for you. Reach out to your coach for help incorporating new positive habits into your routines.
Healthy Smartphone Habits for Sleep

Smartphones can feel like an extension of our hands sometimes. You’re likely reading this on your phone! But, just like some people remove their contact lenses before bed, it’s important to separate yourself from your cellular appendage. Lots of people sleep with their phone right next to them, which can have a negative effect on their sleep. If you’re one of those people, there are steps you can take to break the habit, get better sleep, and add some healthy boundaries between you and your phone.
This activity will:

items: Help you think about your nightly routine and how your phone figures into it,
Give you tips on how you can create a healthier relationship with your phone,
Help you cut back on looking at your phone before bed.

components.text: Understanding the WHY
Set a “sleep alarm”

Looking at your phone before bed makes it harder to fall asleep. The blue light from your phone has similar wavelengths as sunlight, which is a natural trigger for your brain to wake up. So, looking at that light before bed tricks your brain into thinking it’s time to be awake. Plus, looking at social media or doomscrolling can cause anxiety that also can make it hard to relax and fall asleep.

The first step to separating yourself from your phone before bed is to understand why you look at your phone. Understanding why may help you reduce your pre-bedtime screen usage. Think about or write down why you look at your phone. Then challenge those reasons. Is it because you’re bored before bed? If so, can you read a book or magazine? Is it that you want to catch up on social media? Can you set aside time to do that earlier in the day?
Your ideal relationship with your phone

Think about how you want to use your phone. Take a moment to reflect or write down what that looks like during the day and at night. Do you want to stop using it before bed? If so, try putting your phone away (out of reach) about an hour before bed. Visualizing or writing down how much you want your phone in your life can help you make a change to achieve that goal.
One small step
What small change can you make today for better sleep? Think about your ideal relationship with your phone. How can you make that ideal relationship a reality?

items: If you want to avoid looking at your phone before bed, try setting a “phone bedtime alarm.” Set a reminder on your phone an hour before bed to put your phone away. Even putting your phone away 10 minutes before bedtime is a good start.

If you reach for your phone when you have trouble sleeping, and would rather not, try moving your charger out of your room. If you’re at home now, do it now. If you’re not home, set a reminder to do it when you get home. Moving your phone away from your bed removes the temptation to look at it before bed and in the middle of the night.

components.text: So many of us are attached to our phones. Our phones are intentionally designed to make us want them in our hands all the time. It’s no wonder it’s a hard habit to break. So, if your phone usage is affecting your sleep, it may be time to make a change. If you need support or more ideas for changing your phone habit, reach out to your coach who can come up with goals that fit your specific needs.
How to Adjust to Change

There’s no doubt that many recent changes, like working from home, social distancing, and sharing a space with family 24/7, can be stressful. But, how we adjust to these changes can make a big difference in our happiness. Learn strategies on how to adjust better to change.
The Importance of Sleep

We all know that sleep is very important for our physical and mental health. However, when daily demands shift and time becomes scarce, sleep is the first thing we push aside. Learn why sleep is important, how to prioritize it, and how to establish a bedtime routine with guidance from a Headspace Care expert.
Starting a New Behavior

When you’re feeling down, it can be easy to get stuck in patterns of behavior that don’t help your mood. Finding a new behavior to replace the one that doesn’t serve you can help and can be easier than just quitting the first, unhelpful behavior. But what do you do if you’re unable to put the new behavior in action? By weighing the pros and cons, you can feel more confident about starting your new behavior.
This activity will help you:

items: Examine the new behavior and remember why you want to do it
Feel more confident about starting a new behavior

components.text: Let’s get started

items: What’s the new behavior you're considering, like your SMART goal or alternate behavior.
Look at the pros of doing the behavior.
Look at the cons of doing the behavior.
Repeat steps 2 and 3, but look at the pros and cons of not doing the behavior.

components.text: In a journal, piece of paper, or in a note on your phone, write the SMART goal or alternate behavior you're considering, debating, struggling with, or feeling stuck on.
Try to brainstorm some pros of doing this goal or behavior.
What would be useful about doing this? If you can, come up with at least two pros. Try to stay open-minded and not judge yourself for what you come up with. Just let yourself write.
Now, what are the cons of doing this goal or behavior?
What would be unhelpful about doing this? If you can, come up with at least two. There are no wrong answers.
Now, flip it. Let's talk about not doing this goal or behavior.

Brainstorm the pros of not doing this goal or behavior. What would be useful about not doing this? If you can, come up with at least two pros. Like before, try to stay open-minded and not judge yourself for what you come up with. Just let yourself write.
What are some cons of not doing this goal or behavior? What would be unhelpful about not doing this? If you can, come up with at least two cons. And just like before, there are no wrong answers here.
Weighing the Pros and Cons

items: Weigh the pros and cons of doing and not doing the behavior.
Take a close look at the pros of not doing the behavior. Are these pros more valuable to you than the pros of doing the behavior? Which are more important to you?

components.text: After giving the above some thought, what do you think?

options.name: I want to do this goal or behavior
I do not want to do this goal or behavior

components.text: You said:
I want to do this goal or behavior

It's good to hear you want to give your goal or behavior a try. A lot of times, after weighing pros and cons, we end up seeing that choosing not to do the behavior will only make things stay the same or get worse.
It's important to invest in behaviors that will benefit you and help you accomplish what matters to you.
You said:
I do not want to do this goal or behavior

A lot of times, after weighing pros and cons, you might see that the behavior isn’t right for you or won’t end up helping you. It's important to invest in behaviors that will benefit you and help you accomplish what matters to you.
Great work thinking about your goals and behaviors. Remember, if you need help coming up with a new behavior or weighing the pros and cons, reach out to your coach.
Living With Bipolar Disorder

Bipolar disorder is a significant, and often lifelong, mental health condition. Although there are differences among the types of bipolar disorder, they typically involve a combination of episodes of low or depressed mood and episodes of irritable, high, or manic moods. Diagnosis is complex and requires assessment by a licensed professional. Without proper treatment and management, it can negatively impact many aspects of life including relationships, work, and, of course, mood. However, if you’ve been diagnosed with bipolar disorder, it does not have to define you. With the right support in place, you can live life to the fullest.
This activity will:

items: Highlight ways you can manage symptoms by taking care of yourself;
Offer tips to build a support network to help you manage symptoms;
Give you strategies to reflect on how bipolar disorder fits into your larger identity.

components.text: Engage in self-care to manage symptoms
Maintaining healthy routines for your body can help prevent mood episodes. This includes:

items: Sleep. Try to have a consistent sleep routine. Both sleeping too much and not sleeping enough are linked to an increase in mood episodes.
Exercise. Regular exercise can help prevent depressive symptoms and regulate mood.
Diet. Notice if there are certain foods that make you feel better or worse. Try to eat a balanced diet and stick with foods that help you feel your best.
Avoid substances. Drugs and alcohol (and even caffeine!) can increase vulnerability to mood episodes.

components.text: There is a strong link between life stressors and bipolar episodes. Managing stress is an important part of managing symptoms.
Try to incorporate routines into your daily life. Having this predictability can reduce stress.

items: For example, create a routine of around 3-5 activities that you do each morning when you wake up (e.g., get dressed, brush teeth, eat breakfast, write in a gratitude journal).

components.text: Practice mindfulness. Learn to notice when stress is starting to become overwhelming so you can take action

items: For example, set a time every day to check in with yourself on how you are managing stress. Ask yourself: How did I sleep last night? Have I been eating regular, healthy meals? Do I generally feel in control of my emotions? Do I feel that I have support in my life?

components.text: Make time for yourself. Schedule breaks and make time for the things you enjoy on a daily and longer term basis.

items: For example, set a time each day to take a walk or have a cup of tea before bed.

components.text: Build a support network and treatment team
Find people in your life who can support you in meeting your healthy living goals.

items: Forge relationships with people who can help you de-stress and who don’t encourage substance use or staying out late.
Consider whether it is necessary to end certain relationships which make it more difficult to reach your goals.

components.text: Because bipolar disorder is a complex and lifelong condition, you will need a team of professionals to support you in your treatment including primary care providers, psychiatrists, therapists, and/or coaches.

items: Actively participate: Remember, this is your life! Ask questions and make sure to tell your providers about your concerns.

Problem solve: Work with your team to find solutions if you’re having difficulty with some aspect of treatment such as remembering to take your medication or remembering to attend therapy appointments.

Keep trying: It’s OK to feel frustrated at different times with treatment, and it’s OK to tell your team you’re frustrated. Don’t give up and try to remember that you and your team are all working together to help you live your best life.

components.text: Remember that this disorder does not define you!
Managing mood symptoms can be a lot of work, but there is so much more to you than just bipolar disorder.
Grab a journal or a piece of paper and reflect on the following:

items: What other parts of your identity are you proud of?
What are your core values, and how is managing your symptoms part of working towards those values?
What have you accomplished over the past year? Don’t forget the small stuff!

components.text: Bipolar disorder is a complex, chronic condition that takes a lot of work to manage across a lifetime. Taking care of your physical health, reducing stress, and gathering your support team are critical to success. Above all, remember that managing bipolar disorder is only one part of your life.
Solving Problems Within Your Control

Some problems are in our control, while others are not. For the problems that we can control, especially ones that make us feel bad, problem solving can help. Problem solving in this case isn’t about eliminating a problem you’re having. It’s about making the problem a little less difficult.
This activity will:

items: Teach you about the problem solving process;
Help you choose a problem you want to work on;
Take you through the process to help you find a solution.

components.text: Problem solving step-by-step

items: Specify the problem you're struggling with in specific and concrete terms.
Brainstorm solutions.
Evaluate the pros and cons of each solution.
Choose a solution and answer a few questions about it.
Choose a time you'll try out the solution and a time to assess the results.

components.text: Keep in mind, solving a problem doesn't always mean the problem will go away. Problem solving can help you change a problematic situation—that’s in your control—by finding and acting on a solution.
Let’s get started
Think about or write down in a journal a problem you're struggling with.
Try to get as specific and concrete as possible. Include details. For example, how long has this problem been going on? How often does it occur? What's the exact situation or context?
Next, let’s brainstorm.

Try your best to come up with three solutions to this problem. Remember, they don't need to solve the problem. Think of small steps you can take and try not to judge these solutions. Just let yourself write. What would you tell a friend who was in this situation? What would you suggest they do to address the problem?
Now, examine the pros and cons of each solution to decide on the best one to act on. What would be both helpful and unhelpful about each solution?
Then evaluate. Looking at the pros and cons of each solution, which one looks best to you?
Once you’ve chosen the best solution, think about what steps you need to get started. Also consider how difficult the steps will be.
Ask yourself, “What would make it difficult to implement this solution?” and, “What will you do to address these difficulties?”
If you need help with any of these steps, talk to your coach who can guide you through the process.
The Science Behind Breathing
This activity is a quick introduction to grounding techniques and the science behind how they can help you manage stress.
The Science: Grounding

Grounding is a technique that can bring about mindfulness. Mindfulness activates a part of the brain called the posterior cingulate cortex area. This area of the brain in particular is found to be more active in people who experience positive emotions and have a more positive outlook.

Grounding is a foundational technique worth practicing again and again. Grounding techniques are quick and simple. They're helpful in moments of high stress (when you’d rate your stress level higher than, say, a 7). So keep grounding in mind when you're having a moment of acute stress.
Deep Breathing: 4-7-8
Here's what you can expect to take away from today's activity:

items: A technique you can use anywhere to manage in-the-moment anxiety.

components.text: This breathing exercise is especially useful for falling asleep at night, for curbing food cravings, and for reducing anxiety in the moment.
Here's how it works:

items: Sitting comfortably, exhale all the breath out through your mouth.
Inhale slowly, counting silently to yourself up to 4.
Hold your breath in for a count of 7.
Exhale slowly to a count of 8.
Repeat this cycle 3 more times for a total of 4 cycles.

components.text: For this technique, try to find a quiet place where you can get comfortable and won't be disturbed. Don't worry if you have trouble keeping up with the audio. If this is the case, just go at your own pace, inhaling to a count of 4, holding to a count of 7, and exhaling to a count of 8. When you're ready, the audio on the next page will guide you through the whole thing.
Your Current Stress Level
How stressed are you feeling right now?
Grab your headphones and let's get to it.

How stressed are you feeling right now?

same.body: This activity doesn't seem to have affected your stress level. You can try to do this sort of exercise next time you are feeling stressed and see if it works better for you with practice or talk to your coach to find another activity that's better for you.

You can try to do this sort of breathing next time you are feeling stressed and see if it works better for you with practice. Or, talk to your coach to find another activity that’s better for you.

components.text: Grounding Your Stress

Grounding techniques help you calm your mind by focusing on something else. When your mind has a healthy distraction, you get distance from the thoughts and feelings that cause you stress. In a stressful situation, grounding techniques can help you feel calmer in the moment.
In this activity you’ll:

items: Get a brief overview of grounding techniques and learn how they calm your mind.
Learn how to use grounding techniques to deal with high stress situations.

components.text: Grounding to Create Calm

Grounding techniques take fewer than two minutes and they're meant to be used in times of high anxiety or emotional distress. Like the name suggests, grounding techniques help you feel more grounded and calm.
These techniques are useful to practice when:

items: You'd like to find moments of calm during the day.
You need to take a break from a stressful situation.
You're having trouble falling asleep.
You can't seem to shake an ongoing feeling of stress or anxiety, making it hard to focus.

components.text: Here are three different grounding exercises you can try.
Choose one that is best for you right now.

items: The Sit practice is best for times when you have a moment to take a break and can return to the same spot over and over. Times when you're at home, work, or school are best for this practice.
The Count practice is perfect for helping yourself fall asleep at night, or for taking a breather from any stressful situation.
The Observe practice asks you to observe a particular object, which you can carry with you throughout the day. This makes it especially good for times of ongoing stress.

components.text: Which type of grounding would you like to try?
Your Current Stress Level
How stressed are you feeling right now?
Grab your headphones and let's get to it.
Your Current Stress Level
How stressed are you feeling right now?

decreased.title: This grounding exercise worked for you!
decreased.body: The good news is your stress level went down after completing the exercise. The better news is that grounding helps more when you do it more often. Feel free to give one of the other techniques a try, too.

same.title: Your stress level stayed the same.
same.body: Don’t sweat it. You’re still getting the hang of it. You may want to try another grounding technique to see if it works better for you. You can always talk to your coach about your experience and get their advice.

increased.title: Your stress level increased.
increased.body: You can try a different grounding technique and see if it works better for you. You can always reach out to your coach to help you find a technique that’s tailored to you.

components.text: Creating a Mental Vacation

Something as simple as imagining a pleasant scene in your head can have a lot of positive physical and mental benefits. It can help you relax, control negative emotions, and cope with stressful or anxiety-provoking situations.
In this activity, you’ll:

items: Learn an effective relaxation technique you can do from anywhere, anytime.
Get simple, step-by-step guidance on how to create pleasant mental imagery to help you relax.

components.text: Pleasant Imagery

Sometimes you can’t lay out on the beach, go for a walk by a lake, or hike up a mountain to watch the sunset. In fact, if you’re like most people, that’s almost never an option when you’re in the middle of something stressful or anxiety-provoking.

Luckily, your body doesn’t actually mind too much whether you do something relaxing, or whether you just imagine it. It responds in very similar ways–calming your heart rate and slowing your breath. Some people call this visualization, or visualizing. We call it pleasant imagery.
No matter what you call it, research shows that practicing pleasant imagery can reduce food cravings, ease stressed feelings, and boost mood. In other words, your imagination is pretty powerful.

We've got a few guided pleasant imagery audios for you to try, but it's important to realize that you can do this anywhere on your own. All you have to do is choose a pleasant scene to visualize in your mind, and let yourself fill in the details. If your mind tries to wander to the many things minds like to wander to, just gently bring it back to the scene you're creating, filling in details, adding textures, and seeing yourself in the scene in vivid detail.
All you need to do is this:

items: Get comfortable.
Select a pleasant image to focus on.
Pay attention to your breathing.
Visualize what you hear.

components.text: On the next page, choose a scene to visualize. You can go ahead and get started or set a reminder to do this later.
Where would you like to go?
Don’t think too hard about it. Just choose the place you’d most like to be right now.
Your Current Stress Level
How stressed are you feeling right now?
When you are ready, tap on the play button below to start the practice
Your Current Stress Level
And now how’s your stress level?

components.text: The Power of Pleasant Imagery
Here's what you can expect to learn from today's activity:

items: Learn why mental  imagery can be effective when you can’t physically change scenery.

components.text: Pleasant Imagery

Sometimes you can’t lay out on the beach, go for a walk by a lake, or hike up a mountain to watch the sunset. In fact, if you’re like most people, that’s almost never an option when you’re in the middle of something stressful or anxiety-provoking.

Luckily, your body doesn’t actually mind too much whether you do something relaxing, or whether you just imagine it. It responds in very similar ways–calming your heart rate and slowing your breath. Some people call this visualization, or visualizing. We call it pleasant imagery.
No matter what you call it, research shows that practicing pleasant imagery can reduce food cravings, ease stressed feelings, and boost mood. In other words, your imagination is pretty powerful.

We've got a few guided pleasant imagery audios for you to try, but it's important to realize that you can do this anywhere on your own. All you have to do is choose a pleasant scene to visualize in your mind, and let yourself fill in the details. If your mind tries to wander to the many things minds like to wander to, just gently bring it back to the scene you're creating, filling in details, adding textures, and seeing yourself in the scene in vivid detail.
Check out the activity card 'Creating a Mental Vacation'. In case you don't have that in your 'For You' section, talk to your coach.
Practicing Self-Care

If “self-care” brings to mind bubble baths and scented candles, you’re not alone! Self-care sometimes gets a bad rap as being a selfish or frivolous activity. There’s a lot more to it, however. Self-care is about taking care of your mind and body to help reduce stress in the moment, and better manage stress in the future. Making a commitment to try one self-care activity is a great way to start adding self-care into your routine. Let’s get to it!
In this activity you’ll:

items: Learn the best ways to take care of yourself during a stressful time.
Build a list of activities you can do when you're stressed.
Choose your own self-care activity and create an actionable goal

components.text: Your current skill level
How confident do you feel in making self-care a part of your regular routine?  0 = Not at all confident, 10 = Completely confident
What is self-care?

Self-care is deeply personal and unique to what brings you comfort and calm in difficult moments. Self-care can include any activity that helps you maintain your physical and mental health or to prevent and manage an illness. This means that self-care could even include simpler things like practicing good hygiene, healthy eating, remembering to take your medication, or even taking the time to learn more about your health - like you’re doing right now!

Self-care can sometimes feel selfish, but It’s important to remember that self-care allows you to develop a healthy relationship with yourself, which is a critical first step towards feeling ready to interact with and care for others. And remember, a self-care activity that works for someone else, may not work for you. With an infinite amount of activities to try, it can be hard to know where to start. Next, we’ll help you figure out what you might want to try and how to work it into your routine.
Let’s reflect
Take a moment now to reflect on the following questions. Consider writing down your responses to help you organize and document your thoughts:

items: Are there activities you’ve done in the past that have brought you comfort during difficult times? If so, what are they?
Are these activities things that you currently have access to?

components.text: Based on your reflections above, do you currently have self-care activities in your life that are helpful right now? (It’s OK if you don’t!)

Grounding 101

Grounding is a technique considered to be part of an approach to psychology called mindfulness. Mindfulness activates a part of the brain called the posterior cingulate cortex area, which is found to be more activated in people experiencing positive emotions, and those with a generally positive outlook. Grounding techniques can help reduce stress and improve overall well-being.
This activity will:

items: Describe what a grounding technique is;
Explain the research that makes grounding techniques an effective way to deal with stress;
Help you understand the mental health effects of breathing activities

components.text: Grounding is a foundational technique worth practicing again and again. Grounding techniques are quick and simple and useful in high-stress moments.

You may have found that many relaxation techniques have to do with breathing. There's a scientific reason behind that. When you inhale, your diaphragm (a muscle underneath your lungs) moves down, pulling your lungs with it and allowing them to fill with air. On your exhale, the opposite happens—your diaphragm moves up and pushes the carbon dioxide out of your body, exchanging it for oxygen from the air.

When you breathe normally, oxygen only reaches a portion of your blood vessels. But when you practice deep breathing, you allow oxygen to reach the blood vessels in all the nooks and crannies of your lungs.
All that increased oxygen helps trigger alpha waves in your brain. Those are the waves responsible for relaxation.
So you can think of deep breathing as a sort of switch to flip when your body needs an extra boost of peace and calm.
Why We Avoid Things
Here's what you can expect to take away from today's activity:

items: Raise your awareness of the things we avoid.
Understand how they can contribute to our stress and shape how we act every day.

components.text: So, grab your headphones, and let's get started.
The Things We Avoid

Today, we’re not talking about things we feel or do when we’re stressed. Today’s activity is about something a little bit different: it’s about the things we don’t do when we’re stressed. The things we avoid doing.

There’s this classic thing little kids do with their hair. Their parents tell them to brush their hair. But, you know, brushing hurts, and it’s really hard to play on your iPad and brush your hair at the same time, so...kids don’t always want to brush. Luckily, they have figured out a better way. If they just take a couple of swipes of the brush over the top of their head, they can smooth the hair on top and make it look like the rest is brushed, too. The tangles and the hair brushing are out of sight, out of mind. Sometimes they do this every day for many, many days. But many, many days later, they’re left with a big, huge knot underneath those few brushed hairs on top. The kind of knot that only a good pair of scissors can handle.
So eventually, their strategy stops working for them. They end up with more tangles in the long-run. Plus, they have to start brushing their hair.
Masters of Procrastination

So this whole little kids and hair brushing thing. This isn’t so different from what many of us do as adults. Because when we’re stressed out, we’re masters of avoiding our stressors. We’re masters of procrastination, and procrastination’s close friend–multi-tasking.

As people who tend to feel quite a bit of stress, we tend to feel overwhelmed by everything that’s happening in our lives, by all the demands put on us, by all the uncertainties in whatever’s coming next.

So if you have something like that...something you know you avoid because it makes you panic, or want to run in the other direction….even if it’s just procrastinating on your work…. this is where you’ll want to work with that behavior.

Say, just for the sake of explanation, that you’ve been putting off opening up your medical bills for awhile now. You just can’t bear to think about seeing how much more money you owe. So you avoid your bills. Out of sight, out of mind. The instinct to avoid is in fact a really a nice thing you try to do for yourself. You’re trying to protect yourself — that’s a very natural impulse...not one to beat yourself up about. It’s not that you’re doing anything wrong.

The problem is, as any kid who’s had a knot cut from their hair will tell you, avoidance is a strategy that doesn’t really give us the results we want in the long-run. We want it to give us a sense of control, a greater sense of safety and calm. But usually, something else happens.
The Trouble with Avoidance

Every time you choose not to open up those bills...every time you shove them underneath another stack of envelopes, or conveniently leave them in the mailbox for one more day...every time you do that...you’re actually making your stress about the situation stronger.

Because you’re believing the story your mind is telling you–that something bad will happen if you open up those bills. Or that you won’t be able to handle the negative emotions that opening them causes you. And when you act on that story, you’re strengthening your belief in it. You’re never getting the chance to prove yourself wrong.

For most people, it takes a lot of mental energy to keep avoiding the things that stress us out. And that’s the best case scenario: at worst, there are more tangible consequences to not getting done the things you need to get done. So you can see how out of sight really isn’t out of mind. Your stress ends up having more control over you than you do over it.
That’s really the problem with avoidance behaviors like procrastination. They reinforce the stories we’re telling ourselves about the thing we’re avoiding, and they keep us stuck in the stress cycle.

But then there’s more than procrastination. There’s multi-tasking, too. You may not think of it as an avoidance behavior. In fact, usually multi-tasking feels like the opposite of avoidance — you’re getting so much done, right? Not so much. You’re actually trying to avoid the pain of the thing you really need to get done by dulling it with something that gives you a little more pleasure. See? Avoidance. But more on that later.
So what can you do?

Changing these avoidance behaviors can be done. But it can be uncomfortable. It requires us to face our anxieties, to step out of the modes of working that feel comfortable even when they’re not helpful. Relaxation techniques can help with this. Adding relaxation techniques to your routine is one of the best behavioral changes you can make when it comes to managing stress.

properties.name: How to Cope with the World Reopening
properties.description: How to Cope with the World Reopening

components.text: How to Cope with the World Reopening

The Covid-19 pandemic has re-shaped nearly every aspect of our lives. With vaccination increasingly prevalent in the United States, businesses, schools, and offices are beginning to reopen. If you’re feeling overwhelmed at the thought of things “going back to normal,” you are not alone.
This activity card will:

items: Discuss why you might be feeling anxious about interacting with others more regularly again
Provide opportunity for reflection
Offer tips to help you gradually feel more comfortable with “going back to normal”

components.text: Navigating social situations

After more than a year of staying at home and rarely seeing people outside of your small circles, you might be feeling nervous about everyday interactions with other people. It’s common to feel like you’re out of practice with “water cooler” talk at work and “small talk” at the grocery store. You may be wondering if you’re able to navigate social situations like you used to.
Write down your questions
Grab your journal and write down some of the questions you might be asking yourself. Here are some common things people are wondering:

items: Am I even able to navigate social situations like I used to?
Have I developed social anxiety?
What should I talk about at work? What should I keep private?
How will I access medical and mental healthcare during my 9-5 workday?
How will being back in the office change how I participate in and advocate for things that are important to me?

components.text: Write down multiple answers/outcomes

Now in your journal, write an answer to the questions you posed. After writing your initial thought, challenge yourself to think about one additional possible answer or outcome to your question. This is not always easy to do, so take your time. It may help to consider how a trusted loved one might answer your question. Here are some other things to consider:

items: This is a period of significant transition, and it is normal to feel some anxiousness.
We have experienced and are experiencing a period of tremendous loss. Many people are feeling overwhelmed.
As painful and challenging as the pandemic and reopening have been, it is a shared human experience. You’re not alone.

components.text: Tips to practice
As you face reopening and prepare to go back to the office, school, or any other part of life, consider the following tips to help you feel more comfortable:

items: Start at home: Practice small talk and other worrisome situations at home with a trusted loved one. If you live alone, try practicing in your mirror or on a video call with a friend. Although it may seem silly, it will help you feel prepared and less alone in this situation.

Gradually reintroduce yourself to the activities you’re worried about. If possible, take it slow. If you are given the option, consider going back part-time to allow yourself extra time to cope and recharge.
Practice! There may be activities you have not done in over a year. The more you engage with these activities and practice getting back into them, the more comfortable they will feel.

Encourage yourself to identify hope. Use your journal to talk yourself through feared situations. Remember that you have done these activities before, and you can become comfortable with them again over time.

components.text: You are not alone

After well over a year of isolating ourselves in the name of safety, it is difficult to simply turn back on our social natures. Remember that you are not alone in this, and many people are finding “getting back to normal” to be a difficult and anxious process. Try to give yourself time to ease back into these situations and foster hope by remembering that you have done them before.

properties.name: Reflecting on a Year of COVID-19
properties.description: Reflecting on a Year of COVID-19

components.text: Reflecting on a Year of COVID-19

This past year has been wildly difficult for so many people. As we enter the second year of the COVID-19 pandemic, we’re still adjusting and re-adjusting while also trying to maintain a sense of routine and normalcy. Now that vaccines are more available, cases are going down, businesses are opening up, and the sun seems to be shining a little brighter, it’s important to reflect back on the year and see how far we’ve come.
This activity will:

items: Help you reflect on the last year;
Give you space to mourn what changed and what you lost this last year;
Empower you to set goals for yourself this year.

components.text: Strategies for reflecting
1. Set time aside to look closely at the last year of COVID-19.

items: Schedule a time when you won’t have distractions.

With a piece of paper and a calendar, take time to go through each month and really reflect on what occurred during that time. Reflect on the good things as well as the challenges. Write down your reflections for each month.
Pick out the highlights and low points and jot down what you learned from those experiences.
You can do this exercise by yourself or with loved ones as an open discussion.

components.text: 2. Spend some time with the hard stuff.

items: Everyone lost something this year—whether it was a job, a loved one, a relationship, a hobby, or just time with people. All these things need to be mourned and processed, but that can be hard when you’re still going through the loss.

Allow yourself to grieve these losses. Often we feel guilty doing this because we feel someone may have had it worse or that this is just something everyone is going through, but each loss is important and changes are hard for everyone.
Let yourself feel the loss by thinking, reflecting, and processing. Note what has changed and what will continue to change. Remember how that loss felt and the emotions attached to it.

Sit with this feeling and find a way to memorialize that loss. Try lighting a candle, journaling, sharing stories with loved ones, anything to bring attention to the hard times you experienced so you can start to process and ultimately grow.

components.text: 3. Recognize your own strength and start to plan the path forward.

items: Chances are that each challenging experience has helped you develop greater strength. With each difficult experience, you’ve likely overcome a challenge.
Take some time to reflect on the difficult times and note what you did to get through each obstacle. What strengths did you develop? What skills did you strengthen? How did you show up?
Think about the ways in which you are stronger than you were at the start of the pandemic. From here, how do you want to continue to grow?
Set goals for the next year so you can continue this growth, gain some momentum, and have something to look forward to as you continue to push through the stress of COVID-19.

components.text: You’ve overcome so much this year and that is definitely something to celebrate. Take the time to appreciate yourself, your loved ones, and the hard work you’ve put in as an individual and with your loved ones. You’ll soon be able to get out and celebrate your strengths and your journey… When it’s safe of course. Soon enough!
Managing Election Stress

The 2020 election has created additional stress and uncertainty for many people. Learn strategies for navigating challenging conversations, avoiding information overload, and using self-care to protect your mental health leading up to the election and beyond.
Natural Disasters and Mental Health

When a natural disaster strikes, such as a wildfire, hurricane, or tornado, protecting our physical well-being, and that of our loved ones, is our immediate concern. But once we’re safe, we’re left to assess the damage, pick up the pieces, and deal with the emotional impact. Both in the moment and after a natural disaster, we often don’t consider how our mental health is affected. This activity can help you manage the stress.
This activity will:

items: Give you tips on coping with stress caused by a natural disaster,
Suggest techniques you can use before, during, and after a natural disaster to stay calm.

components.text: Relief for Stress in the Moment

When a natural disaster strikes, it can cause a range of responses, from anxiety, helplessness, and fear to depression or even numbness. Grounding techniques can be especially helpful for coping with stress from traumatic events. Below is a technique called “Coping with Difficult Emotions,” which is also an activity card in the app. Give this one a try, or ask your coach to assign you other grounding techniques that work for you.
Coping with Difficult Emotions
When you’re experiencing a difficult emotion, using your five senses can help provide comfort.

Here are a few healthy self-soothing activities to engage each of your five senses. (Of course we recommend staying away from activities that can lead to unhealthy behaviors.) Give one a try or come up with your own!
Hearing

items: Listen to a favorite album or station.
Call a friend or family member.
Play a musical instrument.

components.text: Touch

items: Make a warm drink and notice the warmth as you hold it and drink it.
Get or give a massage.
Wrap yourself in your softest blanket.
Take a hot or cold shower or bath.

components.text: Taste

items: Add a favorite flavor to your water (try lemon, lime or mint).
Eat a few bites of your favorite treat.
Notice the taste of each ingredient in your next snack or meal.

components.text: Smell

items: Stop and smell some nature outside. (Bring the object to your nose.)
Put on a favorite scented lotion.
Light a scented candle.
Boil some citrus rinds or cinnamon.

components.text: Sight

items: View your favorite artist's work online.
Watch a dance performance.
Lie down outside and watch the clouds or stars.
Watch some baby animal videos.

components.text: Coping with stress and finding meaning after a natural disaster
Though we can't always prepare for natural disasters, we can manage our responses and create a plan of action. These tips can help.
Avoid the news

items: Though it can be tempting to stay glued to the news for up-to-date information, doing so can actually overwhelm you and decrease your ability to make good decisions. Instead, try setting a time limit to allow yourself to check in on news periodically, while ensuring that you're spending most of your time away from news and social media.

components.text: Let it all out
Feelings of stress, anxiety, and fear sometimes don’t respond to attempts of self-soothing, such as grounding or breathing exercises.  If you notice you need a release, try some of the following:

items: Use a worry chair. Designate a chair or specific spot in your home where you can sit and worry. Set a timer for 10 minutes so you can allow yourself to deeply experience anxious thoughts and feelings. You might want to write them down. Then, when the timer goes off, it's time to move on! It can help to have an activity planned for afterwards that will engage your attention.
Talk about your feelings. Talk to a friend, a loved one, or a Headspace Care coach or other professional.
Do some judgement-free journaling. Write about your feelings without judging what or how you’re writing.
Express your feelings through a creative outlet, like drawing, making a collage, or painting.

components.text: Give back

items: If you are worried about others but not sure what to do, try to find a way to support those who are struggling. Donate your time at a shelter or donate resources, such as food, blood, or money. Anything and everything helps during a natural disaster. Here are some great ideas to get you started: https://www.mentalfloss.com/article/563422/california-wildfire-victims-how-to-help

components.text: Gratitude

Even in the darkest of times, we have things to be grateful for: family, friends, a roof (even if it is a temporary one). What do you have to hold onto right now to help you remember that it won’t always be this way?
For ideas on how to express gratitude, ask your coach to assign you these activity cards:

items: Gratitude List
Count your blessings
Savor the good

components.text: Replace Unwanted Behaviors

Often when we’re feeling down, we fall into patterns of behaviors that are easy to do, but that ultimately make us feel worse, like staying up late binging on TV. It can be a challenge to just stop doing these behaviors. But, finding an alternative behavior to replace the one you want to stop can help.
This activity will:

items: Explain effective ways to choose replacement behaviors
Show you examples of ways to choose a replace behavior
Help you strategize a way to implement the new behavior.

components.text: Deciding Between Two Paths

Imagine you're trying to make your way up a hill. But there are lots of branches and rocks in front of you. You look over to your left and notice a clear path. It'd be way easier to take this path than the rocky one. The clear path is your current behaviors, the ones that are familiar to you. You've taken this path tons of times and done these behaviors a lot. But, it turns out it’s not leading you to where you want to go. But taking the trickier path is worth it because it challenges you to move towards something you care about, even when it’s hard.

Let’s look at a behavior that’s not serving you well—one that you keep doing, but that leads to emotions that make you feel bad. Your goal eventually is to swap out this behavior for something else that can improve your mood.

For example, let’s say the behavior that isn’t helping your mood that you’d like to replace is that you watch TV for a few hours every night. The idea is to make a plan to replace watching TV for a few hours with an alternate behavior that's specific and measurable. What if you watched TV for one hour on Tuesday? Or spent 20 minutes making lunch for the next day on Sunday? Or FaceTimed a family member for an hour on Friday?

Here's a specific example: Terrell frequently stays in bed for an hour after he wakes up in the morning and then calls in sick to work. He wants to replace this behavior. When he looks at what’s going on in his mind that precedes this behavior, he realizes that he starts thinking about how much he dislikes his job. The behavior is that he stays in bed. The consequence is that he then feels guilty about staying in bed. He also wonders why he can’t just deal with the fact that he doesn’t like his job and just go. But that makes him feel worse about himself.

This pattern of behavior is part of the cycle that’s making Terrell feel really down. Through tracking and examining his behavior, Terrell noticed that the first behavior in this pattern—staying in bed—is a useful place to begin to break the cycle to help him feel better.
An Alternate Behavior
Terrell will develop a plan to experiment with a new behavior instead of lying in bed. Here are the alternate behaviors Terrell brainstorms.
Terrell's alternate behavior brainstorm:

items: As soon as I wake up I'll get dressed.
I won't let myself skip work at all anymore.
I'll sit up and read instead.
I'll only stay in bed for 30 minutes.

components.text: How did he come up with these? He brainstormed everything he could possibly do instead of staying in bed, and he tried to focus on things that he finds enjoyable and that make him feel accomplished.
How difficult? How helpful?
We want the alternate behavior we choose not to be too difficult and to be as helpful as possible. We want to actually be able to do it, and we want it to help us create a more positive mood.
Let’s look at Terrell’s alternative behaviors again:

items: As soon as I wake up I'll get dressed.
I won't let myself skip work at all anymore.
I'll sit up and read instead.
I'll only stay in bed for 30 minutes.

components.text: He decides the first and second alternate behaviors are unrealistic. He's been lying in bed for an hour almost every morning, so it may be tough for him to just get up and get dressed. And it'll be hard for him never to skip work again. Terrell notices the last behavior could be helpful and not too difficult, but he wants to try something other than lying in bed.
