The third behavior seems like it will be a challenge but not too difficult—he can stay in bed. But he'll sit up and read instead of lying there. It hits the sweet spot.
Making it specific.
Terrell's alternate behavior:
I'll sit up in bed and read.
Terrell will try replacing lying in bed in the morning with this new, alternate behavior. But first, he needs to make it as specific as possible. He needs to answer questions like:

items: What exactly?
Where exactly?
For how long?

components.text: It's important to break the behavior down into small, specific steps, so he knows exactly what he's doing.
Terrell's specific alternate behavior:
When I wake up in the morning, I'll sit up in bed and read for 15 minutes.
Making it stick.
Terrell's specific alternate behavior:
When I wake up in the morning, I'll sit up in bed and read for 15 minutes.

The last step is important. The action should be based on a plan, not a mood or emotion. When the time comes for Terrell to try this new behavior, it will be hard for him to talk himself out of it because he made a solid plan to do it.
Terrell's final alternate behavior:
When I wake up in the morning on Thursday, I'll sit up in bed and read for 15 minutes.

To keep himself accountable, he sets a reminder for himself to try it (and tells his Headspace Care coach about his plan). Keep in mind, this is only an experiment for Terrell. Making the plan and trying it out is all that matters right now.
A Few Tips When Choosing a Replacement Behavior
Before you create a new path up the hill, we've got a few strategies for you to keep in mind.

items: It's all about small steps. Change can be scary. And it's easy to revert back to old behaviors that feel comfortable. Starting with the smallest behavior—the smallest step possible on the new path—helps ensure you’re successful.

Don't forget your map. The plan is the most important part. It's your map up the hill. Make sure you look at the week ahead to see if your new behavior can fit into your schedule. Sharing your plan with your Headspace Care coach or a supportive friend can also help with this.

Stay open-minded. Experiment with creating and carrying out a plan. Give your new, alternate behavior at least three tries before deciding if it's right for you. Then, you can tinker with other behaviors to see what works best.

components.text: Now, give it a try.
Learn how to change a behavior that may be keeping you down, by replacing it with a new behavior. It's like an experiment. Ultimately, you’ll figure out if the new behavior is more helpful to you.
When I wake up in the morning on Thursday, I'll sit up in bed and read for 15 minutes.

items: Choose a behavior you'd like to change. Keep in mind, the problem can also be the absence of a behavior. You might want to add something healthy that you notice is missing.
Create a specific and measurable new behavior to do instead. For example, "I will take my medicine" is a specific behavior. "I want to get healthy" is more of a result. See the difference?
Create a plan for when you'll experiment with the new behavior.

components.text: Your alternate behavior should be as helpful as possible. Meaning, ideally it'll help you create a positive mood. Alternate behaviors that you enjoy doing or that make you feel accomplished can be helpful. You also don't want it to be too difficult. You should be able to do it. To summarize, you want your alternate behavior to be:

items: Helpful
Not too difficult

components.text: What do you think? Does the alternate behavior you have in mind meet the criteria above?
Let's make your behavior specific and measurable. Your behavior should answer one, some, or all of the following:

items: Where will you do this?
Who, if anyone, will be there?
How long will I do this behavior?
How often will I do this? Give your alternate behavior at least three tries to see if it works for you.

components.text: Make your alternate behavior specific and measurable.

What do you need to try your alternate behavior this week? Are there supplies you need? If someone else is involved, have you checked if they're around? Will the behavior fit into your current schedule? If getting started soon isn't possible, go back and come up with others. Find a time to experiment with your new behavior. You’ll want to try it out at least three times before deciding if it's helping you and your mood.
And remember...

Trying your alternate behavior is just that—an experiment. Keep an open mind. If you find it helps you feel better, that's great. If not, that's OK, too. Right now, all that matters is that you follow through with your plan and give it three shots.
And of course, your Headspace Care coach is always here for support.

properties.name: Finding Joy When You Feel Down

components.text: Finding Joy When You Feel Down

The feelings of pleasure and accomplishment can come from small moments, like eating your favorite ice cream, getting a hug, checking tasks off your to-do list, even completing part of your routine, like brushing your teeth. But feeling down or depressed can make it hard to find pleasure in these activities.
This activity card will:

items: Explain how and why feeling down can make it difficult to experience pleasure;
Help you find an activity to do that can bring you joy.

components.text: How feeling down can get in the way of pleasure and accomplishment

Feeling down can reduce your ability to feel positive emotions, making it hard to notice feelings of pleasure. It’s common to withdraw, isolate yourself, and stop doing things you used to really enjoy. This in turn can lead to you feeling even less happy.

Similarly, when you’re feeling down, it’s common to fall behind on tasks like work, errands, or chores, and even basic care activities like washing your face. But doing these tasks, even though they're small, can help you feel more confident and accomplished. On the flip side, avoiding these activities when we feel down makes it more difficult to feel accomplished and confident.
When it’s not easy to engage in the activities that you used to enjoy

Before feeling down, you may have been able to do more activities that made you happy. Try not to compare the past with the present. Remember, when you feel down, it impacts what you do and how you feel.

It’s common to feel like you don’t deserve to feel good. But, remember, you DO deserve to feel good. Your happiness matters. Your coach can work with you to help you experience the people, places, and things that bring you joy.

When you do the small tasks that make you feel good, you may think that your positive feelings won’t last. Doing a small task that makes you feel good likely won’t make you feel happy or accomplished all the time. It may just boost your mood for a short time, or not at all. What's important is to let yourself experience these feelings. When you’re feeling down, it's normal to worry about the positive feeling slipping away or tell yourself you’ll just feel bad afterwards. But this makes it tough to enjoy the positive. If you notice yourself worrying or focusing on the negative, try bringing your attention back to positive feelings of pleasure or accomplishment.

When you do an activity that used to bring you joy, ask yourself, “How do I feel?” Take a minute to identify the feeling—maybe it’s pleasure or confidence—and then, enjoy that feeling. Your coach is here to support you as you engage in these positive moments.

properties.name: Problem Solving When You Feel Down

components.text: Problem Solving When You Feel Down

There’s a vicious cycle that tends to happen when we’re feeling down, which leaves us feeling even worse. When we’re feeling down we tend to see our situation as hopeless. And when we see our situation as hopeless, we feel even more down. But, by doing a technique called problem solving, we can break out of that cycle.
This activity will:

items: Teach you how problem solving can help you feel better when you’re down;
Give you examples of other people using problem solving;
Walk you through the steps of choosing and acting on a problem to solve.

components.text: Starting Small

Problem solving requires a lot of determination, which is why it can be helpful to start with smaller behaviors you’d like to change. This activity will walk you through coming up with a clear and structured method for thinking through the problems to be solved.

First, let's clarify what problem solving means. It doesn't mean making a problem go away, especially if it's out of your control. Part of problem solving is figuring out if a problem is within your control, which we'll talk about, too. Problem solving is trying to change a problematic situation by finding and acting on a solution.
That last part, acting, is important. It's not enough to just brainstorm solutions—you've got to act on them, too. And if they don't work? You'll brainstorm another and try again.
Example #1
Morgan, who has been feeling down lately, has a big exam coming up and is having trouble focusing on studying. First, Morgan defines the problem in really concrete, specific terms.
She says, “I have an exam coming up. I feel overwhelmed when I think about studying. I can’t find the motivation or even know what I need to do to get started.”

The next step is brainstorming. While Morgan can't change the fact that she has an exam coming up, there are steps that she can take to feel less overwhelmed. So she brainstorms solutions to the problem of feeling overwhelmed. The solutions don't need to totally solve the problem. Small steps are great. Morgan just lets herself write, keeping in mind that there are no wrong answers.
Morgan brainstorms about what she can do to feel less overwhelmed. Here’s what she comes up with:

items: Ask my teacher for help with a study plan
Talk to a friend in my class about her plan for studying
Look back through my class notes refresh my memory
Make a list of questions I have about the exam topic

components.text: What else could Morgan do? What would you suggest?
Pros and Cons
Next, Morgan evaluates the pros and cons for each solution. Try answering the following questions to yourself for each of Morgan’s solutions:
1. How would this solution help Morgan?
2. How would this solution be unhelpful to Morgan?

For example, talking to a friend in her class could be a way for Morgan to think of her own study plan,  but it could also make her feel bad or anxious if her friend is a lot farther along with her own studying.
Let's look at Morgan's problem solving steps. She:
1. Identified her problem.
2. Brainstormed possible solutions.
3. Evaluated the pros and cons and selected the best one.
4. Figured out the steps to take action.
Next, she'll:
5. Plan a time to try out her solution.
6. Try her solution at this time.
After she tries her solution, she’ll:
7. Evaluate the solution. If it didn't help her feel less overwhelmed, she'll go back to her brainstormed solutions and try another one.
Morgan decides she'll try her solution on Tuesday at 10am. A few days later, she evaluates how it went.

Keep in mind, a solution doesn't have to solve the problem. It doesn't have to get Morgan a good grade on the exam. A solution is successful if it makes the situation a little less problematic. And if it doesn't? That's OK, too. Morgan can always brainstorm other solutions.
Exploring Problems

Sindura recently found out that she's been diagnosed with diabetes and is having a tough time coping with her new diagnosis. Sindura has been feeling very low and wants to problem solve around her situation. So she acknowledges her problem: “I was recently diagnosed with diabetes and I just don't know what to do about it.”

As much as we want to, we just can't change certain problems, like chronic illness. Sindura can't change the fact that she has diabetes. But, she can use this problem solving technique to  better cope with having diabetes. She can still find some ways to make the most out of life, even though she’s coping with an unsolvable problem.
The first step is for Sindura to think of another problem that she can impact and that will help her better cope with her diagnosis.
Another problem is that she’s having a hard time remembering to take her medications.
This other problem is solvable. Solving this problem will help her handle her illness, but she isn't trying to change something that's out of her power, like the illness itself.
What's another solvable problem that Sindura might choose? Here are some other problems she has:

items: I am not doing a good job communicating with my doctor.
My test results came back positive.
I need to change my diet because of my illness.

components.text: She can change the first and third problem on the list above, but she can’t change her test result.
Shifting the Problem
Let’s go over the steps so far.
Sindura's problem is: She was recently diagnosed with diabetes and she just doesn't know what to do about it.
So, she thinks of another problem to work on: She’s having a hard time remembering to take her medications.
See how the new problem is solvable? It's helping her handle her illness, but isn't trying to change something that's out of her power, like the illness itself.
She chooses another problem to solve: She is not doing a good job communicating with her doctor. She brainstorms steps she can take to work on both of these other problems.
Unsolvable Problems

There are tools that can help you cope with problems that can’t be solved. Sindura, for example, can't change the fact that she has an illness. This is unsolvable, and therefore wouldn't be a good problem to focus on when using this problem solving technique. But within this problem, there may be something she can do to improve the situation. You can still problem solve to live life to the fullest even with an unsolvable problem.
Practicing acceptance can also help you cope with the reality of your situation.
It can help you move away from feeling stuck and hopeless to acknowledging and accepting things that are out of your control.

But at the same time, you can look within the unsolvable problem to see if there's something that is in your control. Like Sindura communicating with her doctor or changing her diet. Problem solving can help you find and plan around those pieces that you can change.
Self-Soothe Writing Activity
Keep a list of soothing techniques for any stressful situation.
INSTRUCTIONS

items: On an index card or piece of paper, write "Self Soothe."
On the other side, write three soothing techniques that you can turn into long-term habits. Some ideas are: walking, meditation, and a long bath.

components.text: WHAT'S NEXT?
Keep this list in your purse or wallet. Take it out whenever you feel stressed!
WHY
If you live with anxiety and stress, it's important to remember that you have power over these emotions. This list will empower you to take care of yourself in healthy, sustainable ways.
Soak Up the Sun
Regular sunlight helps reduce depressive symptoms
INSTRUCTIONS
Try to go outside every day and expose yourself to the sun, especially in the morning. Even on cloudy days, the amount of sunlight you get from a short walk is often enough to impact your mood.
WHY
Sunlight can improve depression, especially if your depression tends to come in the winter. Sunlight also provides the body with Vitamin D, and has been shown to decrease sleepiness.
Thinking Forward
Realize that depression doesn't last forever.
WHAT TO DO
You may feel like you'll always be depressed. That's not true! Keep hopelessness in perspective: remind yourself that research suggests that depressive episodes last about five months on average.
And even during an episode, you can experience moments where you feel better, even "normal."
WHAT ELSE?

Keep a careful eye on not just your mood, but other factors like appetite and energy. Why? Research shows that mood is one of the last symptoms to improve. If your appetite is returning, or you're feeling less indecisive, these are all hopeful signs.
Accepting When You Feel Down
Accept your depression to move forward.
INSTRUCTIONS

Depression can be like quicksand. The more you struggle, the deeper you sink. The more you try to escape your depressive symptoms, the more stuck you can get. Instead, accept that you're feeling depressed. Be kind to yourself and work towards other things that are also important in your life. Can you work towards goals *and* carry your depression with you?
WHY

This is a central premise in Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT), an empirically-supported treatment for depression, anxiety, and many other disorders and physical conditions. Rather than fight the depression directly, ACT encourages individuals to "allow their depression in" as they work towards pursuing other important things in life.
Strategies for Coping with Depression

We all struggle with difficult emotions, but sometimes those emotions lead to unwanted thoughts and can be so overwhelming that we don’t know what to do or to whom to turn. In times like that it’s common to withdraw from family and friends and isolate. It takes courage to admit how you’re feeling, even if you’re only admitting it to yourself at first.
In addition to reaching out for professional help when you’re feeling depressed, this activity will share some strategies that may help alleviate your difficult emotions.
1. Establish a routine

items: Having a daily routine can help provide a sense of accomplishment and improve sleep, which contributes to good physical and mental health.

Take small steps. Routines can be as simple as waking up, going to bed, and eating meals at the same time each day. Allocate time each day for exercising or walking outside. Incorporate getting dressed (or at least out of your pajamas) as part of your routine.
Celebrate getting through each day. Remember that these steps set the groundwork for accomplishing larger goals.

components.text: 2. Remember your personal goals

items: Think about what you’d like to get done the next few months or years. If it’s easier, start with what you want to do in the next few weeks.
Write your goals down in a journal or display it on your wall as a reminder of the things you’d like to accomplish.
A friend or a Headspace Care Coach can help hold you accountable.

components.text: 3. Discover what self-care means for you

Self-care doesn’t necessarily mean bubble baths or other luxuries. Self-care is whatever works to energize and replenish you. It helps build resilience and prepares your body for coping with unwanted situations.
Try to be intentional in incorporating self-care into your daily routine. There are three basic forms of self-care: physical, mental, and social.

items: Physical self-care could be eating healthy food, sitting down with a warm cup of calming tea, or taking an evening walk.
Mental self-care could be taking time to check things off your to-do list to give you peace of mind, starting a mini garden and tending to it daily, or meditation.
Social self-care could be engaging with others at a level that is manageable to you, and knowing how to say no to social situations that make you uncomfortable.

components.text: 4. Connect with friends and family

items: While being alone can sometimes feel comfortable, surrounding yourself with loved ones can help protect your mental health and be a resource you can draw upon in times of need.
Plan an event, virtually or socially-distanced, where you can connect with others over an enjoyable activity and at a cadence that feels manageable to you.

components.text: 5. Find a safe friend/adult to talk to about how you’re feeling.

items: These thoughts can sometimes be strong and scary and it’s OK to reach out and tell someone else how you’re feeling.
**If a friend reaches out to you for support, make sure you let them know you hear them and it’s okay to feel that way. Then work together to find them the resources and support they need.**

components.text: Remember, Headspace Care Coaches are here to listen and help support you. You can also reach out to other behavioral health coaches, counselors, or therapists for support. Should you feel unsafe, call the Suicide & Crisis Lifeline.

properties.name: Exercise Habits to Improve Your Mood

components.text: Exercise Habits to Improve Your Mood

Research shows that regular exercise can improve your mood and reduce symptoms of depression and even prevent relapse. There's also evidence that regular exercise can promote higher quality sleep and increase energy, increase self-esteem and a sense of control, and improve brain health.
This activity will:

items: Help you establish a new exercise routine or make changes to current one;
Suggest new exercise activities to try.

components.text: Exercise and Mood
While exercise isn't considered a cure for when you’re feeling down or depressed, it does have mood boosting effects and can even help prevent you from feeling down in the future.

It's best to find something physically active that you enjoy and think you're likely to repeat over time. You can set simple goals to start, make your workouts social, get moving outside, and add your favorite music.
This activity can help you establish a new exercise routine, make changes to your current one, or try out a new kind of activity.
What sounds good to you?
Where would you prefer to exercise?
How about company?

options.name: I'd like to exercise with a friend or two.

components.text: About how much time could you set aside in a day for exercise?
And what time of day works best for you?
How often are you exercising per week right now?
Which of these sounds like the most reasonable intensity level for you right now?

options.name: Exercising at the gym or running outside

components.text: Let's get moving...
From what you've shared, it sounds like you might enjoy:
Stretching in a chair
Going for a slow walk
Exercising at the gym or running outside
Training for a triathlon
in the:
Morning
Afternoon
Evening
Try doing one of these in the morning for just a few minutes.

These are just a few ideas to get you started. You could choose one that looks fun and try it out this week. But, if you don't see anything you like, your coach can help you brainstorm something that works for you.

We know it's not always possible to do what sounds ideal (for example, it's hard to run outside if it's snowing, or walk with friends if they're busy). So, for right now, just choose something that feels reasonable to start this week. You can always make a different exercise goal later on.
What works for you?
This week, I'd like to try exercising for:
Just a few minutes
About 30 minutes
45 minutes to an hour
Now, set your goal.
Let's set a SMART (specific, measurable, attainable, relevant, and time-bound) goal for exercise this week.
Write your SMART goal down in a journal or keep it in your mind.
Before beginning any new exercise routine, it's a good idea to check in with your doctor.

It can be hard to get started on a new goal. Tell your coach how you'll work around any barriers that might come up. Your coach is here to help you problem solve, cheer you on, and help keep you accountable for achieving your goal. Also, you can always come back later and set a new SMART exercise goal in the future. You've got this!
Alcohol Use & Mental Health

Alcohol use, which can impact your mood, is very common both among people who are feeling down and those who aren’t. It's also important to note that drinking is not always a problem behavior, but it’s helpful to assess whether it might be a problem for you right now. It’s one area that you can focus on when trying to improve your mood.
This activity will:

items: Explain how alcohol use can affect your mood and other areas of your life;
Give you resources if you’re concerned about your alcohol use.

components.text: Coping and Causing

It’s common to use alcohol as a short-term coping strategy to deal with feeling down. It's also common to get hooked on the cycle of drinking to cope with low mood. It can often give you immediate relief from feeling sad or down (even though it may lead you to feel worse later on). That relief, however, reinforces the behavior, and can lead to relying heavily on alcohol to cope. But, alcohol isn't a healthy or effective long-term coping strategy because alcohol directly affects your body and brain in ways that can make your mood worse.

Regular heavy drinking can change your brain chemistry, causing low mood. It can negatively impact your quality of sleep (which has a lot to do with your mood). Also, alcohol use can cause hangovers, which can lead to a cycle of waking up feeling ill, anxious, jittery, and guilty.

Alcohol can also affect your relationships, friendships, work, and home life. Problems associated with drinking can increase risk of feeling down and can lead to arguments with family or friends, trouble at work, memory, and sexual problems. When your work and home life are negatively impacted, it can make you feel even more down.
Support

Substance use is often the type of behavior that requires more than self-management. If you have concerns about your alcohol or other substance use, talk to your Headspace Care coach, therapist, or psychiatrist. They can also help you, especially if it feels like it’s too much to handle on your own.
Resources

If you've tried unsuccessfully to reduce or quit drinking in the past, community support or 12-step programs can be good options. Anyone in the US or Canada can find nearby AA meetings on the  AA website (https://www.aa.org/). Also, check out the Smart Recovery program (http://www.smartrecovery.org/).
Preparing for Mood Dips

After diving in to strategies in the Headspace Care app and/or working with your coach or therapist, we hope you are feeling much better! Life has ups and downs, and it is very common to have dips in mood after you start feeling better. The good news, though, is that there are specific tools to prepare for and manage those dips.
This activity will:

items: Give you tips for noticing the signs of lapsing or relapsing;
Show you how to keep yourself on track if times get hard;
Help you develop a relapse prevention plan to steer yourself back on track.

components.text: Lapsing and Relapsing
Lapses are when you slip back into a habit, thought pattern, or emotional spiral you've already learned to manage effectively.
Relapses are a bit bigger. They’re when you seem to slide all the way to the beginning and return completely to old habits or behaviors.
It’s an important distinction because it takes a lot of lapses to fully relapse. In other words, if you catch yourself in a lapse, you can get back on track before things spiral too far.

Sometimes it can be tricky to tell if you're lapsing. Since low moods are part of life, it's normal to have a couple days of feeling down or having difficulty getting started in the morning. But, if you notice that you're feeling really down for a while, it might be a good idea to check in with yourself to see if you're starting to get stuck in the low mood.
How to Monitor Your Mood
Monitoring your mood will help you avoid lapsing in the future, and if you do lapse, it can help you avoid relapsing.
To monitor your mood, identify the four following categories:

items: Your early warning signs (behaviors, physical signs, thoughts, and emotions)
Your high stress situations
Your skills
Your support systems

components.text: Early Warning Signs

Think back on a time when you felt down. Then, think back to the very beginning of that time—the first few moments when it occurred to you that something wasn't quite right—when you noticed that you might be slipping into a low mood. Becoming familiar with the early warning signs of feeling down gives you power. If you can identify signals of feeling down before it starts, you may be able to stop the feeling in its tracks.
Early warning signs fall into four major categories:

items: Physical feelings in your body (e.g. tense muscles or an upset stomach)
Emotions (e.g. feeling overwhelmed or feeling upset)
Thoughts (e.g. thinking that everything is hopeless or thinking that you aren’t appreciated)
Behaviors (e.g. having trouble getting out of bed in the morning, or eating unhealthy foods)

components.text: Your Early Warning Signs
What are some physical signs that you notice right at the beginning of a low mood?

options.name: trouble sleeping or sleeping too much

components.text: How about emotions you tend to notice?

options.name: lack of excitement about things you enjoyed

components.text: OK, now think about the thoughts you have right before you notice feeling down. Do any of these look familiar?

options.name: thinking others are out to get you
thinking you can’t do anything about how you feel

components.text: What are some behaviors you notice?

options.name: spending less time doing activities you enjoy

components.text: High-Risk Situations
High-risk situations are life changes or situations that you know bring you stress and make you more vulnerable to feeling down.
It's worth noting that events that can be seen as positive (like getting promoted or married) can also be a source of stress, since they're still big changes.
Would you consider any of these situations high risk for you?

options.name: starting a new job or school
moving or other changes in your home

components.text: Reach out for help

It can be nice to have the added support of someone you trust. It doesn't mean you’ve done anything wrong and it isn’t a sign of weakness. Asking for help means you're taking your mental health seriously.

It's helpful to have a list of people handy (whether they're your coach, therapist, or psychiatrist, family members, friends, or even coworkers) that you know you can reach out to for support. They can help you stay accountable for achieving your goals and help you notice your subtle warning signs that you might miss at the time.
Keep a list of people in your phone, or add your friends and family to your favorites in your contacts.
Other Strategies to Prevent Lapses or Relapses

When you notice that you're experiencing some of those early warning signs, and maybe even find yourself in a high-risk situation, here are a few general strategies that can help. For support tailored to your specific needs, reach out to your coach.
If...
You’re eating more or less than usual.

items: Track what you are eating for a few days. Notice if your eating is different than usual. Commit to making one small change over the next week. For example, maybe you add in one extra service of fruits or vegetables per day.

components.text: You’re not getting the right amount of sleep.

items: Track your sleep for a few days including time to bed, time to fall asleep, wake up time, and whether or not you felt rested. Has your bedtime crept later and later? Are you pushing snooze more than normal? Try to make one small change over the next week. For example, going to bed 15 minutes closer to your usual bedtime or pushing snooze one less time.

components.text: You continue to experience significant physical signs or symptoms such as extreme fatigue, aches and pains, sexual problems, sleep disturbance, or weight loss or gain.

items: Reach out to your primary care provider to discuss. It may be helpful to rule out possible medical causes for these issues.

components.text: You’ve started to feel down or feel less excitement about things you enjoy.

items: One of the best ways to combat this is to schedule pleasant events. This could be as small as your favorite cup of tea in the afternoon or as large as a weekend getaway. We all need things to look forward to!

components.text: You have more negative thinking patterns.

items: Work on challenging these using strategies you’ve learned. Consider, what would a trusted friend tell you about this thought? What evidence do you have to support the thought? What evidence do you have that does not support the thought?

components.text: You’ve found yourself increasingly using substances to try to regulate your mood.

items: Try to take a step back and look at how this may be impacting your mood. For many people, substances like alcohol, marijuana, and even caffeine, can make them more vulnerable to negative moods creeping in.

components.text: You’ve stopped taking your medications as prescribed.

items: Check in with your prescriber. Make sure to tell them about any side effects or concerns you’ve had so that you can work to find a sustainable medication regimen.

components.text: You’ve recently experienced a big life event that you feel may be contributing to your recent mood dip.

items: Try to remind yourself that it is temporary. Think about how you might feel in one week, month, year, etc. once the stressor has passed.

components.text: As always, if these strategies are not helping or you find your mood dipping further down, reach out to a mental health provider to determine what steps will best help you.
Your lapse and relapse plan when you start to feel down:
You said your early warning signs are:
Physical:
•   change in appetite
•   extreme tiredness
•   general aches and pains
•   sexual problems
•   trouble sleeping or sleeping too much
•   weight gain or loss
Emotional:
•   sadness
•   loneliness
•   hopelessness
•   lack of excitement about things you enjoyed
•   irritability
Thoughts:
•   difficulty concentrating
•   thinking you'll always feel down
•   thinking others are out to get you
•   thinking you can’t do anything about how you feel
Behaviors:
•   sleeping more or less
•   eating more or less
•   using substances
•   not taking medications as prescribed
•   spending less time doing activities you enjoy
•   procrastinating at work
•   fighting with your partner
•   staying home more often
Your high risk situations:
•   starting a new job or school
•   taking on new responsibilities
•   a major holiday or anniversary
•   a new relationship or commitment
•   pregnancy
•   moving or other changes in your home
•   other health problems
When you start to feel your warning signs, which strategy will you do?

options.name: Discuss physical symptoms with your primary care doctor
Look at the impact of your substance use
Check in with your medication prescriber
Look beyond a temporary big event or change

components.text: It's also helpful to post reminders in places where you'll see them often (e.g. a post-it on your mirror reminding you to do an activity when you notice yourself starting to lapse). You can also share this plan with a close friend who can help you watch out for warning signs, or give you added support during a high-risk situation.
Your relapse plan:
•   Track your diet
•   Track your sleep
•   Discuss physical symptoms with your primary care doctor
•   Plan something fun
•   Challenge your negative thinking
•   Look at the impact of your substance use
•   Check in with your medication prescriber
•   Look beyond a temporary big event or change
•   Reach out for support
You've got a plan when you feel like you may have lapsed or relapsed. Also, don't forget that your coach is here to help you stay on track.
Healthy Sleep Habits
Sleep and depression: it's more than counting sheep.

When you’re feeling down, sleep can be an added source of stress. You may sleep too much without feeling rested, or have trouble falling asleep or staying asleep, or you may stress about sleep during the day. This can really impact your mood.
This activity will:

items: Explain the difference between your sleep clock and sleep drive
Show you habits that can improve your sleep and mood
Help you establish healthy sleep habits

components.text: Having trouble sleeping looks different for everyone.
Choose any of the following that you experience:

options.name: Worry about the consequences of poor sleep
What if I don't experience any of those?

components.text: Sounds like you're sleeping pretty well...
We're glad to hear that you're not experiencing any of those sleep issues right now.

Even though you might be sleeping well at the moment, we think it's always a good idea to learn a bit more about how to optimize your sleep. There may be one small thing you can add in to make your night's sleep even more restful. Or, you can store up this information for a time in the future when you might need it.

When you're feeling low and tired, you might withdraw and spend more time in bed instead of being out and about. Spending more time awake in bed will lower your urge for sleep. It'll make it even harder to get good quality rest when you finally do try to fall asleep at night.
Plus, if you're having anxious thoughts and difficult emotions before sleep and upon waking, you might even start to associate the bed or bedroom with anxiety and those difficult emotions.
The poorer quality sleep you get can make the symptoms you started with even worse.
Thoughts, behaviors, and Sleep
How do you think about sleep? And what do you do when you're not getting enough of it?
You shared that sometimes you experience:
Difficulty falling asleep
Difficulty staying asleep
Feeling unrested in the morning
Distress or worry about sleep
Worry about the consequences of poor sleep
irritability
Depressed mood
Difficulty concentrating
Fatigue

When you're feeling low and tired, you might withdraw and spend more time in bed instead of being out and about. Spending more time awake in bed will lower your urge for sleep. It'll make it even harder to get good quality rest when you finally do try to fall asleep at night.
Plus, if you're having anxious thoughts and difficult emotions before sleep and upon waking, you might even start to associate the bed or bedroom with anxiety and those difficult emotions.
The poorer quality sleep you get can make the symptoms you started with even worse.
So, how does sleep work?
There are two main systems that help us sleep well: a body clock and a sleep drive.
Let's start with the body clock…
Your body clock sets your internal rhythm.

Everyone's body clock is a little different (think: night owls and early birds). It can also be different from the time you see on the clock that hangs on your wall. Your body clock is like an internal timer to tell you when to wake up, when to get sleepy, and when to go to bed. But, the less we listen to it, the weaker its signal becomes.

Imagine someone asked you to travel across three different time zones multiple times over the course of just one week. Doesn't sound too great, right? You'd probably feel pretty groggy. Well, that's essentially what we're asking our bodies to do when we go to sleep and wake up at drastically different times, even if we're not traveling.

Ideally, we want to match our schedule to our body clock, and not the other way around. So, if your body is telling you that your natural wake up time is 6am, you don't want to stay up until 2am. For most people, there's a healthy middle ground: you fall asleep sometime after 9pm, and you wake up before late morning.
Let's see how your body clock's doing now.
Let's talk about your body clock...
I go to bed at about the same time every night.
I wake up at about the same time every morning (even on weekends).
By the time I get into bed at night, I'm very sleepy.
I wake up feeling refreshed and energized.
I don't feel the need to nap throughout the day.
Here are three great ways that you can keep yourself on track and keep that body clock signal strong:

items.body: Getting regular sunlight earlier in the day will help shift your body to an earlier rise time (and getting sunlight later than usual can do the opposite). While everyone's experience is different, when you’re feeling down, it’s typical to have trouble waking up early.

We want to match our schedules to our body clock as much as possible. So, it's best to get out of bed at the same time every single day, regardless of when you went to sleep, or what day of the week it is (that means the same time every day, even on weekends).

The body clock doesn't always work in 24-hour chunks like a regular clock, so performing daily routines at around the same time each day can help strengthen the signal. (Bonus: structure is also really helpful for improving mood.)

options.name: What if my work hours make this harder?

components.text: Sometimes that 10:00 PM bedtime just isn't happening.
So, what if you're doing shift work outside of the 9-5?

Maybe you work in the evening or night, early morning, or even rotating shifts. That could make it pretty hard to stick to your body clock. You might get drowsy while working, or feel wide awake when it's time to sleep.
A few things to keep in mind with shift work:

items: For night shifts, try your best to keep the same sleep and rise times each day (even on your days off).
If you're rotating, try to rotate shifts clockwise–you'll want to go from a day shift, to an evening shift, to a night shift rather than the other way, or rotating without a pattern.
When you're preparing for a new shift, try your best to adjust your sleep and wake time gradually.

components.text: Your coach is here to help you find ways to strengthen your body clock signal, no matter what your work schedule might be. Talk to your coach to come up with a plan together.
What is sleep drive?
Your sleep drive is the pressure or urge your body has to sleep at any given point.

Imagine a glass filling with water. Ideally, when you wake up, the glass is empty or at its lowest point (you're not tired at all). Then, as the day goes on, it fills and fills until it's at the top. You can fall asleep and have high quality, deep sleep. Ahhh...
The idea that you can make up for lost sleep can actually work against you. Do you do any of these?

items: Stay in bed longer after waking
Napping
Sleeping in
Go to bed early
Cut back on usual activities

components.text: Engaging in the habits above every once in a while isn’t terrible, but these habits can be harmful to your sleep if they become a pattern over time. It's just that the more time you spend in bed awake (during the day, or tossing and turning at night), the lower your sleep drive will be.

If you lose sleep one night, you’ll actually build more of an urge to sleep the following night, and you'll have deeper, more restful sleep when you do. The best way to make up for a long stretch of poor quality sleep is to add no more than 30-60 minutes a night (instead of trying to play catch-up).
There’s no set number of hours you should be sleeping each night. It's about quality of sleep, not quantity.
So, what can you do?
Sleep hygiene is what we call the behaviors that strengthen your body clock and sleep drive.
Here are behaviors that have been proven to truly help with consistent quality sleep:

items: Leave the bed and bedroom if you're having trouble sleeping. Do something else that's not too stimulating, but that's more enjoyable than tossing and turning in bed. For example, knitting or reading a dry article would be better than watching the news or online shopping.

Try not to do wakeful activities in bed. By that, we mean: listening to music, watching TV, texting/talking on the phone, using your computer, eating, planning, or working. Sleep hygiene means using the bed for sleep and sex. That's it.

Don't try to sleep. We know, this one sounds strange. But, ideally, the process of falling asleep should be effortless. And we've learned that worrying about sleep (or the consequences of not sleeping well) can actually bring more negativity or anxiety to your bedroom. So, if you find that you're tossing and turning, circle back to that first option and leave the bedroom entirely.

Think of sleep hygiene like any sort of cleanliness. You want your bed and bedroom to be a clean, mentally and emotionally clear space that's only used for sleep—not as a home office, and not as a kitchen table.

components.text: There are a few special cases where you might need more than just sleep hygiene.
Are any of the following true for you?
I'm taking a higher dose of medication than what my doctor prescribed in order to sleep.
I snore heavily.
I wake up choking or gasping for air.
Someone has told me that my legs or feet jerk or twitch repeatedly during the night.
I often wake up in the morning with the bedsheets very tangled.
I have an irresistible urge to move my legs, especially when I'm trying to sleep.
Thanks for letting us know.
You share that sometimes:
I'm taking a higher dose of medication than what my doctor prescribed in order to sleep.
I snore heavily.
I wake up choking or gasping for air.
Someone has told me that my legs or feet jerk or twitch repeatedly during the night.
I often wake up in the morning with the bedsheets very tangled.
I have an irresistible urge to move my legs, especially when I'm trying to sleep.
In some cases, that may be a sign of a sleep disorder or medical condition–in that case, you'll want to talk to your doctor.
Habits that Can Help

For many people who feel down or experience depression, fatigue and difficulty sleeping are sources of stress. Research shows that it can work both ways—depression can cause sleeping problems, and difficulty sleeping can worsen symptoms of depression.
Because feeling down leads to tiredness and fatigue, it can be hard to engage with work, friendships, and relationships.

Here is a list of exercises that might help. Everyone's different, but research shows that this list is a great place to start. And don't worry, you don't have to try these all out at once. As you read through, notice if there's one that feels like it might help. Then, you can create a goal around it.

items: Wait until you're feeling pretty sleepy before getting into bed.
Reserve your bed for sleeping and sex only.

Leave the bed or bedroom when you're having trouble falling asleep or staying asleep. Then, choose an activity that's not too stimulating to do until you get sleepy–maybe you read a boring section of the newspaper, or do a repetitive task.
Try a relaxation practice before bed (meditating, a deep breathing technique, reading, etc.)
Set some screen-free time for yourself in the hour before bed.
Avoid alcohol, cigarettes, and heavy meals in the evening.
Establish a regular relaxing bedtime routine.
Keep the bedroom a TV-free zone.
Make sure that the sleep environment is pleasant. Mattress and pillows should be comfortable. The bedroom should be cool, dark, and quiet.
Try going to bed and waking up at the same time each day.

components.text: Note: For some people might help to work with a specialist to fully address sleep difficulty.
Want to set a SMART goal for sleep?
SMART goals are Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, and Time-bound. Your goal can be whatever you think would be a reasonable, helpful place to start.
You're on your way to deeper sleep.
Choose one you'd like to try out this week:

options.name: Wait until you're feeling pretty sleepy before getting into bed.
Reserve your bed for sleeping and sex only.
Leave the bed or bedroom when you're having trouble falling asleep or staying asleep.
Try a relaxation practice before bed.
Set some screen-free time for yourself in the hour before bed.
Avoid alcohol/cigarettes/heavy meals in the evening.
Establish a regular relaxing bedtime routine.
Keep the bedroom a TV-free zone.
Make sure that the sleep environment is pleasant.
Try going to bed and waking up at the same time each day.

components.text: Your Sleep SMART Goal
You chose:
Wait until you're feeling pretty sleepy before getting into bed.
Reserve your bed for sleeping and sex only.
Leave the bed or bedroom when you're having trouble falling asleep or staying asleep.
Try a relaxation practice before bed.
Set some screen-free time for yourself in the hour before bed.
Avoid alcohol/cigarettes/heavy meals in the evening.
Establish a regular relaxing bedtime routine.
Keep the bedroom a TV-free zone.
Make sure that the sleep environment is pleasant.
Try going to bed and waking up at the same time each day
If you notice that your sleep problems are really interfering with your life, don’t hesitate to speak with your doctor or a sleep professional.
Talk to your coach about how to make this goal SMART (Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, and Time-bound). You got this.

properties.name: Establish a Routine to Feel Better

components.text: Establish a Routine to Feel Better
When you feel down, it can take a toll on your routine. You may need to look for ways to get your routine back on track, create a new one, or just give your current routine a checkup.
This activity will:

items: Help you establish a comforting routine in your daily life.
Help you to maintain and possibly improve your current routine.

components.text: Your Routine
Consider the following areas of your daily routine:

items: Your sleep schedule
Your eating schedule
Social time
Time spent being physically active
The overall structure of your day

components.text: It’s common to lose some of the daily rhythm of life when you’re feeling down. So, it can be helpful to look at the structure of your day now and see if things have shifted since you’ve been feeling down. For example, are you going to bed and waking up at the same time you used to? Or, do you find yourself with more unstructured time on your hands? Your emotions can impact your sleep routine and the amount of free time you have. Some of the daily activities help you regulate moods, which is why it’s important to focus on routine.
Depression can absolutely impact your daily routine. Consider the following areas of your routine once again:

items: Your sleep schedule
Your eating schedule
Social time
Time spent being physically active
The overall structure of your day

components.text: Now, what part of your routine would you like to focus on?

Picking just one area to focus on is hard because the different parts of your routine are all connected. For example, your sleep schedule can impact your eating schedule. Just choose one area for now.
YOU SAID:
Sleep schedule
Sleep is a key part of your routine. When you’re feeling down, it's normal to struggle with falling asleep, staying asleep, or oversleeping.
Which of these resonate with you the most?
YOU SAID:
Difficulty falling asleep
Keeping a regular bedtime and wake time that doesn’t vary much day-to-day (even on weekdays and weekends) is the goal. This is what establishing a routine around sleep can look like.
During the day:

items: Try not to nap.
Do some physical activity during the day, whether it's riding your bike or walking down the street.

components.text: Around bedtime:

items: Only get into bed when you're sleepy.

Get out of bed if you can’t fall asleep. Seriously, get up and leave your bedroom. Try doing something enjoyable but that's not too active. Like reading, working on a sodoku puzzle, or making a cup of hot tea.
Get back into bed whenever you feel sleepy.
Repeat the above three steps however many times you need to.

components.text: YOU SAID:
Difficulty staying asleep

Keeping a regular bedtime and wake time that doesn’t vary much day-to-day (even on weekdays and weekends) is the goal. This is what establishing a routine around sleep can look like. When you know you won’t fall back to sleep, try not to force it. In other words, don't try to sleep if you can't.
Try these strategies out instead:

items: Get out of bed. Seriously, get up and leave your bedroom. Try doing something enjoyable but that's not too active. Like reading, working on a sodoku puzzle, or making a cup of hot tea.
Get back into bed whenever you feel sleepy.
Repeat the above steps however many times you need to.
When you're awake, don't look at the clock or your watch.

components.text: YOU SAID:
Difficulty getting out of bed
Keeping a regular bedtime and wake time that doesn’t vary much day-to-day (even on weekdays and weekends) is the goal. This is what establishing a routine around sleep can look like.
Here are some strategies to try out:

items: Try not to hit snooze on your alarm.

Plan something enjoyable to do when you wake up. Maybe get out of bed and sit in your favorite chair, or have your favorite coffee or breakfast food. You might read the newspaper or watch a morning talk show you like. Don’t feel like you need to hop out of bed and begin rushing through the day. Take time to enjoy what it feels like to be awake.

components.text: Our Meal and Eating Routine
YOU SAID:
Eating schedule
When you’re feeling down, it’s common not to eat at the same times you used to. Or sometimes, you may not feel like eating at all. Your meal and eating routines can get thrown off.
Which of these resonate with you the most?
YOU SAID:
No interest in eating
Feeling down can definitely impact your interest in eating. Here are a few ideas for you to establish more of a routine around eating, even if you really don't feel like it.
Some solutions:

items: Set reminders for each of your meals, rather than only eating when you feel like it.
Plan meals you really enjoy eating, whether it's including your favorite food or making a certain recipe.
Try to look at eating as a pleasant activity for the day.

Eliminate possible barriers to eating, like not having food at home. Could you go to the grocery store or try a meal delivery service? Try to view grocery shopping or ordering food a satisfying activity.

components.text: YOU SAID:
Meal times are off track
Feeling down can definitely impact your eating and meal schedule. Here are a few ideas for you to establish more of a routine around eating.
Some solutions:

items: Set reminders for each of your meals.
Set a goal to wake up and eat something for breakfast. Even if you decide to go back to bed later, this is a good start.
Eliminate possible barriers, like not having food at home. Could you go to the grocery store or try a meal delivery service?

components.text: Time with Others
YOU SAID:
Social time
When you feel down, you can sometimes find that you aren't spending as much time with friends or family members, or even any other people, as you used to.
Which of these resonate with you the most?

options.name: Less time with friends or loved ones

components.text: We're here for you.
YOU SAID:
Less time with friends or loved ones
Could you try this?

Set a SMART goal around spending time with others. When setting SMART goals, the idea is to start small. Maybe you begin by just sending a text or an email, or making a phone call. Over time, you'll gradually increase the amount and type of social interaction you're having. Perhaps getting coffee with a friend, attending a family wedding, visiting a former classmate, or inviting a neighbor over for dinner.
We're here for you.
YOU SAID:
Feeling isolated from others
Could you try any of these?

items: Create opportunities to be around people. Maybe you can start a new behavior to study at the public library, walk around the shopping mall, sit on a bench in a busy park, or see a movie. Just being around others, even if you don't know them, can help.

Try initiating a conversation with or smiling at someone. You might greet a cashier at the drugstore, or ask a server at a cafe how their day's going. Asking a question in class or complimenting the person sitting next to you are easy ways to feel a little less isolated, too.

components.text: Being Active
YOU SAID:
Time spent being physically active
Sometimes the amount of time you spend being active decreases when you’re feeling down. But there are ways you can add activity back into your routine.
We recommend this:

Set a SMART goal to do something active. It doesn’t have to be a specific goal, behavior, or activity around exercise specifically. It can be around any activity that gets you up, like baking or meeting a friend to watch a game at a bar. Or set a SMART goal to do five sit-ups before bed.
Less structure in your day?
YOU SAID:
Overall structure of your day

Your routine is like an anchor. When you lose the anchor, you can drift away, get off course, and end up having less structure and too much free time during the day. If that happens, you no longer have a routine and daily activities to keep you anchored down and feeling steady. You may need to find a new anchor.
Here are some ideas:

items: Plan a new behavior during this unstructured time.
Plan a pleasant or satisfying activity during this time.

Think long-term. Could you commit to learning a new skill or working on a long-term project? For example, practicing sketching, working on planting a garden, planning a future trip, or attending a daily class.

components.text: OK. You've now got a few ideas for how you can create, improve, or maintain more of a daily flow in your life specifically around: Overall structure of your day.
Tell your coach specifically how you're going to work on changing, maintaining, or improving your current routine this week. Your coach is here to support you.
Activities to Boost Your Mood

Finding time to experience pleasure and accomplishment can boost your mood. But, when you’re feeling down, it can be hard to engage in activities that you once found pleasurable. Starting small with just one activity a day can help you feel better and more motivated to keep going.
This activity will:

items: Help you identify small, pleasant, or satisfying things you enjoy doing every day;
Give you a list of ideas of pleasant or satisfying activities to try;
Find activities that fit with your needs.

components.text: Choose the outcome you’d like:
Which would you like to start out with?
Activities that you enjoy
Below is a list of activities. Maybe you’ve already tried some and they bring you joy. Maybe there are some you’re curious about. When choosing activities to try, keep in mind:

items: At least one activity should be something you can do immediately, without needing anything to get started.
The activities you choose shouldn't be too difficult. For example, if you've never done yoga before, doing it could be pretty difficult.

components.text: Choose as many as you'd like.

The idea here is for you to experience pleasure at least once each day. You can always come up with more activities to add to your week. We recommend having at least three ready to try.
Give one of these activities a try, ideally today or tomorrow.
Activities that make you feel accomplished
Choose activities that you've tried before and make you feel accomplished and satisfied, or choose some that you’d like to try. Keep in mind:

items: You should be able to do at least one activity immediately, without needing anything to get started.
The activities you choose shouldn't be too difficult. For example, if you've never done yoga before, doing it could be pretty difficult.
