Remember, doing these activities may give you a boost for just a short time. But, it’s important to do at least one thing every day that’ll boost your mood, even just a little. If the activities aren’t making you feel better, talk to your coach for other ideas.

properties.name: SMART Goals to Boost Your Mood

components.text: SMART Goals to Boost Your Mood

When it comes to feeling down, the good news is that your actions can impact your feelings. So, by changing your behaviors, you may be able to improve your mood. Using the SMART goal technique can help you figure out a behavior to start or change.
This activity will help you

items: Understand why changing your behavior can improve your mood;
Learn what a SMART goal is;
Set a SMART goal that fits with your life and values.

components.text: Behaviors that Matter

It’s common for your behaviors to reflect how you’re feeling. If you’re feeling low, you may close the blinds, crawl into bed, pull the covers over your head, and not get up for the rest of the day. But these actions won’t help lift your mood, in face they may keep you feeling bad. Over time, this becomes a vicious cycle that can lead to you feeling worse.

So, what if you act the opposite of how you’re feeling? This is where you have some power to change your mood. When you’re feeling low, choosing to do something that you enjoy, or that’s important to you can lift your mood.
When you’re feeling down, what you choose to do matters.
It’s not enough to simply “do more” or “be more active.” What matters is increasing behaviors that you care about, behaviors that support your values.

Think about the following areas of your life: family, friends, intimate relationships, career, volunteer work, health, hobbies, school. Are there some that stand out as areas that you care about and where you'd like to make a change? For example, if you're feeling really lonely lately and know that your personal relationships have been suffering, you might want to set a goal to do something that affects your relationships.
This activity will help you choose activities that really matter to you personally.
Choose an activity using a SMART goal

When you choose an activity based on a goal, rather than on a feeling, it can help change your mood more effectively. To set a goal, try the SMART goal technique. SMART is an acronym for the steps to plan and carry out an effective goal, and change your mood.
SMART goals are:

items: S - Specific
M - Measurable
A - Attainable
R - Relevant
T - Time-bound

components.text: When you act on SMART goals that reflect your values, you can better improve your mood.
If you already have a SMART Goal in mind, you can set it right away. If you'd like to go step-by-step, here's what to do:

items: Pick a life area that you want to focus on.
Set a SMART goal that's specific, measurable, attainable, relevant, and time-bound.

components.text: Do you already have a SMART Goal in mind? Or would you prefer to take it step-by-step?

options.name: I know my SMART goal already

components.text: What life area do you want to focus on?

Your SMART goal will be based on a life area that's important to you. It's key for your goal to reflect your values and what's meaningful to you. When you act on these goals, it helps create and maintain a positive mood.
Pick a topic that's significant to your life.
Setting Your SMART Goal
OK, let's get to it. If you need help, you can always reach out to your coach. Don't worry about getting it just right.
Remember, SMART goals are:

items: Specific
Measurable
Attainable
Relevant
Time-bound

components.text: FOR Example:
I want to talk to my spouse in person on Mondays for 15 minutes over the next two weeks.
Put all the pieces together. Write down or say out loud your full SMART goal that includes each of the above.
S:Specific
Now you've got the broad life area you want to focus on, the next step will be to get more specific.

For example, if your broader goal is to get a new job, that's great, but where do you go from there? Because it's not a specific behavior, the goal becomes hard to act on. Editing your resume or doing research on an industry are examples of specific, actionable behaviors you can carry out.
It's important to set goals around specific behaviors, not the desired outcome.
You'll be setting a specific goal around the area you chose:
Physical health
Social relationships
Intimate relationships
Employment or career
Hobbies or recreation
Volunteer or charity work
Spirituality
M: Measurable
Think about the following questions as they relate to your specific goal.

items: How often will I do this?
How long will I do this for?
How many total times will I do this?

components.text: A: Attainable

We don't want your goal to be too hard or too easy. For example, if you're really new to running, starting out running three times a week might be tough. You can revise your goal to make it more attainable.
R: Relevant
This means making sure your goal is significant to you and reflects a life area you feel is important.
T: Time-bound
SMART goals don't just disappear, go away, or ride off into the sunset. You set them for a certain amount of time. To make your goal time-bound, consider the following question:
How long are you going to be working towards this goal? To start out, see if you can complete your goal within the next couple days, or a week.
Reach out to your coach for help with mastering SMART goal setting.

And, don't forget the big picture: Adopting your goal and behavior can have a lot of influence over your mood. Getting your coach's input can ensure you're on the right track—a track to feeling better.

properties.name: Behavior Tracking to Help Your Mood

components.text: Behavior Tracking to Help Your Mood

When you’re feeling down, it’s common to avoid the things that you used to enjoy. Sometimes, even if you do those activities, they might not give you the same pleasure that they used to. You can end up stuck—choosing behaviors that reinforce your mood, rather than ones that can improve it. By keeping track of your behaviors, you can identify and start to change the behaviors that aren’t serving you.
This activity will show you:

items: Examples of behaviors that perpetuate bad feelings;
How to identify the behaviors;
How to track your behaviors that don’t serve you.

components.text: Example #1: Getting over a breakup

Let’s talk about Gabriel, who recently went through a difficult breakup and has been experiencing a depressed mood. He's been feeling a lot of shame and sadness about the relationship ending. When his friend reaches out to try and hang out, Gabriel decides not to meet up with his friend. He ignores his friend's text.
As a result of deciding to ignore the text, how do you think Gabriel might feel?

options.name: Regretful that he decided not to respond
Sadder about what happened with his partner

components.text: You said he may feel:
Regretful that he decided not to respond
Sadder about what happened with his partner
More ashamed over the breakup
You’re right. He might feel this way. All of the options are possibilities actually. The point is that ignoring the text from his friend isn’t going to make Gabriel feel any better.
And as a result of feeling this way, what might Gabriel do?
You said he might:
Isolate himself from other friends
Dwell on the breakup

Once again, both options are possibilities and neither would help Gabriel feel better or improve his depressed mood. Gabriel could easily end up in a vicious cycle of doing (or not doing) behaviors that make his mood worse.
Tracking Your Behaviors
The first step to identifying and changing the behaviors that aren’t serving you well—and may be perpetuating the vicious cycle—is to keep track of them.
By tracking what you're doing day-to-day, you'll start to gather information about what the cycle might look like for you.

First, record in a journal as much detail as you can about the behavior, so you've got information to work with when you're trying to discover patterns. For example, what did you do between waking up and arriving at work? We know it's not realistic to track every little thing, so just jot down as much as you can.

Also, keep in mind you don’t need to record your behaviors over a long stretch of time. Sometimes, when we’re feeling down and we track our behaviors, looking back at them can feel discouraging or disappointing. If that's the case, just gather some information over a few days so you can make important changes.
Once you start to see a pattern, you can think about how your behaviors or activities are impacting your mood. Which behaviors are helping you feel better? Which aren’t?
Putting the Behaviors in Context
When examining which behaviors might affect your mood, it can help to put them in context. What’s going on before or after you engage in the behavior? Looking at the context can help you:

items: Determine what might be influencing or triggering the behavior. This is called the “antecedent.”
Determine how the behavior is ultimately serving you. This is called the “consequence.”

components.text: Identifying the Impact Your Behavior
When you identify a behavior, remember the ABCs to help you see the context and identify the consequence.
A - antecedent, B - behavior, C - consequence.
Let’s take a closer look at the ABCs.
A: The Antecedent

Your feelings, thoughts, and actions depend on the context. The context could be a specific situation, the environment, or something you experienced a long time ago that might contribute to how you think, feel, or act today. This is the antecedent.
Understanding the antecedent—what influenced or triggered a behavior—can help you figure out how to change the behavior.
B: The Behavior

If you want to increase or decrease a behavior, sometimes the antecedent is actually what you need to change. Remember Gabriel? If Gabriel always thinks about his breakup while walking through the park where he and his partner used to walk, he might want to stop going to that park for a while. From there, he could see that helps him dwell less on the breakup.
C: The Consequence

What effect did the behavior you identified have on you? This effect is the consequence. When you investigate the consequence of a behavior, you can better determine if you want to increase or decrease it.

Connecting your behavior to a specific antecedent and consequence can be tough. If you’re having trouble, reach out to your coach to help you connect the dots so you can effectively change your behaviors and start feeling better.
Example #2: Dealing with work stress

Let’s look at Charlotte. Charlotte has a very successful career, but has been feeling down for a while. She’s overwhelmed at work, where she’s recently taken on more responsibilities. Charlotte now works late every night and spends the weekend finishing projects. She used to spend time with her friends, which really made her happy, but has no time anymore. They complain about it, which makes Charlotte feel guilty and bad about herself—like she’s let them down.
Let’s figure out the antecedent, behavior, and consequence. Starting with the behavior.
What’s Charlotte’s behavior here? Remember, a behavior is something we do or an action we take.

options.name: Charlotte has been overwhelmed at work
Charlotte feels guilty and bad about herself

components.text: That’s right.
YOU SAID:
Charlotte works late every night
YOU SAID:
Charlotte has been overwhelmed at work
Actually, the behavior is that Charlotte works late every night, which is caused by her feeling overwhelmed.
YOU SAID:
Charlotte feels guilty and bad about herself
Actually, the behavior is that Charlotte works late every night. The impact is how she feels.
Now, let’s figure out the antecedent.
BEHAVIOR: Charlotte works late every night
What do you think is the antecedent? It can help to think of the antecedent as the context or situation. What’s been going on that could have contributed to the above behavior?

options.name: Charlotte has been overwhelmed at work
Charlotte spent time with her friends

components.text: You got it.
YOU SAID:
Charlotte has been overwhelmed at work

This could be why she's been working late. Feeling overwhelmed is stressful, and it makes sense that Charlotte would spend more time at work if she's feeling that way. But, that behavior isn't helping her mood. Staying late at work isn't fixing the problem of feeling overwhelmed.
YOU SAID:
Charlotte spent time with her friends
The antecedent is actually that Charlotte has been overwhelmed at work. That’s what led to her behavior of working late every night.
YOU SAID:
Charlotte has a successful career
The antecedent is actually that Charlotte has been overwhelmed at work. That’s what led to her behavior of working late every night.
Here's what we know so far.
ANTECEDENT
Charlotte’s been overwhelmed at work
BEHAVIOR
Charlotte works late every night
Last question. What’s the consequence for Charlotte? What’s the effect of the behavior? What impact does this behavior have on Charlotte?

options.name: Charlotte will get moved to another department
Charlotte will have an even more successful career
Charlotte has no time for her friends and feels guilty

components.text: Close.
YOU SAID:
Charlotte will get moved to another department
Based on the information, we know that as a result of working late every night, Charlotte has less time for her friends and feels really guilty about this. This is the consequence.
It's true that Charlotte could possibly get moved to another department or have a more successful career. But the emotional impact is that she feels guilty.
Close.
YOU SAID:
Charlotte will have an even more successful career
Based on the information, we know that as a result of working late every night, Charlotte has less time for her friends and feels really guilty about this. This is the consequence.
Charlotte may have a more successful career, but that’s not necessarily going to happen. It’s not the direct consequence of her working late every night.
Correct.
YOU SAID:
Charlotte has no time for her friends and feels guilty.
That’s the consequence. The impact of her behavior of working late every night.
Connect the dots.
The antecedent, behavior, and consequence impact each other.
ANTECEDENT
Charlotte's been really overwhelmed at work
BEHAVIOR
Charlotte works late every night
CONSEQUENCE
Charlotte has no time for her friends and feels guilty

What happens from here? When Charlotte feels guilty, she may not feel like seeing her friends anyways. She could throw herself into more work. But this could just keep her feeling guilty. It's that same cycle.
What could Charlotte do to stop this cycle? What could she do to feel better?

options.name: Talk to her boss about her workload>
Plan in advance to see her friends
Call her friends to talk about what’s going on at work

components.text: Good option.
YOU SAID:
Talk to her boss about her workload
Plan in advance to see her friends
Call her friends to talk about what’s going on at work
Any of the choices could interrupt the cycle.
Feeling down causes us to engage less in the activities that make us feel better. When we’re not doing these things, it's harder to be in a good mood.

For Charlotte, spending time with her friends helps her maintain a positive mood. When she doesn't do this, her mood is impacted. She feels down and guilty. Coming up with a solution to help her spend time with her friends, like the one you chose above, can set her up to start feeling better.

Instead of working more in response to feeling overwhelmed, Charlotte can come up with a different strategy for managing that feeling, one that will also allow her to see her friends and ultimately improve her mood.
Recap

Tracking your behaviors can help you see what’s impacting your mood. The first step to track your behaviors is to describe and define what’s going on. Then, choose a behavior to examine, and take a close look at its antecedent and consequence. Write it all down in your journal, and remember to reach out to your coach who can help you connect the dots.

properties.name: How Food Can Affect Your Mood

components.text: How Food Can Affect Your Mood

The food we eat can affect our moods. In fact some studies have found that healthy diets can help with symptoms of depression and anxiety, not to mention health food can give us energy and help us focus.
This activity will:

items: Explain how food affects your mood
Give you suggestions for healthy foods to eat

components.text: The Science Behind Food and Mood

Your gastrointestinal (GI) tract (where your food is digested) is often referred to as your “second brain.” It contains billions of bacteria that directly affect the production of neurotransmitters, which carry messages from your gut to your brain.
Eating healthy food produces “good” bacteria, helping to send positive messages to your brain. The brain receives these messages clearly, and your emotions reflect it.
Eating unhealthy foods can cause inflammation in your GI tract, slowing down production of messages going to the brain, which in turn can cause your mood to worsen.
Food that can help boost your mood
Foods that contain Omega-3s, like fish, walnuts, flaxseed and soybean
People with low mood tend to have lower levels of omega-3s, suggesting that consuming more of these foods may help.
Foods with probiotics, like yogurt, Kefir, sauerkraut, tempeh, kombucha and pickles
Probiotics have anti-inflammatory effects, which may help mitigate depression’s inflammatory reaction in the body. They may improve digestive health, reduce depressed mood, and promote heart health.
Fiber rich foods like fruits and vegetables
Fiber helps your body absorb sugar more slowly, decreasing sugar rushes and crashes, allowing you to feel more focused and alert.
Green vegetables like spinach, broccoli and kale
Spinach and other green vegetables contain the B vitamin folate. Folate helps boost the metabolism of serotonin, dopamine, and noradrenaline (neurotransmitters important for mood).
Keep exploring!
What other foods might be linked to mood? Perhaps keep a food/mood diary to see what foods you are eating and how they affect your mood.
Your coach can discuss how your specific diet may affect your mood and ways you can improve it.
Learning About Antidepressants

Antidepressants prescribed by a psychiatrist can help manage depression. These medications may help to reduce the intensity and frequency of depressive thoughts and feelings over time. Antidepressants may or may not be the best option for you right now. It can help to learn some basic facts and guidelines about these medications. If you have additional questions, please reach out to your Headspace Care care team to learn more about antidepressant medication and Headspace Care’s mail-order pharmacy option through Capsule.
This activity will:

items: Give you an overview of antidepressants;
Explain what may occur when you start or stop an antidepressant

components.text: Starting a Medication

items: It typically takes about 4-6 weeks to notice any effects. So, be patient if you don't notice an improvement right away.
The side effects can be worse at the beginning; often, they balance out as your body adjusts.
It's very important to take your medications exactly as your doctor prescribes.
Even if you start feeling better, you should keep taking them unless you and your doctor decide otherwise.

components.text: Medication Side Effects

items: Common side effects may include diarrhea, dizziness, dry mouth, headache, nausea, shaking (tremors), sweating, and/or change in sexual function. In some rare cases, side effects such as confusion or sleepiness, agitation or panic symptoms, insomnia, and weight gain may occur. In those cases, you should reach out to your doctor or psychiatrist.

Sometimes, the side effects of a medication can outweigh the benefits. If you're not feeling well, it's still important to keep taking the medication until you've checked in with your doctor. He or she will often have you taper off of the medication slowly. Stopping abruptly can lead to discontinuation syndrome. You and your doctor can come up with a specific plan together.
There are several antidepressants and people respond differently to each one. You and your doctor may have to experiment with a few (or a combination) to find what works best for you.

components.text: Bottom line: Talk to your psychiatrist

Your Headspace Care coach is here to support you in achieving any goal you set your mind to. But, it's important to note that your coach isn't able to offer any guidance or advice around medication. Your psychiatrist can answer questions you have about medications for depression.
Getting meds through Headspace Care

Headspace Care offers members in certain markets a fast, seamless way to get their mental health medication delivered to their front doorstep through the mail-order pharmacy service Capsule. Headspace Care can also work with your current pharmacy, if preferred. Appointments with a Headspace Care psychiatrist are typically available within days. After completing an initial evaluation, a Headspace Care psychiatrist will use an evidence-based approach and judiciously prescribe an appropriate medication if indicated and desired by the member.
If you're curious to learn more, here are a few helpful resources:
National Institute of Mental Health: [www.nimh.nih.gov](https://www.nimh.nih.gov/)
MedlinePlus: [www.medlineplus.gov](https://www.medlineplus.gov)
Mayo Clinic: [www.mayoclinic.org](https://www.mayoclinic.org)
Identifying Emotions

Emotions—even difficult emotions—are an important part of life. Even if you try, it’s hard to avoid them. While you can’t stop emotions from occurring, you can learn to manage them when they feel overwhelming. The first step to managing them, of course, is identifying what they are and what triggers them.
In this activity, you’ll:

items: Learn more about emotions and how to identify them.
Learn how to manage your emotions effectively.
Reflect on how managing emotions could be helpful to you.

components.text: The Function of Emotions
Researchers argue that almost all emotional feelings stem from one of six basic, universal emotions: anger, disgust, fear, surprise, sadness, and happiness.
For example, annoyance, resentment, and grouchiness are all aspects of anger. Pity, defeat, and hurt, stem from sadness. Satisfaction, excitement, and contentment are variations of happiness.

But how and why do our emotions happen? One theory suggests that emotions are our response to physiological sensations. So, when you feel your heart rate speed up, you feel scared as a result of that sensation. Other theories suggest the opposite. We physically react to our emotions. We're fearful, so our heart rate goes up. No matter which theory is true, psychologists agree that emotions are essential
Emotions serve many purposes—they allow us to connect with others, help us make decisions, and motivate our behavior.

Emotions also help us understand what’s going on around us. For example, the nervousness you feel while walking down a dark street at night keeps you alert to your surroundings, which helps keep you safe. But feeling nervous doesn’t always mean you’re potentially in physical danger, such as when you feel nervous before a presentation. Learning what your feelings mean and what purpose they serve is part of identifying them.
Identifying Emotions
Identifying your emotions helps you manage them.
You can learn how to handle situations and relationships if you pay attention to your emotions as they're happening. Identifying your emotions is a skill that takes practice.

Psychologists call that skill Emotional Intelligence (EI). EI is the ability to correctly identify, perceive, and control emotions. It also is considered to be a predictor of success in work and relationships.
Here's how to practice and build your Emotional Intelligence:
1. Be mindful and nonjudgmental of your primary emotion.

Sometimes you might have secondary feelings about your primary emotion. You might feel shame about feeling depressed, or anger over feeling hurt. Allow yourself to feel whatever your primary emotion is without judgment.
2. Think of the trigger.

What event or situation prompted your emotion? When did it start? First, think of it like a detective. Look at the facts without interpreting them. Then think about what interpretations you originally made that could have caused your emotion.
3. What does your emotion make you want to do?
Does it make you want to be completely alone? Act out? Eat? Yell? Drink? Retaliate?.
4. Pay attention to your physical sensations.
Are you choked up? Is your heart rate elevated? Noticing your physical symptoms will help you learn about how they connect to your emotions.
Here are a few common physical feelings that tend to be associated with the six universal emotions:
Surprise:
Increased activity in your chest and throat. Decreased activity, or a heavy feeling, in your legs.
Sadness:
Heavy feeling, or decreased activity in arms and legs and an increased, or stressed feeling in your neck, chest, and stomach.
Fear:
Increased activity in your upper body, including your stomach.
Happiness:
Warm activity through your entire body.
Disgust:
Disgust, like fear, lives in your upper body.
Anger:
Increased activity if your upper body, focused in your heart.
These physical sensations can help you identify how you’re feeling emotionally.
Managing Emotions
Managing Emotions

Managing your emotions means keeping yourself in your optimal range of emotions so that you’re able to function and thrive. Identifying your emotions is the first step in managing them, but once you’ve got that part down, how do you stay within your optimal range? This activity can help.
Here you’ll:

items: Learn to Identify different triggers that can affect your emotions
Learn strategies to manage your emotions
Have an opportunity to practice the strategies

components.text: Managing emotions can seem like a vague concept. Waiting for emotions to pass, surviving them, or refusing to feel them at all are misconceptions of what it means to manage emotions.
Managing emotions is keeping yourself in your optimal emotional range so that you can still be able to fully function and thrive. Here are a few strategies that can help.
Self-Care

Self-care activities, such as taking care of your physical health, including balanced eating and exercising, avoiding unsafe substance use, and sleeping well are all useful ways to manage your emotions. Having a good routine of self-care will help you keep your emotions in the range that works best for your life. When you’re tired, hungry, run down, or generally unwell, your emotions can slip into a range that prevents you from fully functioning.
Have you noticed that your emotions are affected if you're tired, hungry, run down, or not feeling well?
Acknowledge
It's helpful to acknowledge that a lot of our emotions are simply reactions to our physical state, and that they will change as our physical state changes.

If you know that you tend to become more sensitive when you haven't been sleeping well, you may start seeing a pattern. More sensitive = not great sleep. Less sensitive = better sleep. So, if you find yourself feeling more sensitive and you’re not getting enough good sleep, there’s a good chance that when you get the sleep you need, you’ll likely feel better. Of course prioritizing self-care all the time is the best way to keep your emotions in a constant manageable range.
Identify and Limit Triggers

Limit events that set off unhealthy emotions. If there are events that trigger unhealthy emotions, such as seeing a particular friend, visiting a specific place, or interacting with someone at work, try to limit those events. While it may be impossible to completely eliminate these events, you can try to set boundaries.
Can you think of an event that triggers an unhealthy emotion?  If so, what is it? How can you reduce your exposure to the event in the future?
Acknowledging the triggers and planning to limit them is a helpful way to manage your emotions.
Mindfulness and Acceptance of Emotions
One last strategy:
As you go through your day, pay attention to how you’re feeling. Being aware of your emotions can help you take action (or refrain from actions) to help you stay in your ideal emotional zone.

For example, if you know how you’re feeling before you get really upset, you could seek out a friend, leave a situation, or do something you enjoy to prevent you from getting too upset. Noticing how you feel takes a lot of practice. It’s something you can work on throughout life!

Sometimes your emotions can feel so extreme that it feels impossible to manage them. In this case, it’s better to accept them. This concept -- radical acceptance-- stems from Buddhist teachings that say that suffering comes from struggling against your pain. The struggle is more painful than the pain itself. When you practice radical acceptance, you allow yourself to fully feel your emotions. It’s about accepting the moment rather than working on feeling better or telling yourself you shouldn’t feel that way. Accepting your pain can help you avoid suffering and can actually make you feel more optimistic about moving on.
Taking the Opposite Action
Here's what you can expect to take away from today's activity:

items: Learn how to identify your negative emotions.
Learn how to counter your emotions with an action plan.

components.text: Opposite Action is a technique to use when you're experiencing strong negative emotions. It works by doing exactly the opposite of whatever your emotion wants you to do.
Here's how it works:

items: Choose which negative emotions you're feeling most strongly.
Identify what the opposite actions are for those emotions.
Check in with your coach about it after.

components.text: You can do this anytime on your own, or if your emotions are high and your thoughts are racing, you can always do it here in this exercise or with your coach
Choose one emotion you’re experiencing right now:
Even if you’re experiencing several emotions, just choose one to start.
Stress
Instead of trying to block out or distract yourself from stressful thoughts, take some steps toward overcoming what you feel stressed about.
For example, if you feel stressed about starting dating after divorce, then take a step in this direction. Talk to friends who have been through this process about what their experiences were like.

It often helps overcome avoidance patterns if you do the thing you’re afraid of repeatedly. After doing something repeatedly, you might still feel some stress about it but it won’t be so strong you need to avoid that thing in the future.

items.body: Approach, don't avoid. Whatever you're stressed about, embrace it.

components.text: Anger
Try expressing sympathy or empathy

The goal of this isn’t to benefit the other person. The idea is actually that you’ll feel better. Often you’ll also improve the situation compared with what the consequences would’ve been if you’d reacted to feeling angry by attacking, defending, or withdrawing.
This might feel like faking it 'til you make it. And that's sort of how this works. The behavior comes first, and the positive emotions follow.

items.body: Express sympathy or empathy for someone else. Or, gently avoid instead of attacking.

components.text: Sadness
When you feel sad, you probably notice yourself withdrawing, slowing down, and retreating into yourself.
In certain ways, this is helpful. Time and space to think can help you manage your reactions to difficult situations.

But sometimes an opposite action can help lift your sadness, especially when thinking and withdrawing only makes your sadness feel more intense. An opposite action for sadness is doing something caring and generous for others.
Helping another person leaves you feeling confident, competent and productive. It helps you re-engage with people, and takes you away from your own negative thoughts.

items.body: Do something kind or generous for someone else.

components.text: Depression
When you feel depressed, you probably notice yourself withdrawing, slowing down, and retreating into yourself.
In certain ways, this is helpful. Time and space to think can help you manage your reactions to difficult situations.

But sometimes an opposite action can help lift your sadness, especially when thinking and withdrawing only make your sadness feel more intense. An opposite action for depression is doing something caring and generous for others.
Helping another person leaves you feeling confident, competent and productive. It helps you re-engage with people, and takes you away from your own negative thoughts.

items.body: Do something kind or generous for someone else.

components.text: Inadequacy

Feeling inadequate can come with deeply ingrained beliefs that you hold about yourself. Emotionally, inadequacy can feel like sadness or a fear of failure. It may also come along with thoughts that others are better than you.

The opposite action in this situation is to practice self-compassion and self-love. That means reminding yourself of your achievements and skills, your strengths and your positive characteristics. Think about what a parent, partner, sibling, or friend might tell you if they were there with you. Then tell it to yourself.
Act confident. Choose to focus on your strengths and abilities. If you can show confidence to others, you may just begin to feel it inside yourself.

items.body: Give yourself compassion, just like a loved one would. Project confidence.

components.text: Disappointment
Disappointment is all about expectations. When you feel disappointed, it's because your expectations of yourself or others were not met.

That means the opposite action here is all about understanding your expectations. Take a moment to consider what you're expecting of yourself or other people. Readjust your expectations to be more in line with what you and others can provide.

items.body: Adjust your expectations.

components.text: Fear of Failure

Fear of failure may be related to a fear of being exposed as inadequate. You might feel like you're really incompetent in some way, and you may worry that others will figure you out. This is sometimes referred to as Impostor Syndrome–the fear of not really living up to what others expect of you.

The problem with fear of failure is that it can get in the way of your performance at work, in school, and in your relationships. So the key to opposite action here is to remind yourself that perfection is not the goal. The goal is to willingly engage with whatever tasks you have to accomplish. That's all.
Remind yourself that you're capable of accomplishing these tasks and handling your fear at the same time.

items.body: Don't let fear stop you from performing. Be afraid, and keep going anyway.

components.text: Fear of Rejection

Fear of rejection often comes at a cost to your personal relationships. They might be less close, less meaningful, and ultimately less fulfilling for you. Sometimes fear of rejection doesn't even look like fear in your head. Sometimes it looks like you telling yourself that you have better things to do than meet new people at a party, for example.

Opposite action here means taking on the temporary fear of rejection in pursuit of a greater pay-off: better relationships and closer connections. Try asking yourself: are you willing to tolerate temporary fear if it means there's a lasting pay-off in the end?

items.body: Permit yourself to feel a fear of failure. Embrace it. Take a risk.

components.text: Lethargy

Try making a list of things that you can do. Ideally, these should be things that can be realistically attained in the short-term. For example, despite a feeling of lethargy, you are capable of doing small things like washing the dishes, doing laundry, or tidying up. These are all behaviors that directly go against the feeling of lethargy, which can create an opposite emotional experience. Effective opposite action requires willingness to throw yourself into the task at hand, even if you don’t feel like it. The idea is to focus on how you will feel as a result of acting opposite to the current emotional experience.

items.body: Make a list of things you can do.

components.text: If you really step back to think about it, is your guilt justified? Think about what a loved one might tell you about this situation. Be honest with yourself:
Justified Guilt

You did something that you believe justifies the guilt you're feeling. That's okay. We all do things that go against our better judgment. The key now is not to avoid your feelings of guilt, but rather to do something to make amends.

If another person was injured by what happened, apologize. This isn't just because apologizing is the nice thing to do. It's because apologizing allows you to take responsibility for your guilt, and puts your transgression out in the open. Truth and acceptance are powerful opposite actions to guilt and shame.

If you can't make things better with others involved, practice acceptance and forgiveness with yourself.  Imagine how a loved one might talk to you about the situation. Consider what your motivations were at the time of whatever happened. It's likely that, deep down, you honestly believed it would make the situation better for yourself. Often times when we do something to hurt others, it's actually motivated by self-love and self-protection. Even if it wasn't the right thing to do, it didn't come from a bad place. Accept yourself for your mistakes, and then give yourself permission to let go of them.

items.body: Accept your actions and ask for forgiveness.

components.text: Unjustified Guilt
Avoidance is the most common response to guilt, shame, or embarrassment. It's understandable, but it doesn't really help.

Instead of avoiding what you feel guilty about, try approaching instead. That doesn't necessarily mean you have to go do the thing that makes you feel guilty over and over and over again. You might start by talking to loved ones about it. Think of people who have had similar experiences, or those who won't be judgmental of your experience.
The goal isn't necessarily to get advice, but rather to receive support and non-judgment from someone else, and to show yourself that you can face the thing that's making you feel guilty.
That said, if doing the thing that makes you feel guilty over and over and over again sounds like something you can do, it may be a good option.

items.body: Approach, don't avoid.

components.text: Justified Shame

You did something that you believe justifies the shame you're feeling. That's okay. We all do things that go against our better judgment. The key now is not to avoid your feelings of guilt, but rather to do something to make amends.

If another person was injured by what happened, apologize. This isn't just because apologizing is the nice thing to do. It's because apologizing allows you to take responsibility for your guilt, and puts your transgression out in the open. Truth and acceptance are powerful opposite actions to guilt and shame.

If you can't make things better with others involved, practice acceptance and forgiveness with yourself. Imagine how a loved one might talk to you about the situation. Consider what your motivations were at the time of whatever happened. It's likely that, deep down, you honestly believed it would make the situation better for yourself. Often times when we do something to hurt others, it's actually motivated by self-love and self-protection. Even if it wasn't the right thing to do, it didn't come from a bad place. Accept yourself for your mistakes, and then give yourself permission to let go of them.

items.body: Accept your actions and ask for forgiveness.

Instead of avoiding what you feel ashamed about, try approaching instead. That doesn't necessarily mean you have to go do the thing that makes you feel guilty over and over and over again. You did something that you believe justifies the embarrassment you're feeling. That's okay. We all do things that go against our better judgment. The key now is not to avoid your feelings of guilt, but rather to do something to make amends.

Often times when we do something to hurt others, it's actually motivated by self-love and self-protection. Even if it wasn't the right thing to do, it didn't come from a bad place. Accept yourself for your mistakes, and then give yourself permission to let go of them.

components.text: Practicing Acceptance
Here's what you can expect to take away from today's activity:

items: Learn a technique that will help you be more mindful of your emotions.
Practice ways to accept emotions and handle them in a productive manner.

components.text: This technique may be helpful during times when:

items: You need some help focusing.
You've been struggling with a difficult emotion, like anger, shame, or guilt.
You're having trouble letting go of this emotion or it's causing you stress.

components.text: As this practice involves being open to and accepting of your emotions, it's best if you try this technique in a comfortable setting where you can feel safe expressing your emotions.
Your current skill level
How confident do you feel in your ability to practice acceptance? 0=Not at all confident, 10= Completely confident
Grab your headphones and let's get to it.
Your current skill level
How confident do you feel in your ability to practice acceptance? 0=Not at all confident, 10= Completely confident

increased.title: Your confidence in this skill increased.
increased.body: Continue to practice this skill and use it when it will be helpful to you.

same.title: Your confidence in this skill stayed the same.
same.body: This activity doesn’t seem to have affected your confidence level in using this skill. You can try this activity again and see if it works better for you with practice.

decreased.title: Your confidence in this skill went down.

components.text: Tracking Emotions
Keeping track of your emotions and their triggers can help you anticipate and prepare for them when they arise in the future.
Identifying Emotions

Before you identify your emotions here, remember to be mindful and nonjudgmental about how you're feeling. Try to identify your primary emotion, and not your secondary emotion (e.g. your primary emotion might be that you’re depressed, and your secondary emotions might be that you’re angry, hurt or ashamed of being depressed).
What are you feeling right now? Choose your strongest emotion.
Keeping this emotion in mind, consider each question:

items: What prompted you to feel your current emotion?
Think of the trigger. What event or situation prompted your emotion? When did it start?
Do you physically feel the emotion anywhere in your body? If yes, where?
Think about whether you feel the emotion in your face, your muscles, your heart, etc.
What action does your emotion make you want to do? Does it make you want to be completely alone? Act out? Eat? Yell? Drink? Retaliate? Laugh?

components.text: All done.
Identifying your emotions can be challenging, but you just did it. Nice job.
Coping with Difficult Emotions

Difficult emotions are part of everyone’s life at some point. Whether it’s grief, anger, shock, to name a few, difficult emotions let us know that something is wrong and could use our attention. Sometimes difficult emotions can feel overwhelming. When this happens, there are strategies to help you cope. This activity will teach you some of these strategies.
Building Your Mental Toolbox

When difficult emotions arise, you can use tools to help you cope in the moment. Rather than suppressing difficult emotions, using strategies to get through the emotion when it feels extreme or overwhelming can help.
Everyone deals with their difficult emotions differently, so it’s important to learn and use the strategies that work best for you. Over time you’ll build your own personal mental toolbox.
Distraction

Have you ever felt overcome by a difficult emotion? It can feel like there’s no way to separate yourself from your anger or your grief. What do you do in that moment? When you realize the emotion has become too big to manage, there are strategies to cope.
One strategy is to use distraction.
Distraction does not mean you’re avoiding your emotion. Rather, it allows you to get distance from your emotions in the moment.
Grounding and mindfulness techniques can be helpful here. For example, a grounding technique can be to focus your attention on an object, which can distract you from those overwhelming emotions.

The best way to distract yourself is to do something unrelated to your emotion, something that can occupy your short-term memory, such as getting a cup of coffee, or seeing a movie. Or, try distracting yourself by doing something nice for someone else. It can help you feel better and take your mind off yourself.
The next time you’re having a strong, difficult emotion, such as anger or grief, what distracting activity can you plan to do?
E.g.: Watching reruns of my favorite TV show.
How likely are you to try the distracting activity the next time you feel overwhelmed by a negative emotion?
Make a plan you can believe in.

You said you're not likely to try the distraction activity you came up with. It could be that the activity you came up with might not be distracting enough. If you don’t believe that it’ll work to distract you the next time you have a difficult emotion, then you’re unlikely to try it.

Can you think of another activity that’s more likely to distract you? Often a social activity works well to get you out of your head. But, if you don’t think anything will be able to distract you, we’ve got a few other ideas.
The next time you have a difficult emotion, try “radical acceptance,” which is fully accepting that you are experiencing pain.

It’s about allowing yourself to experience the feelings without judgement or struggle. Then you can begin to find ways to feel better. Accepting your pain can also help you feel more optimistic about moving on from the pain.
Consider writing a new distraction activity that you think is more likely to work.  E.g.: See a movie with a friend.

It's great to have a distraction plan that you believe will work. It might even take a few different distracting activities for you to be able to get a handle on your emotions. One thing to keep in mind, though, is that you don’t want your distracting activities to disrupt your day more than your difficult emotion would.

Sometimes, however, you might feel the difficult emotion so strongly that it’s impossible to distract yourself from it. In this case, try radical acceptance. This is when you accept the pain of the emotion without judgement or struggle, rather than try to minimize it or reduce it. Once you accept it, you can start to focus on feeling better.
Self-Soothing
When you’re experiencing a difficult emotion, using your five senses can help provide comfort.

Here are a few healthy self-soothing activities to engage each of your five senses. (Of course we recommend staying away from activities that can lead to unhealthy behaviors.) Give one a try or come up with your own!
Hearing
Listen to a favorite album or station.
Close your eyes and see if you can name each noise you hear.
Call a friend or family member.
Play a musical instrument.
Touch
Make a warm drink and notice the warmth as you hold it and drink it.
Get or give a massage.
Wrap yourself in your softest blanket.
Take a hot or cold shower or bath.
Taste
Add a favorite flavor to your water (try lemon, lime or mint).
Eat a few bites of your favorite treat.
Notice the taste of each ingredient in your next snack or meal.
Smell
Stop and smell some nature outside. (Bring the object to your nose.)
Put on a favorite scented lotion.
Light a scented candle.
Boil some citrus rinds or cinnamon.
Sight
View your favorite artist's work online.
Watch a dance performance.
Lie down outside and watch the clouds or stars.
Watch some baby animal videos.
Improving the Moment

Sometimes coping with a difficult emotion can be done by countering it with something positive, like imagining a pleasant image, focusing on relaxation, or encouraging yourself with a positive message. Give it a try. Close your eyes and imagine you are somewhere more pleasant. Or, try a relaxation technique, or a positive message to yourself.
Adding to your toolbox

Difficult emotions are part of everyone’s life at some point. Difficult emotions let us know that something is wrong and could use our attention. You just added a few new tools to your mental toolbox. Next time a difficult emotion arises, which of the techniques will you try?
Have Some Fun
Having fun is not only nice, it’s also necessary for your well-being. There are incredible mental health benefits to having fun!
Here you’ll:

items: Learn all about the benefits of having fun.
Get help coming up with activities you enjoy.
Learn why you should make time for fun!

components.text: The Benefits of Cultivating Positive Experiences
Fun, engaging activities help you feel less stressed and boost your energy. They also generate lots of positive emotions like amusement, happiness, and joy.
Experts suggest that positive emotions actually broaden our attention, expand cognition, and encourage new, creative, and flexible ways of thinking and doing.
What that means is that over time, we develop new physical, psychological, and social resources that give us new ways to handle stressful situations.

In a sense, making time for positive emotions is similar to saving money. That extra reserve gives you the freedom to consider a wider range of possibilities and breathe a little easier when plans change unexpectedly. It gives you resilience.

Adding fun and positive emotions to your life makes you less vulnerable to your triggers and better able to cope with difficult emotions. Having fun isn’t going to fix everything. But it’s an often-overlooked tool that you can use to take care of yourself and improve your overall emotional self.
Enhancing Positive Experiences

One great way to outweigh difficult emotions is to increase the number of positive experiences in your life. Scheduling pleasant activities into your day can help your emotions stay in an ideal range. This technique will help you do just that.
Here's how it works:

On the next page, choose the activities you find the most enjoyable.  Remember to engage in some of these activities over the next 24 hours.  Just take some time to reflect on what you enjoy doing most.
Increase positive emotional experiences
Below, we've listed more than 30 pleasant activities. Pick a few that you hadn't planned on doing and do them in the next 24 hours.
Pick a few fun activities to do.

options.name: Start a collection (shells or coins etc.)

components.text: Sounds fun!
YOUR ACTIVITY/ACTIVITIES

Go to a movie
Listen to a full album
Soak in a bathtub

Repair something

Set up a reminder to make sure you remember to do your chosen activity/activities in the next 24 hours. Have fun!
The Flip Side

It’s enticing to scroll through news and social feeds for updates on the latest disaster, disagreement, or drama. While we can’t deny what’s happening around us, we can do something about how it makes us feel. In this video workshop you’ll learn about the benefits of gratitude and new strategies for incorporating positivity into daily life.
Dealing With Mother’s & Father’s Day
For many people, Mother’s Day and/or Father’s Day are some of the most challenging days of the year. If you struggle to cope when these days come around each year, you are not alone.
This activity will:

items: Help you understand the origin of these holidays.
Discuss the many reasons why these days are a challenge for many.
Help you create an action plan to cope as these holidays approach.

components.text: What is the origin of Mother’s Day and Father’s Day?

Did you know that Anna Jarvis, the woman credited with founding Mother’s Day, regretted doing so and even campaigned to have the designation rescinded? She had envisioned the day as being one to honor one’s mother and the care they gave their children. That is, a quiet honoring at home. She was appalled by the commercialization of the holiday that ensued including flowers, candy, cards, jewelry, etc. Father’s Day was designated afterwards to complement Mother’s Day. Today, Mother’s and Father’s Day are often accompanied by a barrage of advertisements and social media posts by companies, celebrities, and our own family and friends.
Why are these days challenging?

Mother’s Day and Father’s Day can be very challenging days because for many they represent loss. For others, they may feel they are bombarded with images of families who do not look like their families.

items: Those who are grieving the loss of their mother or father
Mothers and fathers who are grieving the loss of a child
Those who are struggling with infant loss, miscarriage, or infertility and long to be a parent
Those who have a strained relationship with their parent or with their child
Those who have chosen not to be a parent
Those many diverse families who are not made up of one mother and/or father

components.text: Whatever the reason or reasons, if these days are challenging for you, be sure to make a coping plan.
Disconnect from social media

items: These days (and even the days surrounding them) are often full of emotional triggers.

components.text: Decide how you want to spend the day.

items: Engage in coping and self-care strategies such as getting outside, exercising, or engaging in a hobby.

components.text: Practice self-validation

items: Remind yourself that whatever you are feeling is valid and true. Your feelings make sense based on your experiences, even if others don’t understand.

components.text: Consider whether you’d like to share your feelings with others.

items: You may want to talk with trusted others about how these holidays are not joyful for everyone so that they can better understand what you’re going through.

components.text: Reflect on whether there are any sentiments you would like to celebrate.

items: Remember, these holidays are fabricated days. You can celebrate whatever sentiments you want on whatever day you choose.

components.text: Remember, if Mother’s Day and/or Father’s Day are difficult days for you, you are not alone in feeling this way. There are many reasons why people find these holidays challenging, and the founder of mother’s day herself regretted what the day has become. If you are still struggling to cope, reach out to your coach to discuss and brainstorm additional strategies to help.
Understanding Languishing

Languishing falls somewhere between joy and depression. It can be described as feeling aimless or lacking in purpose, or not being able to focus or function at full capacity. For many people during the pandemic, languishing has been the dominant state. It can be a challenge for people who feel like they’re languishing to start feeling joy again, but there are strategies that can help.
This activity card can help you:

items: Understand the current state of emotion you may be in, known as languishing
Gain actionable steps for overcoming languishing

components.text: What is Languishing?

The state of languishing is not quite happy and not quite depressed. Some describe it as not having a clear sense of purpose, or even a clear sense of what exactly they’re feeling. Some simply describe it as feeling “meh.” If you’re languishing, you may want to get out of this state, but aren’t sure how.
We’ve got some tips to help you move forward. Choose one that you’d like to work on and at the end, we’ll share strategies for you to practice this week.

options.name: Adjust the way you speak to yourself

components.text: Acknowledge and share your story.

Take the time to truly reflect on your feelings about your circumstances and name your emotions. Then, tell your story, whether it’s through journaling, talking to a friend, making a video, or through forms of art. Be honest with others in sharing how you truly feel and what you’re going through—your struggles, how you’ve coped, how you have grown, or how you’re working to heal yourself.

Acknowledgement and storytelling can help you let go of shame and can allow you to remove the story in your mind and bring it to reality. Acknowledgement helps you feel more in control; it gives you ownership of your life, helps you truly understand the reason behind your feelings, and most importantly, allows you to create a plan of action to move yourself out of your current state. Storytelling makes connections between people and can create a path to healing. It can remind you that you aren’t alone in the way you feel, and it brings out compassion in others and helps us be more compassionate with ourselves.
Let’s try it out
This week, set a goal for yourself. Choose one of the following to tell the story behind your feeling of languishing:

items: Journal
Talk to a friend
Make a video
Another form of art

components.text: Consider adding some time on your calendar this week to follow through with the goal that you selected.

Bonus! Now that you’ve chosen one to work on this week, check out how artists, athletes, musicians, and leaders are sharing their stories about mental health at [Headspace Care Chats.](https://www.ginger.com/chats)
Rewire your thoughts

Our brains are neuroplastic, which means our brains can change through growth and reorganization. Your brain is constantly changing based on your thoughts. Although you have been stuck in a phase of languishing, you can rewire your brain to move past this. Your mindset determines how you respond to challenges as they arise each day, and in the long run, how you work on overcoming symptoms of anxiety and depression. One way you can shape your mindset each day is through a routine called priming your day. You can do this first thing in the morning for about five to ten minutes. Here’s how it works:

items: Set an intention for the day. This is like setting a goal for yourself on the values you want to embody and what you want to aspire to throughout the day. For example, “I will be compassionate and patient today.”

State three things you’re grateful for. These don’t have to be big things. They can be as simple as having good coffee to drink in the morning, waking up in a comfortable home, or being able to breathe. Gratitude forces you to focus intentionally on the good and what you have, rather than the areas that are lacking or that you’re unhappy with in your life.

Recite positive affirmations. With both hands on your heart, breathe in “I am” statements that empower you, such as “I am loved,” “I am grateful,” “I am whole.” This form of meditation helps you think of yourself with more compassion and self-love, which can help reduce symptoms of anxiety.

components.text: Let’s try it out
Give priming a try now (even if it’s not morning). As you complete each step, go ahead and check it off your list.

options.name: 1. What’s your intention for the rest of the day?
2. What three things are you grateful for?

components.text: You’ve just practiced priming! If you found it helpful or inspiring, give it another try tomorrow morning. Try setting aside some time on your calendar as a reminder.
Adjust the way you speak to yourself.
Part of strengthening your mindset is changing the way you communicate with yourself.

It’s common to lean toward a negative bias. By intentionally and mindfully choosing your thoughts and the way you talk to and about yourself, you can build resilience. For example, rather than saying, “I don’t have any motivation to complete my project; I haven’t put in effort, this is useless,” try to show yourself compassion and discover why you haven’t been able to accomplish the project. You might instead say, “This project has taken me longer than usual to complete because I’ve been focused on caring for a family member who needed me. I will adjust my deadline and write out my next steps to complete it.” This shifts your thoughts from shame and blame to one of empathy. It better enables you to move forward.
Let’s try it out
Give it a try. Is there something you’ve been blaming yourself for? Let’s take just a few minutes to identify just one thing that you may be blaming yourself for.

Once you’ve identified this, try to think of a way to reframe the blame and show yourself more compassion. You can write this down on a post-it note or on your phone as a reminder throughout the week as a helpful reminder for when you find yourself starting to take the blame. If you need help reframing the blame, you can also reach out to your coach for guidance.
Reframe Your Thoughts

Another way to get out of the cycle of negative thinking that’s linked to languishing is with a thought-evaluation tool, which can help you change the way you view and react to your situation. When you find yourself having difficult thoughts about a situation, this tool can help you identify what your thought process is.

Here’s how it works: Take out a sheet of paper and draw a vertical line down the middle, making two columns. At the top left side, write “Shame, Blame, and Justification.” At the top right, write “Personal Responsibility.” Write down the things you’re blaming yourself for or trying to justify in the left column. Then, in the right column, write what you can do to take responsibility with compassion, or find a solution to the problem.

This tool is designed to help you shift from a primal brain to the conscious brain, acting as a guide for making informed decisions based on reasoning, rather than reactive, illogical, or irrational thought processes, which can make you feel like you're a victim of your circumstances.
Move your body.

Your body and mind are connected. Exercise and movement can help reduce stress and anxiety that may build up throughout your day. Choose activities that you enjoy, such as biking, walking, dancing, yoga, or weight-lifting. Consider the “Sandy Beach Towel” analogy when thinking about how exercise can help with stress and anxiety: at the end of the day, when you pick up your towel to leave the beach and shake out the sand, there’s still going to be sand stuck in your towel that you bring home. That’s the anxiety that sticks with you. You might have a lot of “sand” that comes home with you, or just a little. Use the “Sandy Beach Towel” analogy to gauge how much anxiety you have and how much movement your body needs to “shake out” your anxiety.
Let’s try it out

Try to take just five minutes right now to move your body. It doesn’t have to be anything difficult or tiring. Consider stretching in your seat or any type of movement to help you “shake out” the stress and anxiety. If now isn’t a good time, add some time on your calendar for this week  to remind yourself to take just 5 minutes to move your body.
Free Yourself from Languishing

Languishing can feel a lot like being stuck in thick mud. However, just like being stuck in the mud, with some effort and movement, there is a way out. Acknowledging your feelings and sharing your story can help you feel more in control, can help you cultivate compassion for yourself, and can create a path to healing. Reshaping your mindset and adjusting your communication can help you build resilience and be prepared to manage challenges as they arise. Finally, incorporating movement can help release stress build-up at the end of each day so you can free yourself from the thick mud of languishing.
Grieving Pregnancy Loss

If you’ve experienced a pregnancy or infant loss, you are not alone. It’s important to acknowledge that the loss can forever change you. It’s not an easy process, but grieving is necessary. Choosing to feel it now can help you avoid having the grief hit you unexpectedly later.
This activity card will:

items: Provide you with strategies to help you through the grieving process of a pregnancy or infant loss;
Offer tips to support a loved one who has experienced pregnancy or infant loss.

components.text: Here are some mental health tips to help you through the grieving process:
Let yourself grieve.
Cry and lean into the grief. Take your time while you heal. You’ll feel a mix of emotions. For me, they were shock, sadness, disbelief, anger.
Rest and practice self-care.

Your mind and body are working hard to process the loss. Give yourself time to rest and heal. Engage in nourishing self-care practices like taking warm baths, ordering your favorite takeout, or going for walks. After checking with your doctor about starting exercise, try this yoga class for after pregnancy loss. If possible, take time off of work, or alter your schedule.
Accept help.
If you have people who can help, allow them to care for you while you’re healing. Accept offers for meals and help around the house.
Seek out support from a therapist, coach, or counselor.

Depression, PTSD, anxiety and postpartum depression are all common after pregnancy loss. Your shifting hormones can affect your emotions, too. Check in with yourself and reach out to a professional for help.
Join a support group, share your story.

Talk about the loss with others. I know it’s hard, but talking about your loss lessens the stigma around pregnancy and infant loss for other women. It can give you hope to hear how others survived their losses. Listen or read others’ stories. Check out this article and this book. Join an online support group. Reach out to a pregnancy and infant loss toll free number.
Honor your baby's memory.

Doing so can help with the healing process. A few ideas: create a memory box with ultrasound photos, write a letter to your baby, save baby clothes you bought. Purchase a piece of jewelry or memento to remember your baby. Create a playlist to honor your baby. Name the baby if you’re comfortable with that.
Remember that everyone grieves differently.

There’s no right or wrong way to mourn your loss. Your partner might mourn differently than you, so do your best not to compare your grieving process to theirs. Take the time you need to grieve. And remember that healing is not a linear process. Many women who have gone on to have healthy children still mourn their loss or losses. Allow yourself the grace and compassion you deserve.
And, if there’s someone you know who’s gone through a loss…

Hold space and check in often. Tell them you’re sorry for their loss, that you’re there for them. Reach out regularly, check in close to the due date, and even one year later. Since grief can come in waves, it’s important not to let them feel isolated even after a long time has passed.
Remember everybody grieves differently. Honor your grief any way you see fit. Afterall, there’s only one you, and it’s your right to heal, find happiness, and have peace again
Managing Seasonal Affective Disorder

Seasonal Affective Disorder, or SAD, is a subcategory of depression that consists of depression-like symptoms, which tend to occur during certain seasons. SAD is most commonly prevalent in fall and winter, but SAD can occur in spring and summer, too. SAD is often marked by decreased mood, decreased energy, increased feelings of isolation or loneliness, disrupted sleep or eating, and a change in overall self-esteem.
This activity card will share a few tips that can help:

items: Identify potential sources of your SAD symptoms;
Help you feel better during the down months;
Improve daily routines to increase overall well-being.

components.text: What causes SAD?

SAD is thought to be caused by a combination of decreased light in the winter months and our body’s natural reduction in serotonin levels during colder times of the year. Even though we can’t control these elements that may cause SAD, we can do some things to help lessen the impact.
Strategies to help reduce the effects of SAD
Find ways to increase your serotonin levels.

items: Exercise. Doing aerobic exercises regularly has been shown to be an effective way to boost your serotonin. It can be hard to motivate yourself to exercise if you experience SAD, but once you get going, chances are you’ll be glad you did.

Sleep. It’s tempting to sleep more in the winter months due to the weather and our tendency to be less active in winter. Maintaining a healthy sleep schedule can boost your well-being. This includes pushing past the urge to take long naps during the day. Start by working on getting into a routine of falling asleep and waking up at similar times to give yourself the necessary amount of time to rest.

components.text: Try to access as much light as possible.

items: The further north a population lives (and thus, the fewer hours of daylight during winter it gets) the more that SAD tends to impact that population on average. Regardless of where you live, make sure you make the most of the daylight you have. Take walks during the sunny hours of the day even if it means waking up a bit earlier to catch those rays. Experts recommend at least 30 minutes of walking in the sun a day to help with SAD.

Since the winter months have less light, you might have to be proactive about making time to catch the sun. Check the weather ahead of time and schedule time to get outside when the sun is out. Find ways that your normal indoor activities can be adapted to allow you time outside. Exercising outside is helpful for mood generally, and other activities like reading, meal prepping, working, and even watching Netflix can be done outside with a few adjustments. Sit outside for your next Headspace Care coaching session!

components.text: Spend time reflecting on the current season and the season ahead.

items: If you experience SAD in winter, reflect on some things that you like about winter. It can be useful to plan certain activities that you only do during this season. Perhaps it is snow-related activities like building a snowman or going skiing, or maybe it is the feeling of curling up under a warm blanket. When we have a list of winter activities we like, we’re better able to recognize the good things about winter, and it gives us something to look forward to.
Sometimes the dead of winter feels never-ending, but we know it eventually ends and the beauty of spring follows. Look forward and think about the things you are excited about in the coming season.

components.text: If you find that these strategies aren’t effective in minimizing SAD, talk to your doctor about other strategies or possible medication options. Reach out to your coach who can help you tailor a sleep routine that fits with your life.
Headspace Care Overview for Teens

Welcome to Headspace Care! Here you’ll find an overview of what you can expect with Headspace Care. We recognize it’s important that you have autonomy when it comes to your care. We also know that parents and guardians play a crucial role in your overall well-being. So, we want to make sure you know what information will be kept private and what will be shared as you work with Headspace Care.
This card will explain:

items: What you can expect from your care with Headspace Care;
What types of challenges Headspace Care can and can’t help you with;
How your parent or guardian will be involved;
What information will and won’t be shared.

components.text: Who will I work with for my care?

You’ll start out working with a coach who will provide you with care via text-based chat. If you need extra support, a coach may recommend adding a therapist to your care team. Generally, your coach and/or therapist will be able to provide the support that you need. If you could use additional support within the Headspace Care platform, your therapist will explore the possibility of making a referral to a Headspace Care psychiatrist. Clinicians (in other words, therapists and psychiatrists) provide care through scheduled video sessions. Coaches, therapists, and psychiatrists make up your care team and work together to provide seamless care so you can pick up right where you left off no matter who you were last working with.
What kinds of things can Headspace Care help me with?
Your Headspace Care care team can support you with a variety of challenges, like:

items: Managing anxiety
Relationships with peers
Stress about getting into college
Academic issues like time management and building effective study skills
Managing diagnoses like depression and anxiety

components.text: What kinds of things can Headspace Care NOT help me with?
Headspace Care is unable to provide care if you require:

items: Close medical monitoring
In-person services
Specialized care for eating disorders
Care for substance use disorders

components.text: We are unable to provide care to teens who are actively suicidal or homicidal.

We will do our best to get you connected to services that can help. If you are experiencing one of the above issues, please talk with your coach or clinician. We might refer you to an outside therapist or psychiatrist in specific situations.
In addition, we are unable to prescribe stimulant medication, which is often used in the treatment of ADHD. We are, however, able to provide therapy and coaching for ADHD.
How much involvement will my parent or guardian have in my care?

First, your Headspace Care care team is here to care for YOU. We encourage you to take ownership of your care while also partnering with your parents or guardians, who can provide a crucial level of support when you are dealing with mental health concerns.
Here’s how your parent/guardian may be involved in your care:

items: When you begin care at Headspace Care, we’ll ask your parent or guardian to complete a survey to get their perspective of how you are doing and what’s happening at home.
Your coach will communicate with you to determine how parents or guardians can support you.

If you need extra support, your coach may recommend working with a clinician, who you would meet with over video. In this case, your parent or guardian would be invited to join the first video appointment, and on an as-needed basis.

components.text: How will my parent or guardian know how I’m doing?

Ideally, you'll be able to talk directly with your parent or guardian to share how you're feeling and if you're reaching your goals, but we know that’s not always easy. We won't share the content of your Headspace Care conversations with your parent or guardian, but they will be able to see in the app which services you've used (i.e., coaching, therapy, and/or psychiatry) and when you've used them. There are some cases in which we will need to share information with parents, guardians, and local law enforcement. Please see the following FAQ about those situations.
What else should I know?

Your treatment records, including clinical notes and coaching transcripts, will be handled in full compliance with the law in the state in which you reside. We’ll send you and your parent or guardian a document that outlines the law in your state, and informs you of your rights when it comes to making treatment decisions and accessing records.

Regardless of state law, it is Headspace Care policy that our care team will share the following information with parents, guardians, and local law enforcement where applicable to help to ensure your safety.
Guardians will be notified by your Headspace Care care team when assessment determines that you are:

items: Engaging in self-harm (e.g., cutting, burning, or hitting) that are of concern
Experiencing active suicidal ideation (e.g., thoughts of killing yourself, accompanied by a plan or intent)
Experiencing active homicidal ideation or intent to inflict serious bodily harm on others (e.g., thoughts of harming others, accompanied by a plan or intent)
Exhibiting signs of grave disability, such as psychosis or mania
Engaging in substance use that is of concern
Engaging in eating disorders that are of concern

components.text: Law enforcement and/or state specific agencies will be required to be notified when:

items: Child abuse is reported including physical, sexual, emotional and/or neglect

Sexual activity or sexual assault when certain situations and age relationships between the partners occur. Reporting to law enforcement and/or state agencies is dependent on member’s age and state laws.
It is determined that you are in imminent risk of harm to self or others

components.text: What if I am in crisis?

If you are in immediate need of assistance and feel you may harm yourself or others, please call 911 or the Suicide & Crisis Lifeline or visit the Teen Hotline: [https://teenlineonline.org/talk-now/](https://teenlineonline.org/talk-now/) for immediate assistance and inform your parent or guardian.
For more non-urgent situations, we encourage you to reach out to your care team to determine the most appropriate next steps. Just tap the Chat tab in the app to text with your coach.
Coaches are available anytime you need immediate support. We look forward to working with you and helping you with whatever you may be going through.
