properties.name: Grieve Your Way To Feeling Better

components.text: Grieve Your Way To Feeling Better

Grief is a normal, natural, and healthy response to different types of loss. Commonly we think of grieving over the loss of a loved one, but we can also grieve over the loss of habit, such as smoking. Grieving is a process of fully experiencing your emotions without judgement. It can get ugly, but that's OK.
This activity will:

items: Give you an idea of what to expect as you grieve.
Teach you how grieving can help you feel better.

components.text: Ride the rollercoaster
Grief has a mind of its own. You never quite know what emotions are going to show up. This can be incredibly intimidating and uncomfortable.

Staying in check with yourself and your emotions during this process helps you move through the anguish and agony, and helps you arrive at acceptance and peace. Remember, grief isn't all sadness either. There are often times of happiness and laughter during the process too.
Stay with it
There is no right way to grieve. Everybody responds to loss differently. The impact of the loss can vary greatly. The point is to make a conscious effort to feel it out.
First, check in with your body.

Jot down how you've been feeling since the loss. Are you tense or tight in any specific areas of your body? Where? Are you full of anger or rage? If so, what are you angry about? Do you just want to escape the world and hide out? How does that serve you? Are you always on the verge of tears? Jot it all down.
The more expressive you can be, the more clarity you'll have on what your emotions are and how to get through them.
Do something about it

If you're feeling tense in your body, ask yourself what your body needs and then give it to yourself, no questions asked. Maybe it's a hot bath or shower to soothe your muscles? A massage to work out the tension? Maybe it's just some rest and relaxation. If you're feeling anger, let it out—scream, punch pillows, break pencils, exercise, or just express it to a loved one. Maybe you feel like you're always on the verge of tears. Cry one of those hearty, child-like cries. More likely than not, you will feel some sense of relief, even if the relief doesn’t have long-term effects.
If you keep checking in with yourself and allow yourself to feel what you’re feeling, and act on those feelings with kindness and compassion, the pain will eventually dissipate.

And don't forget to celebrate too. Take time to laugh and remember the positive experiences you had. Reminisce with others about the good times, the ridiculous times, the absurd times. If you are grieving a person, reminisce on their physical mannerism, their quirks, or their unique expressions.
Be gentle

Grief is a very normal response to loss. It's important to allow your emotions to come to the surface, to feel them thoroughly, and to remain gentle and compassionate with yourself and your process. Grief can be short-lived or it can last a while. The important thing is to remain free of self-judgement as you work though the many unexpected emotions that loss brings out.
Stage of Grief: Denial
Denial is often the first stage of grief. You may deny the truth as a way to protect yourself from the shock.
You might avoid facts, isolate yourself from others, and refuse to acknowledge the current situation. This is perfectly normal.
Stage of Grief: Anger
As the reality of loss sets in, you may become more vulnerable. The pain of the loss can grow so great that you turn the hurt into anger.
You might lash out at yourself, friends, family, providers, and even the person you lost. It's okay to be angry. Try not to judge yourself, just allow yourself to feel.
Stage of Grief: Bargaining
Grief can leave you powerless, and it's normal to try to regain control. Bargaining sets in when you find yourself making promises to a higher power, wishing you could have done something different.
Bargaining is another way your mind tries to avoid reality. Again, there's no need to judge yourself for this normal impulse.
Stage of Grief: Depression
Depression is when sadness and rumination set in. You may find yourself wondering what you'll do, listing regrets, questioning your ability to move on.
You might find yourself pulling away from others, sleeping a lot, crying, or feeling hopeless.
Again, allow yourself to feel without judgment. This stage will also pass. Depression can be a sign that you're allowing yourself greater emotional vulnerability, moving closer to acceptance.
Stage of Grief: Acceptance
Acceptance is the stage in learning to accept your grief as the new normal, and may start to take part in life again.
This is not the same as being “okay” or “all right” — some people never feel “okay” about the loss of a loved one.

In this stage, you may realize that you can't maintain the past. Now that a loved one is gone, you may find yourself readjusting around their loss. For example, reassigning certain roles they filled to others.

You might feel that you're betraying your loved one by living a new life. This is perfectly normal — remind yourself that while you can't replace a love one, you can forge new connections. Acceptance may simply be having more good days than bad ones.
Stage of Grief: Acceptance
Acceptance is the stage in learning to accept your grief as the new normal, and may start to take part in life again.
This is not the same as being "okay" or "all right" — some people never feel "okay" about the loss of a loved one.

In this stage, you may realize that you can't maintain the past. Now that a loved one is gone, you may find yourself readjusting around their loss. For example, reassigning certain roles they filled to others.

You might feel that you're betraying your loved one by living a new life. This is perfectly normal — remind yourself that while you can't replace a love one, you can forge new connections. Acceptance may simply be having more good days than bad ones.

You might avoid facts, isolate yourself from others, and refuse to acknowledge the current situation. This is perfectly normal.
Stage of Grief: Depression
Depression is when sadness and rumination set in. You may find yourself wondering what you'll do, listing regrets, questioning your ability to move on.
You might find yourself pulling away from others, sleeping a lot, crying, or feeling hopeless.
Again, allow yourself to feel without judgment. This stage will also pass. Depression can be a sign that you're allowing yourself greater emotional vulnerability, moving closer to acceptance.
Habits and the Brain

Forming habits—especially good ones—can be challenging. Learning about the science behind habit forming can be useful to help you understand why it’s so hard and how you can overcome the difficulty and make a new, good habit stick.
This activity will:

items: Give a quick overview of how your brain forms habits
Explain the science behind forming habits
Share the research about how to keep good habits

components.text: The Science
The part of the brain called the basal ganglia is largely in charge of your habits. When behaviors are habits, your basal ganglia allows you to do them on autopilot without much decision making.

When you do things that aren’t habits, your prefrontal cortex helps you make decisions about your actions. So, when you start doing something for the first time, it’s mostly your prefrontal cortex helping you make the conscious decision to do that.
Over time, as your habit develops, your basal ganglia takes over the job and it becomes more automatic and requires less effort.
To make the switch in your brain, there are some specific steps to take. Let your coach know if you would like to learn more about creating new habits.
The Science of Habit Loops
The part of the brain called the basal ganglia is largely in charge of our habits.

When behaviors are habits, our basal ganglia allows us to do them on autopilot without much decision making. When we do things that aren’t habits, our prefrontal cortex helps us make decisions about our actions. So, when you start doing something for the first time (like watching less TV), it’s mostly your prefrontal cortex helping you make the conscious decision to do that. Over time, as your habit develops, your basal ganglia takes over the job and it becomes more automatic and requires less effort.
Your basal ganglia is also the home of dopamine.

Dopamine is a hormone that acts as a neurotransmitter in the brain and gets released in the basal ganglia when something rewarding happens. For example, eating soup when it rains may be a deliciously rewarding habit for you. When you formed that habit, dopamine was firing which made your brain learn that eating soup when it rains makes you very happy.
Find the sweet spot.

Research has shown that missing a single day of habit loop practice does not reduce the chance of forming a habit. This is great news for you because you can rest assured that your efforts will make a huge difference whether you change right away or take more time for things to stick.

The same research shows that everyone requires a different amount of time for behaviors to become habits. You can think of this as your sweet spot. If you're trying to start or drop a habit alongside another person (like exercising with a friend), remember that someone else’s sweet spot might be different from yours. With practice you’ll learn what your sweet spot is.
Habit Loops
Powerful parts of the brain control and help shape the habits we do every day. Understanding how they work can help you make new, good habits stick.
This activity will explain:

items: The science behind forming habits
Some research about how to keep good habits

components.text: The part of the brain called the basal ganglia is largely in charge of our habits.

When behaviors are habits, our basal ganglia allows us to do them on autopilot without much decision making. When we do things that aren’t habits, our prefrontal cortex helps us make decisions about our actions. So, when you start doing something for the first time (like watching less TV), it’s mostly your prefrontal cortex helping you make the conscious decision to do that. Over time, as your habit develops, your basal ganglia takes over the job and it becomes more automatic and requires less effort.
Your basal ganglia is also the home of dopamine.

For example, eating soup when it rains may be a deliciously rewarding habit for you. When you formed that habit, dopamine was firing which made your brain learn that eating soup when it rains makes you very happy.
Find the sweet spot.

Research has shown that missing a single day of habit loop practice does not reduce the chance of forming a habit. This is great news for you because you can rest assured that your efforts will make a huge difference whether you change right away or take more time for things to stick.

The same research shows that everyone requires a different amount of time for behaviors to become habits. You can think of this as your sweet spot. If you're trying to start or drop a habit alongside another person (like exercising with a friend), remember that someone else’s sweet spot might be different from yours. With practice you’ll learn what your sweet spot is.
How to Be More Optimistic

How we interpret a situation, and the meaning we attach to it, all comes down to our explanatory style, or the way we view the world. The most common explanatory styles are optimism and pessimism. Research shows that optimists are better able to regulate their emotions, bounce back from stressors more effectively, and even live longer than pessimists. If you tend to have a pessimistic explanatory style, this activity can help you start to change your perspective and reap the benefits of optimism.
In this activity card, you’ll:

items: Evaluate whether your thinking styles lean more optimistic or pessimistic;
Identify what thinking traps you might commonly fall into;
Take action to replace pessimistic thinking with optimism.

components.text: The difference between pessimistic and optimistic thinking
If you have a pessimistic style, you may interpret events as permanent, pervasive, and personal. Someone with an optimistic style, however, may see events as situational, specific, and external.
Next we’ll review a few examples of these two different styles.
Pessimistic thinking style

items: Permanent: “This will last forever.”
Pervasive: “This is going to undermine everything.”
Internal: “This is all my fault.”
Uncontrollable: “There is nothing I can do about it.”

components.text: Optimistic thinking style

items: Temporary: “This too shall pass.”
Specific: “This has to do with what is happening now.”
External: “This is not entirely my fault.”
Controllable: “There are some things I can do to manage the situation.”

components.text: So how can you tell if you tend toward pessimistic or optimistic thinking?
Below are some common traps that people who tend to view the world pessimistically fall into.

items: Fortune telling or future tripping: “I will mess this up.”
Black and white thinking: “I have never been good at this, therefore never will be.”
Mind-reading: “My boss thinks I am incapable.”
Overgeneralizing: “I always choke before a presentation.”
Labeling: “I’m a loser.”
Overestimating danger: “I will make a fool of myself if I try and pitch this idea.”
Filtering for negative: “Everyone liked my ideas except for ____ so it must be terrible.”
Catastrophizing: “I will blow this presentation and then get fired.”
“Shoulds”: “I should never make a single mistake when talking to _____.”

components.text: Use optimism to reduce pessimistic thinking traps.
Try these strategies to increase your sense of optimism:

items: 1. When you’re in an uncomfortable situation, view it as a challenge, rather than a threat that you need to run away from.
2. Assess what you can control in the situation. Ask yourself what small steps can lead to positive outcomes.
3. Ask yourself questions about the situation rather than sit back and ruminate on missteps.
4. If you’re having difficulty accessing positive emotions, take a moment to sit back and breathe.

5. Perspective is important! Flip the script. To get a realistically optimistic assessment of a situation, check out the Cognitive Reframing activity in the app, or ask your coach to assign this activity.

components.text: Developing a new perspective on the world won’t happen overnight, but there are small changes you can make to your thinking that will allow you to see situations in a new light. If you’re feeling stuck or need more suggestions, reach out to a professional for help.
How to Maintain Your Optimism

Being optimistic has many benefits from making your daily life more pleasurable, reducing anxiety, and building resilience. Some studies even show it can lead to a longer life. Optimism is sometimes confused with simply thinking positively (which can veer into “toxic positivity”), but being optimistic doesn’t mean ignoring the challenging parts of life. Optimism has to do with how you view the world, even when faced with tough situations.
This activity card will help you:

items: Evaluate whether your thinking styles are optimistic or whether they’re heading towards “toxic positivity.”
Identify when you’re using toxic positivity to cope with issues, and how to get back on track toward optimism.

components.text: The difference between optimistic thinking and toxic positivity.
“Toxic positivity” thinking includes:

items: “Good vibes ONLY.” With toxic positivity, there’s no room for complexity or other emotions.
“Just change your outlook and you will be happy.” Toxic positivity doesn’t account for the nuances of situations or address challenges such as mental health issues or institutional inequities.
“You’ll get over it!  Just look on the bright side.” It doesn’t allow for one to experience feelings.
“Everything will be fine.” It doesn’t allow for one to prepare for a challenging situation.

components.text: Optimistic thinking includes:

items: “This too shall pass and I will prepare the best I can for whatever the outcome.”
“This is hard, but I have done hard things in the past. How can I approach this with compassion?”
“There are some things I can do to manage the situation.”

components.text: What to watch for if your optimism slides into toxic positivity
If you find yourself in any of these situations, sliding from optimism to toxic positivity, there are actions you can take to increase your sense of optimism. Here are few scenarios and solutions:

items: 1. If you find yourself suppressing negative emotions and feel guilty for having them, check in with your emotions and allow yourself to be curious about them. Remember, feelings aren’t facts. Reach out to someone who can help you process them.

2. If your words are positive, but inside you feel sad or hopeless, take a minute to sit with your thoughts and examine what’s really going on. You might find a more optimistic way to look at your situation.

3. If you find yourself being insensitive with others who are struggling and aren’t able to “look on the bright side,” it might be a sign that you aren’t able to give others what you can’t give yourself—space to feel, grieve or process in a holistic way. Take a step back and ask yourself what about others’ sadness is triggering for you.
4. If you offer people (unsolicited) advice and lecture them instead of listening to what they are saying, take time to step back, listen and empathize.
5. If you deny the reality of situations to the point where you’re unable to cope with outcomes or adapt to changes, create a “hope for the best and prepare for everything else” mindset.

components.text: Viewing the world from an optimistic point of view can add pleasure and happiness to your life. But when that optimism becomes extreme, and leads you to ignore the difficult parts of life, it’s no longer optimism, it’s toxic positivity. If you feel like your thinking leans more towards toxic positivity, reach out to a professional for help... One common trait of an optimist is knowing you can change and improve.
Breathe with the Dot

In this 60-second breathing exercise, you'll be guided through five cleansing breaths. Deep breathing can help you feel more calm, present, and focused. Give this exercise a try if you're new to deep breathing or could use a 60-second pause in your day to help you feel less stressed and more relaxed.

**About Headspace**
We're pleased to now offer Headspace meditation exercises as part of our collection of self-care resources. Tap "Begin" to try this Headspace exercise.
Feeling Overwhelmed

In this exercise, Headspace founder, Andy, will guide you through a three-minute journey to help you reset and recharge. At the end of the three minutes, you may find yourself feeling less overwhelmed and ready to continue with your day with more clarity. Taking a moment to clear your mind can help you reframe your thinking and focus on what's important.

**About Headspace**
We're pleased to now offer Headspace meditation exercises as part of our collection of self-care resources. Tap "Begin" to try this Headspace exercise.
Getting Started: What is Headspace?

Headspace Care members now have access to Headspace: meditation and mindfulness made simple. With hundreds of guided exercises for sleep, focus, movement, and more topics for any moment, Headspace can help you stress less, sleep soundly, and boost mental wellness — so you can live happier and healthier.

Headspace is included with Headspace Care. If you’re a current Headspace member, this new subscription provided by your organization will be separate from your personal subscription. To sign up for a new Headspace account through your organization, check your email for instructions on how to enroll.
Goodnight Wind Down

At the end of a long day as you're trying to fall asleep, does your mind replay the events of the day, or think about all you need to do tomorrow, or even worse — worry about not sleeping? If you have trouble falling asleep at night, these visualization exercises can help you “switch off” your mind and soothe your body so you can more easily drift off to sleep.
After you press play, tap the gear on the bottom right to choose a different length.

**About Headspace**
We're pleased to now offer Headspace meditation exercises as part of our collection of self-care resources. Tap "Begin" to try this Headspace exercise.
Hans Zimmer Focus Music

Because you're believing the story your mind is telling you–that something bad will happen if you open up those bills. Or that Film score composer and Academy Award winner Hans Zimmer (Lion King, Pirates of the Caribbean, Dune, etc.) created a sweeping, cinematic soundtrack that will help you maintain focus while you engage in any activity. If your mind tends to wander or if you're just in the mood for music that will inspire you, grab your headphones and get focused with this Headspace original.

**About Headspace**
We're pleased to now offer Headspace meditation exercises as part of our collection of self-care resources. Tap "Begin" to try this Headspace exercise.
Letting Go of Stress

Ongoing stress affects your mental and physical health and can be difficult to manage, especially when the stressors are beyond your control. In this Headspace course, you'll be guided through three levels of exercises — Learn, Practice, and Master. Throughout the course, you'll cultivate a healthier mind by developing your awareness of stress, and you'll learn how to reframe negative emotions. Not ready for the full course? Give the first 11-minute exercise a try.

**About Headspace**
We're pleased to now offer Headspace meditation exercises as part of our collection of self-care resources. Tap "Begin" to try this Headspace exercise.
What is Coaching?
Check out this video for an overview of coaching and what you can expect when you connect with a coach.

properties.name: Headspace Care Adult Therapy & Psychiatry Intake
properties.description: Headspace Care Adult Therapy & Psychiatry Intake

components.text: Welcome to Therapy & Psychiatry
Before your first therapy and/or psychiatry session with us, we have to collect some information that will help us better understand you and provide personalized, productive care.
What you should know:
This form MUST be completed at least 48 hours before your first session.

Why? It takes time for your responses to appear in our system, and your care provider will need to have your information to provide the best treatment possible. Receiving a complete form allows your care provider to focus on your care, instead of gathering this information during your first session.
This form can take about 20 minutes to complete.
Your answers will be saved automatically, so you can leave and return to the form anytime.
Privacy and security are our top priorities.
We follow industry standards to ensure your data is secure. Headspace Care is HIPAA compliant and  HITRUST certified.
Medication
An intake session is needed before prescriptions can be prescribed. If you need an immediate refill, you should keep working with their current provider.
Have a question?
For technical questions, such as how many sessions you have, if you have to include insurance information, or how much clinical care will cost, please reach to Member Support through the “Chat” tab.
For questions about treatment, such as what medications may be right for you, please reach out directly to your clinician.
If any questions in the intake don't apply to you, simply indicate such.

Please be aware that this form should not be used to communicate urgent or emergent matters, as it will not be immediately reviewed. If you are located in the United States and you are having thoughts of suicide or self-harm, please call or text 988, the Suicide and Crisis Lifeline. If you are in immediate danger, please contact 911 or go to the nearest emergency room. If you are located outside of the United States, please contact your local crisis or emergency resources or go to the nearest emergency room.
This form can take about 20 minutes to complete.
Your answers will be saved automatically, so you can leave and return to the form anytime.

components.title: Rescheduling & Cancelation Policy
components.summary: If you need to reschedule or cancel an appointment, our Member Support team is always happy to assist. You must notify us 48 hours or more before the appointment if the appointment needs to be canceled or rescheduled. If the appointment is canceled with less than 48 hours notice or if you do not come to their appointment, you will be charged a $125 fee for the missed appointment. This policy helps us ensure all of our patients can receive timely care, as we are not able to frequently fill slots canceled within 48 hours. We appreciate your attention to the policy.

components.text: Please indicate that you understand you will not be prescribed a controlled substance.

Headspace Care psychiatrists CANNOT prescribe controlled substances including stimulants, benzodiazepines or opiates. These require an in-person visit due to prescribing regulations for telemedicine. However, our clinicians can treat most conditions without these substances.

You can find a list of common controlled substances [here](https://www.deadiversion.usdoj.gov/schedules/orangebook/c_cs_alpha.pdf). If you have questions, you can contact Member Support through the “Chat” tab.

If we are in-network with your insurance payer, you will be charged your regular co-pays for visits.

properties.name: Adult Intake: Welcome to Headspace Care Therapy & Psychiatry
properties.description: Welcome to Headspace Care Therapy & Psychiatry

components.text: Welcome to Therapy & Psychiatry
Before your first therapy and/or psychiatry session with us, we have to collect some information that will help us better understand you and provide personalized, productive care.
What you should know:
This form MUST be completed at least 48 hours before your first session.

Why? It takes time for your responses to appear in our system, and your care provider will need to have your information to provide the best treatment possible. Receiving a complete form allows your care provider to focus on your care, instead of gathering this information during your first session.
This form can take about 20 minutes to complete.
Your answers will be saved automatically, so you can leave and return to the form anytime.
Privacy and security are our top priorities.
We follow industry standards to ensure your data is secure. Headspace Care is HIPAA compliant and  HITRUST certified.
Medication
An intake session is needed before prescriptions can be prescribed. If you need an immediate refill, you should keep working with their current provider.
Have a question?
For technical questions, such as how many sessions you have, if you have to include insurance information, or how much clinical care will cost, please reach to Member Support through the “Chat” tab.
For questions about treatment, such as what medications may be right for you, please reach out directly to your clinician.
If any questions in the intake don't apply to you, simply indicate such.

Please be aware that this form should not be used to communicate urgent or emergent matters, as it will not be immediately reviewed. If you are located in the United States and you are having thoughts of suicide or self-harm, please call or text 988, the Suicide and Crisis Lifeline. If you are in immediate danger, please contact 911 or go to the nearest emergency room. If you are located outside of the United States, please contact your local crisis or emergency resources or go to the nearest emergency room.
This form can take about 20 minutes to complete.
Your answers will be saved automatically, so you can leave and return to the form anytime.

components.text: What services are you seeking at this time?
Please review and agree to our Therapy policies:

components.title: Notice of Privacy Practices for Protected Health Information
components.summary: Explains how we handle your data and how you can get access to this information.

components.title: Telehealth Consent
components.summary: Describes the risks associated with teletherapy and who we may share information with.

components.title: Therapy Outpatient Services Contract And Informed Consent
components.summary: Outlines our professional services and policies, including: billing, reimbursement and confidentiality.

components.title: Rescheduling & Cancelation Policy
components.summary: If you need to reschedule or cancel an appointment, our Member Support team is always happy to assist. You must notify us 48 hours or more before the appointment if the appointment needs to be canceled or rescheduled. If the appointment is canceled with less than 48 hours notice or if you do not come to their appointment, you will be charged a $125 fee for the missed appointment. This policy helps us ensure all of our patients can receive timely care, as we are not able to frequently fill slots canceled within 48 hours. We appreciate your attention to the policy.

components.text: Please indicate that you understand you will not be prescribed a controlled substance.

Headspace Care psychiatrists CANNOT prescribe controlled substances including stimulants, benzodiazepines or opiates. These require an in-person visit due to prescribing regulations for telemedicine. However, our clinicians can treat most conditions without these substances.

You can find a list of common controlled substances [here](https://www.deadiversion.usdoj.gov/schedules/orangebook/c_cs_alpha.pdf). If you have questions, you can contact Member Support through the “Chat” tab.

components.text: Please enter your insurance information.
If we are in-network with your insurance payer, you will be charged your regular co-pays for visits.
If we are not in-network with your insurance payer, you will be charged in full for services rendered. If we become in-network with your insurance company, we will contact you.
Would you like to receive monthly superbills sent to your email address?
This will allow you to submit claims for potential reimbursement to your insurance payer if we are not yet in-network with them.

items.body: Completed
Completed

This section can take about 15 minutes. Your answers will be saved automatically, so you can leave and return to the form anytime.
Knowing your medical history before you begin therapy and/or psychiatry will help your care provider better understand you and provide you with the most personalized, productive care possible.
< 1 minute

components.text: Some people have periods lasting several days when they feel much more excited and full of energy than usual. Their minds go too fast. They talk a lot. They are very restless or unable to sit still and they sometimes do things that are unusual for them, such as driving too fast or spending too much money. Have you ever had a period like this lasting several days or longer?

cards.condition: (medicare.values['supplemental_medicaid_and_or_medicare'] == true || medicare.values['none_of_the_above'] == true || insurance-company.value == Amerihealth) && (clinical-care-private.values['i-understand-clinical-care-private'] == true) && ((sought-services.values['therapy-and-psychiatry'] == true && accept-therapy-and-psychiatry-terms.values['accept-therapy-and-psychiatry-terms'] == true) || (sought-services.values['therapy'] == true && accept-therapy-terms.values['accept-therapy-terms'] == true) || (sought-services.values['psychiatry'] == true && accept-psychiatry-terms.values['accept-psychiatry-terms'] == true))

components.text: People who have episodes like this often have changes in their thinking and behavior at the same time, like being more talkative, needing very little sleep, being very restless, going on buying sprees, and behaving in many ways they would normally think inappropriate. Did you ever have any of these changes during your episodes of being excited and full of energy or very irritable or grouchy?

components.text: You're all set!
Thank you for your time and patience in completing the therapy and psychiatry intake. Your responses will help our clinicians prepare for their first appointment with you.
Headspace Care Introduction
Watch our introductory video below to learn more about Headspace Care.
What is Headspace Care Coaching?
Welcome! Here we’ll give you an overview of Headspace Care coaching and what you can expect when you connect with a coach.
Coaching is an excellent complement to therapy and psychiatry sessions.
Your coach works collaboratively on your care team with your therapist or psychiatrist.  We highly recommend connecting with a coach in addition to your therapist or psychiatrist.

You can check in with your coach anytime about challenges that may arise between appointments with your therapist or psychiatrist. In addition to one-on-one support, once you start working with a coach, your coach will handpick self-guided activities tailored to your needs.
What is Headspace Care coaching?
Coaching is a collaborative relationship where you and your coach work together to help you:

items: reach your goal,
identify small steps that you can take along the way,
make adjustments as needed to keep you on track,

components.text: What is coaching, how does it work, and who are my coaches?

items: Coaching focuses on the present and what you want to accomplish in the future.
Coaching happens through in-app text-based chats with your coach.
Coaches either have a graduate degree in psychology or a related field and/or a coaching certification from an accredited program.

components.text: What types of topics and issues do coaches typically help with?
Coaches can help with any issue you’re struggling with. Common issues our coaches help our members with include:

items: Stress
Anxiety
Depression
Work-related stress
Relationship issues
Trouble with sleep

components.text: What does a coaching session look like?

items: Coaching sessions are text-based conversations that take place in the app.
They typically last about 30 minutes
In your first session, your coach will tell you more about how Ginger coaching works and what to expect going forward.
You and your coach may discuss what your goals are, what challenges you’re facing, and what brought you to sign up for Ginger.
You and your coach will work towards developing your care plan.

components.text: How can I make the most of coaching?

items: Be ready to be an active participant in your change process.

Be willing to step out of your comfort zone and make adjustments to your daily way of behaving and/or thinking. (As one of our Headspace Care coaches, Gillian, says, 'If you do what you've always done, you'll get what you've always got.)'

Understand that coaching requires committing to new actions to achieve a new goal. Coaching is not meant only to be a place to explore or express your emotions. Coaching is about focusing on what you can do moving forward in the future.

Be open and honest with your coach. Letting your coach know about your challenges will allow your coach to understand your needs and figure out a plan for achieving your goal. Some topics may be uncomfortable to talk about. Your coach has experience helping people with a range of unique challenges and will always be judgement-free.

Make time for the self-guided exercises your coach will send you. Taking time for these exercises will reinforce the work you and your coach do together and will help you stay grounded to achieve your goal.
Let your coach know what’s working and what isn’t with your coaching sessions. Your coaches are always open to making adjustments that fit your needs.

components.text: Headspace Care Teen Therapy & Psychiatry Intake
Recommended therapy for your teen

Teens may be referred to psychiatry in addition to therapy if the therapist, teen and guardian feel that the teen could benefit from another layer of mental health support. Psychiatrists work collaboratively with the care team, teen and guardian to explore the teen's diagnosis and treatment plan. Psychiatrists are state-licensed to prescribe medication and monitor its effect on the teen's health.
About the intake form. Please read.

Before your teen’s first therapy, please fill out this intake form. The information you provide will help the therapist better understand your teen and provide personalized care from the start. This form will take about 10 minutes to complete.

Please be aware that this form should not be used to communicate urgent or emergent matters, as it will not be immediately reviewed. If your teen is experiencing an emergency or in need of immediate assistance, please contact the National Suicide Hotline at 988, call 911, or go to your nearest emergency room.
Instructions

Please answer the questions and confirm you have read the documents below. If any questions in the form are not relevant to your teen, please indicate that. If you have questions about the form, please reach out to caresupport@headspace.com or to a Member Support specialist through the “Chat” tab.
This form must be filled out at least 24 hours before your teen’s first session.

Thank you,
The Headspace Care Team
Please review and agree to our Therapy policies:

components.title: Notice of Privacy Practices for Protected Health Information
components.summary: Explains how we handle your teen’s data and how you and your teen can get access to this information.

components.title: Telehealth Consent
components.summary: Describes the risks associated with teletherapy and who we may share information with.

components.title: Therapy Outpatient Services Contract And Informed Consent
components.summary: Outlines what our professional services and policies, including: billing, reimbursement and confidentiality.

components.title: Rescheduling & Cancelation Policy
components.summary: If you or your teen need to reschedule or cancel an appointment, our Member Support team is always happy to assist. You or your teen must notify us 48 hours or more before the appointment if the appointment needs to be canceled or rescheduled. If the appointment is canceled with less than 48 hours notice or if your teen does not come to their appointment, you will be charged a $125 fee for the missed appointment. This policy helps us ensure all of our patients can receive timely care, as we are not able to frequently fill slots canceled within 48 hours. We appreciate your attention to the policy.

components.text: Thank you
Thank you for your time and patience in completing the therapy and psychiatry intake for your teen. Your responses will help our clinicians prepare for the first appointment with you and your teen.
Your teen will also be asked to complete a similar (shorter) check-in prior to the first appointment.
Headspace Care Teen Therapy Intake
Recommended therapy for your teen

Therapy consists of video sessions with a state-licensed clinician to help a teen gain an understanding  of why patterns develop and identify ways to create change. Headspace Care therapists are trained in a variety of evidence-based therapeutic approaches and have either a master's or doctoral degree.
About the intake form. Please read.

Before your teen's first therapy or psychiatry session, please fill out this intake form. The information you provide will help the therapist or psychiatrist better understand your teen and provide personalized care from the start. This form will take about 10 minutes to complete.

Please be aware that this form should not be used to communicate urgent or emergent matters, as it will not be immediately reviewed. If your teen is experiencing an emergency or in need of immediate assistance, please contact the Suicide & Crisis Lifeline, call 911, or go to your nearest emergency room.
Instructions

Please answer the questions and confirm you have read the documents below. If any questions in the form are not relevant to your child, please indicate that. If you have questions about the form, please reach out to caresupport@headspace.com or to a Member Support specialist through the "Chat" tab.
This form must be filled out at least 24 hours before your teen's first session.

Thank you,
The Headspace Care Team
Please review and agree to our Therapy policies:

You or your teen must notify us 24 hours or more before the appointment if the appointment needs to be canceled or rescheduled.  If the appointment is canceled with less than 24 hours notice or if your teen does not come to their appointment, you will be  charged a $125 fee for the missed appointment. This policy helps us ensure all of our patients can receive timely care, as we  are not able to frequently fill slots canceled within 24 hours. We appreciate your attention to the policy.

properties.name: What is Headspace Care Therapy & Psychiatry?

components.text: What is Headspace Care Therapy & Psychiatry?
Whether you’re new to therapy or psychiatry, or you’ve worked with a therapist or psychiatrist before, here you’ll learn all about what therapy and psychiatry is like at Headspace Care.
This activity card will:

items: Provide an overview of therapy and psychiatry at Headspace Care.
Give you an idea of what to expect during your sessions.
Highlight how Headspace Care coaching can complement therapy and psychiatry.

components.text: How do I get started with a therapist or psychiatrist?

In the app, chat with a Member Support specialist to start the process of scheduling an appointment. You’ll fill out an intake form so the Member Support team understands your needs and can best match you with a clinician. A Member Support specialist will then find a time that works for you and your assigned clinician. Once your appointment is scheduled, you’ll receive a confirmation email. You’ll also receive an email reminder and an in-app reminder before your appointment.
What do I need for my therapy/psychiatry session?

Therapy and psychiatry sessions happen through video chat in the Headspace Care app —which means all you need is your phone. You also have the option to have your appointment on your computer through Zoom. To use your phone for your appointment, go to the ‘video’ tab at the time of your appointment. To use your computer, download Zoom here: https://zoom.us/download.
You might want to find a quiet, private place where you’d feel comfortable having your appointment.
When should I reach out to my coach?

Coaching is an excellent complement to therapy and psychiatry sessions. Together, your coach and therapist or psychiatrist make up your care team. We highly recommend connecting with a coach in addition to your therapist or psychiatrist.
You can check in with your coach anytime about challenges that may arise between appointments with your therapist or psychiatrist.

Your coach can also help you remember insights and lessons and provide you with the opportunity to practice new skills regularly. And, your coach can help you work on exercises that your therapist or psychiatrist may assign.
How are coaching and therapy different?

Coaching is a collaborative relationship that focuses on where you are in the present and your goals for the future. You and your coach work together to identify small steps you can take to achieve your goals, making adjustments along the way to keep you on track.

Therapy consists of video sessions with a licensed clinician to help you address ongoing psychological symptoms, or patterns of thought, behavior, or emotion that no longer serve you. Therapy allows you to dive deeper into past or present issues to make positive change in your life. (While therapy may address childhood or other long-term issues in some cases, therapists help you manage present challenges.)
Therapy sessions are scheduled in advance and happen over video.
What can a psychiatrist help me with?

Psychiatrists are medical doctors who can prescribe medication to manage more severe or enduring symptoms. Your psychiatrist will work with you to determine the right psychiatric treatment based on your needs. You and your psychiatrist will meet every 4-8 weeks to evaluate how your prescribed medication(s) are affecting you. Depending on the evaluation, your psychiatrist might increase or decrease the dosage, or prescribe a different medication.
How long are therapy and psychiatry sessions?
Sessions with a therapist are 45-50 minutes, based on your need. With a psychiatrist, the first appointment is 45 minutes and follow-ups are 20 minutes.
Frequency and number of sessions will be determined based on your needs. You and your clinician will be able to discuss this during your first session, and adjust as needed moving forward.
Want more info about therapy and psychiatry at Headspace Care?
What are the qualifications of Headspace Care therapists and psychiatrists?

Headspace Care therapists are state-licensed healthcare professionals trained in a variety of evidence-based therapeutic approaches and have either a master's or doctoral degree. Headspace Care psychiatrists are medical doctors with four additional years of psychiatric training. They're state-licensed to prescribe medication and monitor its effects on your health.
Can Headspace Care psychiatrists prescribe medication?

Headspace Care psychiatrists are able to prescribe psychotropic drugs, which are medications that target the reduction of mental health symptoms. Examples include certain antidepressants, antipsychotics, and anti-anxiety medication. Headspace Care psychiatrists are not permitted to prescribe controlled substances, including stimulants, benzodiazepines, or opiates, as they require in-person visits for a prescription. Headspace Care psychiatrists are able to treat most issues without the use of controlled substances.
How do I change my therapy or video appointment?
To change your appointment, contact the Member Support team in the app at least 48 hours before your scheduled session.
What’s your cancellation and no-show policy?

If you need to cancel an appointment with a therapist or psychiatrist, we ask that you do so at least 48 hours in advance. This policy helps us ensure all of our patients can receive timely care, as we are not able to frequently fill slots canceled within 48 hours. For appointments canceled with less than 48 hours notice of your scheduled appointment, you will incur a fee of $125, based on your employer or plan benefits. Please let our Member Support team know as soon as possible if you need to reschedule your session.
Finish
Ready to schedule an appointment with a Headspace Care therapist or psychiatrist? To get started or if you have further questions, tap the “Chat” tab to connect with a Member Support specialist.
What is Therapy?
Check out this video for an overview of therapy.

components.text: Measuring Your Treatment Journey

Welcome to Headspace Care! It takes a lot of courage to seek help. The Headspace Care care team is here to guide you on the path to feeling better and reaching your goals. Your Headspace Care clinician will work with you to define your goals, measure your progress, and adapt your care plan accordingly. Throughout your treatment journey, your clinician will also equip you with the skills to continue to improve on your own and/or with the support of your Headspace Care coach.
This activity will:

items: Introduce you to Headspace Care’s goal-oriented, measurement-based, collaborative care model. (In other words, introduce you to what it looks like to work with a Headspace Care therapist and coach, and how your progress is assessed).
Let you know what to expect on your Headspace Care clinical treatment journey

components.text: How does Headspace Care clinical care work?

At Headspace Care, our clinical team uses a goal-oriented, measurement-based, collaborative care model. We’ll go through what each of these pieces mean below. At a high level, our clinicians work with you to identify your treatment goals, help you measure and track your progress, and ultimately equip you with the skills to empower you to continue the work outside of clinical care with the support of your Headspace Care coach.
Goal-Oriented
Goal-Oriented means your clinician will work with you to establish and work toward specific goals. These goals serve as a north star to guide your treatment journey.
Measurement-based

Measurement-based means your clinician will monitor your progress toward those goals using your scores on the assessments you filled out during your intake. As treatment progresses, your clinician will also ask you to complete regular follow-up assessments in the Headspace Care app to help them understand how things are going for you and inform treatment decisions, which will be reviewed every four sessions.
Collaborative

Collaborative means that we use a team approach that includes your engagement with your app content, regular coaching sessions, and clinical sessions to help you learn independent coping skills, establish adequate self-care routines, and improve your well-being so you no longer need treatment. Oftentimes, members graduate from clinical care and continue with coaching alone.

At Headspace Care, our goal is to help you reach your treatment goals and teach you the skills to sustain the progress on your own. In short, we’re not trying to keep you in clinical care forever, but are working to get you to a point where you no longer need clinical treatment. Your clinician will work with you to determine when you’re ready to move on from treatment. Every fourth session, your clinician will discuss your progress with you and collaborate on the next phase of treatment.
What should I expect from my session?
As you start working with your clinician, you’ll work together on the following areas to create your personalized treatment plan:
Develop your treatment goals:

Your clinician will walk you through SMART (specific, measurable, attainable, relevant, time-bound) goals and help you develop SMART goals for yourself. These will help you and your clinician assess how you’ll know when you’ve completed treatment.
Align on which symptoms are to be addressed in treatment and outcomes:

Your clinician will use your check-in responses at intake and follow-ups (in the app) to inform goals and help guide you. Your check-in responses on the frequency, intensity, duration, and onset/start of your symptoms will be particularly helpful, so remember to do your Anxiety & Depression and Adaptability check-ins in between sessions when they are assigned.
Learn about symptom response rates & indicators of success:

Once you’ve aligned on symptoms to focus on, your clinician will discuss reasonable outcomes to expect for your symptoms and goals. Your clinician will teach you techniques and offer tips to use in your daily life to enhance your mental health and also improve your symptoms. You and your clinician will discuss how you will measure treatment success so that you know what to expect. One way that treatment effectiveness is often measured is with the check-in responses through the app.  At the end of treatment, members who have a full response experience a 50% or greater symptom improvement and members who have a partial response experience a 30% symptom improvement as measured by these assessments. Some other indicators of success include: maintaining a lower score on the app check-in  measure, reduced frequency/intensity/duration of a symptom, increased use of a positive coping behavior as outlined in your SMART goals.
Set expectations for the estimated number of clinical sessions needed:

Your clinician will typically work with you in four session segments and assess your progress every four sessions. At the end of your intake appointment, your clinician will also typically recommend a frequency and expected length of treatment based on your current measures and treatment goals. Most Headspace Care members will graduate from therapy within 8 sessions.
Let’s get started!

Thanks for taking the time to learn more about your Headspace Care clinical treatment journey. At Headspace Care, our goal is to get you access to high-quality care, measure your treatment progress, and ultimately empower you with a toolkit of knowledge and skills to carry the work forward long after you graduate from clinical care. If you haven’t already completed your latest assigned check-in, take a few minutes now to complete it so that you and your clinician can continue to evaluate your progress. And remember that you can also reach out to your Headspace Care coach for additional support as you work on achieving your day to day goals.
How does Headspace Care work?
Check out this video for an overview of how Headspace Care works
Resources for Extra Support

Welcome! It took a lot of courage to reach out for help. Even though your parent/guardian has declined the option for you to work with a Headspace Care therapist or psychiatrist, we are still here to support through coaching and guided self-care content. Additionally, here are some other resources that may be helpful.
Finding someone to talk to
[7 Cups](https://www.7cups.com/): Free & low cost telehealth
[Anxiety & Depression Association of America](https://adaa.org/finding-help/telemental-health/provider_listing): Find a therapist in your state who specializes in Anxiety & Depression
[Crisis Text Line](https://www.crisistextline.org/): Crisis text support
[Kids Health](https://kidshealth.org/en/teens/mhealth-care.html): Tips for finding low cost teen mental health resources
[National Alliance on Mental Illness Helpline](https://www.nami.org/help): Mental health helpline & crisis resources for teens
[National Eating Disorder Association](https://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/help-support/contact-helpline): Eating disorders helpline
[Teen Line](https://www.teenline.org/): Teen-led helpline
[The Trevor Project](https://www.thetrevorproject.org/get-help/): Chat, call, or text with a crisis counselor and access LGBTQ support & wellness resources
[Your Life Your Voice](https://www.yourlifeyourvoice.org/pages/home.aspx): Get help via call, text, email, or the app
Additional mental health tools & resources
[Headspace](https://www.headspace.com/teens): Free access to mindfulness & meditation exercises
[Born This Way Foundation](https://bornthisway.foundation/resources-for-help/): Mental health and crisis resources for teens
[Erika's LIghthouse](https://www.erikaslighthouse.org/teen-empowerment/): Teen mental health empowerment

[National Institute of Mental Health](https://www.nimh.nih.gov/get-involved/education-awareness/shareable-resources-on-child-and-adolescent-mental-health): Shareable documents and videos on teen mental health & wellness

[Society for Adolescent Health & Medicine](https://www.adolescenthealth.org/SAHM_Main/media/Clinical-Care-Resources/Mental-Health-One-pager-for-Adolescents_jhedt-FINAL_1.pdf): Comprehensive mental health & wellness resources for teens
[The Jed Foundation](https://jedfoundation.org/): Suicide prevention non-profit
With the exception of Headspace, the third-party resources referenced are not affiliated with or endorsed or tested by Headspace Care.

Getting Started with Headspace Care
Welcome! This activity card will:

items: Introduce you to what Headspace Care offers.
Explain the difference between Headspace Care coaching and therapy.
Show you an example of how you might work with your new coach.
Help you prepare for your first coaching session.

components.text: But first… What’s an “activity card”?

An activity card contains information about mental health techniques that you can access on your own. There are different types of activity cards. Some contain audio guides, others are self-guided mental health exercises, while others contain articles, research and tips. Your coach will make suggestions on activity cards that are right for you. Feel free to explore!
What’s the difference between coaching and therapy?

Coaching focuses on where you are in the present and your goals for the future. Coaching is a collaborative relationship. You and your coach work together to identify small steps you can take to achieve your goals, making adjustments along the way to keep you on track.

Therapy consists of sessions with a licensed clinician to help you address ongoing psychological symptoms, or patterns of thought, behavior or emotion that no longer serve you. Therapy allows you to dive deeper into past or present issues to make positive change in your life.
How Does Coaching Start?
You’ll work with your coach to create a care plan that is tailored to your specific needs. Your coach will help you develop skills to overcome a barrier or achieve a goal.

Give it a try here! One of the skills our coaches teach is called “thought reframing.” With thought reframing, you first identify a thought that’s causing you discomfort and then think about it in a new way. Want to try a quick example?
OK. First, choose a sample thought:

options.name: Everyone else on my team knows what they’re doing. I’m not even sure why I got this role. I have no idea what I’m doing
I don’t have enough friends. People don’t reach out to me because they don’t like me and they’re probably doing fun things without me.

components.text: This is a relatively common thought but it’s probably not entirely true. By noticing this thought and shifting it slightly you can reduce your anxiety and free up some motivation to tackle your goals.

Here’s how we would reframe the thought: “My team is confident and competent but they likely have days where they feel totally out of their league. Everyone is learning together. I worked hard to get this role and I have the resources to ask for support when I feel uncertain.”

Thought reframing is just one example of a skill you might work on with your coach. It’s research proven to reduce anxiety. Next, find out what you can expect in your first chat with a coach so you can get started!

This is a relatively common thought but it’s probably not entirely true. By noticing this thought and shifting it slightly you can reduce your anxiety and free up some motivation to tackle your goals.

Here’s how we would reframe the thought: “I might have fewer friends than I would like but there’s no ‘right’ number of friends. People might not be reaching out because they’re busy. I can consider being the one who reaches out and checks in first.”

Thought reframing is just one example of a skill you might work on with your coach. It’s research proven to reduce anxiety. Next, find out what you can expect in your first chat with a coach so you can get started!
What to Expect in Your First Coaching Session
If you haven’t already, we recommend scheduling your first session with a coach. In this initial conversation you’ll:

items: Learn more about how Headspace Care coaching works and what to expect
Discuss what brought you to Headspace Care and what your goals may be
Share any challenges you’re currently facing
Work towards developing your care plan

components.text: How you and your coach track your progress

After your first chat you’ll see a new survey on the home screen. This survey will help you and your coach track your progress. Please complete the survey, and of course, reach out to your coach anytime.
With Headspace Care, someone is always by your side as you face life’s challenges.

properties.name: Surveys help us track your progress

components.text: Talk To Someone Right Now
Call the Suicide & Crisis Lifeline
What is Coaching?
Coaches Corey and Shannon answer teens’ frequently asked questions about coaching and how it works.

If you haven’t chatted with a coach yet, give it a try! You don’t need a clear reason to reach out. Headspace Care coaches are here to listen, provide non-judgmental support, and help you build skills to cope with challenges. You can schedule a session or reach out for immediate support.
What is Psychiatry?
Check out this video for an overview of psychiatry.

properties.name: Am I in the Right Career?
properties.description: Am I in the Right Career?

components.text: Am I in the Right Career?

It’s common to wonder whether we’re on the right career path. There’s no universally correct pathway when it comes to work—it all depends on your specific passions and values. Additionally, life events push and pull us in different directions over time, so it’s important to check in on our career satisfaction at regular intervals.
This activity will:

items: Help you ask the right questions when considering whether you’re on the right career pathway for your happiness.
Help you understand different thinking patterns that influence how we perceive our career choices.
Help you create an action plan for further reflection and discussion with trusted others.

components.text: If you’re feeling uncertain about your career, reflect on the following questions:
Did something negative happen recently that’s contributing to me feeling this way?

items: If so, try to separate the negative event with your feelings in general about your career.

components.text: Have I noticed a more general sense of discontent at work?

items: If so, work on resolving any stress or conflict that has recently come up first to prevent making a reactionary decision.

components.text: Why did I choose this career initially? Does it align with my core values? Is it providing for my basic needs?

items: Understanding what led you to certain work in the first place can help you notice if your priorities are the same or if they have shifted over time.

components.text: These are common thinking patterns. Take a moment to reflect on them:
Am I falling into the “Sunk cost fallacy?”

items: The “Sunk cost fallacy” leads us to continue to do activities or stay in a career because we have already invested time, money, and energy into them, even if we no longer enjoy it.

components.text: Do I feel obligated to do this type of work? Are there family pressures? What type of pressure am I putting on myself?

items: We often can fall into a “should” thinking pathway wherein we feel that we “should” act a certain way due to external pressures.

components.text: How would I feel about myself if I continued on this pathway? How would I feel about myself if I change careers?

items: Imagine that ten years have passed and you’re reflecting back over those ten years. Think about how you will have wished you had prioritized your goals.

components.text: Steps you can take to evaluate your career choice:

items: Reflect and consider ranking your career values, such as your passion about the work, salary, time commitment, location, seniority, etc.
Create a pros and cons list for your current career. How does your current work align with your career values listed above.

Research other possibilities. Spend some time reading through open job postings. Learning what else is out there can help you clarify what you like and dislike about your current work. It may also help you think about whether a specialization or different branch of your field might interest you more.

Talk with trusted family and friends. Having the additional perspective of those that have known you for a long time or know you very well can help highlight factors you may have forgotten in the moment.

Commit to checking in with yourself at regular intervals to ensure you’re on the right path. Whether you decide to make a change right now or not, remember that you can always revisit this question again in the future.

components.text: Asking for What You Need
Assertive communication is important for healthy working relationships. With this style of communication, your needs and the needs of those around you are both met.
Think of a situation where you want or need something from someone else.
Think about your request.
This activity will walk you through an example of how to ask for what you need.
What’s Your Request?
Let’s consider the request you thought of and make sure it is, in fact, assertive.

While it's easy to want to give the long list of reasons why the other person should give you what you want, research shows that presenting just one reason–the most persuasive–is most likely to get you what you want.
Think about your most persuasive reason.
Practice Self-Respect

Just a reminder: People are more likely to treat you with respect if you have self-respect. If you believe you deserve what you're asking for, your whole demeanor will show it, and people will respond in kind.
Why is this request important to you? And why do you deserve to have the other person consider your request?
How do you think the other person will feel when you make this request? Does that in any way change how you want to make the request?
How will the other person likely feel and react to your request?
An Optional Exit
In some situations, it might make sense to give people a way out. But, this depends on the nature of the request and how important it is to you.
Some requests are meant to be firm and we don't have to give the person an easy out. Requests that are about protecting yourself or your boundaries will usually fall into this category.
Think about how you can give the other person a way to say no?
Nonverbal Communication

Consider your nonverbal communication, too. Your posture and tone of voice are also doing the communicating. Standing up straight with an even tone of voice can help convey your message in a way that'll be well-received.
Your Plan
Think or write down on a piece of paper: your request, your reason, why you’re worth it, how the other person will feel, and maybe a way for the other person to say no.
All these pieces come together to form your most effective request. Take some time this week to try it out.
One last question...
How helpful did you find Asking for What You Need?
Great, thanks for letting us know.
Effective Communication Styles
When you’re in the new role, being able to communicate clearly and effectively is key.
In order to build strong working relationships, it’s important to become aware of your own communication style and improve it where necessary.
This activity will:

items: Discuss three common styles of communication. Then you’ll have the option to check out a few examples.
Teach you the most effective style
Allow you to practice your own communication in an effective style

components.text: Passive Style
My needs don’t matter. Everyone else’s needs matter.
If we communicate in a way that suggests our needs don’t matter (passively), our needs don’t get met. And your needs matter. It's tough to express your needs when you think they aren’t worthy
Aggressive Style
Only my needs matter. No one else’s needs matter.
If we speak aggressively, people may have a hard time understanding our points of view. It’s difficult to collaborate and work well as a team if others feel we don’t care about their needs.
Assertive Style
My needs matter. And other’s needs matter, too.

Communicating assertively is the sweet spot. It strikes a balance between meeting our own needs while considering that others have needs to be met, too. Assertive communication is a skill used by effective leaders.
Practicing assertive communication will help you to create strong and healthy relationships with your new team.
In this activity we’ll share three examples of different communication styles.
Here’s an example
Can you come in on Tuesday?

Katrina shows up to work each day, except on her day off, which is Tuesday. On Monday, her manager asks Katrina if she'd be open to coming in on Tuesday. ”Things have been busy and I need an extra hand,” she says. Katrina made plans with her family on Tuesday and would like to tell her boss that she can't come in.
What's an assertive way Katrina can tell this to her boss?

options.name: It’s ridiculous for you to ask me to come in on my day off.
Sure. I’ll come in tomorrow. I’m sorry I didn’t initially offer
I have a commitment tomorrow but am happy to help you as much as I can today.

components.text: This is an aggressive style.

An aggressive style disregards others' needs (in this case, the boss's). When we communicate aggressively, we tend to criticize, blame, or attack, and use ”you” statements. You can probably see why it's difficult to maintain close, connected relationships when we communicate aggressively.
Working on communicating assertively in a way that respects both your own needs and others' needs, is one way to maintain and improve healthy relationships at work.
This is a passive style.
This is passive, considering Katrina doesn't want to come into work on her day off. When we communicate passively, we fail to express what we want and tend to say things like, ”I'm sorry.”
As a result, we can end up feeling like we're weak or we get walked all over by others. When we're feeling that way at work, it's hard to show up as our best selves.
Working on communicating assertively, in a way that respects both your own needs and others' needs, is one way to maintain and improve healthy relationships at work.
This is an assertive style.

Assertive communication happens when we express our opinions, feelings, and needs while also communicating respect for others. This statement achieves this balance. It considers both Katrina's and her boss's position. Because of the balance, assertive communication helps us feel connected to others (and vice versa), which leads to relationships that benefit both people.
Working on communicating assertively, in a way that respects both your own needs and others' needs, is one way to maintain and improve healthy relationships at work.
Challenging Imposter Syndrome
Challenging your thoughts can help reduce feelings of imposter syndrome and can help you feel more confident and capable.
This activity will help you:

items: Identify the emotions behind your negative self-talk
Look at those thoughts from a different perspective to challenge them
Recognize your worth at work

components.text: What is Imposter Syndrome?
When You Don’t Feel Your Worth
Have you ever thought the following about your success at work?
“I've tricked people into thinking I'm more competent than I really am.“
“I just got lucky–I don't really have the skills for the job.“
“I was only successful because that project was easy. If it'd been harder, I would have failed.“

If you’ve ever said or thought something similar to those statements, you may have imposter syndrome. Imposter syndrome means feeling less competent than you are, feeling like a fraud, and that you might be found out for it. It’s also incredibly common. Imposter syndrome can hold you back from success at work.

Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) can help you identify the underlying thoughts and negative self-talk that keep you feeling stuck or incompetent. It allows you to take a closer look and see what those around you see: that you're truly capable.
The first step is to identify a recent time where you had a strong emotion related to imposter syndrome.
Think about the last time you were feeling really down about yourself and your abilities at work, or when you were worried that people didn’t think you were competent.
Now, let's explore the thought behind that emotion. Which of the following seems most closely tied to the feeling you were having?

options.name: I tricked everyone into thinking I was capable
I only did well because it was easy
That other person is way more capable
That went well but it is not enough

components.text: YOU CHOSE:
I tricked everyone into thinking I was capable
This thought can often lead to feeling like you're a fraud or a fake. Often there's a fear that people around you will figure out you're less capable than they thought.
But consider that those around you think you are capable. How would it feel to see yourself the way others see you?
Try thinking of a new, more flexible thought that takes into account the strengths that others see in you.
YOU CHOSE:
I tricked everyone into thinking I was capable
NOW, THINK ABOUT OR WRITE A MORE FLEXIBLE THOUGHT.
Take a moment to think about how you feel about the thought you chose. Now, think about how you feel about the new thought.
Hopefully, the second thought invites more flexibility and helps you to feel more confident and capable in your role. Over time, this type of thinking may become more natural for you.
YOU CHOSE:
It was just luck.

When you attribute your successes to luck, it's easy to discount all your efforts and wins along the way. The credit goes to external circumstances, and it's harder to recognize your internal qualities and skills.
Try crafting a more flexible thought, one that recognizes both external and internal factors. Consider all of the steps on the way to your success that you had control over.
YOU CHOSE:
It was just luck
NOW, THINK ABOUT OR WRITE A MORE FLEXIBLE THOUGHT.
Take a moment to think about how you feel when you read the thought you first chose, and how you feel considering the one you just wrote.
Hopefully, the second thought invites more flexibility and helps you to feel more confident and capable in your role. Over time, this type of thinking may become more natural for you.
YOU CHOSE:
I only did well because it was easy.

This thought tends to discount or downplay accomplishments. Regarding the work you did as simple or easy makes it hard to accept praise. It also makes the assumption that, if the task had been harder, you would have failed.
Try writing a new, more flexible thought that takes into account your personal skills that led to success in this particular task.
YOU CHOSE:
I only did well because it was easy.
NOW, THINK ABOUT OR WRITE A MORE FLEXIBLE THOUGHT.
Take a moment to think about how you feel when you read the thought you first chose, and how you feel considering the one you just wrote.
Hopefully, the second thought invites more flexibility and helps you to feel more confident and capable in your role. Over time, this type of thinking may become more natural for you.
YOU CHOSE:
That other person is way more capable

It's normal to compare ourselves to others. But sometimes, we're comparing our beginning to someone else's middle or end. Or, we're unaware of the difficulties they're having, and we imagine it's all rosy.

Try writing a new, more flexible thought that has a bit more compassion for the fact that you're new to this role. See if you can focus this new thought on your own process, rather than that of a colleague.
YOU CHOSE:
That other person is way more capable
NOW, THINK ABOUT OR WRITE A MORE FLEXIBLE THOUGHT.
Take a moment to think about how you feel when you read the thought you first chose, and how you feel considering the one you just wrote.
Hopefully, the second thought invites more flexibility and helps you to feel more confident and capable in your role. Over time, this type of thinking may become more natural for you.
YOU CHOSE:
That went well but it is not enough

Sounds like your success feels a bit like a moving target. When we're in a new role with a lot of pressure, it's easy to discount success and feel like we always need to be striving for more. But it's important to give yourself credit for what you've accomplished and recognize your successes.
Try writing a new, more flexible thought that gives yourself credit for a recent success.
YOU CHOSE:
That went well but it is not enough
NOW, THINK ABOUT OR WRITE A MORE FLEXIBLE THOUGHT.
Take a moment to think about how you feel when you read the thought you first chose, and how you feel considering the one you just wrote.
Hopefully, the second thought invites more flexibility and helps you to feel more confident and capable in your role. Over time, this type of thinking may become more natural for you.

Spend some time in the next few days making an effort to see yourself the way others see you. Try to recognize your own worth and accomplishments. Give your colleagues credit for recognizing talent when they see it.
Next time you notice you’re having a strong emotion related to imposter syndrome, this technique is here for you to explore the thoughts behind your feelings.
How’d that go?
Thanks for sharing.
Imposter Syndrome
When You Don’t Feel Your Worth
Have you ever thought the following about your success at work?
“I've tricked people into thinking I'm more competent than I really am.“
“I just got lucky–I don't really have the skills for the job.“
“I was only successful because that project was easy. If it'd been harder, I would have failed.“

If you’ve ever said or thought something similar to those statements, you may have imposter syndrome. Imposter syndrome means feeling less competent than you are, feeling like a fraud, and that you might be found out for it. It’s also incredibly common. Imposter syndrome can hold you back from success at work.
This activity will help you:

items: Identify negative self-talk
Challenge imposter-syndrome thoughts
Recognize your worth

components.text: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) can help you identify the underlying thoughts and negative self-talk that keep you feeling stuck or incompetent. It allows you to take a closer look and see what those around you see: that you're truly capable.
Up next, we'll take a look at the thoughts that come up most often for you. Then, we'll help you challenge them, so you can start feeling your worth.

properties.name: The Stress of a New Job
properties.description: The Stress of a New Job

components.text: The Stress of a New Job

A new job with new responsibilities is exciting, but can also come with stress. Needing to learn a new skill or new information, in addition to changes in your routine, can be overwhelming. If you find yourself stressed about work, this activity can help.
This activity will:

items: Help you identify how work is affecting your stress level
Teach you grounding and relaxation exercises to help you manage stress caused by work.

components.text: The Stress of a New Job
Which of the following are true for you? Tap any that apply.

options.name: I feel more pressure in my new role
I’m having interpersonal difficulty at work
I feel less qualified to do my job

components.text: Sometimes, changes at work can feel stressful.
You said:
I feel more pressure in my new role
I’m having interpersonal difficulty at work
I feel less qualified to do my job
I‘m working longer hours
None of these
Sounds like you’re not experiencing any challenging work stressors today. That’s great to hear.

Those feelings and experiences can definitely cause stress. To help you feel more relaxed, try a breathing or grounding exercise. We’ve got several activity cards in the app dedicated to relaxation techniques.
The Stress of a New Job
Which of the following are true for you? Tap on any that apply to you.

options.name: I have more responsibility at work
I’m adjusting to working with new people
I have higher expectations for myself

components.text: Sometimes, changes at work can seem pretty exciting
You said:
I have more responsibility at work
I’m learning new things
I’m adjusting to working with new people
I have higher expectations for myself
None of these

It also looks like the more positive work changes didn’t resonate with you either. If you do experience any stress from change in the future, remember that it’s totally normal, regardless of whether it’s a seemingly positive or challenging change.

While these are potentially exciting and positive changes, it’s normal to feel stressed about them. Any type of change or transition can have an impact on your life—whether it’s an exciting one or a challenging one.
Identifying these changes and you did in this activity is also an important first step.
Ask your coach to share more grounding and relaxation techniques if you’re interested.
Grounding with Your Senses
