When you’re experiencing stressful changes at work, sometimes it helps to take a minute to relax. Try this technique to feel grounded and get in-the-moment relief.
Time to turn up the volume or put on headphones. Audio guidance is about to begin.
Grounding 5-4-3-2-1
You can do this technique anywhere, though it helps to find a quiet spot where you won’t be interrupted.
When you’re ready, start by looking around you. Name five things you can see. These can be anything in your surroundings: a TV, a person, a piece of furniture. Just find five things.
Now, identify five things that you can hear. Maybe you hear a door shutting, or a bell ringing. Whatever you may hear right now, name them silently to yourself.
And now, identify five things that you can touch, or feel with your body.
Now, let’s go back to what you can see.
What are four things that you can see right now? It’s OK to repeat the things you saw last time. Say them to yourself silently.
Now, moving onto sounds. What are four sounds you can hear right now?
What are four things that you can touch or feel right now? Is there a unique texture, shape, or composition to these things?
Now back to sight. Find three things that you can see right now. Just make a note of them to yourself
What are three things that you can hear? Notice if there are any new sounds.
Now find three things that you can feel or touch, right now, and focus all of your attention on these sensations.
Now back to sight. What are two things that you can see right now?
What are two things that you can hear?
What are two things that you can touch or feel?
What are two things that you can hear?
OK, final round now: What's one thing that you can see? What's one thing you can hear? What's one thing you can feel?
Excellent. You're finished. Take a deep breath in through your nose and out through your mouth. You should feel just a little bit more grounded, a little more present.
Remember that you can return to this practice any time your muscles are tight, your anxiety is high, or you’re finding it difficult to focus.
How’d that go?
How helpful did you find Grounding 5-4-3-2-1?
Thanks for letting us know.
Managing Video Presentation Anxiety

Fear of public speaking is quite common... Making a presentation for work or school in front of colleagues, supervisors, classmates, or teachers can make the fear feel even bigger. Add on the pressure of speaking on live video from your home, and it’s not surprising that many people have anxiety when it comes to making a video presentation. Here are a few tips to help you cope with that anxiety and begin to overcome your fear.
Don’t avoid video presentations.

While trying to avoid video presentations all together might seem like a good idea, avoidance will only exacerbate anxiety over time. Keep in mind that after you do a presentation once, you’re likely to be less fearful the next time. Plus, if you avoid making presentations, it could interfere with the potential for more responsibilities and opportunities.
Practice.

Practice your presentation on the platform on which you’ll deliver it, and in the space where you’ll be before the meeting, without an audience. Start a meeting without anyone there, or invite a close family member to join the meeting. This will help you feel more confident with your delivery and more comfortable with your content. You can also practice navigating the technology.
Create a calming workstation.

Set up your workstation with objects that relax you and make you feel comfortable. Remember, during video presentations, colleagues only see a small square of you. Put a sticky note with a mantra at eye level on your computer, give yourself something soft or squishy to hold while you present, or place a picture of a loved one nearby.
Do something relaxing immediately before.
Take deep breaths. Go outside for fresh air. Do a short meditation. Stretch. Tell yourself, “I’ve got this.”
Celebrate!
Plan something fun or special afterward to reward yourself. No matter how you may feel about it afterward, you did it, and you can be proud. Treat yourself to something you enjoy. You’ve earned it!
Ask for support.
Reach out to your coach, who can help you modify these strategies—or come up with new ones that work for you—before in-person presentations or an important meeting. And remember, you’ve got this!
Handling Negative Feedback At Work

It is human nature to want to receive positive feedback from others. It can be hard to hear that your boss doesn’t think you did a good job. Receiving difficult or negative feedback about work performance can be upsetting, but it doesn’t have to be a setback. Rather, it can be an opportunity for growth. Learning how to approach and handle a critique from your boss can help you better cope the next time you hear it.
This activity will:

items: Help you cope with negative performance feedback.
Recognize how to change your mindset for growth.
Develop skills to successfully navigate strong emotions at work.

components.text: Know that receiving negative feedback in any situation can be challenging.

As humans, we can have a bias towards negativity. When we hear something about ourselves that isn’t flattering or needs improvement, we tend to focus on it more than positive comments. It can be challenging to keep in mind a balanced perspective when you’ve heard something negative. Know that having this reaction is normal and you are not alone.

items: Remember, this is only one piece of feedback. What other feedback have you received from your boss? Can you think of a time when you did get positive feedback?

components.text: Try to keep in mind that negative feedback does not define you personally or professionally. Pay attention to the total feedback — both positive and negative. Keep it in perspective. We all make mistakes sometimes. Remember that the feedback does not mean you’re a bad person and work is only one part of your life.

Recognize that it may also be difficult for your boss to deliver the feedback. Ideally, they want you to be successful in your role at work, so remember that their feedback is essential to your success.

Some work situations may require further reflection on the health of the relationship with your boss. If you don’t feel like that person is capable of supporting you, talk to your coach about specific ways to manage your own emotions around the situation.
Recognize how negative feedback can be utilized as a catalyst for growth.
Develop a growth mindset, which can be key to coping with negative feedback.

items: Having a growth mindset allows you to remain the “victor” of your work story because you have the power to improve.

A growth mindset allows you to take the information and integrate it so that you can adapt and change. It is a way of thinking that permits you to recognize how to grow from adversity and remain the hero of your own story. It recognizes that you can overcome challenges and learn from your experiences. Think of an affirmation, which can help you remember how to make difficult feedback part of your success story.
An affirmation is a statement made in the present (as though it has already been achieved) that can strengthen your thoughts to support a goal you want to achieve. Here are a few examples:

components.text: - I approach all situations with a positive attitude.
- I am willing to learn from this feedback so that I can improve.
- I will meet x, y, z goals by _____
Keep your affirmation posted in your work space to remind you of your resilience and determination to improve your performance.
Reassess your strategies for success at work and develop a coping plan.

Keep the conversation open with your boss in order to improve the situation. Ask for a strategy for your growth and create a plan of action that includes SMART— Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Realistic, and Time-bound— goals.

Take time, emotionally, for yourself directly after this feedback. Doing so can improve your ability to cope with any difficult feedback and prevent you from becoming upset for a prolonged period of time. Do something to help improve your mood. Here a few ideas:

items: Connect with a loved one or friend.
Go out for a walk, or other exercise.
Do something positive and uplifting to help you stay balanced if your mood begins to dip.

components.text: Remember that it’s natural to feel upset or disappointed. Give yourself some space for these feelings and revisit the task once you’re able to have more focus.
Do something that makes you feel competent and happy. Engage in a hobby, parenting, or something that helps you feel relaxed.
Get support. Reach out to coworkers, family, or friends if you need additional support

No one enjoys receiving negative feedback from their boss, but when you do, there are ways to cope and put the feedback in perspective. Try a few of these strategies and remember that negative feedback can be a great motivator for your own success.
Preparing for Performance Reviews

Yearly employment reviews can bring up feelings of stress, anxiety, confusion, and even dread for people who are uncomfortable with evaluation or feedback. To help set yourself up for success, there are frameworks you can use to prepare for an effective performance review.
This activity will:

items: Introduce you to DBT (Dialectical Behavior Therapy) and skills to boost interpersonal effectiveness
Walk you through three specific frameworks you can leverage in your next performance review

components.text: Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT)

We know on some level that as employees we are consistently being evaluated, but it is very different to have a formal discussion around our strengths and weaknesses. Some bosses will have employees fill out self-evaluation forms as a precursor to these evaluations, and even that step can bring up discomfort and questions. You might wonder, “Should I be honest about how I feel about my performance?” “Should I hedge towards acknowledging all the growth and positive things I did over the past year?” Or, “Should I try for a more balanced approach?”

These questions can be uncomfortable before an evaluation by your boss. However, there are some skills and approaches that can drastically reduce anxiety and help you to feel better prepared and focused going into a meeting like this. These approaches and skills are important parts of Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT) — an evidence-based therapy that can help with high stress situations, created by Dr. Marsha Linehan.

DBT is based on the idea that some people struggle with extreme emotional responses, and that certain coping skills can help them find a middle path, or a way to tolerate feelings while staying focused on goals. Since yearly reviews can be emotionally fraught, DBT skills can be useful in preventing extreme responses. DBT also provides skills to manage painful emotions and decrease conflict in relationships, so it is well suited to help us navigate yearly reviews

One key element of DBT is “Interpersonal Effectiveness.” Interpersonal Effectiveness is all about being able to get along with others while getting what you need out of your relationships. It also emphasizes the importance of balancing your needs with the needs of others, so this area is particularly relevant in the context of yearly reviews
DBT often utilizes acronyms to summarize the skills and approaches it teaches. Here are three DBT frameworks to help you boost your interpersonal effectiveness for your performance review.
Use “D.E.A.R. M.A.N.” to receive feedback objectively
This framework is all about getting what you want out of a situation.

items: Describe what you want: Be clear and concrete in what you want out of this evaluation, or what you want over the next year.
Express your feelings: Don’t expect your boss to read your mind about how you feel about your job. Make your feelings known by using the framework: I feel _______ because _______.
Assert yourself: Don’t beat around the bush. Be confident in expressing what you need from your boss.
Reinforce positive responses: If your boss agrees with you or validates your goals or desired outcomes, a simple “Thank you” and a smile goes a long way.
Mindful: Stay focused and don’t forget the objective of the interaction. This isn’t the time to complain about minor coworker interactions. Focus on your own needs and goals.
Appear confident: Consider your posture, tone, eye contact and body language.
Negotiate a compromise: Knowing you may not be able to get everything you want, be open to negotiation, whether it comes to asking for a raise, other benefits, or areas you’d like to be trained in.

components.text: Master relationship effectiveness with “G.I.V.E.”
This framework is all about fostering positive interactions with other people and acknowledging other people’s needs.

items: Gentle approach: Don’t attack, threaten, or express judgment of your boss. This might seem obvious, but some statements can be misinterpreted, and remember: they want you to succeed!
Interested: Show interest in both the complements and criticisms offered in your evaluation. Don’t interrupt, and don’t get defensive.
Validate: Acknowledge their feelings, concerns, and questions. Try to respect their opinions even if you disagree, and try to recognize when your requests may be demanding.
Easy: Have an easy attitude. Try to smile and act lighthearted.

components.text: Learn to be fair to yourself with “F.A.S.T.”

Sometimes in evaluation situations people can become self-effacing or even betray their own values in an attempt to receive approval or get what they want. Using the F.A.S.T. technique can prevent these things from happening, and help you maintain self-respect during such interactions.

items: Fair: Be fair to yourself in these discussions. Just because you get criticism doesn’t necessarily mean you are a bad employee or that this is the wrong job for you. Try to get feedback from other sources as well for additional perspective.
Apologize: Don’t apologize unless it is warranted. Don’t apologize for making a request, having an opinion, or disagreeing.
Stick to values: Don’t compromise your values just to be liked or get what you want. Stand up for what you believe in.
Truthful: Avoid dishonesty such as exaggeration, acting helpless as a form of manipulation, or outright lying.

components.text: Well done!

Great work taking the time today to learn new skills that can help you prepare for your next performance review! Remember that a yearly evaluation doesn’t have to be a stressful conflict. With these new skills and approaches, a review can actually become an opportunity to create a better job situation. Your boss does not have to be your adversary, but can be a person who can help you get what you want and grow to be a better employee along the way. If you need additional support with work stress, feel free to check out the “Career” section of the self-care library or reach out to your Headspace Care coach.
Self-Care at Work

Work can be a source of accomplishment, fulfillment, and growth when balanced with your other life values. On the flip side, work can also be a source of stress when the demands of work or other areas of your life require more of your time and energy. We’ll walk you through some common signs of work burnout and offer some self-care strategies that can help.
This activity will:

items: Introduce why self-care is important in the context of work
Guide you through cognitive, emotional, physical, and behavioral warning signs of work burnout
Provide strategies for self-care to help you address these different warning signs

components.text: Why self-care?

It’s important to recognize that you are a human and that your value goes beyond your work output. Part of being human means that you need time to recharge and take the time to care for yourself. Self-care doesn’t just mean warm baths, spa days, or yoga — it also includes taking the time to balance your responsibilities and set boundaries. It can feel difficult to prioritize yourself, especially when you have others at work who are depending on you, but keep in mind that in order to work with and care for others effectively, it’s important to care for yourself first. When work stress builds up over time, it can be common to feel burnt out, disengaged, and frustrated. For caregivers, it can also be common to experience compassion fatigue, which is an inability to react sympathetically to a crisis or disaster due to overexposure.

Whether you’re already feeling overwhelmed with work or are hoping to take proactive steps to prevent work burnout, learning the different warning signs can be helpful. We’ll also walk through some specific strategies based on your warning signs.
Signs that you need self-care

Below are some different warning signs of work stress and even burnout. Take some time to review them now and select all of the categories (e.g., cognitive, emotional, physical, and behavioral) that feel relevant to you.
Cognitive

items: Intrusive or unwanted thoughts
Decreased sense of safety
Decreased trust in others
Difficulties with attention and concentration
Increased forgetfulness
Loss of hope

components.text: Emotional

items: Increased anger and irritability
Lower frustration tolerance
Depression
Increased feelings of anxiety
Emotional withdrawal from colleagues, friends, and family
Over-identification with certain consumers

components.text: Physical

items: Chronic fatigue
Increased somatic complaints
Headaches, stomach aches, back pain, etc.
Increased muscle tension
Physiological arousal in the form of palpitations and hypervigilance

components.text: Behavioral

items: Difficulty sleeping (insomnia or oversleeping)
Overworking
Impairment in day-to-day functioning including missed or cancelled meetings / appointments
Decreased use of supervision
Increased isolation
Chronic lateness
Increased absenteeism

components.text: Pick all of the categories that resonate with you:
Cognitive strategies for self-care

If you’re noticing some cognitive warning signs, it can be helpful to take some time to reflect on your perspective on work and potentially identify some ways to find more balance between work and all the other important aspects of life. Below are three questions you can use to start your reflection. Consider writing down your responses:

items: Would the world fall apart if I step away from my work for a day or a week? If it feels that way, what are some steps that are needed so that I can step away?

Are my expectations about my workload, responsibilities, and capabilities  reasonable and realistic? If not, what are some ways that I can reset these expectations (e.g., extending work deadlines, finding additional support, etc.)
What are my motivations for work? Are my expectations about the rewards and limitations of work realistic?

components.text: Emotional strategies for self-care

If you’re noticing some emotional warning signs, it can be helpful to evaluate your work relationships and identify ways to find the support you need. Below are some strategies that can help. Consider choosing one strategy to try out this week:

items: Set and keep healthy boundaries with others
Avoid making big decisions when you are feeling stressed
Make and maintain professional connections that include opportunities to discuss the specific nature and stresses of your work.
Reach out to trusted colleagues for advice and perspective
Identify sources of support for your work and use them

components.text: Physical and/or Behavioral

If you’re noticing some physical and/or behavioral warning signs, it can be helpful to take some time for yourself to relax and practice healthy lifestyle habits. Below are some strategies that can help. Consider choosing one strategy to try out this week:

items: Arrive to work on time and leave on time
Take your allotted breaks
Use your time off
Ask for help from others
Eat intuitively
Exercise regularly/engage in a physical activity you find pleasurable
Get the amount of sleep you need to feel refreshed every day
Balance work with other activities that provide opportunities for growth

components.text: Physical and/or Behavioral

If you’re noticing some physical and/or behavioral warning signs, it can be helpful to take some time for yourself to relax and practice healthy lifestyle habits. Below are some strategies that can help. Consider choosing one strategy to try out this week:

items: Arrive to work on time and leave on time
Take your allotted breaks
Use your time off
Ask for help from others
Eat intuitively
Exercise regularly/engage in a physical activity you find pleasurable
Get the amount of sleep you need to feel refreshed every day
Balance work with other activities that provide opportunities for growth

components.text: Mindfulness for Self-Care

Mindfulness is a skill that can help you manage work stress and practice healthy self-care. Mindfulness is not a relaxation exercise, or a way to avoid difficulties, or about achieving a different state of mind. Mindfulness is being present in your experience no matter how distressing it may be. You don’t necessarily need to spend a lot of time or meditate. Below are some specific ways to incorporate mindfulness in your daily life:

items: Reverse the order in which you do things
Change the way you get ready in the morning
Use your non-dominant hand
Use the mouse with the opposite hand, brush your hair with the opposite hand
Change up your routine
Drive a different way to work, eat something new for breakfast

components.text: Well done!

Congrats on taking the time today to learn more about how you can practice self-care in how you work. Remember that self-care is important towards finding balance and developing a healthy relationship with work. It can be as simple as taking a few minutes each day to reflect on how you work or even checking out a new activity card in your Headspace Care app to learn more. If you need additional support or want a personalized self-care plan, consider reaching out to your Headspace Care coach.
Separating Work and Home Life
How confident do you feel in your ability to separate your work life from your home life?

Whether you work from home or work outside of the house, it’s easy for your work life to creep into your home life over time. More and more, jobs are becoming remote, and even when they’re not, work is still accessible 24 hours a day through phones and computers. Now more than ever it is critically important to set boundaries so that your time away from work can be used to focus on other important parts of your life.
Here are some strategies that will help you:

items: Set boundaries when it comes to balancing work and home life;
Practice really clocking out of work when the day is done;
Start to see the value in prioritizing “you time.”

components.text: To separate work from home, try some of these tips:
Make a list of what you want to accomplish in the day, then reflect upon that list.

items: Starting your day with a list of things you want to accomplish can really help you be more productive with your time during the day.
Look back on your to-do list at the end of the day to see all that you’ve achieved. It can help you check out better at the end of the day.
If you don’t get to the whole list, that’s fine! What can you save for tomorrow and how can you prioritize those things next time?

components.text: Note your strengths and values outside of your work identity

items: If your work identity tends to consume you, it can be hard to let go of at the end of the day. So it’s important to really note the other aspects of yourself that make you who you are.

Take some time to note your strengths outside of work. This can help you tap into the value of investing in those strengths and not just your work strengths. For example, if your humor is one of your strengths, find ways to use it with friends and family.

If you are struggling with identifying your strengths outside of work, it might be helpful to reflect on your personal relationships and think about why people in your life love you. Most likely, those closest to you aren’t going to love you just for the value you bring to your work. Hey, there’s nothing wrong with even asking those people what they see in you!

components.text: Set a schedule or time limit for the work related tasks you do outside of your normal work hours

items: Just as it is important for you to be at work by a certain time, it is important to you to be out of work by a certain time. Often having a schedule to control this can really help.

Set a time that works for you to clock out. When this time comes, promise yourself to stop checking the emails, taking calls, etc. Turn your phone off, shut down the computer, turn off the notifications—do whatever it takes for you to give yourself back this time.

Use this time off to engage in other activities that matter to you. Connect with loved ones, relax, or take time for a hobby. Do things that strengthen your personal side, things that recharge you. Do things you enjoy!

components.text: If separating work from home is especially challenging and you feel like you’re always on, check in with your coach who can help you find more strategies tailored to your unique situation.
How confident do you feel in your ability to separate your work life from your home life?

properties.name: The Importance of Taking Time Off
properties.description: The Importance of Taking Time Off

components.text: The Importance of Taking Time Off

Taking time off to relax can help you reduce stress and stay energized at work. Still, it can feel difficult to take the time to unplug. It’s easy to find excuses for why you can’t take a vacation. This activity card will explain why time off is important and will offer tips to help you address those reasons so you can actually take the time you need.
This activity will:

items: Discuss common excuses for not taking time off
Offer tips and ways to address these excuses so you can feel less stressed about taking your time off.

components.text: Work-Boundary Types

Taking time off is an important way to restore energy and feel refreshed, which is a key part of your health and well-being. It can also help you return to work feeling more positive and productive. While there are a variety of things that get in the way of taking a vacation, here’s a few of the most common anxieties that people feel around taking vacation:
Select all of the thoughts that resonate with you, then we’ll show you ways to overcome these anxieties:

options.name: I don’t have the time/money to plan a vacation.
I don’t want to burden my coworkers.
People don’t take vacations at my company.

components.text: “I don’t have the time/money to plan a vacation.”

Booking flights, hotels, rental cars and coordinating with friends or family to plan a trip can be stressful — and expensive. While it’s inspiring to travel to new places, taking a staycation (i.e. taking time off in the place where you live) can be a relaxing — and inexpensive — way to spend your time off. You can catch up with friends, take a yoga class in the middle of the day or spend time learning a new skill or hobby.
“I don’t deserve a vacation.”

All too often, it’s the employees who work the hardest who feel like they haven’t “earned the right” to take a vacation. If this is the case for you, ask yourself if feeling this way is coming from a place of negative self-talk. You may be putting a lot of pressure on yourself to perform, and it’s keeping you from taking a break. If you’re feeling uncertain, be transparent. Try talking to your manager and ask them what they think. If it’s not the right time or if you need to put in a little extra effort, work with them to create a plan that will help you get where you need to be to take time off.
“My customers/clients need me.”

It can be very hard to step away to take a vacation, and this is often more difficult when you have people depending on you for care, emotional support, health, etc. It’s also challenging to break away when you care deeply about the work. If this is preventing you from taking time off, remember that tending to your own self-care will help you be more available when caring for others. It’s important to feel like you can trust that the rest of your team will carry the torch in your absence.
“I don’t want to burden my coworkers.”

Whether you’re on a large or small team, it’s hard to take a vacation knowing that your workload will be taken on by your team. One way to overcome this is to make a trade and offer to play a support role for them when they take a vacation. You can also try taking a few short vacations at first to see how things go. If you’re feeling burnt out, take a long weekend by taking off a day or two that week. Small, short-term vacations can make a big difference and don’t necessarily require travel or a lot of planning.
“People don’t take vacations at my company.”

Company culture also has a lot of influence over whether people take their vacation time or leave it on the table. To prevent feelings of stress or vacation-guilt on your team, consider normalizing the positives of vacation by asking your team members about what they’re looking forward to during their vacation and how it went when they get back. If you see others on your team feeling burnt out, you can also suggest that they take some time off to recharge. Everyone plays a role in supporting a culture that encourages time off.
Great job!

It’s important to take the time to recharge and care for yourself. You’ve already taken an important step today by learning ways that you can relieve common anxieties that might be preventing you from going on vacation. Vacation can help you come back feeling stronger, inspired, and more creative. Take a moment now to reflect on how vacation has helped you in the past. If you need additional support in putting together a plan so that you feel more empowered to take time off, reach out to your coach for guidance.

properties.name: Tips for Being Productive at Work
properties.description: Tips for Being Productive at Work

components.text: Tips for Being Productive at Work

Staying productive at work can be challenging, especially in the modern age of work with email, messaging, and phones connecting us even when we’re not in the office. Many of us face open-ended days of constant communication and switching tasks without knowing what to prioritize and when. Managing time, staying on task, and remaining organized can be difficult. It’s no wonder so many of us feel like we can’t stop working, even on evenings and weekends, and that we feel compelled to stay productive.
We’ve put together tips that will:

items: Help improve your productivity while maintaining your well-being
Help you stay focused
Help you feel more organized and in control of your time at work

components.text: Eliminate digital distractions.

Keep social media and other distractions out of sight. When you’re working, try to keep your phone in another room and turn off sounds and notifications. Or turn your phone off completely. Allow yourself to check social media during breaks and after work. Similarly, instead of constantly checking work-related emails, which can also be distracting, set aside two or three times during the day to check your email. Apps and extensions can help limit social media, news, and email use.
Create distraction-free focus time for work and breaks.

items: Set aside blocks of time when you’re only focusing on one task at a time without any distractions. Constant context switching can have a negative impact on focus, as doing multiple things at once requires your brain constantly to refocus. Consider using the Pomodoro technique—a time management tool to help you do concentrated work for a set period of time, followed by a break. If you do have lots of different tasks to do, try grouping similar tasks together.

When you’re tired or stressed, productivity tends to drop. Taking two or three 15-minute scheduled breaks during your work day can help replenish your energy. Have a consistent start and end time and step away from the computer if you use one. Move your body, or take care of basic human needs such as refueling with food, water, or resting.

components.text: Break larger projects into small tasks.

If you have a large project to tackle, break it down into smaller tasks. Then, break those actions down into even smaller tasks, until you have written down every detail that you need to do to complete the larger project. Once you have all steps listed, organize them in groups by order of importance, or time they will take to complete. Give each task an assigned time to be completed to meet the deadline. Delegate or eliminate tasks you don’t need to do. Instead of simply being busy, think of productivity as being busy doing the right things.
Move your body!

Periodically throughout the day, get up and move. This will be even more effective if combined with fresh air. If you aren’t able to get outside or move, consider changing your position. If you work at a computer, try using a standing desk, sitting on the floor or on a pillow, using a desk treadmill or bike, or sitting on a yoga ball.
Prepare snacks and meals outside of work hours.

Prepare ahead of time for distractions. If you anticipate being hungry or thirsty, prep drinks and snacks the night before. Have a few healthy snacks on hand, like cut fruit or vegetables that you can grab when you’re hungry.
Get enough sleep each night.

It’s hard to be productive when you’re tired during the day. Practice good sleep habits. Try to go to bed at a consistent time each night. If possible, charge your phone outside of your bedroom to avoid the temptation of looking at it before bed. (Check out Headspace Care’s sleep tips in the app or on Headspace Care Roots for more ideas for healthy sleep habits).
Reflect

At the end of each day, look back and ask yourself: what went well? What was challenging? What changes can I make to help tomorrow go more smoothly? Reflecting on your day provides you with data so you can assess what to do more often, and what actions aren’t serving you any longer.

Similarly, if you always feel tight on time, you can keep track of how you spend your workday. Doing a time audit can help you see where you're spending unnecessary time, when it might be best to schedule breaks, when you’re most productive. It can also help you identify common distractions. For three to five days, keep track of everything you do and how long you spend on each task.
Remember your motivation.

Keep a reminder at your workstation. Maybe you’re working towards a promotion or you want to get your work done so you can spend more time with your family. Knowing your “why” is important for staying motivated and focused.
Take time to get grounded.

When you feel overwhelmed, stressed. or worried, your productivity and focus can drop. Take some deep breaths. Try making your exhales two or three counts longer than your inhales. If something is on your mind, try judgement-free journaling.
Disconnect at the end of the workday

When work doesn’t have a clear separation from your personal life, productivity can suffer. At the end of the work day, physically separate yourself from your work tools and environment. Try creating a shutdown ritual that allows you to switch gears, process the day and decompress. You might want to work on a hobby, go for a walk, or listen to a song to separate work from the rest of your day.

Whether you work from home or go into an office or other workplace, separating your work life from the rest of your life can help prevent burnout and keep you focused during work hours. Remember to take care of yourself by getting enough sleep and exercise. If you find that you could use more help with getting or staying focused, reach out to your coach for support.
Work Boundaries

Boundaries are critical in order for you to feel safe, secure, respected, individual, and cared for in a relationship. While we often think of relationships as being with romantic partners, friends, and family, our work relationships also make up a big part of our lives and can influence us more than we realize. A common challenge faced by many individuals is navigating and managing relationships at work — and more often than not, the solution is setting clear boundaries.
This activity will:

items: Define two different kinds of work boundary types
Guide you through statements to help you understand your own boundary style
Offer reflections to help you better understand how you might adjust your boundaries to help you build healthy work relationships

components.text: Work Boundary Types

At work, our boundaries can directly impact success, work-life balance, teamwork, collaboration, confidence, ability to receive feedback, and more. An important way to assess your work boundaries is by gauging how porous or rigid they are.

items: Porous boundaries: Individuals with porous boundaries with their coworkers often have a certain constellation of personality characteristics that make them more of a “people-pleaser” or someone who depends on external validation to feel secure at work. This can at times drive them to take on too many responsibilities, become highly sensitive to feedback or constructive criticism, and be more at risk for stress and burnout.

Rigid Boundaries: These boundaries are so firm that they prevent people from connecting, negotiating, and collaborating. Folks whose boundaries are more rigid may struggle with requesting help, trying new ways to do things, and hearing feedback without getting defensive. Working with others, who may have different working styles, requires flexibility. Having rigid boundaries, without flexibility, can hold someone back from growing in their career.

components.text: Take some time now to answer the following statements to assess where your boundaries fall on the spectrum of porous to rigid. When answering, it can be helpful to use a specific incident or situation in which you allow(ed) your boundaries to be crossed or a time when you crossed a coworker’s boundaries.
Check all the statements that apply to you:

options.name: I tend to put the needs of others before my own
I tend to resent other people for being inconsiderate
I tend to look down on other people for being needy
If someone criticizes me, I will often doubt myself and consider that they might be right, even though deep down I know that they are not right
If someone provides constructive feedback, I tend to ignore their feedback

components.text: I tend to put the needs of others before my own

Individuals with more porous boundaries often put the needs of others before their own. In the workplace, this can surface as having difficulty saying no to requests, even when you already have a lot on your plate. This can also show up as being “always-on” and available to respond to email, Slack, and work messages, even during your time off.
Take a moment to reflect on this and consider the following:

items: What are you actually expected to do in your role at work
What are your work limits?
What are some things you can do to set better boundaries in these types of situations? (e.g., uninstalling your work apps from your phone or turning of notifications)

components.text: I tend to resent other people for being inconsiderate

Resentment is an emotion that can tell you a lot about how you’re feeling in terms of whether your boundaries might have been crossed. Individuals with porous boundaries may often feel this especially when they have not clearly defined and communicated their boundaries. Consider taking a moment to reflect on the last time you felt this.

items: What are some ways in which you could have more clearly communicated your boundaries (if you didn’t)? For example, if people tend to reach out to you while you are taking time off, consider reminding people before your time off that you will be unavailable.

Try to evaluate your co-worker or manager’s intent. Are they expecting an immediate response or can it wait until you’re available? It can often help to have an open conversation about communication styles and timing in order to set clear expectations.

components.text: I tend to look down on other people for being needy

It can be common for people with rigid boundaries to feel that others are needy when they are requesting help for something that is not your job. It’s important to keep your own boundaries and also find ways to collaboratively work with your team. Consider taking a moment to reflect on the last time you felt this:

items: Were there opportunities for you to be flexible with your boundaries, without losing them? For example, consider if this is a unique situation that is urgent or if this tends to be a pattern.

Have there been instances in the past where you may have needed support? The reality is that we are all human and we are all going through different life experiences that can impact how we work. Consider reflecting on a time where you may have been going through something challenging that required you to ask for help. Or, if you have not had that experience, try to think of how you might want others to respond to you if you were going through a difficult time.

components.text: If someone criticizes me, I will often doubt myself and consider that they might be right, even though deep down I know that they are not right

This statement is important and highlights whether porous boundaries are allowing your self-esteem to be impacted by the perspectives of others. Take a moment to reflect on a situation where you may have felt this way:

items: What if instead of abandoning that little voice in your head that says “hey that’s not right!” or “this person is missing the point” you get curious about the person’s criticism.  Can you consider that another person’s opinion or perspective could be a reflection of their lack of knowledge about the situation rather than the “truth”.  Ask them what brought them to the conclusion they are sharing.  See if there is room to clarify something or respectfully disagree.

A lot of times another person’s criticism of you has to do more with them than you.  Ground yourself with the knowledge of your value and what you bring to the table.  People criticize for a variety of reasons and many of them have little to do with the receiver of the criticism.

components.text: If you need additional support to build your self-esteem, consider trying out some of the activity cards in the “Self Esteem” category.
If someone provides constructive feedback, I tend to ignore their feedback

For people who have primarily negative experiences with feedback, it can be common to develop rigid boundaries that prevent you from hearing or benefitting from the point-of-view of others. Take a moment to reflect on a situation where you may have felt this way:

items: Instead of becoming defensive, get curious. What is this person trying to share by providing this information?  Is there something you can learn about the situation that has made them share this constructive feedback?

Commit to growth. We can only improve when we get feedback on what is working and what needs to be improved.  Make the assumption that the feedback is coming from a desire to support this growth.  Check in with yourself about the feedback and measure it against what you know to be true about your performance at work, such as your strengths and limitations.

components.text: Well done!

Today you took an important step in evaluating your boundaries at work. Did these statements make you think of other boundary issues you might have? Where might it serve you to strengthen these boundaries? Where might you need to let go a little bit?

As you process these questions, you may even find yourself wanting extra support or clarity. You can always reach out to a coach who can help you to strengthen the boundary work you are doing or consider documenting these reflections in a journal on a regular basis. The great thing about boundaries is that once you know where they are, you can play with them, push them a little bit, and find it easier to communicate about them with others.
Manage Workplace Stress and Burnout

Workplace burnout can impact your performance at work by making you feel emotionally and physically exhausted. When you acknowledge what is causing you stress, you can start to identify and use strategies to prevent burnout.
This activity will help you understand:

items: How setting boundaries with your time can minimize and even prevent workplace stress and burnout.
How to ease the feeling that your life is at work vs. you work at home.

components.text: Work burnout can creep up when you’re going about your everyday tasks and responsibilities. Acknowledging the signs of burnout is your first line of defense against it.
Here are a few signs you may be experiencing burnout:

items: You’re feeling cynical and critical towards work and your duties.
You rarely feel motivated throughout your week, making it hard to get tasks completed.
You are impatient with coworkers, clients, and anyone you have to interact with during your workday.
You aren’t performing at a level that is consistent or that you’re feeling proud of.

components.text: There are some reasons you might be burning out:

items: You haven’t created clear boundaries and you aren’t certain when your work day is ending or beginning.
You have stopped engaging with or enjoying things outside of work that are nourishing, meaningful, or inspiring to you.
There have been major shifts to your work environment or social life and you haven’t been able to adjust to the present situation.

components.text: Sustained levels of stress can be harmful to your overall well-being, your relationships, and your career. Take a step back to notice if you’re experiencing any of the following factors:

items: Fatigue
Trouble sleeping
Inability to make healthy food choices
Relying on or overusing alcohol or drugs to unwind
Depression and anxiety
Suppressed immunity
Heart disease
High blood pressure
Type 2 diabetes

components.text: Strategies to manage workplace burnout

Name it. It’s sometimes easier to reconcile our feelings by naming them. Have you been reluctant to just let yourself feel?  Sad, angry, frustrated, etc… Name it, claim it and don’t fear it.  Just naming and accepting the emotion can be freeing and can help you create more space to move through it.  Moving through it makes it possible to...
Create a strategy: Once you recognize the signs and symptoms of your burnout, you can start to think about how to revise your routine.
For example, you can:

items: Incorporate mindfulness and relaxation into your workday. Take short breaks to breathe, look at something funny, or check in with a friend.
Build up hobbies and create moments of joy outside of work to replenish you.
Find enjoyment in the little things. What are the parts of your job that you really like? How can you focus on those aspects more during your work day?

components.text: Once you assess these you will be able to:

items: Think more broadly about how you can create possibilities for self care, self advocacy, and healthy boundaries for work-life harmony.

Collaborate with the people in your life both at home and at work to lighten your load.  Allow other people to be resources to you. Find places where a little bit of “teamwork can make the dream work” for you professionally and personally.

components.text: For other ideas on how to separate work from home, whether your work at home or outside of the house, reach out to your coach who can help you manage your stress and come up with new solutions.
Gratitude List
Keep a gratitude journal to battle depressive symptoms.
INSTRUCTIONS
Note a few things you're grateful for. Family friends, the ability to breathe, cold water... write anything, big or small!
Please write it down on a piece of paper.
WHAT'S NEXT
Add to your gratitude list every night. While you're doing it, reflect on what's going right in your life.
WHY
Reminders of the good in your life can help change your attitude. Indeed, CBT has found that such journals can help with depressive symptoms.
Judgement-Free Journaling

Journaling is a great self-care exercise that allows us to put negative thoughts down on paper instead of bottling them up in our mind and body. Write down whatever comes to mind and let those pesky negative thoughts go!
Journaling offers relief
Did you know that the simple act of journaling can help you manage anxiety, reduce stress, and cope with depression? Journaling actually helps control your symptoms and improve your mood by:

items: Helping you prioritize problems, fears, and concerns.
Tracking any symptoms day-to-day so that you can recognize triggers and learn ways to better control them.
Providing an opportunity for positive self-talk and identifying negative thoughts and behaviors.

components.text: What should I write about?
Here are some quick tips to help get you started:

items: Start writing about where you are in your life at this moment. Describe your living situation, your work, and your relationships. Are you right where you want to be?
For five to ten minutes just start writing in a “stream of consciousness.” Don’t edit your thoughts or feelings and don’t correct your grammar. Don’t censor your thoughts.
Cultivate an attitude of gratitude by maintaining a daily list of things you appreciate, including uplifting quotes. When you feel down you can read through it for a boost of gratitude and happiness.
Maintain a log of successes. Begin by writing the big ones you remember then regularly jot down small successes that occur during the week. As you pay attention, your list will grow and inspire you.
Make a playlist of your favorite songs. Write about the moods they evoke. When you hear a song that triggers a strong memory, write down how you feel and explore that time and space of your life.

If there’s something you are struggling with or an event that’s disturbing you, write about it in the third person. This will give you distance and provide a new perspective. Write down what you learned about yourself. Develop your intuition.

Write down questions or concerns then take a deep breath and listen for a response from your Higher Self.  Let yourself write automatically. If you don’t get an answer right away, stay open throughout the day. It will come to you.

components.text: Write your cares away

Keeping a journal helps you establish order when your world feels like it’s in chaos. It helps you get to know yourself by revealing your innermost fears, thoughts, and feelings. Look at your writing time as personal relaxation time, a time when you de-stress and wind down. Look forward to your journaling time, and know that you're doing something good for your mind and body.
Positive Evidence Diary (Part II)

One very common finding in depression is attentional bias, or the tendency to notice and remember things that are consistent with one's negative mood. You can work against this attentional bias by keeping a Positive Evidence Diary.
FIRST
Keep a numbered list of all the things (big or small!) that you did successfully today. For example, maybe you woke up on time, made breakfast, spoke with a friend and put gas in your car.
THEN
For the next week, record these accomplishments every day.
WHY

If a depressed person feels "like a failure," he or she is very likely to pay attention to things that went wrong or shortcomings in the day. Work against this attentional bias by noting the things you did correctly or successfully—you might be surprised by the length of your list!
Keep a Success Diary

When we feel down, we tend to pay more attention to the things that go wrong during the day than to the positive parts. Noticing the good things in your day may help with your mood. Fight the impulse to only see the negative by taking note of your successes. You might be surprised by how many there are.
This activity will:

items: Help you be your own detective and track down evidence of the good things in your life—no matter how big or small;
Encourage you to record every success, big or small;
Help you make a new list of accomplishments every day for a week.

components.text: Strategy: Positive Evidence Diary

One very common finding in depression is attentional bias, or the tendency to notice and remember things that are consistent with one's negative mood. You can work against this attentional bias by keeping a Positive Evidence Diary.
FIRST
Keep a numbered list of all the things (big or small!) that you did successfully today. For example, maybe you woke up on time, made breakfast, spoke with a friend and put gas in your car.
THEN
For the next week, record these accomplishments every day.
WHY

If you’re feeling down, you’re more likely to pay attention to things that go wrong during the day. Work against this attentional bias by noting the things you did correctly or successfully—you might be surprised by the length of your list!
Forgiving Others

A common misconception about forgiveness is that when we forgive someone for something, it’s all about the other person’s experience or feelings. Forgiveness, however, can occur without ever speaking to the wrongdoer. Forgiveness is an emotional change that occurs within the person who has been wronged. It’s a process that takes time and that can help us heal from the anger or sadness we may feel, so we can use that emotional energy elsewhere in our lives.
This activity card will:

items: Explain what forgiveness is and how forgiving someone can benefit you.
Discuss why forgiveness is important.
Present a journaling activity to help you think about forgiving someone else.

components.text: What is forgiveness?

Psychologists generally define forgiveness as a conscious, deliberate decision to release feelings of resentment or vengeance toward a person or group who has harmed you, regardless of whether they actually deserve your forgiveness.

Forgiveness does not mean forgetting or condoning the wrongdoing, granting legal mercy, or reconciling a relationship. You can forgive a person while in no way believing that their actions were acceptable or justified. It’s a process that’s unique to every individual and situation.
Forgiveness can help you:

items: Give grace to yourself.
Embrace the peace of mind that comes with releasing that which no longer serves you.
Empower you to recognize the pain you suffered without letting that pain define you.
Increase your self-esteem and giving you a sense of inner strength and safety.
Stop the negative thought patterns that may arise when someone has hurt you.
Heal and allow you to move on in life with meaning and purpose.
Let go of anger, resentment, shame, and other emotions associated with an injustice, even though they are reasonable feelings.

components.text: Just as important as defining what forgiveness is, it’s helpful to understand what forgiveness is not.
Forgiveness is not:

items: Letting someone get away with something.
A sign of weakness.
Condoning or excusing offenses.
Glossing over or denying the seriousness of an offense against you.
An obligation to reconcile with the person who harmed you, or release them from legal accountability.
A quick formula you can follow.

components.text: Why Practice Forgiveness?

Research over the past few decades has revealed enormous personal benefits to forgiveness. Here are some of the most compelling benefits of forgiveness for individuals, relationships, and communities.

items: Forgiveness makes us happier. Forgiving others can make people feel happy, especially when they forgive someone to whom they feel close. Also, happy people are more likely to forgive others.

Forgiveness protects our mental health. People who receive therapy designed to foster forgiveness experience greater improvements in depression, anxiety, and hope than those who don’t. Forgiveness may also play a role in preventing suicide.

Forgiveness improves our physical health. When we dwell on grudges, our blood pressure and heart rate spike, which are signs of stress that can be harmful. When we forgive, our stress levels drop. Studies also suggest that holding grudges might compromise our immune system, making us less resistant to illness.
Forgiveness benefits relationships. Forgiveness can stop the feelings of distrust and lack of commitment, allowing us to repair our relationship before it dissolves.
Forgiveness is good for workplaces. Employees who are more forgiving are also more productive and take fewer days off, partly thanks to reduced stress around their relationships.

components.text: If you’re considering forgiving someone who has wronged you, journaling can help you think it through.
Do you want to try a journaling activity? We’ll share some prompts to get you started.
Here are a few journaling questions to help you think about forgiving someone.
What happened? How has it impacted your life?
Without looking back at the definition, how would you describe forgiveness?
What are the pros and cons of deciding to forgive the person who wronged you?
Whether or not you’ve made the decision to forgive, describe how things might be different if you decide to do so. Be as specific as possible.

How have you benefited or might you benefit by forgiving the offender? Consider how forgiveness has affected your emotional health, behavioral changes that resulted from the injustice, and time/energy spent thinking about the offender.
Describe how you have grown or what you’ve learned from this instance and your efforts to forgive. How has your worldview changed? Are you stronger than you were before deciding to forgive?

Forgiving someone can be quite challenging, but it can relieve you from difficult emotions and help you move past the incident so that you can spend your energy on the areas of your life that bring you joy. If you’re having trouble letting go of resentment, talk to your coach who can help. Also, be sure to check out another resource in the Self-Care tab of the app, Forgiving Yourself.

Forgiving someone can be quite challenging, but it can relieve you from difficult emotions and help you move past the incident so that you can spend your energy on the areas of your life that bring you joy. If you’re having trouble letting go of resentment, talk to your coach who can help. Also, be sure to check out another resource in the Self-Care tab of the app, Forgiving Yourself.
Forgiving Yourself

Carrying our past mistakes or regrets with us each day is an unnecessary burden we place on ourselves. Self-forgiveness is about letting go of the mistakes. It’s both an act and a process that emphasizes self-love and self-respect. It starts with the deliberate decision to let go of the resentment or pain we’re feeling. When a feeling no longer serves a positive purpose in our lives, we can detach ourselves from it and start the process of self-forgiving.
This activity card will:

items: Discuss the process of forgiving yourself.
Explain the steps of how to start forgiving yourself.
Go over the benefits of self-forgiveness.

components.text: Self-Forgiveness

When it comes to forgiveness, forgiving yourself can sometimes be more difficult than forgiving others. Often we are our own harshest critic and toughest judge. One reason it can be so challenging to forgive yourself when you know you’ve done or said something wrong is that your mistake often doesn’t align with your values or intentions. Moving through the process of forgiveness, you may find that you lapse back into old feelings of anger and resentment. It’s normal to have those feelings. Part of what makes this a process is reminding yourself again and again that you are choosing forgiveness. The good news is that it’s possible to successfully forgive yourself.
Where to begin:

items: Ask yourself, “What needs forgiving?” Acknowledge and accept the situation, including what’s causing the pain, hurt, resentment. Accept it without judgment or self-recrimination.

If you’re ruminating (i.e., thinking about it over and over again) and continuing to be self-critical over this situation, try switching up your inner conversation from first person to third person and consider how an outsider would see the situation. Consider how you might describe a friend who was in this situation. This can help cultivate self-compassion and help silence your inner critic.

Imagine how your life would be different if you no longer felt the burden associated with this situation—if you no longer felt guilt, resentment, regret, disappointment or shame. Imagine your day-to-day life without it. What would that look like? Make some notes.
Place your hand on your heart, breathe deeply, and consciously say, “I forgive myself for ______________________________.
Finally, say to yourself aloud or silently, “I release my attachment to this situation. It was part of my past, and today, I’m beginning anew.”

components.text: The Benefits of Self-Forgiveness

Take your time. Work through as many situations as you’d like, and look at the process as a learning opportunity. In self-forgiveness, it’s important to honor yourself as a person, with all of your imperfections. Forgiveness is all about you, and it’s an important part of your healing process. The more you practice forgiveness, the better you get at it and the easier it becomes. Self-forgiveness can give you peace of mind and a chance to move on to happier days.

Facing your own mistakes and shortcomings isn’t easy and is often attached to underlying beliefs about yourself, such as believing that you always say the wrong thing, or that you’ll never be able to achieve a goal. Self-forgiveness starts with addressing and reframing these beliefs.

Once you have established a practice of forgiveness, you may find that you have a better understanding of what it feels like to be at peace with your life, have more energy to focus on the present, and be able to be more mindful.
Journaling Prompts for Better Sleep

There are all kinds of reasons people can’t fall asleep at night: fear, stress, anxiety, caffeine, the sound of the jack-hammering across the street. While we can’t do anything about the jack-hammering, we can provide you with some writing prompts for calming your mind and letting go of worry.
This activity will:

items: Help calm your mind before bed;
Give you techniques that may improve your sleep;
Help you think about a bedtime routine that works for you.

cards.slug: Grab a journal or a piece of paper

components.text: Grab a journal or a piece of paper
Before you’re ready to go to sleep, write down your thoughts and answers to the following prompts:
What do you need before bedtime?

Everyone needs something a little different to help them fall asleep. Make a short list of what you need before bedtime. Maybe it’s a bath, a cup of tea, a dark room, a book, quiet meditation, or soothing music. Take a moment to figure out what you need and write it down. Stopping to consider what works for you can help you make a deliberate choice before bed.
Choose one thing you'll do tonight to improve your sleep.

Look at the list you made from the prompt above about what you need before bedtime. Can you choose one of those things and make a plan to act on it tonight? Maybe it’s making yourself a cup of tea before bed. Or meditating? Or speaking kindly to yourself? Or writing down things that cause you stress? Or focused breathing? Choose one and give it a try tonight. Set a reminder in your phone to do that one thing tonight.
Write yourself a note about something positive.

Some people find nighttime stressful. Ending the day can bring up anxieties. By telling yourself something positive, it can help you calm down. You can write about something good that happened in your day, something positive about a loved one, something you read about, a positive affirmation, or anything that will bring a smile to your face.
Write what keeps you up at night.

It may seem counterintuitive to write about what keeps you up at night before bed, but getting worrisome thoughts down on paper can help them get out of your head. Write down some of the things that buzz in your brain when you wish it was sleeping. What do you worry about? What events replay in your mind? Do you lie awake thinking about all the things you have to do the next day? If so, make a to-do list and leave it by your bed. It'll be there when you wake up, so you don't have to worry about forgetting it.

If you’re new to journaling or want to learn more about how it can help you, reach out to your coach. Your coach can help you incorporate journaling into your bedtime routine and help you establish goals around getting better sleep.
Taming Thoughts
In this video workshop you’ll learn how thought patterns can perpetuate stress and anxiety, and how to manage unhelpful thoughts.
From Scarcity to Abundance Mindset

Thanks to social media, news, and people around us who tend to be pessimistic, we may tend to notice what we’re lacking instead of what we have. This is known as a scarcity mindset, whereas paying attention to what we have is an abundance mindset. When we’re surrounded by others with a scarcity mindset, it’s easy for us to fall into that way of thinking ourselves. But, challenging the scarcity mindset and focusing on appreciation and abundance has benefits that can be truly life changing.
This activity card will:

items: Explain the benefits of having an abundance mindset;
Help you start to shift from a scarcity to an abundance mindset;
Form a practice of gratitude and appreciation;
Reflect on your progress to help you grow.

components.text: How an Abundance Mindset Can Benefit You

Appreciating what you have, rather than what you lack, has been proven to help in a number of ways. It can improve overall happiness, your relationships, energy levels, sleep quality, and productivity. In fact, one study showed that those who have a more positive, abundance focused mindset tended to live seven and half years longer than others.
Strategies for Shifting From a Scarcity to an Abundance Mindset
Start your day by reflecting on the positive things around you.

items: Wake up a little earlier to start your day off at a slower pace than usual. Use this time to notice the good that is around you.

Before getting out of bed, take a moment to reflect on how you feel and to engage your senses. For example, rather than focus on the bad night of sleep you may have had, appreciate that you have a bed and that you likely have enough energy to get through the day.

Most people start their day with a list of things to do, but try making a list of things you have that will help you enjoy the day. Maybe your list includes important relationships, resources, personal qualities, or material goods.

components.text: Practice showing appreciation for others.

items: One big indicator of a scarcity mindset is being critical of others. For example, maybe you view your co-workers as competition or you automatically don’t like your friend’s new friend. Finding ways to appreciate others is a good way to start to combat this mindset.

Start actively pointing out things you like about someone before you start to think of the negative. Over time, your brain will start to change it’s go-to thoughts of criticism as you continue to challenge it.
Thinking about positive aspects of someone else is a great first step. Take the next step by actually complimenting someone else.

components.text: Look back to notice how far you’ve come

items: Often we get caught up in wanting more that we forget how much we already have. Taking time to reflect on your life can help you notice what you have and how that has helped you get to where you are now.

Set time aside to really reflect back on your life, go back as far as you want. Remember that first apartment, your first job, your first relationships. Admire how things have changed and how you’ve always gotten by with what you have.

Reflect on your childhood or even the journey of your family through the generations. No matter how you do it, taking the time to really appreciate your path can help you build pride and remind you that you have had everything you’ve needed all along.

components.text: When you start to change your mindset from scarcity to abundance, you may notice your overall well-being and happiness increase. If you’d like support with any of the strategies here or support with developing an abundance mindset, reach out to your coach who can chat more about it with you.
Acceptance and Emotions
Acceptance means allowing things to be exactly as they are. It can apply to many situations, from grieving a loss to accepting a person for who they are. Acceptance can also apply to your emotions.
In this activity you’ll learn to:

items: Accept your feelings regardless of what they are.
Listen to your emotions and learn from them.

components.text: When it comes to your emotions, acceptance means allowing your feelings to be whatever they are. Letting anxiety be anxiety, letting irritability be irritability. It means not judging yourself for having negative feelings.

There’s one thing that gets in the way of practicing acceptance: the belief that accepting our feelings will keep us from changing. We think that if we choose to accept our bodies as they are, for example, we’ll never be able to lose weight. Or if we accept our stress, it’ll never go away.
This is precisely the opposite effect acceptance has on our lives. Far from keeping us stuck in destructive habits or negative emotions, acceptance actually allows us to create change.

Accepting your emotions when you’re feeling down can sometimes help you move on from them. But what does it mean to “accept your emotions”? And how do you do it? This mindfulness exercise will help you to practice accepting how you’re feeling in the moment.
Here’s why.

Our emotions have messages for us. They tell us that it’s time to slow down, pay attention, and hear their signals. They let us know that there’s something we want or need–compassion, or reassurance, or a sense of safety, for example. If we’re busy trying to avoid or fix our feelings, we’re missing the point. We’re not getting the message we need to get, and we’re not able to take good care of ourselves. So it’s by listening to those messages, not ignoring them, that we’re able to create change for ourselves.
In fact, sometimes all our feelings really want is to be heard. Simply taking the time to pay attention to them will actually allow them to pass a whole lot quicker.

components.text: Be in the Moment

Embrace the current moment by practicing mindfulness in your day to day routines! This simple mindfulness activity will help you stay present in your day to day activities. Paying attention to simple things like a shower can reduce negative feelings and help you feel calmer.
Mindfulness works
We're going to learn one easy way to find peace by staying present.
Studies have shown that practicing mindfulness in your every day routines can reduce stress, anxiety, and depression and improve relaxation and your overall wellbeing!
And these are just a few of the many health benefits of practicing mindfulness! Who knew staying present had all these perks?
So, let's find out how to find peace in your daily routine.
It's surprisingly easy

Think of a daily routine that you usually do thoughtlessly, like brushing your teeth, walking the dog or eating breakfast.  Next time you do this activity, focus all your attention on your senses and feelings.
What sounds do you hear?
What do you smell?
What are you seeing?
Pick up something. How does it feel in your hand?
Give yourself a minimum of five solid mindful minutes. If your mind wanders (it will, and that’s ok), gently bring it back to your activity. The more you practice, the more natural it feels!
What sounds do you hear?
Spend a minute listening to the world around you.
Birds, the wind, your own breathing...
What do you see?
Take a minute to look at everything around you.  Do you notice anything you hadn't noticed before?
Cards, dining table, clouds...
What do you smell?
Smell is one of the oldest and most powerful senses.  It can bring you back to memories almost instantly.
Rain, perfume, a garden...
What do you feel in your hand?
Is it heavy or light? Smooth or rough? Cold, warm, or neither? Think about the size, shape and texture.
Happy, Sad, Angry, Guilty...
Any time, anywhere
You can practice mindfulness from anywhere at anytime.  You can do it right now.
It really only requires you to become present in any moment.
Practice during lunch.  Stay present when you're on the bus on the way to work or school.  Really stay present as you make that first cup of coffee in the morning.
Again, the more you practice, the more being present becomes a way of life.
Your five senses are a great way to get in touch with the present.
Finding peace in your routine

Avoid negative and intrusive thougths by staying in the here and now.  Just pay attention to your routine like showers, brushing your teeth, walking the dog.  Focus on your senses -- what you hear, see, smell, etc.

Practicing mindfulness by paying attention to your senses in your everyday routines helps keep you present and grounded.  It's really simple and very effective technique you can practice anywhere at anytime.  You only need to remember to do it!
Introduction to Mindfulness

Mindfulness is about noticing and acknowledging your thoughts and feelings, regardless of what they are. It’s about looking at your relationships with those feelings. Mindfulness has been shown to have benefits on health and well-being and is used by millions of people in the U.S. and across the globe.
This activity will:

items: Explain what mindfulness is.
Teach you about the benefits of mindfulness.
Help you practice mindfulness.

components.text: First, do you want to listen to the audio or read along?
Ok, grab your headphones and let's get to it.

In 1952 at the Maverick Music Hall in Woodstock, New York, a young pianist had just taken the stage to perform a piece called 4’33” written by a composer by the name of John Cage. The musician took his seat at the piano, and then...nothing.
He sits.
The audience sits and waits.

This is an art-loving crowd. They’ve chosen to go to a recital of contemporary music, so they’re curious and open-minded. They’re at full attention, watching the musician as he readjusts himself a bit in his seat, listening to the wind outside blowing against the auditorium’s walls.
A couple of minutes into the piece, it starts to rain outside. Still alert and waiting, the audience listens to the drops of rain on the auditorium’s ceiling.

By the third minute, still no music. Some people start talking. Some even get up to leave. The rest of the audience listen to their echoing voices and footsteps. Still listening and watching at full attention.
Then, after 4 minutes and 33 seconds, the musician leaves the stage. The performance is over.

This performance turned out to be one of the most controversial pieces of art in recent musical history. It’s a piece that often comes up in conversations about whether what John Cage made was music or not music, whether it’s good art or bad art. For our purposes, we’re considering that John Cage’s piece, music or not, was in fact a great experiment in mindfulness meditation.
The Core of Mindfulness

Mindfulness is open, non-judgmental awareness of the present moment. We cultivate mindfulness by purposefully paying attention to the things we never really give much thought to, like the raindrops on the auditorium roof, or echoing footsteps in the aisle.
John Cage knew this: he’d been studying meditation for years before he composed 4’33”.

And he knew that as an audience, they had the mindset of meditators: they were open-minded observers, curious and at full attention. All he had to do was add silence, and he was able to direct the audience’s attention to the present moment, to all the sights and sounds they normally ignore

Today, mindfulness meditation is having its moment in the world of medicine. Mindfulness courses are offered in hospitals all across the country to help patients deal with everything from high blood pressure to chronic pain and terminal illness.
The Way it Works
Why does mindfulness work? What about this nonjudgmental moment-to-moment awareness actually makes us feel better?

Mindfulness can help us change how we relate to our negative thoughts and feelings. When we’re struggling with difficult thoughts or feelings, most of us relate to them in a reactionary way. We tend to think our negative thoughts and feelings mean that something’s wrong. We judge the thoughts and feelings we’re having, and then, we spiral down.
Say you’re feeling really stressed about succeeding in all the different parts of your life: work and family and friendships and whatever else you’ve got going on.
You have a thought along the lines of “I’m never going to be good enough.
Since you’ve had a stressful thought, your body responds. Your chest tightens; your stomach sinks. And then something else happens, something subtle and unnoticeable, but important.

Your mind believes your thoughts and feelings. It thinks something's very wrong, and it goes searching for what that is. This is when you start to spiral. Because now not only do you feel stressed, you feel stressed about the fact that you’re stressed.

Mindfulness asks us to treat our thoughts and feelings more like the weather. We don’t walk outside on a rainy day and think that the rain is wrong, even if we’d rather it wasn’t raining. We know that rain is a fact of living on planet Earth and we know it will stop raining. So, we put on our raincoats, and we get through the day.

In mindfulness, the idea is to treat our own thoughts and emotions with the same lightness. The same sense of acceptance. All of the hard, stressful, scary thoughts, feelings, and situations that happen in life are just like the weather. They’re an important, unavoidable part of life. We suffer when we judge ourselves for having these feelings, or we assume we’re wrong or that the world is wrong. We think our thoughts and feelings mean something needs to be fixed.
That’s the non-judgmental part.
The Present-Moment Awareness Part

By focusing on our bodies, our minds, and the present world around us, we separate ourselves from our uncomfortable thoughts or feelings. When we practice mindfulness, we’re like the audience at the 4’33” concert. We’re curious spectators of our thoughts. As spectators, we have distance from our thoughts. When we have this distance, we can begin to trust that we are more than our thoughts and feelings. We don’t need to believe them or take them seriously. We can just let them pass.
Seeing our thoughts from a distance without judgement does not come naturally. We need to train our minds -- which is where formal meditation practice can help.

Meditation practice typically consists of setting aside five to 30 minutes a day to train our mind to think in this new way. It’s usually done sitting down, though you can lie down if sitting for that long is uncomfortable. Since mindfulness is about paying purposeful attention to the things we don’t usually notice, in formal meditation practice we observe our breath, the sensations in our body, our thoughts that pass through our mind, sounds around us, and all of the other elements of our present moment.
When you meditate, think of yourself as a spectator. Be curious, be open-minded, and be ready to experience wherever your body and mind go.
