components.text: Mindfulness Practice Challenges

Mindfulness can feel daunting when you’re just starting out. You might wonder if you’re doing it right. Fortunately there’s no “right way” to do it. Here we address common challenges to practicing mindfulness, especially for those who are new to it.
Lost in Thought

There’s a commonly believed myth that meditation is about creating a blank space in your head where nothing enters or exits. But meditation is not about getting rid of your thoughts. That would be extremely difficult to do, especially for people who are prone to feeling anxious or worried.
Meditation is about noticing your thoughts, acknowledging them, and letting them go. The point of meditation isn’t actually to achieve some sort of state of unthinking.

Instead, meditation and mindfulness practices are simply about awareness. Really, it’s just a different way of paying attention. Mindfulness is paying attention to the present moment, being aware of your environment, of your physical state, and yes, of your thoughts.

Still, if you find yourself getting lost in thought while meditating, you’re not alone. It’s one of the most common challenges of meditation. Our minds are very active. Mindfulness just asks you to become aware that you’re actively thinking. Because, if you can do that, then you can start to gain a certain distance from your thoughts. If you can say to yourself, “this is a thought,” then you can also be aware that your thought isn’t necessarily reality or something you should identify with. Your thought is just passing across your mind’s awareness, kind of like weather passing across the sky. It might be raining right now, but you know it’s likely to be sunny again soon. Similarly, if you have a negative thought, then you can recognize that it’s just a thought and it’ll eventually leave to make room for another thought. The negative thought is just one of many types of thoughts that you’ll have in your lifetime.

You don’t need to resist your thoughts or try to make them go away. While you’re meditating, let yourself become aware of your thoughts, but also become aware of everything else: the silences, the sounds, the state of your body and your environment.
Here are a few other common challenges of meditation.
The Physical Side of Meditation

Have you ever had any trouble with the physical aspect of meditating? For example, some people have trouble sitting still–they end up feeling restless and edgy. Other people have the opposite problem–they find themselves becoming sleepy. Then there are those who find the practice of sitting to meditate to be physically painful.

Well, there’s a good reason for all of that. You know that feeling you get when you’ve been on a boat and you finally get off of it and it still feels like the ground is moving? It can happen after a really long car ride sometimes too. Sitting down to meditate can sometimes feel like that. Just because you’ve sat down to meditate, it doesn’t mean that you won’t bring what you were already feeling to the table. If you were feeling restless when you sat down, you’ll probably still feel restless. And if you were already exhausted, you’ll feel that too.

So...what should you do? Try to practice awareness of everything you’re feeling. If you’re feeling restless, pay attention to where you feel the restlessness in your body. What parts of you are itching to move? And if you’re exhausted, give your attention to that. Where do you feel the tiredness? Try to keep yourself engaged and aware of your exhaustion without giving in to it. If you find the practice physically painful, it’s OK to change how you’re sitting so that you’re as comfortable as possible. If that means lying down, lie down. Really, there’s no wrong way to meditate. You’re in the best position to become an expert on yourself and your well-being and how to make mindfulness work for you. The more you sit with awareness of what your body is feeling, the more you’ll recognize that just as your thoughts are passing influences, so are the physical sensations in your body. So, if you give the sensations your attention when they demand it, that’s a good thing. Just don’t identify yourself with the sensations. You are not the pain in your side. You are not the restlessness you’re feeling. Those are simply physical sensations that make up one part of your present moment.
All of the Feelings

The last big challenge many people have has to do with emotions. It can be quite challenging when big emotions swell up while meditating. If this happens to you, try not to resist feeling the emotions. Instead, practice acknowledging the emotion. If you can, name it. Tell yourself, “Right now I’m feeling really sad.” Try to find where you feel the emotion in your body. Try not to follow the story of the emotion. Just be with the emotion. If for some reason the emotion does become overwhelming, it’s okay to end your meditation practice and try a grounding or distracting activity instead. You can always pick up your meditation practice again the next day.
Other Challenges
You might have other challenges that are more specific to your particular set of circumstances. Most challenges to meditating can be met by simply practicing meditation and acceptance more.

In the Buddhist tradition, there’s a story about the Buddha inviting his demons to sit and have tea with him. The idea translates to a non-religious meditative practice too. You invite your thoughts, your restlessness, your tiredness, your aching back, your worries, your fears, and your doubts to sit down with you and have tea. You’re not giving in to these troubles, you’re simply acknowledging them, and approaching them with a friendly and open attitude.
Practicing Positive Imagery

Imagery is the practice of imagining something in your mind that isn’t directly in front of you or that you aren’t currently experiencing. Even if the concept of “imagery” may be new, it’s likely something you’re already practicing whenever you recall a scene from the past or try to visualize a task. Practicing positive imagery can help you feel more calm, confident, and prepared.
This activity will:

items: Provide an overview of imagery
Guide you through two positive forms of imagery and how to practice these techniques

components.text: What is imagery

Even though the term “imagery” may be new, you probably practice imagery already! For example, when you imagine the best driving route to the grocery store, you are practicing imagery. When you recall the scene from playing a board game with your family last week, you are practicing imagery. When you close your eyes and intentionally recall the image of a loved one, you are practicing imagery. This is different than simply having a memory. The difference is that there’s intention behind practicing imagery. Sometimes when we think of memories, we are ruminating on the past about things that “could have” or “should have” gone differently. When we practice imagery, we are trying to bring up an image, feeling, or memory in a more positive way, to help us re-focus on what we want to cultivate more of in our lives (e.g., happiness, connection, acceptance).”
Next, we’ll discuss two helpful types of imagery and give tips for how to practice them.
Calming imagery

items: Why? Practicing calming imagery can help to shift your body into feeling that you are safe, secure, and calm. Sometimes, thoughts can spiral out of control and lead to some pretty funky places. By refocusing your attention on calming imagery, your body may follow suit and calm down as well.

When? Turn to calming imagery before stepping into an anxiety provoking situation, while feeling anxious, stressed, worried, or tense, and when decompressing from a stressful situation. Many people find that practicing calming imagery in the morning and at night as part of a daily routine helps them to be prepared to practice it when stressful or chaotic times arise, which can happen when least expected.

How? Typically, people close their eyes and imagine a peaceful place, a calming color (light yellow, blue, etc.), a nice memory (taking a walk or cooking a meal with a loved one), or a calm feeling (for example, peace or happiness).

Fun fact: It’s great to practice calming imagery when you are actually feeling calm so that when the intense feelings of stress arise, you can more easily and quickly turn to doing calming imagery to bring you a sense of calm amidst the storm. When you know that a stressful situation is coming (for example, if you’re worried about meeting new friends, going to the doctor’s office, or driving in a car), calming imagery is a great way to calm your bodies and minds before stepping into a stressful situation.

components.text: Performance Imagery

items: Why? By mentally preparing and imagining a future situation that you will be in, you can better anticipate and plan for how you want to perform and act in the future.
When? Days or even weeks before an upcoming stressful event or an event where you want to perform well.

How? For example, imagine yourself standing tall and proud while giving an important presentation at work. Or, imagine yourself being calm and relaxed while going to the doctor’s office. Or, imagine the perfect golf swing for the upcoming game that you and your friends have planned next weekend.

components.text: Not-so-positive imagery and how to manage it

Sometimes we use imagery that does not serve us, like when we worry. Worrying is a form of imagery that happens when we imagine the worst possible outcomes of a situation before it happens. This practice is sometimes called “awful-izing” and it happens without us even realizing it. For example, it sometimes happens when…

items: We’re sitting at a red light and our mind wanders to the “what-if’s”
We’re waiting in line for our coffee and we’re thinking about the things that could go wrong in the big work meeting later today
The person we’re calling takes a long time to pick up and we wonder if something bad has happened to them.

components.text: We all worry and we all have the ability to use imagery in more positive and productive ways, rather than going down the rabbit hole of worry. Like anything, imagery is a practice; the more we practice, the easier it gets. To stop the process of “awful-izing,” try following the steps below:

items: Notice: When you find your mind wandering to negative thoughts and worry, try to notice this. Simply being aware of this tendency is an important and helpful first step.
Pause: Take a moment to pause and allow your mind to reset. If you’d like, it can be helpful to take a few deep breaths.
Practice calming or performance imagery: Once you’ve taken a moment to reset, it’s helpful to shift to a more positive form of imagery.

components.text: Great work!

Nice job taking the time today to learn about helpful forms of imagery. Imagery is a powerful practice that can help you to stay calm during stressful situations and prepare for upcoming performances and sports. This week, take some time to practice one of these techniques so that you can easily use this skill when you need it.

If you need additional support and mindfulness practices, check out the “Mindfulness” and “Managing Thoughts” topics in your self-care library. You can also reach out to a coach for additional support.
Body Scan
Here's what you can expect to take away from today's activity:

items: Learn a mindfulness coping technique for stress related to the body - aches, pains, and discomfort

components.text: Non-judgmental observation gives you a new, clearer perspective on your body as a whole, and an appreciation for the parts that are pain-free and strong.
As always with mindfulness practice, it works like this:

items: Find a place to sit or lay down where you won't be interrupted.
Have your headphones ready, and audio guidance will walk you through the whole practice.

components.text: Your Current Stress Level
How stressed are you feeling right now?
Grab your headphones and let's get to it.
Your Current Stress Level
How stressed are you feeling right now?

decreased.title: Glad you're feeling better.
decreased.body: Well done. The good news is your stress level went down after completing this exercise.

same.title: Your stress level stayed the same.
same.body: No worries. You can keep practicing this technique with different mental images, to see if you benefit further. You may also want to discuss potential changes or alternatives with your coach.

increased.title: Your stress level increased.
increased.body: You can keep practicing this technique with different mental images, to see if you benefit from different approaches. You may also want to discuss potential changes or alternatives with your coach.

components.text: Small Steps to Personal Growth

When you’re feeling down, setting goals for personal growth can fall to the bottom of your to-do list. In fact, feeling down and unmotivated can make it hard to do anything, especially the activities that don’t feel urgent. It can be helpful to remember that even when you don’t think you’re progressing, even just making it from day to day is a triumph.
This activity card will help you:

items: Learn how you can be gentle with yourself;
Create and recognize your forward momentum.

components.text: Talk to Your Inner Child

When you’re having thoughts such as, “I’m not good enough,” “I’m not trying hard enough,” “I should be farther than I am,” ask yourself if you would talk to someone else that way, or if you would talk to a child that way. Likely, you wouldn’t be hard on someone who is struggling, so why do you talk like that to yourself?
The next time you are feeling tempted to be rough on yourself, try talking to the child version of you.  Little you doesn’t deserve to be kicked when you’re already feeling down.
Positive Affirmations

One way to make small positive steps in your personal growth is to take just a few moments a day to remind yourself of the messages you need to hear. When you hear something, whether out loud, in your head, or you read it, you start to believe it more and more. So put good things in your head by being proactive about placing them there yourself. Just as we internalize negative messages over time, you can internalize the positive ones, too.

One great affirmation that can work for a lot of people is to remind yourself of the following: “I am doing the best that I can, and that is all I can expect from myself.”  Because it is true: what you’re going through, where you are now in your life, and what your mental health is like, you are always doing your best, and you should remember and celebrate that.
Prioritize Where to Put Your Energy
It’s impossible, of course, to do everything. In moments where there is too much on your plate and you don’t have enough motivation or time, try prioritizing.
Write down everything you need to do, and then look through those items and pick the top few that need to happen right now.

Which of the goals on your list are more immediate? What would make you feel better if you had it off your plate? What can be postponed? While you are making these considerations, also remember to consider your needs. When your energy isn’t limitless but your list is, you can choose what’s important to you. When you can’t do it all, what can you do?
Success List

Most of the time we don’t realize what we’ve accomplished in a day. A lot of what we do is more automatic, and without giving it thought we are also not giving ourselves credit. Instead of ignoring or disregarding your accomplishments, take time at the end of each day to note what you’ve done. Got out of bed? Check.  Ate a meal? Great. Talked to a loved one? Nice! All of these things are successes in your day, so don’t forget them!
Attention 101

Attention is something that many people struggle with, especially in the digital world where there are so many things competing for our attention. To improve your attention, it can be helpful to first understand how attention works in order to start identifying specific areas to target.
This activity will:

items: Guide you through what attention is and how it works
Explain the brain’s executive functions and how it impacts attention
Walk you through identifying key EFs to focus on

components.text: What exactly is attention?

Attention is the ability to selectively focus on one aspect of life that is right in front of you, and sustain this focus, while adjusting and modulating your brain to tune out other factors from your internal and external environments.

All of the information in your internal and external worlds is constantly competing for your attention. To make attention viable, people have to quiet internal and external impulses that are attempting to shift you away from your main focus. When there are many thoughts or activities that are competing for your attention, it can understandably be difficult to focus. In fact, the very act of paying attention can require real effort from your brain.
Your Executive Function

There’s actually a scientific name for that effort that your brain uses to pay attention. It’s called your “executive functions”  or EFs! Your EF acts like the conductor of a symphony. Similar to how a conductor must listen to and direct different instruments to create harmonious music, your brain also relies on your EFs to gather and organize information collected through all of your senses to complete tasks.
There are two major groups of EFs:

1. Organization: The first type impacts how we gather information and also how we organize, plan, and prioritize this information so that we can make evaluations. Some common activities that fit into this first EF category include:

items: Attention
Planning
Sequences of action (especially new sequences)
Problem-solving
Working memory
Cognitive flexibility
Abstract thinking
Learning about and understanding rules (social, school, work, etc.)
Maintaining what you need to do
Selecting relevant sensory information

components.text: 2. Regulation: The second type impacts how we use information to adjust, manage, and control our impulses and actions to solve problems and make decisions. Some common tasks included in this second category include:

items: Starting a task or action
Motivation
Self-control
Emotional regulation
Monitoring internal and external stimuli
Initiating and inhibiting context-specific behavior
Error detection and correction
Moral reasoning and understanding how your decisions affect a situation
Decision-making

components.text: Why do EFs matter?

So why do EFs matter? There are many different types of EFs and attention relies heavily on these EFs working together as a team. Sometimes when these EFs struggle to work together, as is often the case for conditions like ADHD, it can be really challenging to pay attention. Keep in mind that just struggling to use EFs doesn’t make you less intelligent or capable. Understanding how you pay attention and the intricate processes that are involved can help provide more insight into why it might be challenging sometimes to focus.
Tips to Refuel & Refocus

For people with ADHD, it can feel draining and effortful to engage your EFs and sustain attention. When this happens, it can mean that your senses are overstimulated and just need some time to be centered again. It’s important to refuel yourself when you’re feeling drained so that your EFs can function effectively to help you stay focused.
Pick one tip to try out this week when you’re finding it difficult to focus:

options.name: Set a 10-15 minute timer and try an activity that can help calm & regulate your senses again. For example, go outside for a walk, play with your pet, lift weights, play with a fidget toy, hold something warm or cold, rock in a rocking chair, jump on a trampoline
Break up your task into small chunks and give yourself small rewards after completing each chunk.
Visualize the longer term reward or outcome that you’re working towards.
Take a three-minute break to relax or meditate during or after your task.
Write down positive affirmations on a sticky note that you can refer to for encouragement throughout the task.
Set up a timer to focus on the task for 20-25 minutes and then another timer to give yourself periodic five-minute breaks.
Try to make the activity more hands-on. For example, if you need to read a long book or document, consider printing it out and writing quick notes in the margins or on sticky notes to stay engaged.

components.text: Remember that any new skill takes time to practice, so it’s completely normal if the tip doesn’t work right away. If you’d like, you can also come back to this activity next week and try another tip.
Great work!

Nice work on staying with this activity card until the end! Today you learned about your executive functions and how they play an important role in your ability to focus. Using your EFs requires many parts of your brain to cooperate and work together as a team, and this can understandably be a tiring task.
This week, when you’re feeling drained, try to take a moment to appreciate how hard you and your EFs are working and try out the tip that you selected:

Set a 10-15 minute timer and try an activity that can help calm & regulate your senses again. For example, go outside for a walk, play with your pet, lift weights, play with a fidget toy, hold something warm or cold, rock in a rocking chair, jump on a trampoline.
Break up your task into small chunks and give yourself small rewards after completing each chunk.
Visualize the longer term reward or outcome that you’re working towards.
Take a three-minute break to relax or meditate during or after your task.
Write down positive affirmations on a sticky note that you can refer to for encouragement throughout the task.
Set up a timer to focus on the task for 20-25 minutes and then another timer to give yourself periodic five-minute breaks.
Try to make the activity more hands-on. For example, if you need to read a long book or document, consider printing it out and writing quick notes in the margins or on sticky notes to stay engaged.
If you need additional ideas or support, check out the self-care library for some additional tips & tools to help you stay focused. You can also reach out to a coach for additional support.
Minimize Factors That Affect Focus

If you’ve been having a hard time focusing, there may be behaviors that you do and external factors that are impacting your ability to sustain your attention. A helpful first step towards improving your attention is to identify the potential causes so you can continue on the path towards better focus.
This activity will:

items: Identify behaviors and external factors that might be making it difficult to focus
Guide you through small steps towards changing these factors

components.text: Factors that impact attention
Below are some common issues that can influence attention. Take some time to select some of the things you might be experiencing:
Are you...

options.name: Not eating healthy or hydrating enough
Spending an excessive amount of time on electronic devices

components.text: Not getting enough sleep

Getting the right amount of sleep for you can help you focus, be in a good mood, respond rather than react, pay attention to your actions, and more. Not everyone needs the same amount of sleep. When you know how much sleep you need, it’s important to get an average of that amount over time. Research has also shown that it’s important to try and stick to a regular sleep schedule. So, for example, sleeping 10 hours on the weekend, but only 5 hours during weekdays means that on average you are still only getting an average of 6.4 hours of sleep per night. This type of sleep deprivation can add up over a long period of time if you are not mindful. According to research, the physical effects associated with sleep deprivation include increased weight, insulin dysregulation, and excess caloric intake after dinner.

Sleep quality, in addition to the amount of sleep, affects focus, too. Factors such as a sleep disorder (e.g. sleep apnea), restless legs, children or animals sleeping in bed with you, a partner who snores, regularly waking up at night, using electronics before bedtime, discomfort with a mattress and sleep clothes, room temperature, or drinking too much caffeine can interfere with your sleep quality, making you sleep deprived over time. This means even if you are in bed for eight hours per night, you can be sleep deprived by poor quality sleep.
The following are tips to increase sleep quality and get to bed on time:

items: Try to keep a regular sleep schedule. Go to bed about the same time each night and try to get up at the same time each day.

Keep your bedroom free of distractions and factors that interrupt your sleep. If your pets and children interfere with your sleep, then get them their own bed and train them to sleep in their own bed. Keep your room cool and quiet, and add white noise (e.g., fans, pleasant sounds, etc) if needed. Your mattress and sleep clothes should feel comfortable to you. Do not eat or drink two to three hours before bedtime. Try not to exercise right before bed.
Create a calming bedtime routine. Many people enjoy drinking a cup of soothing decaffeinated tea, reading a book, meditating, and listening to a bedtime story. Find something that you find soothing.
If you cannot fall asleep, then get out of bed and do something to calm your mind and relax your body. Try to stay away from electronics as this can make it harder to fall asleep.

Keep daily caffeine use at a minimum. Sleep scientists have found that caffeine can stay in one’s body for hours. Those two cups of coffee you had today can interfere with your brain’s ability to naturally sleep, even if you are asleep.

Limit or avoid drinking alcohol. Alcohol is a depressant that has sedative effects, but doesn’t cause a natural or restful state. Alcohol also blocks our needed R.E.M. sleep. Oftentimes, when excessive alcohol is stopped, R.E.M. sleep can have a “rebound effect,” meaning it may return with intensity and cause bad dreams.

components.text: It can feel overwhelming to incorporate all of these tips, so pick just one of the tips to try out this week. Once you’re ready, consider trying another tip.
Reflect on your sleep values

Many people have been in environments that “devalue” the importance of getting enough sleep. For example, college students often will pull “all-nighters” as if they do not need to sleep or will stay up very late to study. Try examining if you have lived a lifestyle that “devalues” sleep. How can you change your thinking to create and accept the value of sleep? Some of the thought restructuring tools in the Headspace Care app can assist you with making these changes.
Not eating healthy or hydrating enough

Many people do not know that some of the signs of dehydration are mental confusion, feeling like you are not able to remember what you need to, or feeling irritated or anxious. Headaches, dizziness, fatigue, chills, and loss of appetite can also be signs.

Naturally it is best to stay hydrated and drink enough water. The U.S. National Academies of Science, Engineering, and Medicine found that the average person needs 15.5 eight-ounce cups of fluids per day for men, and 11.5, eight-ounce cups per day for women.
People who exercise, sweat more, and/or are outside a lot will need to drink more.
The following are tips to make sure you stay hydrated and stay alert:

items: Always have water with you. Many people make it their practice to keep a 32-ounce container of water with them. Drink at least two to three of these per day.
Choose water over other drinks.
Add flavor to your water.
Eat food that is high in water such as soups, fruits, and vegetables.

components.text: Additionally, how and what you eat affects your brain. Not eating enough can cause low blood sugar. Some of the symptoms of low blood sugar include: mental confusion, irritation, nausea, dizziness, anxiety, light-headedness, and fatigue/sleepiness. When you eat too much you can also experience problems. These include sleepiness, inattentiveness, tiredness, and sluggishness.
What can you do to make sure your eating habits help you stay focused?

items: Pay attention to your hunger and fullness cues. Listen to these cues and do not ignore them.
Try eating smaller meals or snacks throughout the day to keep your brain going.
Pay attention and track which foods make you feel energetic and what foods slow you down. Know what works for your body and follow this wisdom.
Keep snacks near you so you can eat a quick snack as needed.

components.text: Experiencing stressful life events

Outside stressors may impair your ability to be fully present. These stressors can include parenting, traffic, caregiving, issues in the news, divorce, marriage, friends and family becoming ill or passing away, your own health, and more.
Feeling stress over external factors can affect your memory, your ability to think, to feel, and to be patient.
So what can you do to decrease feeling stressed?

What you can do to decrease your stress depends on a number of factors, including the stressor, how long it lasts, your sleep, and your support system. Below are some tips that you can consider trying out:

items: Develop a sense of spirituality or connection to something bigger. This could be joining a religious group that you have a connection to, meditating, walking outside in nature, talking to a trusted advisor about your spirituality, or joining a 12-step group. If you try one and it doesn’t feel right, try something else.
Find groups, meetups, and activities that involve other people. It’s important to feel you’re supported, loved, and that you matter to other people.
Talk to a coach. Coaches can help you work through traumatic situations, stressors, and teach you to manage the thoughts, feelings, and actions that make you feel poorly or unsupported.

Practice radical acceptance about your current situation. This does not mean you will experience what is going on forever. It just means accepting what is happening right now, regardless of whether you like it or agree with it.

components.text: Feeling physical pain or distress

Feeling pain can be overwhelming and cause you to solely focus on the pain and on finding relief from the pain. Additionally, many of the medications prescribed for pain can alter one’s ability to think, pay attention, remember, process information, and be present.
Here are some suggestions to help you address your pain:

items: Discuss all medical options with your doctor. Many times they can assist you with a concrete pain management plan.

Seek help from a chiropractor, naturopathic doctor, massage therapist, acupuncturist, or someone who does acupressure. An alternative medicine practitioner can provide solutions to pain management that do not involve pharmaceuticals.
Talk to a registered dietitian or nutritionist. Many registered dietitians or nutritionists can help you design a diet plan that can help to reduce foods that increase inflammation or pain.

Talk to a psychologist about the benefits of pain reduction with neurofeedback or biofeedback. These therapies involve working with practitioners to understand the feedback given to you by your body or specifically your brain (as in neurofeedback). Then the practitioner can work with you to reduce the body signals to decrease the pain or alter the way your brain might be responding to the pain.

components.text: Using drugs and alcohol

It is well known that alcohol and other drugs alter one’s consciousness, attentiveness, mental speed, memory, to stop paranoia, impair problem solving, and one’s ability to inhibit responding. Alcohol, drugs, even caffeine can stay in one’s body and brain even after they no longer feel the effects — sometimes for days.  Over time, relying on alcohol or other drugs can result in emotional and physical changes in the brain and body. Please be mindful and use them in moderation.
Here are some tips to decrease use:

items: Stay mindful of the fact that alcohol and many other drugs decrease your inhibition. When you drink alcohol or use drugs, you are more likely to keep drinking or keep using as you will not notice the effects, or you will be apathetic to the effects, especially if you are feeling good. This is the most common reason people will drink and drive. They do not believe the alcohol has changed their ability to pay attention. One way to be mindful is to pause and ask yourself before each drink or use, “Is this really what I want right now?” and evaluate how this might impact you physically, mentally, and emotionally.

Write down the statements that you often say or think when you drink or use drugs. For example, you might say, “You deserve it”, “You could use it” or “You need it”, “It helps you,” “It doesn’t hurt anyone,” “You are only going to have one”, “You need this to sleep,” or “It will help you sleep.” These “permission statements” often enable people to minimize the effects these substances have on them and lead them to believe they have permission to do something that may be harmful to themselves or others. Read the statements you have written down several times or say them in your head.  After this, you may start to notice these thoughts the next time you go to drink or use other drugs. It can be a clue to you to stop, think, and then decide if this is a good idea at that time.
Ask friends to help you notice. Your friends can provide support and keep you accountable to your goals.

Restrict usage to a minimal amount. It can be difficult in the moment to limit your usage once you start, so consider setting some small goals to reduce your usage. For example, one goal might be to only drink or use on the weekends and to keep that usage within the recommended amount.

components.text: Spending an excessive amount of time on electronic devices

Most people have electronic devices with them for much of the day. Researchers have found that use of electronics interferes with the ability to fall asleep at night, which can affect focus. The screens from devices emit an artificial light which can affect the normal physiological aspects of a normal sleep-wake cycle and suppress melatonin (the natural body hormone responsible for telling your body to go to sleep). Using devices before bed affects not only the ability to fall asleep, but also causes an irregular sleep-wake cycle.
Researchers suggest the following tips:

items: Limit your screen time. Stop screen time one to two hours before bedtime.
Create a bedtime routine.
Go outside. Take a light walk as a break from your device. Be mindful of the sensory information available to you when you are outside. Notice the greenery, or count your breaths.
Read a book. Choose a paper book rather than reading on a device.

Talk to someone. If possible, talk to a loved one in your household. If you find you’re using your device to avoid conversation, make an effort to challenge that. It can be difficult to start a conversation, but there are games and pre-printed conversation cards that can help create laughter and connection and boost your mood, which can ultimately help you focus.

components.text: Consider tracking your activity & reaching out to a clinician

If you are not experiencing any of the above, consider tracking your sleep, water/food consumption, sleep/wake times, alcohol/drug usage, screen time, recent stressors, and physical pain. Sometimes it can be hard to remember all of this information, so consider writing this down in a journal or on your phone. You can also ask trusted family or friends if they’ve noticed any behaviors or factors that could be affecting your focus.

This information can be helpful to help you rule out external factors that might be impacting your ability to pay attention and can also be helpful information to provide your doctor for further assessment.
Well done!

Today you worked on identifying some external factors that might be influencing your attention. It’s important to take the time to reflect on how different behaviors and events can affect you, so congratulate yourself for making this time for yourself today! It can be overwhelming to incorporate all of the tips you learned today, so try to just focus on one thing you can do this week. If you need help putting together a plan or staying on track, consider reaching out to your Headspace Care coach for additional support.
Transition Time Between Situations

Sometimes moving from one space to another can be pretty overwhelming. Leaving work at the end of the day, finishing up a stressful situation, or coming home from a trip can cause us to carry unwanted feelings from one place to the next. Practicing “transition time” can help us mentally prepare to shift situations so we can enter the new space with a fresh outlook.
Practicing transition time can help you:

items: Shake off the stress of a situation so it doesn’t bleed into your next activity;
Practice the art of “clocking out” so you can be fully present in your next situation;
Get in the habit of fully engaging in routines, roles, or tasks.

components.text: How prepared do you feel to handle transitions?
Tips for transitioning from one situation to another
1. Set a time to “clock out” or leave the space you are in.

items: Setting a time is a great way to start to establish boundaries for yourself. Boundaries can prevent you from overworking, which in turn can promote self-care.
Being consistent can be helpful, but sometimes it’s difficult to schedule your day down to the minute. Allow yourself to be flexible each day.

components.text: 2. Give yourself time to reflect on the space you’re leaving.

items: For example, before leaving work at the end of the day (whether you work outside of your home or inside), reflect on the day, what you accomplished, and take a moment to note that it’s ending. Prepare yourself to leave mentally.
Reflecting on the situation you’re leaving helps your brain start to transition so you can focus on the rest of your day.
Use reflection when leaving a stressful situation, getting out of bed, or any other change in your day.

components.text: 3. Create a small routine to do in between different situations or environments.

items: This can be a breathing activity, stretches, or listening to a favorite song.

When combined with reflection, a small routine can help your brain realize it’s time to transition and gear up for the next situation. It’s similar to how taking a shower or eating breakfast is a routine that can mentally prepare you for your day.
Keep the routine simple, but feel free to get creative!

components.text: 4. Give yourself time to acknowledge the space you’re entering.

items: In the same way you reflected on leaving an environment, reflect on the space you’re going to so your mind can fully transition.
Think about what you are about to do. How do you want to operate in that space? What do you intend to get out of the time in this new space?
This helps you not only fully leave feelings from the past situation behind, but it also helps you become more present for the moments ahead.

components.text: We often rush from place to place without stopping to think or appreciate where we are, what we’re doing, or who we’re with. Taking a moment for those in-between times can help you focus better and be more present throughout your day.
How prepared do you feel to handle transitions?
Escape the Productivity Trap

Many of us want to be more productive, yet we may be unaware that we’ve fallen into a “productivity trap.” The productivity trap is when our desire to be productive gets in the way of our happiness and well-being. Instead of falling into the productivity trap, there are tips that you can use to feel more satisfied with your productivity.
This activity will:

items: Introduce the concept of the productivity trap and its impact
Provide four tips that can help you feel more content with your productivity

components.text: The Productivity Trap

In this age of technology, it always seems like there's more to do. We find ourselves unable to have boundaries between work and life, and feel guilty for doing things like walking the dog or resting on the couch. If you don’t complete something or meet an expectation you had for yourself, you might even beat yourself up for falling short, constantly feeling like you’ve haven’t done enough and you’re unable to get ahead.

You might even see your self-worth tied into how much you accomplish, how much you have to do, and how in demand you are. If being in demand or being needed is what you use as a metric for doing a good job, then you can easily mistake busyness for validation. You might set unrealistic expectations for yourself and feel bad if you don’t meet those expectations. It’s a feeling that can get in the way of well-being and happiness, and can be referred to as the productivity trap, or productivity shame.
To avoid falling into the productivity trap, and instead feel more productivity satisfaction, let’s walk through some tips together.
Create process goals instead of outcome goals.

An outcome goal is a goal that brings satisfaction once it is complete, and is more concerned with quantity than quality. An outcome goal could be seen as busy work instead of important work. A process goal, in contrast, can give you satisfaction in the process. We often assume that being productive is getting more things accomplished in a shorter time. Instead, productivity is getting important things accomplished consistently.
An outcome goal, for example, might be trying to check our email constantly throughout the day to have an empty inbox.

A process goal is reading emails 20 minutes in the morning, and 20 minutes in the afternoon, with a timer running, and leaving the unread emails for the next time slot. A process goal makes us take action without worrying about the outcome.
Here are four tips that can help you feel more satisfied with your productivity.
Pay attention to your progress.

It can be easy to feel like you never do enough when you don’t see daily progress. Tracking progress on your process goals can help you see movement and can provide you with a sense of satisfaction. Additionally you can focus on the quality of your process, versus the amount of tasks you completed, and reward yourself for following the process and not for the output you produce.
Disconnect at the end of your work day.

Unplug, shutdown, and log off at the end of your work day. Have clear start and stop times. When you don’t disconnect from work, you’ll likely always feel like there’s more to be done. Physically remove yourself from the devices or location you use for work. Take some time to reflect on your day, be alone with your thoughts and process your day. Work on something non-work related that interests you.
Understand what “enough” means to you.

Without having a clear definition of what “enough” means to you, you can have no clear understanding of when we’ve done enough work for the day, and can fall into productivity shame for not having completed a vague sense of “enough.”
Create realistic expectations of what enough looks like for you each day. Everyone’s “enough” is different.
Productivity Satisfaction

Avoiding the productivity trap means redefining your definition of productivity to be about quality and not quantity. It also means disconnecting your value as a person to your accomplishments, busyness, or task completion. Constantly being busy and getting things done doesn’t typically translate to contentment. When we escape from the productivity trap, we experience more productivity satisfaction, and also more overall life satisfaction.
Make a plan
Nice work today learning about ways to escape the productivity trap! Remember that change takes time so take it one step at a time.
What’s one tip that you can try out this week? Consider taking a screenshot of that tip or writing it down so that you can refer back to it throughout the week.
Choose a tip that you’ll try this week:

options.name: Disconnect at the end of your work day.

Additionally you can focus on the quality of your process, versus the amount of tasks you completed, and reward yourself for following the process and not for the output you produce.
If this tip isn’t helping you, consider trying another or reaching out to your coach for support.

Take some time to reflect on your day, be alone with your thoughts and process your day. Work on something non-work related that interests you.

Create realistic expectations of what enough looks like for you each day. Everyone’s “enough” is different. Write down what enough is for you.

Define what productivity means to you from the perspective of quality, not quantity. Write down your definition in your phone or a piece of paper and keep it where you’ll see it often.
