properties.name: Strategies for Dealing with Racial Trauma

components.text: Strategies for Dealing with Racial Trauma

Racism comes in different shapes and forms, from overt racial slurs to more subtle, but harmful manifestations of racism like systemic limited economic opportunity. Being a victim of racism in any form can affect both your mental health and your physical health. Racism has been shown to be associated with depression, anxiety, PTSD, memory impairment, cardiovascular disease, and other conditions. If you’ve experienced racial trauma, you can take steps to minimize the mental and physical effects on your mind andbody.
This article will share a few strategies to help you care for yourself.
Seek support from safe friends or loved ones.

Focus on connecting with people who empower, validate, and support you. Distance yourself from those who minimize or dismiss your experience. Have open discussions with people you trust. It can help alleviate and normalize feelings of anger, sadness, and anxiety. However, be careful about having repetitive discussions with the same person, which may make your negative reactions worse.
Take steps to regulate your nervous system.

Repeated exposure to racism can be associated with chronic stress, which can negatively impact your health. Mindfulness, meditation, and relaxation exercises can help. Ask your coach to share a few if you’re interested.
Journal

Write down your experiences, feelings, and thoughts. It may help you move through painful emotional experiences, gain perspective, mobilize to take action, improve mood, and decrease stress. Keep it private, or consider sharing it with others if you’d like to use your story to advocate for change. But keep in mind that sharing your story may open up wounds or create additional vulnerability. If you’re wondering about whether to publish or share your writing, talk with a friend, family member, or mental health professional who can help you work through your decision.
Connect with like-minded individuals or groups.
Find a church group, a local chapter of Black Lives Matter or Los Unidos, or just friends who can validate your experience and offer comfort.
Practice resistance.

To combat feelings of isolation, helplessness, and hopelessness, try engaging in activities that promote change. For example, if it’s safe, consider protesting, create a sign to display in your window or yard, or boycott businesses or organizations that contribute to oppression. Signing petitions or supporting organizations and businesses owned by people of color can also be a powerful form of activism.
Nourish your body.

Racial trauma can sometimes make you question whether you should take care of yourself, or whether you matter. One way to remind yourself that you do indeed matter is by nourishing your body, getting enough rest, and engaging in regular movement or exercise.
Nourish your spirit.

Find ways that are culturally relevant to you to connect with a greater purpose, lifeforce, or belief system. This might include going to church, praying, attending a poetry reading, participating in a meaningful ritual, or meditating.
Listen to other people’s stories.
Podcasts by people of color can be a great source of inspiration, connection, and healing. Here are some of our favorites:

items: Emotions in Harmony Podcast
‘Between Sessions’ Podcast by Melanin & Mental Health
Brown Ambition with Mandi and Tiffany
‘The Nod’ by Gimlet Media

components.text: Parenting While Black

Protecting, nurturing and loving our children are common acts of good parenting no matter our race. But parenting Black children in this society adds unique layers of complexity. When our children step outside, a world full of beauty and opportunity awaits them, yet it’s also a world in which racism and white supremacy are a stark reality. As Black parents, we carry deep concern and fear for our children's safety, and we feel the weight of our responsibility to protect and educate them about what they may encounter.
Here are one Headspace Care coach’s strategies that have worked for her family.

Maybe they’ll be useful for your family, too. These strategies are not meant to be exhaustive, nor are they meant for one-time use. Parenting with intention is an ongoing and ever-evolving way of relating to your Black child and preparing them to take on the particular challenges they will likely face in our society.

items: Have your own version of The Talk. Come up with your own version of The Talk to prepare your child to navigate racism. Be mindful of what you want to share, how much you want your child to know about the issues, and what is developmentally appropriate.
Explain our history. Teach your child the history of white supremacy and racism. But also teach them the history of Black people, especially Black people pre-slavery.

Share the successes of other Black people. Tell stories and find age-appropriate books to read with your child. Remind them that ‘We live for the we’. This idea comes from the book of the same name by Dani McClain and perfectly articulates the notion that our lives aren’t meant to be lived without thought of others. We are a part of a whole.
Create a joyful home. Adopt the attitude that joy, in the face of racism and injustice, is an act of resistance and self-care that builds resilience. Laugh, play, and have fun together.

Teach them to manage their emotions, and model it. Remind your children that it’s OK to have hard feelings and that they’re capable of working through them. Show them how to do it by managing your own emotions. If you need tips, check out Headspace Care’s “Strategies for dealing with racial trauma.” Or reach out to a Headspace Care coach who can support you in your efforts.

components.text: Parenting Black children takes thoughtfulness and planning but also intentionality.  As you prepare your children for this world in which racism is a reality that they'll encounter every day, remember to  attend to your own emotional well-being and acknowledge any racial trauma you may have suffered. Take care of yourself so that you can appreciate the wonders that this world has to offer. But also so that you can authentically model joy and hope, and be your children’s living example of resilience, courage, and what is possible.
To read the full essay on which this activity card is based, please click [here.](https://headway.ginger.io/parenting-while-black-with-intention-5ac8a2b1e99a)
Physical Conditions & Mental Health

Your physical and mental health are inextricably linked. Studies have shown that people diagnosed with chronic physical conditions are at a higher risk of developing emotional challenges, whereas lack of mental healthcare can make it difficult to cope or recover from a chronic condition. Just like there are ways to improve your physical well-being, there are preventative measures you can take to care for your mental health.
This activity card will help you:

items: Evaluate your current mental health
Take actions to overcome struggles commonly associated with chronic conditions

components.text: First, assess your current well-being. People with a chronic medical condition are more likely to develop depression than people without a chronic condition. While a mental health professional can make a diagnosis, noticing symptoms of depression in yourself can help you address them, and can be a signal for you to seek professional help.
Do any of these patterns pertain to how you’re feeling currently?

items: Isolation, or the longing to be alone
Feelings of fatigue
Loss of interest in work, personal, and social life
A persistent feeling of sadness

components.text: If any or all of these pertain to you, keep reading for tips to help you manage these feelings.
For isolation…
Build meaningful and supportive relationships.

It’s tempting to isolate yourself, especially if you feel that none of your loved ones can truly relate to how you feel. However, having healthy relationships can help protect your mental health and improve your quality of life. Find family members, friends, or counselors you can turn to and engage with on a regular basis. Build meaningful relationships by being vulnerable and allowing others to support you in times of need. At the same time, remember that it’s important to reciprocate by serving others. Not only does it show others that you appreciate them, it also gives you a sense of purpose which could lead to a more fulfilling life.
For fatigue
Replenish and refuel your body with mindfulness exercises, a healthy diet, and sleep.
While there are different contributing factors to fatigue, the more common ones are stress, a malnourished body, and lack of sleep.

Stress is often caused by one’s lack of ability to control their responses to stressors. While it doesn’t completely eliminate stress, one way to reduce the negative impact of it is by practicing mindfulness. When a stressful situation arises, take a few deep breaths, acknowledge your discomfort, connect inward with the experience, and then take action to lessen its impact.
There isn’t a magic diet to treat depression, however, it can help to eat more nutrient-dense whole foods, and fewer processed foods, sweets, and fried foods.

Establishing a healthy daily routine that includes getting sufficient sleep can also positively impact your mental health. Try to go to bed and to wake up at the same times each day to create a regular sleep schedule.
For loss of interest in your work, personal, or social life…
Be intentional and incorporate activities that bring joy into your day.

When experiencing symptoms of depression, it’s common to avoid the things that may bring you enjoyment or meaning. This can send you into a downward spiral that can make you feel worse over time and can be difficult to stop. With a chronic condition, it may no longer be possible to engage in some of the activities that used to bring you joy. Adjusting to that loss can often be a difficult process that comes with heavy emotions such as grief.

A downward spiral is created by a series of small decisions over a long period of time. So, the way out of that downward spiral can be small steps in the other direction. Take the initiative to plan some sort of pleasurable activity at least once a day. If you are in a transition phase, try exploring and finding new things that you are capable of doing, and that bring you joy and provide you with a sense of meaning.
For a persistent feeling of sadness...
Create moments of happiness and gratitude in your life.

Although it’s completely OK to feel sad from time to time, it’s important not to steep in sadness for long periods of time. Try using this “self-soothe” technique: write three soothing activities that can become long-term habits, such as walking, meditation, taking a long bath, cooking, or whatever works for you. When you feel sad or depressed, turn to this list to remind yourself you have power over these emotions. This list will empower you to take care of yourself in a healthy, sustainable way. You can also keep a gratitude journal. Write down three things you’re grateful for each day, and reflect on the good in your life.

Understandably, strong feelings can sometimes be difficult to manage on your own. If you find that feelings of sadness or depression are overwhelming, try reaching out to a professional who can work with you to dive deeper into what’s causing these feelings, and create an actionable plan to regulate your feelings better. Don’t feel afraid to speak to a therapist who can help you with that. You can also reach out to a behavioral health coach, who can hold you accountable to your goals and get you on track to better mental health.
Honoring AAPI Heritage Month
A conversation on shared experiences within the AAPI community.

In this podcast, Headspace Care coaches Shobana and Mili chat about common shared experiences, the diversity within the AAPI community, and self-care strategies they've used to cope with racial challenges especially with the rise in anti-Asian violence.
First, do you want to listen to the audio or read along?
Honoring AAPI Heritage Month Podcast
Press play to start. Remember to turn up the volume or put on your headphones.
Honoring AAPI Heritage Month Podcast
Shobana:

Hello everyone. And welcome to our podcast in honor of AAPI Heritage Month. My name is Shobana, and I am the coaching community manager here at Headspace Care. And I am here with Mili and I'm going to let her introduce herself.
Mili:

Hi everyone. I'm Mili. I'm one of the behavioral health coaches here, and we are both excited to be sharing some of our own thoughts and opinions, recognizing how diverse the AAPI community is. And so we're going to be speaking from our slivers of that universe.
Shobana:

Absolutely. Thank you for sharing that. So just to give you a brief outlook on what we can expect in our talk today, we're going to talk a little bit more about what is AAPI month, diversity within the AAPI community, and then really tying it to the Asian hate that's been going on right now. How it's affecting the community, how the stigma and silencing can contribute and impact the mental health of those who identify with this. Touching a little bit more on the model minority myth and just going over some questions that we've prepared for each other. And then we're going to wrap up with some self care and the strengths that we can draw from our collectivist culture. Mili, am I missing anything else here?
Mili:
No, I think you've covered all of our ground, we're going to have an exciting chat today.
Shobana:
I agree. What do you think we should start? And is there anything you want to add to that before we get started?
Mili:
I think we should get going. I always think a good place to start in talking about our community is around vulnerability. So I'm going to turn it over to you to kick that off.
Vulnerability
Shobana:

Okay. Thank you for sharing that. So AAPI month is a month where we pay tribute to the generations of Asian and Pacific Islanders who've enriched America's history and have just contributed to the success of this country. We celebrate it in May, it's a month long thing. And I think it's great that we're able to do this podcast and are able to touch on some of the things that actually affect the community. And there's so much diversity within the community itself. And it's wonderful to see how we can all come together and really talk about these things. And one of the things that I've seen come up when I was a coach was the messages around shame and vulnerability. So what do you think or how does shame contribute to messages around vulnerability and what do you think are some of the cultural tropes or stereotypes of normative or conforming behaviors that you feel you must violate to survive or thrive in a dominant culture?
Mili:

I know we're just really starting at the top here, this is just a heavy loaded question, but I have given this quite a bit of thought over the years and generally speaking within AAPI, one of the things that we share is collectivism. Most of our cultures, not every single one, but generally speaking, have this really collectivist idea, which I think tends to fight vulnerability. Because within collectivism, conformity tends to be what binds us and keeps us safe and secure in each of our family systems or cultural groups or communities. And I think that's often the part that's missed. Within each AAPI identity in and of itself, whether it's South Asian, whether it's East Asian or Southeast Asian or from the islands, there's so much diversity intra, within each community itself. So in order to keep that alive and well, I think there's this overarching system of shame that keeps us quiet, that kind of shuts down us sharing our individual experiences, particularly our emotions that are maybe more uncomfortable or may come across as being whiny or complaining or negative about our own culture, our own families, whatever the system is that we're in.
The Model Minority Myth
Mili:

And I think, unfortunately, that's also created here in the US this additional burden because coming in many of our migration patterns have also created and fed this model minority stereotype. For those of us that aren't familiar, it speaks to this idea that Asian-American Pacific Islanders that traditionally inhabit space in the US have achieved a great deal, that they are very oriented towards success, usually determined by wealth or education, historically. So there's been this pressure, this idea from generation to generation to really thrive and to shine in those specific avenues. And I think that continues to feed a lot of the silencing that happens, because if we're supposed to be these models, we don't get to have problems and we don't get to complain about things. And there is this palpable sense of what can we do? How can we evolve and grow from there?

And even in my own life, I, a lot of times, think about the fact that so many of my mom's generation, in that era, really embraced the stereotype. They felt like this helped them stand out and it created a sense of security and safety coming into a new country. And then I see my cousins and my friends, in my own generation, the next step, there is this shift towards seeing it as less of a blessing and more of a challenge or a curse and a difficulty to overcome, because it tends to separate us from our Black and Latin X and other minority group folks that we could be banding with to overcome and have frank discussions about some of the discrimination and challenges that we face here in the US. So the difference, as different as each of these communities is, I think we can have a shared experience of otherness, of really being minority and different. That's my long-winded answer to your question, but I think it also pulls to a follow-up from there.
So to turn it back over to you Shobana, does silence honor cultural values, your cultural values? Is silence really the answer?
Silence & Communication in AAPI Culture
Shobana:

This is a great question. And I think, I just want to say that your answer to that was just really touching. And I really felt that because I immigrated to the US six years ago, and I definitely felt very caught up in the whole model minority myth, like I have something to prove or I have to stand up to be accepted by what seems to be the dominant culture. So it was very, I guess, I wouldn't even say refreshing, just very validating to hear that. So I appreciate you sharing that experience, even the experience of your parents. To answer your question, “does silence honor cultural values?”, I think this is a tricky question and there's really no right or wrong answers. I feel like. I grew up in an Asian country where silence was equated to being polite. It means, this whole term, silence is golden. I remember that being taught to us when we went to school. You were supposed to show up through your actions rather than lots of noise or speaking up. Speaking up was deemed as rude or just disrespectful.

And there were also messages around being silent when something was wrong, not the way we wanted it, because it was equated to humility. It was equated to respect and not shaming the person who has wronged you. So I feel like there are a lot of elements where we were constantly expected to take care of other people's feelings. And then this then contributes to further silencing of our pains or other issues that we may be experiencing. And when I think about it on a community level, it just makes me wonder how many of us grew up with that messaging. Like, you don't talk about your issues, you figure it out, you don't air your dirty laundry. You don't talk about the issues your family is going through because we were supposed to put up this front that we can manage things, that we can get through it and it should just be kept within the community. And I wonder too, did you experience something similar to that Mili?
Mili:

Yeah. I feel like for me, there's so much resonance, Shobana, on this idea of not shaming the person who's wronged you. I think that's something that's very familiar. And even in talking to a lot of my East Asian friends (I identify as South Asian), and so in even those frank conversations, I've heard those kernels come through. This idea that if someone hurt your feelings or there was some sort of offense, even social grace or something deeper than that, that we don't call attention to that and we don't make them uncomfortable. There's so much ongoing shame around “don't call out something you see that's made you uncomfortable.” You deal with it yourself in your own way. And if there is any reason to talk about it, there's one usually designated member, whether it's of your family or of your community that you go to. And sometimes it's a religious leader, sometimes it's just an elder, someone who's older and wiser, and you work it out and you don't take it up directly.

Because we're such an often - again, blanket statement about AAPI - we're a pretty indirect communication culture. Directness is not a big part of how we interact. So there's a lot of coded language and coded messaging in just how we go back and forth. The closest I can ever equate it to, I lived in Atlanta for a little while, is moving from the Northeast to the South. They say, “bless your heart” a lot in Atlanta. And I think to me, there was something very familiar about that because that's very similar to my experience of being South Asian, where there'd be underhanded messages of being really polite and saying something really formally in a way, but the underlying current is, “well, that was dumb, you've just made a huge gash, how dare you behave this way?” Really what it made me think of.
Shobana:

Yeah. And I'm thinking about, just with the recent uptick with the Asian hate and how I've heard from different folks about how they kept silent because it's a safer way to operate. It's safe for them to continue and when they do actually speak up, there's this shock from the outside world, about, “wow, they're actually speaking up about this.” And there's even this underlying message of “should we take this seriously or should we just continue being silent about this?”You know what I mean?
Mili:

I definitely do. I agree with you, there is often from dominant culture, even from another culture, this pushback to this idea of, “you're speaking, you're saying something about this, this is so unexpected.” The identity that's projected of AAPI folks is that we are going to grin and bear it, that we're generally not going to show up to fight where historically we're not seen as the ones that come out in protest.
Shobana:
Absolutely.
Mili:
It's a blanket statement and it's my personal opinion, but I do feel like for many of us that resonates. There's an idea of, yeah, that's true. We don't do that, that's not how we manage it.
Self-Care Strategies
Shobana:

Absolutely. 100%. And I think this would be a nice transition to talk a little bit more about self care strategies that we can incorporate as members of the AAPI community. I'm just curious to know what are some of your own self-care strategies that you feel has been a healthy transition for yourself?
Mili:

Oh, this is a good one. I really love this question because it forces a look inward. And I think this is that mashup of the Asian and American part. So Asian as being collectivist notion. And then to me, American as being this very individualistic journey. I like to really use, and again, this is from my own upbringing...there was such a tie in with religion and spirituality growing up for me. My family is actually South Indian Christians. It's a very specific subset of people, but that's the thing about being from a place like India. We're 2% of the Indian population, but there are a billion Indians. So they're actually quite a few of us out in the world. So one of the things that was really palpable for me growing up was how much support within the community there was.

So I grew up in this co-op in Mumbai. And when I was little, we'd celebrate Christmas because again, that's a huge Christian holiday and it was a big deal, but everyone else that lived in our co-op was Hindu or Muslim. And so they didn't have that tradition. So for me, when I think about self-care, there's this idea of community care, of connecting with, in this case, religion and spirituality, but also the cultural arc. So one of the things that I do at Christmas time is I make this rum cake that my granny used to make. It's of course, born out of the British Indian tradition, born out of this Christian tradition. There's so many things melding together, but it's not about making the rum cake, it's actually about taking it and bringing it to other people who wouldn't have it as part of their cultural identity.

So when I was growing up, we'd take it to mostly our Hindu neighbors or our Muslim neighbors. And then when their celebrations would come, when Diwali came around and there'd be fireworks and things would be blasting off, it was always so sweet because our neighbors would include us and they would always bring me firecrackers because in India it's a big thing that we do, and my family didn't celebrate that tradition. So it was such an inclusive and warm way to use these festivals and traditions and this idea of culture in caring for myself and recognizing and celebrating my heritage and my traditions. Even recently, during this pandemic, I actually ended up making a really good friend in my building and she's Chinese American. And Chinese New Year came around and she invited me over to come to learn and make dumplings with her, which is obviously not something I knew how to do, but I do now. And they were so delicious and it was such a beautiful tie back and throwback to self care in the midst of all this COVID related loneliness and isolation.
So I think, are there other experiences you've had Shobana that you want to connect back to that come to your mind as we talk about this?
Shobana:

Yeah, absolutely. It wasn't until I moved to the US that this term of self care, that was very focused on the individual, came about, at least for me, because I came from again, an Asian country, Malaysia, a very multiracial country. So when we see open houses in Malaysia, it often meant celebratory open houses, which means it's not like people are going to see a viewing of a house, it actually meant that when it's Diwali or Chinese New Year or Eid, folks are having open houses to have your neighbors over for food and drinks and just merriment and all that fun stuff. So it was always so nice to go around and hang out with folks. And so when I think about self care now...one of my forms of healthy coping, I found myself gravitating again towards community care. And that may even look like again, cooking something traditional, and then having my friends over or making a cup of chai in the evenings, just for me to have that space by myself.

It could even mean reading books by authors of color. Those were the ways that I found to just be, well, how do I say this? It has just been nice reconnecting to people that I felt also experienced the same things as I did, and finding self care within the culture, if that makes sense.
Finding the “Self” in Self-Care
Mili:

No, that makes so much sense. As you were saying that, I was just thinking about my Netflix queue through this pandemic. And honestly, half of it is Netflix India. I've never watched so many Indian TV shows as during this time, because it is such a throwback and a tie back. I don't often speak Hindi, it's not a part of my vernacular, even regular part of my life now, but there's this feeling of deeper connection and resonance, because language, again, so much gets lost in translation. So when we think about caring for ourselves, as you were speaking, it really struck me, Shobana. It's so true. The idea of self care requires an identity of self, for so many of us, that's not even reachable, that's not an attainable concept. What do you mean by “self”? I am part of “we”, this is how it is. So it's just a really interesting frame, and I think it brings it back to this idea of what are some cultural expectations that interfere with self care, that really get in the way. What do you think?
Shobana:

Wow, great question. Like I was saying earlier, this concept of self care came about recently when I first moved to the US. Because a lot of the AAPI values, at least from what I've observed in my own experience, are aligned with self sacrifice and doing what's best for others and for the collective good. So the concept of self-care is still a foreign term, especially for a lot of older AAPI folks. Like when I talk about self-care to my parents, they are so lost because there's a lot of internalized messages around rest and relaxation. Taking care of yourself may even come across as selfish, especially when it doesn't centralize others. So given the rich history of immigration within the community, a lot of them had to work hard. And as you mentioned already about the model minority myth, it can be so challenging to separate the self from constantly doing, from constantly achieving, from constantly performing.

So despite being here and away from my family for six years, to feel this sense of thriving, there's guilt that I experience from time to time, from having these opportunities to take breaks and practice self-care, knowing that not a lot of folks back home get to do that. But one of the things that I find, and this is, I would say, maybe a part of me that's radicalized, just reminding myself that self-care and getting rest and taking care of myself allows me to be more present. And that itself has fundamentally changed how I view care in general. And it helped me separate some of these long held associations I've had around rest and guilt. And I think it is something that the community can come together towards. So just encouraging folks. And we see our parents working hard. And it's one of those things of just reminding them, it's okay to put yourself first.
Shobana:

And while there's so many strengths to draw from the collectivist culture, they're also things that we can afford to unlearn and even learn where it came from. Is it the effects of just immigration and having to survive and having to adapt to a new country? Try to find ways to just come back to the self, if that makes sense.
Ongoing Self-Care
Mili:

It makes so much sense. I mean, I think the closest I am often able to arrive at this space is when we think about values that are held within our culture around things like meditation, for example. I think there are a few pockets of aloneness and self-reflection that are very much encouraged within our communities, but it gets lost along the way as we get really driven by achievements and as our roles multiply. And when you're younger and in your own space with just your peer groups, and then you start forming families of your own creation, and then there are more demands from family of origin, that creates all of these nested relationships. Which again, it is about the self because we are connecting to, but then it so quickly becomes about the other because we're so used to mirroring and turning the frame around culturally.

So I just love that you connected the dots in recognizing what an ongoing process it is. It's not a one-time thing where it's like, “oh, today I went and I got (because I did this today) I got my hair washed and blow dried, and that was just...I feel so good. I'm going to party.” I'm not going anywhere, it's a Tuesday, but I did that in order to just get some relaxation and feel really just calm and soothed and also a little bit pampered. That's the other thing, I think you and I offline have chatted about this before, we get so caught up in “it always has to cost money” or “it has to be something that's going to take away from something else.” Often it's as simple as just whether it's chai, whether it's that hot cup of steaming coffee, whatever it is, giving yourself this space for five minutes, 15 minutes (it doesn't have to be a ton of time) that's just your own.
Shobana:
So true.
Mili:

Being with your thoughts to breathe, to just chill out a little bit, without feeling guilty, like “I should be.” Like in your head you're already going through the list of things you have to do when you stop chilling. No you don't.
Support in AAPI Communities
Shobana:

Yeah, absolutely. And right as you were talking, this question came to my mind. What would you say? And I think this would be kind of a natural place for us to wrap things up as well and end it on a high note. What would you say are strengths that we can draw from our collectivist culture or within the AAPI community? What are some things that we can maybe...what are tools that we can use to help support each other and help support the community in general?
Mili:

I love this as a way to wrap up our discussion today, because I think it offers us a way to tie in so many other things we've been talking about. So, while I am acutely aware, trust me, of the cons of collectivism, because there are a few, one of the major pros to me is the fact that I don't have to think twice about picking up the phone and calling one of my aunties that I might not have talked to forever, but she has either an experience or a recipe or whatever it is that I can just do that without it being strange or unexpected. And it's so welcome and it's so hospitable, just the hospitality that's a part of our cultural network. And again, I think a lot of cultures have that and it shows up in different ways, but it's so woven into the fabric of all things AAPI.

You brought up the open house idea and I chuckled about it because growing up in my family, it was always around, we call them prayer meetings, but there was very little praying happening. It was just, it would rotate to different houses monthly, and it was an open house situation, you would drop in, there'd be food, there'd be conversation. And it would just be so warm and so inviting and a sense of closeness, that's a rare and beautiful thing.
Shobana:

I agree. And to add on to that as well, there's so much beauty and resilience within the culture and community that we can fall back on, just remembering that I find an incredible amount of strength reading books by AAPI authors. There's this deep sense connection that I feel seen and feel heard by someone else who's experienced this as well. So that's been one of the strengths that I find myself being drawn to. And of course, in addition to just going back to things that I felt I can connect to and feel close to within the culture itself. Yeah, I think we covered quite a bit today, Mili, and I think this would be a good place for us to pause. Do you have anything else you wanted to add?
Mili:

No, I think this is a great place for us to close this conversation and I would hope, and it's my wish, I know it's yours too Shobana, I'm not going to go ahead and speak for you collectivistically, that people go on to have some of these conversations. That whoever it is that's listening to this podcast that's nodding along or laughing, I hope, at some of the funnier moments that have come up, that they do take that and go on and use that as a connection point or as a launching or talking point around some of these issues to lift some of that silence, to unveil or unpack some of that shame, and to really use the connection of the community and the support within members of the community or outside the community, to gain and flex some of these muscles around vulnerability.

Because I do believe that's when each of us arrives at a place of valuing self-care and really practicing it. Because it is just that, it is a practice that is ongoing and is growing and evolving. So I'll leave it to you to close us out. But that's my wish.
Shobana:
Yeah. I can't top that. That was beautifully said.
Mili:
Thank you.
Shobana:

I'm not going to add anything, but I just want to thank everyone who’s listening in right now and who are here. I appreciate it. And please tune in to our podcast. If you have any questions, you can always reach out to our coaches to gain that further support. Thank you everyone.
Defining My Own Racial Identity
Sam’s story about her experience with racism and how she overcame her friends’ remarks to define her own identity.
Video: selfsea/Peer Health Exchange
Headspace Care activity cards that can help:

items: “Building a Firm Sense of Identity”
“Strategies for Dealing with Racial Trauma”
“Coping with Racism During COVID”

properties.name: Paving the Way for Black LGBTQ+ Folx
properties.description: Paving the Way for Black LGBTQ+ Folx

components.text: Paving the Way for Black LGBTQ+ Folx

In this podcast, Headspace Care coach, Shula Melamed, talks with Dr. J. Garrett-Walker about her research on identity development for Black LGBTQ+ emerging adults and Dr. Garrett-Walker’s own experience growing up and navigating the world. This podcast was originally part of Headspace Care’s storytelling series, Headspace Care Chats.
Biography:

Dr. J. Garrett-Walker is an Associate Professor in the department of Psychology at the University of San Francisco where she teaches African American Psychology, Psychology of Sexuality, and Research Design. She earned her B.A. from University of San Francisco and her Ph.D. from The Graduate Center of City University of New York. Dr. Garrett-Walker examines multiple identities (racial, religious and sexual) for Black LGBTQ+ emerging adults. Additionally, Dr. Garrett-Walker implemented a University wide Check Your Privilege Campaign that sought to raise student, faculty, and staff awareness around social inequalities and privilege. She has become increasingly interested in the ways in which shared educational privilege impacts colorblind racial ideologies and privilege awareness (i.e., white, male, class). The campaign went viral on the internet and has been implemented at universities from Canada to New Zealand.
First, do you want to listen to the audio or read along?
Identity & Black LGBTQ+ Young Adults Podcast
Press play to start. Remember to turn up the volume or put on your headphones.
Identity & Black LGBTQ+ Young Adults Podcast
Shula Melamed:

Welcome to Headspace Care Chats. My name is Shula Melamed and I'm a behavioral health coach at Headspace Care, and your host of this episode. My guest today is J. Garrett-Walker, a professor and developmental psychologist whose research focuses on multiple identity development for black lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, and queer emerging adults. Dr. Garrett-Walker utilizes quantitative and qualitative methodologies to examine the intersections of multiple identities, specifically racial, religious, and sexual identities. I talked to Dr. Garrett-Walker about her research, her life growing up, and navigating the world, and what pride means to her. It's my pleasure to share with you my conversation with J. Garrett-Walker.
J. Garrett-Walker:

Thank you for having me. My name is Dr. J. Garrett Walker and I am currently an associate professor at the University of San Francisco in the psychology department. I examine black LGBTQ mental health, wellbeing and identity development for Black emerging adults I guess I should say specifically, 18 to 29-year-old Black LGBTQ folks.
Shula Melamed:
Amazing, and what led you to pursue this path and what led you to work with emerging adults and what was the inspiration or the motivation?
J. Garrett-Walker:

Yeah. I mean I think that at the time when I was coming up through grad school, there was not a lot of black LGBTQ research being done. A lot of the research on LGBTQ people was focused on cis, white, gay men or focused on HIV prevention, which still primarily focused on the cis gay men, and there really wasn't much being done on black LGBTQ people, not much being done on trans folks outside of HIV prevention, and so I saw that there was a gap in the literature and I wanted to fill it, and I think that because of my own personal experiences, I knew that it was an important avenue or area to research and to explore and so there's a saying in grad school, your dissertation is me-search, so the joke is that everyone, when they go get a PhD, their research study is really about themselves and their life.
Shula Melamed:
Absolutely.
J. Garrett-Walker:

Yeah, even though it's not really about them but it's about topics related to their experiences and I would say that is definitely true for me and so I started to do that work in graduate school before my dissertation but in graduate school nonetheless and I just really wanted to one, make sure that the work that was being done was being done from a positive psychology perspective and not a pathologizing perspective. Psychology has a long history of pathologizing marginalized groups and I wanted to make sure to shift that rhetoric so that future generations of young black LGBTQ people could see the positivity, the resistance, the liberation that we engage in just by our mere existence, right?
Shula Melamed:
Absolutely.
J. Garrett-Walker:
So yeah, that's how I came to the work.
Shula Melamed:

Yeah, the whole research is me-search, right? I think that with a lot of ... You touched on something that I think is really important in research around sexuality and marginalized groups, which is not only focusing on prevention but also focusing on pleasure and promotion and empowerment and just really understanding kind of the strength in the stories and the joy of resistance and all of that, so that's incredible. So are there any specific moments or experiences or stories that you can share that stand out that guided the direction of this or was there a moment or ... Without getting too personal. Like obviously don't share anything that feels too personal but if there's something like a class or an interaction with a professor or with a colleague where you're like, “You know what? I need to definitely put a different spin on this or shine a light somewhere where it's just not being shone.”
J. Garrett-Walker:

You know, what's interesting when I think about that question is I think back to before I even got to graduate school. So at the time at which I applied to graduate school, I was just like this young, early 20-something year old. I had no clue what I was going to do with my life. I was on the precipice of graduating from college and I was like, “What do you do with a degree in psychology?” I had no clue, so in my mind, I was like, “Well I have no clue, so I might as well just go to grad school. Just keep going to school.” Well when you apply to grad school, you have to write a personal statement about what you want to do research on. Given that I applied to grad school and was thinking about my research many, many years ago, the time in which I was applying, it didn't really feel safe to say I wanted to do LGBTQ research. So I actually, in my personal statement, said I wanted to do research on black single mothers and parent-child dynamics, which I was absolutely definitely interested in, but I knew it wasn't what I really wanted. But I needed it in and I didn't want my desire to study LGBTQ folks to be the reason I didn't get into grad school.
J. Garrett-Walker:

So I actually didn't write about my desire to research LGBTQ people. It wasn't until I got to grad school where I was like, “Sorry, just kidding. I really want to do this instead.” So I think about one, that moment. Just having to make that decision to not even write that I wanted to do LGBTQ work and how I don't think that's the case now. I think that people can freely write about wanting to do LGBTQ research and it be welcomed. I think that for me, realizing that I couldn't write about that freely made me consider the fact that maybe I did need to be doing the work anyway. I think that once I got to grad school, like I said, there just wasn't enough research out there. I would write papers in grad school about LGBTQ issues, particularly as it pertained to the intersection of blackness. I could read books by Audre Lorde and I could read books by other people at the intersection of queerness and blackness. There weren't that many of those, most of it was like urban fiction if we did want to read that. But there just wasn't as much academic research.
J. Garrett-Walker

So that's kind of how I got there. I think that's kind of like the professional trajectory. On a more personal level, I think identity development is interesting. The first time someone asked me if I was gay I was 13, and I didn't even really know what gay meant and I didn't understand why they thought that maybe I might be. I didn't understand that I was either. I mean I came from a very religious family, so when I did begin to understand what that meant, what that questioning meant, of course there was a lot of resistance and pushback to it, although I really enjoyed holding hands with my friends who were girls. So it really was an interesting kind of experience growing up and not knowing that what you like is different, and then having to come to that over many, many years of denial or social oppression or whatever the case might be, just figuring it out. Plus young people don't know what they want anyway when they're 13, 16, barely 20, barely know what they want, and I think a lot of that also got me thinking about the importance of identity development. That we have to support young people as they are exploring their identities and what can we learn from them also. What knowledge do they already have that can contribute to us supporting others in their well-being?
Shula Melamed:

Thank you for sharing that. That's interesting how part of our identity development or kind of coming to awareness of ourselves is other people's perceptions of who we are and that can be powerful in a way that can be obviously the imposition of it, but then also maybe being like, “Oh. There might be something there, and what does it mean.” Do you feel like you had the support that you needed for your mental health when you were growing up and when you were an emerging adult and when you were figuring it out and figuring out how to develop the identity and the intersections of them?
J. Garrett-Walker:

No. Not at all. Unfortunately. I think that growing up in a black and religious family, there is no conversation of mental health. Because the cultural phenomenon is, “Well, you don't need to talk to a therapist. You just need to talk to Jesus. You just need to pray. You just need God or whatever.” I think that for many LGBTQ folks, that's increasingly difficult when the religious rhetoric is actually oppressive to them. So how can one who's navigating their sexual identity feel safe to pray or talk to someone who they feel is going to oppress them? So yeah, I definitely did not have the support. I think that my parents also didn't know how to navigate it. They did more harm than they did good, and I think that there are so many ways that parents and community members can support young LGBTQ folks better. I'm trying to find the right words. Because I don't want to say my parents were bad parents, they were definitely great parents, but there were things that they didn't know and I think that there are ways in which they needed to grow also and things that they needed to shift. Sometimes that happens with time, right?
Shula Melamed:
Right.
J. Garrett-Walker:

But I do think that there needs to be this dismantling of mental health stigma within communities. Because if we don't honestly talk about the ways in which mental health impacts us, even if it's the most small thing. Someone could not have depression, not have anxiety, not have anything that's diagnosable, but they could still have experiences that are taxing on their well-being. So we really need to think about how we could support folks, even outside of diagnoses.
Shula Melamed:

Yeah, and it's something that as you were saying, your parents can do the best they can, community can do the best they can, but at the end of the day, even ... You got all the way up to grad school and you're trying to figure out how to study this and to explore this topic and there was no literature. So the interest and the amount of information that there is available and what the effects of the intersections of all of these identities, what that means for getting mental health help, whether it's something more serious like a diagnosable anxiety, depression or internalized homophobia, other things that have different effects every single day that are unseen, that aren't immediately something that you're going to see in a clinic, but can affect people in other ways, so thank you for sharing that. So you did research and you wrote an article on resilience and depression amongst black LBG emerging adults. What were your findings?
J. Garrett-Walker:

Yeah. So it's funny, when we did this research study, well not when we did this research study, when I began to analyze the data for this research study, I was surprised by the findings. I think I already had my own kind of expectations and biases which you're not supposed to have in research but I mean we all come in with them, right? It's a matter of us checking them when we do realize we have them, and I was actually a little surprised by the results. So before I kind of talk about the results, I think that there's this notion in this country that people cannot be queer and religious. Like those two identities are often pitted against each other on polar opposite ends. But for black people, who are the most religious group in this country, you cannot necessarily separate them from their religious identity even when they are queer.
J. Garrett-Walker:

So the reason I did this work on lesbian, gay and bisexual folks, black folks who are queer and religious is because you can't untangle those identities. Black people are raised in the church, so their religion becomes very much a part of their community, a part of how they view the world, a part of how they view themselves. For many they develop their sexual identity along the same time as they're developing their religious and their racial identities. For some people the development of their sexual identity comes a bit later. But regardless of that timeframe, those identities are still all going to be there with that person as they continue to age, and so in my mind, I'm like, “Okay, I know religion has a lot of positive attributes and there's so much research on what religion does to someone's mental health and well-being.” It has shown through and through to be a positive resource for folks. But I also know that it can also do harm to people who are LGBTQ and so I wanted to explore that dynamic some more.
J. Garrett-Walker:

I think what I expected was that if someone has internalized homonegativity, that's how we talk about it in the article, now we kind of articulate it more as internalized heterosexism or internalized heteronormativity, I guess my thought process was, “Well if you have high levels of that, it won't matter. You won't have as much resilience.” But that wasn't the case. What we found is that for folks who had higher levels of internalized homonegativity, which basically means they had more negative feelings about themselves because of their sexual identity, and who were also high on religious faith had the most resilience. Which is not what I expected. I thought that people who were high on internalized homonegativity would have lower resilience regardless of their religious faith, but that wasn't the case.
J. Garrett-Walker:

So what does that actually mean? It means that religious faith is still supporting people, still supporting them with higher levels of resiliency, even when they have high levels of internalized homonegativity. The think about this paper that we can't untangle is we don't know did these people go to churches that used negative religious rhetoric against LGBTQ folks. We don't know if they no longer are part of a church, if they're still in a church. So there are some details that we weren't able to really articulate fully. Those are things that must continue to be explored with future research. But that finding was interesting that religious faith still protects people even when they have had these kind of internalized negative feelings. They still are resilient, they're still pushing through, they're still thriving even in the face of adversity.
Shula Melamed:

That's fascinating. That is so interesting, and it's one of these things where on the overall wellness wheel or when we do coaching and when we're kind of assessing how people are feeling about their lives, one of the areas of overall well-being is spirituality, and so organized religion or not or just having some kind of connection to a spiritual practice can really help people, can make them feel more resilient. But the combination with that and holding the homonegativity is really, really interesting. Did you get any qualitative information about that or that's what you think is the next step with this? To go to the next level is to just kind of see what the qualitative aspects of that are?
J. Garrett-Walker:

Right. For this study there were no qualitative components. I did do another qualitative study later on with black gay, bisexual and queer men and religion and it didn't answer this question about resiliency but I did ask them questions around like, “How has the church kind of impacted your experiences?” Many of them talked very clearly about negative religious rhetoric. So I articulate negative religious rhetoric as the words that churches use to condemn and oppress LGBTQ people through religious texts or religious beliefs, and a lot of them just talk about how when they read the Bible, they see love. God is love. But that's not what the church is saying, right? The church then says something different, and that was a discord for them. So I have another study that's more qualitative that starts to unpack some of this but there's just so much to still be done on this topic.
Shula Melamed:
Yeah, absolutely, and thank you so much for doing it and getting the conversation going. So kind of shifting gears a little bit, do you mind if I ask you a personal question?
J. Garrett-Walker:
You're good. I don't care. I'm an open book.
Shula Melamed:
Okay, perfect. So what was your experience like growing up in the LGBTQ and black community and having all of those identities intersect for you personally?
J. Garrett-Walker:

Yeah. I mean I think like for most people, back in my day when I was growing up, we didn't even grow up in a LGBTQ community necessarily. I think that for some folks, depending on where they live, there definitely was a vibrant LGBTQ community. So if you lived in San Francisco, if you lived in New York, yes it's possible for young people to grow up in LGBTQ communities. But for me that definitely wasn't the experience. I grew up in a very black community but then also a very non-black community, so it's interesting when you think about your communities as you're growing up. So my mom was a cosmetologist and so I always spent a lot of time with her and so I grew up in that community which is like black women space. And then I also grew up in the church, which was a predominantly black church. So I grew up in that black space. But my parents also moved us to a city where I was the only black kid in class. So I had these two separate communities growing up, this predominantly black community and this predominantly white community for school and education.
J. Garrett-Walker:

So I feel like that's a whole nother conversation around understandings of race and racism. I didn't really grow up necessarily in a LGBTQ community. I wouldn't say that I understood that there even was a LGBTQ community until I got to college and I went to USF, so being in San Francisco opens your eyes to things that you otherwise wouldn't know if you grew up in a small town the way that I did. So yeah, so I grew up black. I didn't grow up queer, and by the time I was adult age, 18, I did realize, like I said, that there was this LGBTQ community, and that's when the exploration and the fun and the parties ... In those days, it was very wholesome. Like I don't know, it was just very ... I don't know what it's like now. I mean there's nothing now I guess because of COVID but -
Shula Melamed:
Yeah, now there's a whole other thing going on.
J. Garrett-Walker:

But yeah, we would do school and then on I think it was like Thursday nights, we would go to the club in the city and it was fun and we'd come home and go to sleep and do our homework the next day. It was just like really chill and fun, but I think I learned a lot around the diversity of the LGBTQ community. But I also learned very quickly about the limited expectations too about gender and gender roles in the LGBTQ community that I think a lot of people don't talk about. I think there's a particular expectation for people assigned female at birth, for people assigned male at birth, for how they're supposed to engage or not engage within the LGBTQ community depending on their gender presentation. So I learned a lot of lessons I think as a young 19-year-old and had to make my own kind of decisions about how I fit or didn't fit within those spaces.
Shula Melamed:
Thank you for sharing that and I'm sure that yeah, San Francisco as an 18-year-old after coming out of where you were growing up was probably just like ... Wham, blew your mind.
J. Garrett-Walker:

I mean I wouldn't say it 100% blew my mind. I think because ... So I was born in Oakland, which is close enough to the city, but then when my parents moved us out further, so I think it was kind of far removed but I feel like when I was growing up, there was a lot of Jerry Springer and so I feel like you learned a lot from Jerry Springer.
Shula Melamed:
Yeah, you learn a lot for sure.
J. Garrett-Walker:

You learn a lot about the diversity of just human experience and so I think that once I got to college, it was kind of like, “Oh, okay, well, I mean I watched Jerry Springer so nothing can be as bad as Jerry Springer.”
Shula Melamed:

Nothing, absolutely nothing. Nothing could shock you anymore, right? Well I think it's interesting, now you work with emerging adults mostly, you said 18 to 25, so that's the age group that you're focusing on these days?
J. Garrett-Walker:

Yes. So I work with emerging adults I think because that's also another community that's often overlooked, but it's an age where so much happens. Like so much shifting in your worldviews and your ideologies and your identities happens during that time, and it's the perfect time to really explore how people become who they're going to become, or how they make changes even within that timeframe. Who you are at 18 is not who you are at 25 or 29, and so how those shifts happen as well are really interesting to me from a theoretical perspective.
Shula Melamed:
So how can black LGBTQ+ young adults turn a time of exploration but also confusion, uncertainty, and fear into one of action, collaboration, hope?
J. Garrett-Walker:

I actually want to take the responsibility off of the young people and I want to put the responsibility onto the community as in like the rest of the world. I don't think that it's necessarily their responsibility to make the best out of oppression. I think that oppression needs to not exist. So I think the call and the challenge is actually to the older generation, right? Like how are you all using language that is not supportive of these young people? How are you all enacting laws that are not going to support these young people as they get older? How are you continuing to oppress them through your microaggressions and your microassaults? I really think that that is where we need to put the focus. Put the focus on the broken system, not the people who are harmed by the broken system.
Shula Melamed:

Right, let the emerging adults experience and give them the opportunities to play and to experience and to not feel afraid for their lives and for their rights and really experience life. Protect them and promote them, right?
J. Garrett-Walker:
And we can even talk about even younger than emerging adults, right? I mean there are so many queer youth, young people.
Shula Melamed:
Absolutely. Yeah.
J. Garrett-Walker:

I think because we're at a place in our culture where there is more access to LGBTQ content, whether that's social media or television or books, kids are realizing, “Oh wow.” 13-year-olds now are not like, “Oh. It's not normal for girls to hold hands with other girls?” They're like, “No, it's totally normal for girls to hold hands with girls and I want to hold hands with girls.“ So I think they're at a different place and so it's easier for them to now identify much younger and they need to be supported also. Similarly for trans youth. I mean trans folks have existed since the beginning of time. Colonization made us forget that, and so I think that we also need to stop pathologizing trans youth and making trans youth feel like they're not old enough to make informed decisions about their gender identity because we know that by age three through research that children are very clear about their gender identity, and that research has been consistent and persistent for decades.
Shula Melamed:

Yeah, and what's so interesting is that as there is more of a ... As you said, trans folks have been with us since the beginning of time, right? It's not something new, right? This is part of our human community, it's just the truth. But as more awareness comes, there are opportunities for people to support one another but then I just can't imagine what it's like for trans kids these days with all these bills, you can't play in sports, you can't do this. So there's just that awkward thing that happens all the time when people are fighting for their rights and when people are becoming recognized, where it's just like, “Okay, recognition is needed,” and then all of a sudden boom, here, okay, let's find legislation or let's find a way to put a cap on this and not actually allow it to happen. So the more you're aware of your ability to express yourself a little bit more, the more that you're recognized a little bit more, then comes even more challenges. So that's just something where it's like we have to protect all of our kids.
J. Garrett-Walker:
Absolutely. Absolutely agree with that.
Shula Melamed:

So how can people in marginalized communities ... I know this is going to be making the spaces for marginalized communities to come together and create environments where they can share their mental health stories. Is there anything in your experience like with the emerging adults and even thinking about kids who are younger, what are the environments that seem to be the most supportive and interesting and freeing for these folks?
J. Garrett-Walker:

I think it just really depends on where they live. I can sit here and say LGBTQ centers, I can say the ballroom scene, I can say gay-straight alliances. But realistically, that's not helpful for all young people because that is a very urban experience. When you live on the coast, you're more likely to ... Well, not even the whole coast. When you live in San Francisco, when you live in New York, when you live in other “progressive” cities, you're more likely to see these spaces be created because it feels safer to do so. Unfortunately, where we are now in 2021, nowhere is really safe. Like you said, there's so much legislation happening that's trying to continue to marginalize these young folks. But I think that one of the strongholds of the LGBTQ community and the black community has always been working together. Coming together, telling stories, laughing together, being in community with each other. I think that is how we've thrived over all these years. Even if we just think about how pride even started, like this whole idea of the cafeteria riots in the city in Stonewall in New York, those happened because a bunch of people were already hanging out, partying, having fun, and then they were tired of the oppression, so they responded.
J. Garrett-Walker:

We've always worked together in these communities to support each other. I think that in the digital age, it's actually becoming a lot easier, especially to support young people who live in areas that are not the urban metropolises. They now have access to each other through Facebook groups and Instagram pages and I don't know what these kids do, Snapchat and TikTok, right?
Shula Melamed:
TikTok dances.
J. Garrett-Walker:

All these things where they can find each other, and see each other, and sometimes just seeing another person that looks like you is liberating and freeing and gives you a lot of help to support your mental health, to just know you're not alone. Like if you're a kid who's 14 and you live in ... I don't know, Arkansas, I don't know, I have never been to Arkansas, but I assume that it's probably not the most progressive state.
Shula Melamed:
I don't think so, yeah.
J. Garrett-Walker:

So you live in Arkansas and you just happen to run across a few Instagram pages with a bunch of queer young folks, you're going to be like ... Wow, I'm not alone. I think there's a lot of ways in which we can build community. But again, I'm going to say this like I said to the last question, they shouldn't have to be the ones to make the spaces. The spaces should already be provided for them. Ideally we should live in a world where the space is not needed because every space would be a space where they could have these conversations. I will say that I think as a whole in the United States we need to do better with mental health in general. I don't really think that there's any place in the United States where you can talk freely about mental health without somebody making a statement that's problematic, pathologizing. So I think we need to do better as a country in general with dismantling mental health stigma. Making mental health more accessible. Making mental health covered by insurance, right? Like there's just so many things that we can do as a country to make mental health normalized so that people can have these conversations freely and not feel strange or oppressed because they want to share their truth with their friends, with their parents, with their aunts, with whoever, with their partner.
Shula Melamed:

And also, I was thinking about just like the long shadow cast by just psychology and mental health and with regard to sexuality in general and with ... I mean homosexuality was in the DSM as a disorder not that long ... I mean how many years ago was it? It was like 20 years ago or 30 years ago? It was longer than that, but it was like the 70s. That's really not that long ago.
J. Garrett-Walker:

Not that long ago at all, and I think that the field of psychology is definitely working to undo a lot of the damage that it has done. Right? Like actively working to make sure that conversion therapy is illegal, actively working to make guidelines for sex and sexuality. We have an entire division dedicated to LGBTQ folk issues within the American Psychological Association and there are some other working groups within the organization that are LGBTQ focused. So I definitely think that at least in the United States, the American Psychological Association is aware of their past doings and trauma. However, I will say I think that there's only so much the American Psychological Association can do if the people in the training programs aren't training the next cycle of therapists to have this knowledge. So I'm not a therapist, so let me preface all of this by saying I am not a therapist, I am a researcher. But I do know that there are some folks who finish their entire degrees and never take a class on LGBTQ issues. Like they never take a class on supporting black people, indigenous people, Latinx people. Like there's just not enough cultural awareness, even within these programs, to ensure that the therapists are qualified to support groups who are historically marginalized. I feel like I didn't answer your question also.
Shula Melamed:

No no no, I felt that some of the damage is being undone but there's also so much more work to do and I think that that's true. It's like again, it's like a systemic thing through the academy, through the training programs, where there's also like how do you not learn about sexuality? How do you not learn about how cultural ... I don't even want to say cultural competency but cultural sensitivity or awareness. That is something that is huge, and that's something that needs to be worked on. Like it should be in the classroom, it should be in your program, it should be as you're being trained, but where are there other opportunities to learn that? And to think that that is important too. That's really important.
J. Garrett-Walker:

And it shouldn't just be like one class. It should be infused in the entire curriculum. I think that so many of these institutions like, “Oh, we're so progressive because we have this one class on LGBTQ or we have this one class on blackness,” and it's like, “No actually, race and racism and heterosexism and cissexism and transphobia needs to be woven into your entire curriculum from top to bottom. Class number one to the very last class that students take. Every class should be talking about this, these intersections, about these identities, about the oppression, about all of it.” It needs to be woven in, not just trickled in.
Shula Melamed:

Right, and how that comes out in mental health ... I don't want to say mental health futures, but like how it affects a person's lived experience and how that can be pathologized or that there's a temptation to pathologize these things as opposed to trying to understand where is this anxiety coming from? Of course, somebody might have a higher rate of anxiety or depression if they're dealing with multiple levels of oppression or not feeling seen by their community, by a system, by all of that. So we have ... I want to ask you two more questions if that's okay. What are you working on now and then I want to ask you just because it's Pride Month, to just ask what that means for you and what your hopes are around it and all that?
J. Garrett-Walker:

Yeah. So what am I working on now? I am about to start a research study that explores identity development for non-binary and gender-expansive people assigned female at birth. Again, I always try to do research on groups that are ignored within the academy, within the field of research. A lot of research finding is always about pathology and I don't do that. So I am looking to understand how non-binary and gender-expansive people come to that. Like how do you get to that place when the world is so binary? How are you able to deconstruct that and to live freely in a world that wants to put you in a very small broken box? And what language are you using to describe your identities, what pronouns are you using? Is there consistency across race on the pronouns used for non-binary folks? Just really kind of exploring the experiences of those who no one really cares to explore.
J. Garrett-Walker:

But I find it fascinating and interesting and I think it's work that needs to be done so that we can better support these folks because I mean I guess technically anyone who's gender nonconforming also falls within gender-expansive, so I mean I fall into the category also, so there's some personal interest there too. But I think that the current language around non-binary folks, there's so much more of it now than there ever has been in the past, and I think that we need to think about how we can support these folks in therapy, in schools, government records. Like all kinds of things, there's just so many ways that we need to make sure we're doing this right and we're not continuing to perpetuate more harm.
Shula Melamed:

I just wanted to add to that or to note some things that I've noticed too, and I think that ... I'm almost 43, and it's like...I've seen so much happen, and I don't know how old you are, but I think we've probably seen -
J. Garrett-Walker:
I'm not far behind you.
Shula Melamed:

Okay. Just checking. But yeah, there is just this sense of a little bit more gender-expansiveness. I love that term where there is all of this exploration and I find it so exciting to watch and I love the kids, I'm just watching them and I'm just like, “Yes. Like explore your gender, explore all of that stuff. Tell me what your personal pronoun is. Like I want to know that stuff”, and there are some people that are in my age group and queer folks too or just or like older queer folks who are like, “I don't want to say they. What is they? I don't understand what that is.” And it's like, “Well how are we supposed to support our kids if we're not ... Or how are we supposed to be good elders if we're not going to respect what their personal pronouns are and not try to understand what that experience is like for them.” Like it might have been different for us, but that's a big thing.
J. Garrett-Walker:

Yeah. First, hold on, before I get to that, I can't believe we're elders now. No, absolutely, and we can have a whole other interview about how transphobic the LGBTQ community actually is or the LGBQ community is. There's so much transphobia and cissexism. It's ridiculous, and we need to do better. I definitely agree with that. But yeah, we need to be good stewards and as we reach the elderhood in the queer community, it's going to be up to folks like us to challenge people to do better. I definitely agree with that.
Shula Melamed:

Yeah. I mean putting aside also all the other systemic stuff that we need to be there for them for as well and all people, all people, no matter what your orientation is, whatever it is, like we need to be there for our kids. Just come on. Get it together.
J. Garrett-Walker:
Get it together.
Shula Melamed:
On a personal level, let's do better. That's all we can do personally, and then also what does pride mean to you?
J. Garrett-Walker:

Well I don't know. So I feel like ... So I'm probably going to be the unpopular opinion on answering this question. I think that pride has become commodified and capitalism has thoroughly ruined it. Pride was a revolt. Pride was a stance against oppression, started by a black transwoman and a Latinx transwoman. Let us never forget that history, and I think that now, Pride is just companies putting up a rainbow flag in June and taking it down July 1 and I think that we need to really think about what Pride means to us and how can we make sure that Pride really is rooted in the history of the very first Pride. I think in an ideal world for me, Pride would continue to be resistance. Pride would be liberation. Pride would be safety and Pride would be inclusive of all folks. Inclusive of trans folks, inclusive of queer folks of color, inclusive of queer folks who may be living with a disability. I think that we don't have enough conversations about our deaf queer folks, our queer folks living on the spectrum. Like we just don't talk about it enough and they exist. So I think pride needs to be just more. It needs to be more expansive. Just like we just need to break all the limited binaries and expectations and really get back to the root of fighting for justice.
Shula Melamed

Yeah, and you're doing so much amazing work. Thank you so much for what you're doing, it's incredible and for shining a light on intersections that don't necessarily get the attention that they need to in the academy and so you are contributing a huge, huge part to this and just so grateful to have the opportunity to talk to you and is there anything else you would like to share before we sign off and anything that you'd like to share how people can follow your work, if they're not necessarily an academic, do you have a Twitter or anything else, an Instagram? Do you have a TikTok where we can see you do dances of the emerging adults?
J. Garrett-Walker:

Thank you for having me. No I don't have a TikTok. Our neighbors are always trying to get us to do TikToks, but I don't know that I'm that coordinated. I do have a Twitter, but what's my Twitter handle? I think it's @j_garrettwalker.
Shula Melamed:
Okay, @j_garrettwalker, so people can find you there.
J. Garrett-Walker:
Twitter is the best way. I don't tweet that often, but I have it.
Shula Melamed:
Well thank you so much again for joining us for Headspace Care Chats. This was Dr. Garrett-Walker and Happy Pride everybody
J. Garrett-Walker:
Thank you for having me.
Coping with Racism During COVID

If you’ve experienced racial discrimination during COVID, it may not come as a surprise to you that [a Pew Research Center study](https://www.pewresearch.org/social-trends/2020/07/01/many-black-and-asian-americans-say-they-have-experienced-discrimination-amid-the-covid-19-outbreak/) found that people from minority communities are more likely to report negative experiences due to their race or ethnicity since the pandemic began. Racial trauma can contribute to increased stress, worry, sadness, and other mental and physical health difficulties. If you’ve faced racial discrimiation during the pandemic, we’ve got some strategies to help you cope.
This activity will:

items: Help you understand how negative interactions related to race and ethnicity affect mental and physical health.
Offer suggestions for ongoing coping strategies and support.

components.text: Strategies to help you cope with racial trauma

Asian Americans, Black Americans and Hispanic Americans have reported experiencing racism since the start of the pandemic, and report being worried that wearing a face mask causes others to be suspicious of them because of their race or ethnicity. If you’ve experienced racism during the pandemic, here are some strategies that can help you cope.
Take time to reflect and cultivate your sense of ethnic and racial identity.

items: Research data suggests that those who have a clear sense of personal identity and commitment to their ethnic or racial identity are somewhat less vulnerable to these negative cycles that can occur after discrimination stress.

components.text: Remember that you are not alone.

items: Find supportive people and discuss cultural customs and traditions to cultivate racial pride and identity. Discuss your experiences of discrimination with trusted individuals and get support.

components.text: Focus on sleep.

items: Experiencing racial trauma can affect your sleep, which can in turn lead to an anxious mood and depressive symptoms. Getting better sleep following discrimination stress can help you engage in coping strategies, seek social support, boost your mood and eventually lead to fewer physical symptoms.
Reach out to your coach to discuss strategies for getting good-quality sleep if this is a struggle for you.

components.text: Bring up race and ethnicity with your coach or therapist.

items: Headspace Care coaches and therapists receive training in cultural competency. Although they may not have the personal experience of what you’re  going through, they have the tools to help you navigate feelings related to racial trauma.

components.text: Both racial trauma and COVID can cause feelings of worry, stress, sadness, and anxiety on their own. When you combine racial trauma and COVID, it can make those feelings even worse. Your coach can help you manage these feelings and incorporate these strategies into your life.
Racism & Dating
