Bwalya’s story about her experience with relationships and dating as a Black woman.
Video: selfsea/Peer Health Exchange
Headspace Care activity cards that can help:

items: “Strategies for Dealing with Racial Trauma”
“Coping with Racism During COVID”
“Building a Firm Sense of Identity”
“Taking Care: How Relationships Can Affect Your Mental Health”

components.text: Reach out to your Headspace Care care team any time for judgement-free support and help finding additional resources.

properties.name: Building a Firm Sense of Identity
properties.description: Building a Firm Sense of Identity

components.text: Building a Firm Sense of Identity

Identity—our personality, beliefs and ideas, and social constructs—is foundational to us as human beings. Having a firm sense of identity can help us to overcome challenges associated with a lack of confidence and purpose. It can decrease anxiety and depression, improve our relationships, and boost our overall quality of life.
This activity will help you:

items: Understand the importance of a strong self-identity;
Get started on defining your identity.

components.text: It’s common to overlook identity when addressing mental health challenges. But identity can play a big role in our mental health. The following is a list of challenges that are commonly rooted in self-identity challenges:

items: Lacking a sense of purpose or meaning in life
Feeling a heightened sense of anxiety, particularly in social situations
Feeling insecure or uncertain
Low self-esteem
The inability to celebrate the success of another person
Impostor syndrome—a feeling of being a fraud who will be eventually be found out
Being codependent—relying on someone else’s opinion of you
Lacking a sense of belonging

components.text: Sometimes a change in your wellness routine, or better prioritization and structure in your life can help with the aforementioned issues. When that doesn’t work, however, you may need to dig a bit deeper to explore your sense of identity.
To start to define your identity, try some of the following strategies:
Values Exploration
“Who are you?”
Values exploration prompts you to answer the questions, “What do you value?” and “What is meaningful to you?”
First, find the top values you most identify with. (These can include creativity, kindness, integrity, sense of humor, and many more. Ask your coach for other examples, or do a quick search online.)

Next, reflect on the areas in your life where those values show up. For example, if creativity is one of your values, where is creativity showing up? Is it in your relationships? Or in your career? Are you happy with how that value is showing up in your life? If so, great!

However, if those values are not showing up as much as you would like, consider the following questions: What needs to happen in order for those values to show up more? What will I gain if they show up more? What will I lose if they don’t? What is one step that I can take this week to invite this value into my life?
Strengths-Based Approach
“What are you great at?”

Understanding what your strengths are will help discover who you can be when you’re at your best. Many of us were conditioned to focus on areas that need improvement. Paying attention to your strengths promotes a mindset shift, allowing you to acknowledge how far you’ve come and the skills and strengths that got you there. It allows you to realize that inherently, you are resourceful, resilient, and capable.

In order to adopt a more strengths-based approach, it might be helpful to solicit feedback from those who know you best, whether a friend or colleague. Working with a coach who uses a strengths-based approach can also help.

Make a list in a journal of the strengths you’ve identified either through your own self-reflection or through feedback from others. Then, write down ways you can continue to grow these strengths or ways you can incorporate them more into your life.
Narrative Exploration
“What’s your story?”
The idea of narrative exploration is to foster change (in your behaviors or thinking) through creating a new story of yourself. This is often done with support from a coach.

It’s human nature to give meaning to events. As you live your life and experience various events, you may tend to link those events together in a particular way that creates meaning for your life. The meaning you assign to those experiences will affect the way you approach your life. For example, if you always thought of yourself as the “ black sheep of the family” growing up, you might find yourself constantly feeling left out, thinking you are being punished for being different.

A coach can help you reframe those stories that no longer serve you and can help you create an alternative (though not a false) narrative that encourages new patterns of thinking and behaviors. For example, rather than telling yourself that you were the ‘black sheep’ what if instead you saw yourself as an adventurous risk-taker,  who danced to the beat of their own drum?

Try narrative exploration on your own. One way you can do so is through journaling. Journaling can give you insight into your thoughts about yourself, and allows you to identify areas that need reframing.

One important benefit of journaling is that it can give you a fresh perspective. It can help you rethink your experiences, which can result in a richer and more productive understanding of who you are.
Self-Compassion and Acceptance
“How can I accept myself for who I am?”

When you’re in the midst of an identity struggle, you may have the tendency to be overly self-critical and self-judgmental, fixating on what is going wrong. Self-compassion helps you to accept who you are and to better understand where your traits come from—even the traits you don’t appreciate.

Being overly self-critical keeps you stuck in a rigid mindset. Having self-compassion can keep you motivated to learn and incorporate new habits and behaviors that will serve you. Learning a new habit, however, requires time and persistence and patience.

One way you can develop more self-compassion is by getting in the habit of asking yourself, “How would I treat a loved one if they were experiencing this right now?” Then consider whether you’re treating yourself similarly. If you notice that you’re treating yourself worse than you would a loved one, try to explore why that might be. What feelings come up for you? What thoughts do you have about yourself? How are they different from the thoughts you would have for a loved one?

By working on defining and strengthening your self-identity, you can build the self-confidence needed to help you achieve your goals. If you’re struggling to define who you are, reach out to a coach who can help.
Wellness Wheel

The Wellness Wheel is a holistic tool to help you see which areas in your life are going well and which might need more attention. Identifying these areas can help you strengthen your sense of identity. The Wellness Wheel is divided into eight domains: Social, emotional, spiritual, intellectual, physical, environmental, financial, and occupational. Experts believe that in order to have optimal health and well-being, you should tend to all eight domains.
This activity will help you identify:

items: What areas of your life are going well;
What your primary wellness needs are;
Areas of your life that you can work on with your coach.

components.text: Take a look at the wellness wheel.
Look at each area of wellness on the wheel. Reflect on how successful you feel in each area.
Take time to reflect and cultivate your sense of ethnic and racial identity.
Social Wellness
Emotional Wellness
Spiritual Wellness
Intellectual Wellness
Physical Wellness
Environmental Wellness
Financial Wellness
Occupational Wellness
Now look at the numbers you assigned each area and consider:

items: What is going well in each area?
Why did you assign the number you did?
What would you like to improve in this area?

components.text: Choose one or two areas that you’d like to work on with your coach, or on your own:
Great work reflecting on your different areas of wellness and picking ones to prioritize! Knowing the areas you'd like to improve is an important first step towards meaningful change.

Consider writing in your journal or calendar about one thing you can do this week to boost your wellness in the areas you've prioritized. If you need help creating a plan, you can always check in with your coach for support.

properties.name: Align Your Life With Your Values
properties.description: Align Your Life With Your Values

components.text: Align Your Life With Your Values

Living in a way that aligns with your core values is important for overall satisfaction and happiness. But how do you figure out and prioritize your values? If you feel overwhelmed by this question, you are not alone.
This activity will:

items: Help you understand what core values are.
Help you learn why values are important.
Learn one strategy for helping to clarify your core values.

components.text: What is a core value and why is it important?

items: Values are ideas that help us decide what we want our life to be about.
Values can help guide us in making decisions throughout our life
Values, unlike goals, are not meant to be attainable but instead ways to guide behavior throughout life

Values often fall into different categories, for example: Intimate relationships, parenting, family relationships, social relationships, work, leisure, citizenship, personal growth, health, and spirituality
Remember, even if a value “sounds good” or seems like something we should value, it may not actually be important to us, and that’s OK.

components.text: Thinking back to move forward:
Imagine yourself five, ten, twenty, or thirty years in the future, and imagine looking back over your life. What do you want your life to look like?

items: Where do you want to be? Who do you want to be with you?
What key events or milestones do you hope stick out over those years?
What do you hope the people close to you say about you? What qualities do they admire in you? Why do they care about you so much?
How do you want to feel about your life and the way you spent those years?
What things do you think will be important to you as you look back?

components.text: When you think about these questions, how many are centered on current stressors? Chances are, not many. Usually values are much broader and bigger than what’s happening in the moment.
Remember, you can pursue the life you want right now. What activities can you engage in today that align with your values? For example:

items: If helping children in your community is a core value, look into volunteer opportunities to start putting this into practice.
If a core value is spending time in nature, commit to spending once a month exploring the great outdoors.

components.text: Reach out to your coach to discuss further how you might incorporate these values into your everyday life.
Make SMART Goals
Using the S-M-A-R-T goals model, you can create goals that help set you up for success—right from the get go. S-M-A-R-T stands for:

items: Specific
Measurable
Achievable
Relevant
Time-bound

components.text: Before starting, get creative
When we think about goals, we often go straight to making a change. But goals can also be something you want to add to your life, like more positive thinking or a learning new hobby.
Let's get started.
Specific
Make your goal super clear-cut by writing down:

items: How would you describe your goal?
Why is this goal important to you?
How will you achieve this?

components.text: Measurable
How will you know when your goal is complete? Track progress by asking:

items: What milestones can you set along the way?
How do these milestones measure success?
How will you know you reached your goal?

components.text: Achievable
Set goals that are within reach, but require a stretch by asking:

items: Is this goal even possible?
What new knowledge or abilities will you need?
How have others achieved this goal?

components.text: Relevant
Ask yourself these questions to make sure this goal is something you really want:

items: What’s the reason you want to reach this goal?
How relevant is this goal to your day-to-day life?
Is achieving this goal within your control?

components.text: Time-bound
You've decided the "what" of your goal, now try nailing down the "when."

items: How much time will you need to reach this goal?
Is this a practical timeframe for your lifestyle?
Does the timeframe feel challenging but achievable?

components.text: You've got this - and your coach can help
Now that you're all set to start creating S-M-A-R-T Goals, don't forget to check in with your coach. They'll be there every step of the way to help you create, outline and achieve your goals.
Financial Well-Being

Since 2007, financial stress has been at the top of the American Psychological Association's annual stress survey results. Three-quarters of Americans experience financial stress at least some of the time and more than a quarter experience extreme financial stress most or all of the time. If you’re stressed about finances, you’re not alone.
In this activity you’ll:

items: Identify what contributes to financial stress.
Gain insight into steps you can take to better manage your finances.
Learn how you can cope with financial stress.

components.text: Feelings of stress can sometimes lead to making snap decisions—which aren't always the best for financial decisions. By being mindful of how you're feeling, you can reduce stress and improve your financial well-being.
Here we’ll share a few strategies to consider when experiencing financial stress.
Get clear on your core values
Financial stress can happen when your spending habits aren't aligned with your core values (in other words, what makes you truly happy).

Ask yourself questions (you can even write them in a journal) about what you really want out of life. For example, does dining out make you happy, or do you find yourself doing it more than you’d like due to outside pressures?
Prioritize your mental well-being over spending

Think about how your big picture mental health goals align with your budget and spending. For example, if credit card debt is causing you stress, purchasing a costly spa treatment might feel good in the short-term but cause more stress later on.
Try visualizing your future

One technique that can help you stay on track towards your savings goals is to visualize yourself in the future with the money you’re about to spend. This way you can think twice before treating yourself in a way that contradicts your goals.
Recognize your stress

When you're feeling stressed it can seem impossible to come up with solutions. In moments like these, try taking a break to breathe and just be in the present. Just because a solution hasn't come to mind yet, doesn't mean that it won't.
Reach out to your resources and community

Does your company have financial wellness benefits? Some companies offer a retirement savings plan and financial planning or advising services. Talking to an advisor or trusted friend can also help ease stress.
Celebrate the wins

Financial stress impacts everyone. When you’re feeling it, be kind to yourself and celebrate the wins— even the small ones. Come up with a few “free” or non-monetary ways to celebrate, like going on a hike, watching an extra TV show, or calling a friend.
Reach out to your Headspace Care coach

If you’re feeling bogged down by financial stress, reach out to your Headspace Care coach. Your Headspace Care coach can help you gain perspective during a rough patch and help you start to find your way forward.
Understanding Our Choices

When we would like to change certain habits or behaviors our internal world usually experiences a shift in perspective or a different mindset. With these changes, there are frequently things we can alter in our environment that would better set us up for success. Choice architecture (Thaler and Sunstein, 2008) has long been used in consumer research to see where to place certain products so that those products are more likely to be purchased. Making things easier to see or access makes them more likely to be selected and used.
Choice Architecture In Practice

How does your environment (i.e. home, work, school) help you access things that support your goals or that might compromise them? For example, if there are calorie-rich, nutrient-void (i.e. junk food) options for snacking in your immediate view, what is the likelihood you’ll reach for the unpeeled carrot sticks in your fridge? How would placing a refillable water bottle on your desk perhaps remind you to drink more water? Could putting your sneakers by your bed instead of all the way in the back of your closet possibly inspire you to go for a walk/run first thing in the morning? Consider how choice architecture may be able to impact your goals and what changes you can make in your environment to set yourself up for success.
Mental Maps for Choice Architects

items: How does your mindset affect your choices?
Are there any moods or triggers you can identify that may lead you to make decisions that might not * support your goals?
How might making a choice that supports your goals change the mood that tempts you off track?
How can you make the behaviors or choices you want to support more accessible to you?
How can you make the behaviors or choices you don’t want to support less accessible to you?
What are ways you can remind yourself of the behaviors or choices you want to be making? (vs those you want to move away from?)"

components.text: Self-Compassion for Breakup Stress

When we're going through a breakup, we tend to be really hard on ourselves. Self-compassion is a way of re-training our minds so that we become gentler and more understanding with ourselves and others.
This activity offers two guided meditations to help you have a more self-compassionate state of mind.
Which would you like to get started with?
Envisioning a Compassionate Self

When you look at a painting for a long time, you begin to notice intricate details you didn't see at first. Similarly, when you have the clear intention to increase your compassion, you'll start to notice more and more opportunities to do so.
This practice will help you define what a compassionate person looks like, and will encourage you to see yourself in that role.
Self-Compassion Break
This meditation is designed to help you care for yourself in this time of transition. Try to observe any emotions that come up or any sensations that arise in your body.
Time to turn up the volume or put on headphones. Audio guidance is about to begin.
Envisioning a Compassionate Self

For this practice, you’ll want to be somewhere you won’t be distracted. You can sit or lie down—just make sure to get yourself comfortable. The goal of this technique is to train your mind to practice compassion.
So, to get started, settle yourself in with a couple of deep diaphragm breaths in through your nose and out through your mouth.
Good, and one more round of breaths just like that, feeling your belly rising on your inhale, and falling on your exhale.
And now, let your breathing happen naturally. You don’t have to breathe in any particular way…just let it come and go as it pleases.

And now, try to imagine a deeply compassionate person. What kind of person comes to mind? Try to visualize what they look like, their facial expressions, how they behave, what it feels like to interact with them.
If you notice your mind starting to wander, just gently allow it to drift back to your visualization, developing an image in your head of a deeply compassionate person.
And then, once you have a picture of someone, try to imagine yourself as that person. See if you can feel what it would be like to be them.
Consider what qualities you would have….what, for you, would make you into that compassionate person? It doesn’t matter if you already have these qualities or not. Just try to imagine.
Compassionate people are often considered very warm. Imagine being warm and having warmth. You possess a gentle friendliness.
You are loving and kind. You speak and reach out to others with openness, sincerity, thoughtfulness, and kindheartedness.
Notice how it feels in your body to be warm. Notice if it affects your posture and the expression on your face. Observe what it feels like to have this quality. Just for a few more seconds.

Compassionate people are often considered very wise. Imagine being wise and having wisdom. You possess the insight that much of suffering is not our fault. You are sensitive, but you can also tolerate difficulties.
Compassionate people are also strong. Imagine being strong and having strength. You are sturdy, stable, and calm. You are open, courageous, and resilient when faced with challenges.
Imagine what it feels like to have emotional resilience, even in times of suffering…Imagine what that feels like for you.

Finally, compassionate people have a deep sense of responsibility. Imagine what it feels like to be responsible. You have no interest in blaming or condemning. You want to do the best you can to help others move forward in a difficult situation. You are reliable, accountable, and trustworthy. You are authentic and sincere.
Notice this feeling in your body...and any thoughts that come to mind.
Just for a few more rounds of breaths…
And then, bringing your awareness back to your body, begin to become aware again of the sensation of your body in your seat.
Tune in to any sounds or smells around you, gradually entering back into an awareness of your environment.

Bring your attention now to your forehead, just between your eyes... Taking in the sights around you, take a deep breath and stretch your muscles. You may want to roll your shoulders or rub your neck. Just give yourself a moment to wake up.

And as you prepare to return to whatever’s next in your day, try to carry these qualities with you. And remember that this practice is always here for you when you need to access these feelings again–compassion training is a great way to reawaken those feelings of caregiving and connection to others.
Time to turn up the volume or put on headphones. Audio guidance is about to begin.
Self-Compassion Break

For this practice, you’ll want to be somewhere you won’t be distracted. You can sit or lie down–just make sure to get yourself comfortable. The goal of this technique is to train your mind to practice self-compassion with non-judgment and visualization.
So, to get started, settle yourself in with a couple of deep diaphragm breaths in through your nose and out through your mouth.
Good, and one more round of breaths just like that, feeling your belly rising on your inhale, and falling on your exhale.
And now, let your breathing happen naturally. You don’t have to breathe in any particular way…just let it come and go as it pleases.
And tuning in now to your thoughts, let your mind wander…but try to observe what thoughts come to mind.
You don’t have to observe with judgment.
It’s okay if the thoughts are unpleasant. If you notice negative thoughts about yourself, that alright. Remember that thoughts are just thoughts–they’re not necessarily facts.
But see if you can notice these thoughts without reacting negatively…see if you can approach those thoughts with the same curiosity and care you would for a small child.
And similarly, start to notice if you’re carrying any tension or stress in your body.
Again, approaching these sensations with curiosity and tenderness instead of judgment. Just observe them with care.

Keeping this mindset of curiosity and care, offer yourself the same goodwill, the same love, kindness and compassion you would offer to a child or a pet or another loved one...Try to imagine giving yourself the exact comfort and care you need and deserve.
What do you need to hear right now to feel understood and that you’re absolutely OK the way you are? What wisdom or advice do you have to share with yourself?
Want to read again, listen, or try the other meditation? If you're done for now, that's OK, too. You can always find this technique in your practice section.
All set
You’ve just spent some time practicing self compassion. This is a great step on your journey towards retraining your mind to be gentler and more understanding in this difficult time

properties.name: Defining Your Values After a Breakup

components.text: Defining Your Values After a Breakup

When a relationship ends it can be really disorienting. And because so much of our identity can be tied up in partnership, it takes some time to refocus on our own personal values. While breakups are difficult, they can also be a powerful time for self-reflection.
This activity will:

items: Guide you to think about what matters most to you and why;
Help you refocus on your values after a breakup.

components.text: What Matters to You

When you spend time thinking about what matters most to you and why, you can identify the areas of your life where you'd like to focus your energy day-to-day. It can be really uplifting to invest time and energy into areas you value, have control over, and that feel true to your sense of self.
In the midst of this difficult transition like a breakup, there's an opportunity to get really clear on what matters to you.
Which areas of your life make you feel full and alive? Where do you want to focus your energy and time?
Keeping your values—your view of what's important in life—present in your mind can help guide you in many ways. Living a life according to your values helps you feel more engaged and content.
Defining Your Values
Get out a piece of paper and write down a time that you've felt really proud of yourself, engaged, or connected to what you were doing.
Now think about the moment that you just wrote about. There might be something about how you were feeling, or what it meant to you, that can point you in the direction of your values.
With moments like that one in mind, select your top five values from the list below:
Now, take some time to think about some of your shorter and longer-term goals. Let’s start by choosing one of the values from your list.
Your top values:
Balance
Community
compassion
Courage
creativity
Esmpathy
Enjoyment
Faith
Empathy
Fairness
Family
Friendship
Health
Humilitysss
Independence
Integrity
Leadership
Location
Perseverance
Power
Prestige
Respect
Security
Self-improvement
Service
Success
Tolerance
Wealth
Wisdom
Think of one that you want to focus on.
Take some time first to reflect on your value so you can create some long-term and short-term goals. A value is a direction that you move in—a goal is a step along the way.
Write down where you'd like to be in five years. What's a five-year goal?
Now, write down what goal you would like to have accomplished one year from today?
And, finally, is there anything that you could do today toward your goal? If yes, what? Write it down.
Think about what you wrote as a sort of personal mission or values statement to guide you as you focus your energy.
Now that you've defined your values, notice if you can connect the way you're spending your time this week to one or more of them.
Managing Family Relationships

Family relationships can be complicated in the best of times, but when we’re struggling, these relationships can take an especially big hit. Feeling overwhelmed, stressed, anxious, unmotivated, or depressed, for example, can affect family relationships. Learning how to manage these complex relationships can make your time together easier, and can help you maintain your own mental health.
This activity card will help you:

items: Maintain peace and connect with your loved ones;
Make changes to your own behaviors and how you relate to your family;
Navigate conflicts and difficult moments with your family.

components.text: Develop an Attitude of Gratitude

Try to remember that even when family relationships feel hard, stressful, and overwhelming, there is so much to be grateful for when it comes to family. Remind yourself why you care for your family. As a family or on your own, discuss everything you have to be grateful for, and make a list of three things you can celebrate that day.
How to Better Manage Conflict

Conflict is an inevitable part of coping with others, including family. So when conflict arises, it helps to have strategies for managing it. Here are some ideas for how to best handle familial discord:
Take turns with a family member being the speaker and the listener.

When it’s your turn as the speaker, share what’s on your mind (get tips on using “I” language next). When you’re finished, let your family member know and ask them to repeat back what they heard. Ask them to summarize the main points of what they hear you’re thinking and feeling. If what the listener says is correct, great! Time to switch roles. If not, share your perspective again and then check with the listener again for comprehension. Once you two are on the same page, it’s now the listener’s turn to speak and the speaker’s turn to listen. Go back and forth as many times as you need to make sure that you’re on the same page.

items: Utilize “I” language: Make sure to frame what you’re experiencing from your perspective. So instead of something like, “You never help me with dishes,” you could say, “I am feeling overwhelmed and could use some additional support.  Do you think you could help me with the dishes?”  “I” language changes the problem from your family member to a problem you can solve together. The person isn’t the problem—the problem is the problem!

Take a break! Sometimes you just can’t avoid feeling angry, misunderstood, or hurt with loved ones. When that happens and you can no longer have a productive conversation, call for a break. If you are the one asking for the break, it is on you to set the terms of that break. You determine how long the break will be and are responsible for re-initiating the conversation after the break ends. During the break time, you both have a responsibility to the other to self soothe. For example, you might decide you need a 30-minute break from a discussion.  Over those 30 minutes you might take a shower, listen to music you love, or do something else to help you feel calm again. At the end of that period (consider setting a timer!), go find your loved one and ask them if they are ready to continue the conversation.

components.text: Family Date Nights

When external stressors and pressures make it hard to connect with family members, one of the first things that happens is we usually lose out on quality time together.  Having a set weekly family night can make sure we don’t lose that connection with our loved ones. Here are some ideas for activities to do together:

items: Games, either video or board games
Movie
Sports
Arts or Crafts
Baking
Play
Cooking dinner
Write each of these down on a slip of paper (including others you come up with), put them in a jar, and randomly select the activity for family date night!

components.text: Change the Narrative

When your relationships with family are especially hard, one of the best things you can do is look at the whole picture differently. It can be hard to remember the good times, but can you try to find those few moments when things with your loved one were good? If it seems like you don’t have fun anymore with the person, push yourself to think about the last time you were happy together. We tend not to focus enough on the positives, and it can often feel like things have always been difficult. So take the opportunity to rewrite your story as a family with evidence of the good right in front of you.
Grounding for Parenting Stress
When you're juggling the stress of becoming a new parent, sometimes you just need a minute. Try out this grounding technique, proven to provide in-the-moment relief.
Time to turn up the volume or put on headphones. Audio guidance is about to begin.
How'd that go?
How helpful did you find Grounding 5-4-3-2-1?
Great, thanks for letting us know.
Five
For this practice, it doesn't matter where you are, but it will help if you're in a place where you won't be interrupted.
When you're ready, start by looking around you. Name five different things you can see. These can be anything in your surroundings: a TV, a person, a piece of furniture. Just find five things.
Now, identify five things that you can hear. Maybe you hear a door shutting, or a bell ringing. Whatever you may be hearing right now, just name them silently to yourself.
And now, identify five things that you can touch, or feel with your body.
Four
Now, let's go back to what you can see. What are four things that you can see right now? It's OK to repeat the things you saw last time. It doesn't matter. Just say them to yourself silently.
And now, moving onto sounds. What are four sounds you can hear right now?
What are four things that you can touch or feel right now? Is there a unique texture, shape, or composition to these things?
Three
And now back to sight. Find three things that you can see right now. Just make a note of them to yourself.
And what are three things that you can hear? Notice if there are any new sounds.
And now find three things that you can feel or touch, right now, and focus all of your attention on these sensations.
Two
And now back to sight. What are two things that you can see right now?
What are two things that you can hear?
What are two things that you can touch or feel?
Okay, final round now: What's one thing that you can see? What's one thing you can hear? What's one thing you can feel?
And, you're finished. Go ahead and take a deep breath in through your nose and out through your mouth. You should feel just a little bit more grounded, a little more present.
Remember that you can return to this practice any time your muscles are tight, your anxiety is high, or you're finding it difficult to focus.
How'd that go?
How helpful did you find Grounding 5-4-3-2-1?
Great, thanks for letting us know.
Mental Load of Parenting

Parents often juggle many priorities, such as work, caregiving, managing the home, cleaning, and so much more. This mental load can be overwhelming and can lead to burnout and decision fatigue, especially when there is limited access to support. While it’s not always easy or possible to reduce the burden of so many priorities, healthy coping mechanisms can help with improving overall well-being and managing the mental load.
This activity will:

items: Differentiate between helpful and unhelpful coping mechanisms
Guide you through choosing and incorporating more healthy coping mechanisms

components.text: Helpful coping mechanisms

As parents, it’s important to recognize that practicing helpful coping mechanisms is directly related to better mental health and wellness. However, between caring for children, managing schedules, and the list of to-do’s that seems never ending, it can be challenging to incorporate new patterns and rhythms into your already busy life. One important first step you can take is to identify your own coping mechanisms. Take a moment now to reflect on your go-to coping mechanisms:

items: When difficulties arise, what do you do to cope?
Is this activity or behavior helpful to you?
Does this activity or behavior improve your well-being?

components.text: Below are some examples of helpful coping mechanisms to try:
Helpful coping mechanisms

items: Connect with other parents
Celebrate small wins with your child (ie: tied shoes alone, brushed teeth, said “thank you” without being prompted)
“Does this activity or behavior improve your well-being?”
Delegate tasks (i.e., order take out for dinner, include child in small chores, say “Yes” to help)
Mindfulness
Relaxation tools (e.g., listen to calming music)
Deep breathing
Identify what you are feeling (“Name it to tame it”)
Seek support (i.e., call or text a trusted friend or family member, chat with your Headspace Care coach or therapist)
Establish a routine (create a plan)
Acceptance

components.text: The following are coping mechanisms that may not be so helpful for your well-being. Notice if you engage in some of these and try to replace these with a helpful coping mechanism.
Unhelpful coping mechanisms

items: Ruminating or dwelling on the negative
Binging on food, alcohol, and/or TV
Blaming others
Comparing yourself to others
Overthinking
Negative self-talk
Procrastination

components.text: Incorporate helpful coping mechanisms in your daily life

Now that you’ve taken the time to reflect on your existing coping mechanisms, consider replacing an unhelpful coping mechanism with one that is more helpful. Take some time now to pick one helpful coping mechanism that you’d like to try this week:

options.name: Celebrate small wins with your child (ie: tied shoes alone, brushed teeth, said “thank you” without being prompted)
Incorporate more joy into your day (i.e. dance with your child, listen to music that you enjoy, enjoy your child's laugh)
Delegate tasks (i.e., order take out for dinner, include child in small chores, say “Yes” to help)
Relaxation tools (e.g., listen to calming music)
Seek support (e.g., call or text a trusted friend or family member, chat with your Headspace Care coach or therapist)

components.text: Keep in mind that sometimes it can help to start small, so consider just trying this once a day for the next week and then you can slowly build on this or add another helpful coping mechanism once you feel ready. Your Headspace Care coach can also help you create a personalized plan and SMART goals that can help guide you.
You’re doing great!

Congrats on taking the time to learn more about helpful coping mechanisms. We know that it’s not always easy to use helpful coping mechanisms especially when things get stressful. Being aware of these coping mechanisms can be empowering. The goal isn’t to be perfect, but to slowly start to add more helpful coping mechanisms that can be additive to your mental well-being, rather than more draining. Remember that you can check out the self-care library for additional parenting resources and self-care strategies. You can also always reach out to your Headspace Care coach for support.

properties.name: The Stress of Becoming a New Parent

components.text: The Stress of Becoming a New Parent

Congratulations! Welcome to the wonderful, life-changing, and yes, sometimes quite stressful world of parenthood. This activity card is an introduction to the many parenting activities you’ll find in the app. Here we’ll give you an overview of the types of changes you can expect as a new parent.
Becoming a new parent comes with so many changes.

Your new role as a parent comes with learning new skills, like caring for your baby and understanding the way your baby communicates. And while your baby is your main focus, maintaining your adult relationships is important, too. Plus, your hormones are changing, you’re dealing with sleep deprivation, changes to your relationship, new schedules, and new responsibilities. With everything going on, it’s easy to feel stressed and anxious.
Expectations

And the expectations don't make things any easier. You might feel like this should be one of the happiest times of your life, or that you should know what to do instinctively. But adjusting to such a big change doesn't happen overnight. The expectations we set for ourselves can lead to feelings of failure and helplessness. Taking care of a newborn can be really tiring and challenging. It's OK to feel a range of emotions, both positive and negative.
Worry

If you're experiencing added worry, it may be due to the biological response we have built in to protect our babies. But sometimes the worry can become so intense that it interferes with your day-to-day life. You might also feel down, depressed, or unable to cope with all the new changes.
Getting Support

Only a professional such as a therapist or psychiatrist can diagnose postpartum depression and postpartum anxiety. Activity cards in the app can help you better manage challenging feelings, but if you are experiencing more difficult emotions, you can set up an appointment with a therapist or psychiatrist through the app. This can be done by clicking on the video tab or speaking with a coach.

There are lots of activity cards in the app specifically focused on helping you navigate life as a new parent, including techniques to help you relax and sleep, ask for support, and take care of yourself during this time of transition. Have a look around, or ask your coach to offer suggestions.
Parenting a Child with Anxiety

When parents see their children having anxiety, it can bring up a lot of stress, frustration, and more anxiety for the parent. Understanding your child’s anxiety and how you can support them, as well as support yourself, can help.
This activity will:

items: Guide you through some common symptoms of anxiety for children and teens
Offer some tips and support for managing these symptoms

components.text: Anxiety symptoms in children & teens
If you have a child with anxiety or suspect that they may have anxiety, here are some key signs that you might notice:
Anxiety can cause:

items: The brain to believe in the worst outcomes. For example, someone with anxiety may worry about a disaster that is statistically unlikely to occur. It can be scary for the person to believe that the future will bring hurt, fear, and pain, but those worried thoughts, however, don’t always respond to rational arguments. For most people with anxiety, especially children, it is not helpful to simply command them to “Stop Worrying.” Instead, tell them you understand why they are worried and encourage them to distract themselves with more positive thoughts and activities. Use a grounding technique to keep their mind focused on the present instead of the future. Remind them that they are strong and can handle anything that comes their way. Point out past worries and how they successfully survived the worrying situation. With a sympathetic tone, you can share that their irrational fear is unlikely to occur.

High self-criticism. It may not be only the unpredictable future your child is worrying about, they may also be worried about the past. Your child’s mind may fixate on anything they have said or done in the past. They may be overwhelmed with the worry that they have made a catastrophic mistake. That slip-up three years ago when they mispronounced a word in front of their classmates... That one moment may continue to weave it’s way into their anxious minds and cause them to want to change their name and switch schools. Your anxious child likely has a habit of reliving their most humiliating life experiences, and wanting desperately to AVOID future mistakes. Similar to how you can distract them from worrying about the future, use similar grounding and distraction techniques to focus on the here and now.

Physical symptoms. Your anxious child may complain about stomach aches, headaches, chest pain, dizziness, and many other physical ailments. Always make sure any medical conditions your child has are checked out by a professional. If a medical professional does not believe there is a medical reason for their physical complaints, it could be that somatization (expressing a mental issue with a physical symptom) is the root cause. For example, a fast heart rate and high blood pressure may be solely caused by experiencing anxiety. What’s worse, sometimes somatic symptoms worsen when a person with anxiety becomes even more worried that they are sick. It’s important to find a balance between following up on health concerns while also not running to the doctor for every somatic complaint from a healthy child. If possible, have the medical professional talk to the mental health professional so your child has a team that’s aware of what’s going on and can collaborate on care.

Your child asks a lot of questions. Anything they don’t feel certain about is a potential area for a disaster to occur, and therefore a source of worrying. It is OK not to be able to answer every question, either because you don’t have the answers or you don’t have the time. Maybe you are in the middle of cooking dinner and you can’t address a never-ending flood of questions. Respond calmly that you don’t have an answer or that you aren’t able to focus on that issue at the moment but you will give your child your full attention at another time. Try to find set times to spend talking with your child so you can redirect their questions to the next set time you will be available for them.

Low frustration tolerance & controlling behavior. Your child’s anxiety is taking up a lot of their mental and emotional energy. On a good day they may be able to manage some minor frustrations, but if they are already anxious, the slightest inconvenience or mishap in their day could become a massive explosion. This is often displaced anger, or taking stress out on a problem they can seek to control because they aren’t able to resolve the true problem that is causing them stress. Seek out opportunities to help your child feel in control again by giving options when possible, offering choices, and following their lead on a reasonable request.

Restlessness & sensory overload. Shaking legs, fidgeting hands, and an overall inability to sit still can be signs that your child is experiencing anxiety. The fast heart rate caused by anxiety’s physical symptoms combined with racing disastrous thoughts and fears could lead to an energy overload. Restlessness can best be managed with physical exercise to burn off energy, relaxation to reduce tension, or sensory stimulation to take back control over the senses. Suggest your child splash cold water on their face, turn music on, rip up some old papers, massage their hands with a scented lotion, or use a weighted blanket to create strong sensory experiences. You may need to find a quiet setting with fewer sensory distractions for your child to fully regain control over their sensory system. Note that some children seeking sensory stimulation to redirect their energy may engage in unhealthy behaviors such as hitting or harming themselves, overeating, or breaking items.

components.text: Anxiety comes in many types!

While some anxious children have “generalized anxiety,” some may have a more specific form of anxiety. There are also other specific types of anxiety and it is important to understand the differences to help your child receive the right type of care.
Here are some more specific types and recommendations:

items: Social Anxiety: Your child may be unable to calm themselves around others. Maybe they avoid unstructured social situations and have fears of people not liking them or teasing them. Someone with social anxiety can still develop meaningful and lasting friendships! It is important to remind your child that there will always be people who will enjoy being around them, even when they aren’t feeling their best.

Separation Anxiety: Your child may have a difficult time being away from you or outside of their home. It can be helpful to plan check-ins via phone or text throughout the day. It can also be helpful to make something together with your child (a piece of jewelry, painting a small rock, creating a music playlist) that you can both use throughout the day to symbolize that you are thinking of one another.

Phobia: Your child may have an excessive fear response to a specific thing (e.g., dogs, cars, tests, public speaking). It is helpful to predict as best you can when your child might have to come face-to-face with their fears. A therapist may want to use exposure techniques to support your child in developing coping abilities to overcome their phobia

Panic Disorder: Your child may have panic attacks when they feel very worried. Panic attacks manifest very physically and may include a faster heartbeat, racing thoughts, difficulty breathing, chest pain, blurry vision, excessive sweating, crying, shaking, or rapid body temperature changes. It’s quite common that people who are having a panic attack think they are having a heart attack until a medical provider clarifies they are medically stable. Sometimes kids try to avoid situations where they fear having a panic attack. It’s helpful to have an exit strategy in those places so your child does not feel trapped

components.text: A message of support to you

Kudos to you for taking the time to learn more about your child’s anxiety. There may be days when you do everything possible to spare your child from anxiety, and days when your child needs to relinquish their control because you can’t make any more adjustments to accommodate their anxiety. Try to find a sustainable balance between making accommodations and overburdening yourself. It’s not only impossible to protect your child from a moment of anxiety, but it also may not help them learn to cope.

If you have a history of anxiety yourself, you know how miserable this can be and you may worry that your child will experience the same pain and suffering into adulthood that you experienced. Try to catch yourself from jumping to your own worst case scenario conclusions the same way you would support your child through a disastrous worry. Have hope that your child will develop the tools to manage anxiety and be patient that experiences may be more stressful for you until that time. Remember it is okay (and very important) to take time for yourself.

Anxiety is still stigmatized, but you are not alone. You may want to seek out other parents who have been through this for extra support. And please reach out to a Headspace Care coach for your own mental health support!
Parenting a Child with Depression

When parents learn their child is depressed, it can bring up a lot of confusion, frustration, and even depression in the parent. But there are things you can do to support your child as you learn about mental health treatment options.
This activity will:

items: Guide you through some common symptoms of depression for children and teens
Offer some tips and support for managing these symptoms

components.text: Depression symptoms in children & teens
If you have a child with depression or suspect that they have depression, you might notice the following signs.
Depression can cause…

items: Emotional changes: Even with depression, you may still see your child happy. Your child will still laugh, smile, and experience joyful moments. This does not mean they are no longer struggling with depression. Most likely, your child’s high, or joyful, moments are a little less joyful than they used to be and their low, or sad, moments are more down than they used to be.

Distorted thinking: When people are depressed, they sometimes have distorted thoughts that tell them they are unloved, a burden, and useless. Your child will need many reminders that they are loved, strong, and deserving of affection. Your child will be quick to pick up on any impatience in your tone so make sure to practice your own relaxation techniques to keep yourself calm

Irritability: Your child may see someone in the family with a positive attitude and feel an urge to react or lash out at that person’s mood. Let your child know you understand they are having a bad day and offer to help them. But also remind them of household rules and enforce consequences if they have acted inappropriately toward another family member. For some teens, depression looks like anger; you may not see them cry or appear sad. Make sure you are making more positive statements than corrective statements to your child. If you can’t find things to praise them for, you may benefit from some self-care for yourself (check out other activities in the Self-Care Library for more resources or reach out to your coach for help). We know you deeply love your kid — even if there are days you don’t like being around them.

Exhaustion: If you notice their homework piling up, their bedroom floor disappearing under a growing mess, or an odor telling you they probably haven't bathed recently, it may be that these tasks feel overwhelming to your teen and they don’t have the energy to do them. They may even feel like a failure for not being able to complete these tasks. Help your child break down tasks into small, manageable steps. Celebrate each step to build back a sense of competence and achievement. And offer to help (even if you believe your child should be capable of doing this independently). It may encourage your teen to get moving if everyone in the family is working together. Try putting on some music and cleaning up as a family!

Isolation: You might notice your child is not spending time with friends anymore. Be curious and ask if there are any plans they want to make with their peers. It’s possible your child is having distorted thoughts, and is thinking their friends don’t care about them anymore. Suggest that they invite a friend over for a popcorn and movie night. You may also see your child want to spend more time alone in their bedroom. It’s important for them to have a private space, but if they are left alone with their depression too long, their mood may only get worse. Don’t force them out! Instead, invite them out for a special one-on-one activity that you believe they would enjoy. (Pro tip: While you’re in the car with your teen, casually ask your child how they are doing. The absence of eye contact during car conversations can sometimes be the change they need to open up to you.

components.text: A message of support to you

If you’ve read this far, you are doing so much to support your child and they are lucky to have you. Depression can come from so many sources so please don’t blame yourself or think that you have failed as a parent. You’re going to make mistakes. You’re going to lose your temper. Sometimes your child will be angry and say things they don’t mean...and sometimes you’ll respond angrily with something you don’t mean. That makes you human! You have an opportunity to model your own ability to take some space from the conflict, calm yourself, and apologize for losing your patience.

If you have a history of depression yourself, you also have the opportunity to inspire hope in your child by showing them that it’s possible to have joyful moments together. Remember it is OK (and very important) to take time for yourself.

Depression is still very much stigmatized, but you are not alone. You may want to seek out support from other parents who have been through this. And please reach out to a Headspace Care coach for your own mental health support!
Small Moments for New Parents

This practice is used to guide your thinking away from the difficult parts of your day, and back to the good things that happened. The idea is to cultivate joy and gratitude—to draw positive emotion from even the simplest moments of your life.
This activity will:

items: Help you recognize and appreciate the good parts of your day
Provide a writing exercise to help you appreciate three good moments.

components.text: Time to turn up the volume or put on headphones. Audio guidance is about to begin.
What good things happened to you today?

These don't have to be huge things. In fact, it's great practice to think about the small things. Maybe you had one of your favorite foods for lunch, or you got to sleep in. Think about the answers or write them on a piece of paper.
What's good thing #1?
What's good thing #2?
What's good thing #3?

Now think about or look at each of these good things. For each one, think or write down why it happened. Consider who was involved, and all the circumstances that came together to make that good thing so good.
Think about why Good Thing #2 happened. Consider who was involved, and all the circumstances that came together to make that good thing so good.
Think about why Good Thing #3 happened. Consider who was involved, and all the circumstances that came together to make that good thing so good.
Nice Work
If you’d like help with this activity or want more support coming up with positive parts of your day, reach out to your coach.

properties.name: Getting Support as a New Parent

components.text: Getting Support as a New Parent

As a new parent, you need support. You deserve support. But sometimes it’s difficult to know what kind of support you could use, and even more difficult to ask for that support. But help from others can make your experience as a new parent less stressful. You don’t have to do it alone.
This activity card will help you:

items: Understand that it’s OK to ask for help
Figure out what you need help with
Effectively communicate your needs to get help

components.text: As a new parent, it's OK not to know what you're doing all the time.
And it's OK to ask for help. Support from others can help you take better care of yourself and your baby, especially if you're feeling depleted or overwhelmed.

It can often feel like there's not a spare minute in the day. It's common to feel like you've got to do it all yourself. But often, smaller tasks can be done just as well by someone else as they can by you. Asking clearly for support with those things will give you a little bit of extra time when you can take a deep breath.

Tap into your support system and lean on your friends, family, a partner, or a colleague. Knowing how to ask for support will help you carve out time to take good care of yourself, and it'll make all the difference. There are often people willing to help.
Figure out what you need, and how to communicate your request
You don't have to go it alone.

Is there anything that could make your life easier during this transition? Here are a few ideas of how family or friends could help. Pick one or two that could be helpful and keep it in your mind for this activity.

items: Watch your baby for an hour while you nap.
Pick up groceries.
Do a load of laundry.
Prepare meals to store in your freezer.
Anything else you can think of!

components.text: Things to consider when communicating your needs

While it's easy to want to give the long list of reasons why the other person should give you what you want, research shows that presenting just one persuasive reason is most likely to get you what you want.
What's your most persuasive reason for needing help?
Think about it or write it down on a piece of paper.

Just a reminder: People are more likely to treat you with respect if you have self-respect. If you believe you deserve what you're asking for, your whole demeanor will show it, and people will respond in kind.
Why is this request important to you? And why do you deserve to have the other person consider your request?
Think about it or write it down on a piece of paper.
How do you think the other person will feel when you make this request? Does that in any way change how you want to make the request?
How will the other person likely feel and react to your request?

items: Stressed
Offended
Bothered
Flattered
Honored
Excited

components.text: Lastly, in some situations, it might make sense to give people a way out. But, this depends on the nature of the request and how important it is to you. (Some requests are meant to be firm and you don't have to give the person an easy out. Requests that are about protecting yourself or your boundaries will usually fall into this category).
Here’s an example of how you can give the other person an out: I know you have a lot going on at home as well, so if you are not able to, I totally understand.

Consider your nonverbal communication, too. Your posture and tone of voice are also doing the communicating. Standing up straight with an even tone of voice can help convey your message in a way that'll be well-received.
So, to recap. When asking for support, remember:

items: Your request
Your reason for your request
Why you’re worth it
How the other person might feel when you ask
And, maybe a way for them to say no.

components.text: All these pieces come together to form your most effective request. Take some time this week to try it out, and let your coach know how it goes.
Self-Compassion for Parenting Stress
When navigating life as a new parent, we can be really hard on ourselves. Self-compassion is a way of re-training our minds so that we become gentler and more understanding with ourselves and others.
This activity offers two guided meditations to help you have a more self-compassionate state of mind.
Try one or both of the following meditations, and take a step towards a more self-compassionate state of mind.
Which would you like to get started with?
Envisioning a Compassionate Self

When you look at a painting for a long time, you begin to notice intricate details you didn't see at first. Similarly, when you have the clear intention to increase your compassion, you'll start to notice more and more opportunities to do so.
This practice will help you define what a compassionate person looks like, and will encourage you to see yourself in that role.
Self-Compassion Break
This meditation is designed to help you care for yourself in this time of transition. Try to observe any emotions that come up or any sensations that arise in your body.
Time to turn up the volume or put on headphones. Audio guidance is about to begin.
Envisioning a Compassionate Self

For this practice, you’ll want to be somewhere you won’t be distracted. You can sit or lie down—just make sure to get yourself comfortable. The goal of this technique is to train your mind to practice compassion.
So, to get started, settle yourself in with a couple of deep diaphragm breaths in through your nose and out through your mouth.
Good, and one more round of breaths just like that, feeling your belly rising on your inhale, and falling on your exhale.
And now, let your breathing happen naturally. You don’t have to breathe in any particular way…just let it come and go as it pleases.

And now, try to imagine a deeply compassionate person. What kind of person comes to mind? Try to visualize what they look like, their facial expressions, how they behave, what it feels like to interact with them.
If you notice your mind starting to wander, just gently allow it to drift back to your visualization, developing an image in your head of a deeply compassionate person.
And then, once you have a picture of someone, try to imagine yourself as that person. See if you can feel what it would be like to be them.
Consider what qualities you would have….what, for you, would make you into that compassionate person? It doesn’t matter if you already have these qualities or not. Just try to imagine.
Compassionate people are often considered very warm. Imagine being warm and having warmth. You possess a gentle friendliness.
You are loving and kind. You speak and reach out to others with openness, sincerity, thoughtfulness, and kindheartedness.
Notice how it feels in your body to be warm. Notice if it affects your posture and the expression on your face. Observe what it feels like to have this quality. Just for a few more seconds.

Compassionate people are often considered very wise. Imagine being wise and having wisdom. You possess the insight that much of suffering is not our fault. You are sensitive, but you can also tolerate difficulties.
Compassionate people are also strong. Imagine being strong and having strength. You are sturdy, stable, and calm. You are open, courageous, and resilient when faced with challenges.
Imagine what it feels like to have emotional resilience, even in times of suffering…Imagine what that feels like for you.

Finally, compassionate people have a deep sense of responsibility. Imagine what it feels like to be responsible. You have no interest in blaming or condemning. You want to do the best you can to help others move forward in a difficult situation. You are reliable, accountable, and trustworthy. You are authentic and sincere.
Notice this feeling in your body...and any thoughts that come to mind.
Just for a few more rounds of breaths…
And then, bringing your awareness back to your body, begin to become aware again of the sensation of your body in your seat.
Tune in to any sounds or smells around you, gradually entering back into an awareness of your environment.

Bring your attention now to your forehead, just between your eyes... Taking in the sights around you, take a deep breath and stretch your muscles. You may want to roll your shoulders or rub your neck. Just give yourself a moment to wake up.

And as you prepare to return to whatever’s next in your day, try to carry these qualities with you. And remember that this practice is always here for you when you need to access these feelings again–compassion training is a great way to reawaken those feelings of caregiving and connection to others.
Time to turn up the volume or put on headphones. Audio guidance is about to begin.
Self-Compassion Break

For this practice, you’ll want to be somewhere you won’t be distracted. You can sit or lie down–just make sure to get yourself comfortable. The goal of this technique is to train your mind to practice self-compassion with non-judgment and visualization.
So, to get started, settle yourself in with a couple of deep diaphragm breaths in through your nose and out through your mouth.
Good, and one more round of breaths just like that, feeling your belly rising on your inhale, and falling on your exhale.
And now, let your breathing happen naturally. You don’t have to breathe in any particular way…just let it come and go as it pleases.
And tuning in now to your thoughts, let your mind wander…but try to observe what thoughts come to mind.
You don’t have to observe with judgment.
It’s okay if the thoughts are unpleasant. If you notice negative thoughts about yourself, that alright. Remember that thoughts are just thoughts–they’re not necessarily facts.
But see if you can notice these thoughts without reacting negatively…see if you can approach those thoughts with the same curiosity and care you would for a small child.
And similarly, start to notice if you’re carrying any tension or stress in your body.
Again, approaching these sensations with curiosity and tenderness instead of judgment. Just observe them with care.

Keeping this mindset of curiosity and care, offer yourself the same goodwill, the same love, kindness and compassion you would offer to a child or a pet or another loved one...Try to imagine giving yourself the exact comfort and care you need and deserve.
What do you need to hear right now to feel understood and that you’re absolutely OK the way you are? What wisdom or advice do you have to share with yourself?
Want to read again, listen, or try the other meditation? If you're done for now, that's OK, too. You can always find this technique in your practice section.
All set
You’ve just spent some time practicing self compassion. This is a great step on your journey towards retraining your mind to be gentler and more understanding in this difficult time

properties.name: Helping Your Teen Cope With Anxiety

components.text: Helping Your Teen Cope With Anxiety

When your teenager is struggling with stress and anxiety, it can be hard to know how to help them. We’ve got some tips for you to help with your teen manage stress and anxiety while also strengthening your relationship with your teen.
This activity card will:

items: Help you identify some of the signs of anxiety in adolescents;
Help you identify strategies and coping skills that to reduce their stress and anxiety;
Provide suggestions for ways to strengthen your relationship with your teen while helping them improve their mental health.

components.text: Signs Your Teen is Struggling With Stress and Anxiety

Let’s face it, teenagers don’t always tell their caregivers exactly what is going on with them. Unless your teen tells you that they’re feeling stressed and anxious, you may not be aware of the extent of their struggling. Here are some possible signs that your teen is struggling to cope with stress and anxiety:

items: Have you noticed changes in your teen’s sleeping patterns? Are they having trouble falling asleep? Worrying at night before bed can often make it difficult to fall asleep.

Is your teen complaining of more frequent headaches, stomachaches, or other ailments? Has their primary care doctor cleared them of any physical causes? Stress and anxiety can often manifest as these physical symptoms.

Have you noticed changes in their school grades? Do they suddenly not want to attend school or are avoiding certain friends? Oftentimes our first instinct when we feel anxious is to avoid the thing we are fearful of.

components.text: Coping Strategies
If you know (or suspect) that your teen is struggling with stress and anxiety, here are some initial coping strategies you can encourage your teen to try:
Support healthy patterns of engagement

items: It’s common for your teen to want to avoid situations that can cause more anxiety. Unfortunately, avoidance can perpetuate anxiety and make it worse over time. Talk to your teen about the situations they are avoiding and try a problem-solving technique: Identify the what, why, and how that’s associated with the situation or people your teen is avoiding. Then identify potential solutions to help get them back into participating.

components.text: Encourage less screen time

items: As you talk to your teen more about their stress and anxiety, you may find that they feel worse when they engage in social media or other digital activities. See if they have noticed the link and if they have any ideas themselves of how to change this situation. If they are resistant to cutting back on social media, see if they will commit to turning off notifications or trying a ten minute break to start.

components.text: Participate in self-care and coping strategies together

items: Make activities such as going for walks, getting outside, meditating a part of the family routine. These strategies can help the whole family with well-being and may help your teen feel less alone with their anxiety.

components.text: Helping your teen with coping strategies and stress and anxiety reduction can bring you closer together.
Consider telling them about your own emotional experiences

items: As caregivers, we often try to give our kids the impression that we have it all together and never struggle. Explaining that stress and anxiety are common difficulties may help them feel less alone. Plus, these types of conversations can help build emotional closeness between you.

components.text: Plan something fun to do with your teen!

items: Laughing and having fun are great ways to de-stress and strengthen your relationship. Be open to engaging in something your teen is interested in or try to find a new activity you can enjoy together.

components.text: Keep the communication going.

items: Let your teen know that you are supportive and available to talk. If they are willing, try to plan regular check-ins when they know that they can talk to you about their feelings. Make sure these conversations occur when you both can give your full attention. Allow space for your teen to share how internal and external pressures are influencing their stress and anxiety. Be open to feedback about pressures that might be coming from home, and use this feedback as an opportunity to validate your teen’s feeling while establishing deeper understanding and connection.

components.text: For more ideas, or for support for yourself, reach out to a coach who can help.
Setting Healthy Boundaries for Teens

Raising a teenager is a learning process, with constant changes during this developmental stage. It can be hard to know when and how to be involved in your child’s life. Establishing healthy boundaries with your teenager can help strengthen your relationship and can allow your child the space to develop their own decision making skills.
This card will give you:

items: Tips to help you and your child decide on boundaries;
Strategies for discussing the boundaries with your child;
Tools to prepare for when your child pushes boundaries.

components.text: Decide on the boundaries you feel are priorities for your child and your family.
First, think about the areas in your child’s life that you believe could benefit from boundaries. Some examples are: screentime, curfew, substance use, sex, and study habits.

items: Consider if you’d like to set new boundaries, reinforce existing boundaries, or prepare future boundaries based on your child’s developmental stage or family dynamics.

components.text: Pick a time to discuss the boundaries.

There will never be the perfect time to have a serious discussion with your teenager, so find one that works best for both of your schedules. When the time comes for the conversation, check in with yourself to make sure you feel ready for it. If you’re feeling tired, frustrated, or overwhelmed, give yourself permission to reschedule the conversation for a better time.
Speak to your teen with empathy and respect, while remaining firm, clear and consistent.
Allow your teen to ask questions and share what boundaries are important to them. It can help them open up and see the boundaries as mutually beneficial, rather than imposed on them.
Lead with compassion.

When creating boundaries, remember what it was like to be a teenager. Make sure that all of your child’s parents or guardians are clear and in agreement about the boundaries. When setting boundaries, consistency and clarity is essential for your teen.
Remember that flexibility is not the same as inconsistency.

Accept that boundaries have the potential to evolve over time depending on your child’s developmental needs throughout their adolescent years. Be willing to allow for flexibility, and know that flexibility is not the same as being inconsistent
Expect your teen to push the boundaries.

Once you’ve set clear boundaries, it may feel like the work is just beginning. You now need to uphold them. It’s developmentally appropriate for teens to push boundaries as they navigate their own independence and autonomy. Try not to take boundary pushing personally, and stay focused on supporting your teen with healthy decision making and healthy relationships.
Prepare for consequences.

Maintaining boundaries is an ongoing process that sometimes requires consequences for your child. There are two main types of consequences: natural consequences and consequences that you and your child decide on.

items: A natural consequence might occur if, for example, your child doesn’t do their homework; their grades will suffer. Or if your child is sent to detention after school for misbehaving, they may miss an after-school activity.

Consequences that you and your child decide on ahead of time are for those actions and behaviors that don’t have natural consequences. For example, if your child wakes up late and is late for school in the morning, you might impose a consequence of no screen-time after 9pm.

components.text: Consequences might feel scary, but they can be a way for teens to begin to problem solve.
Re-evaluate.

Setting boundaries is an evolving process. Take time to assess how specific boundaries and consequences are working for your family. As the parent or guardian, try to let go of needing to get everything right the first time. Allow for opportunities to continue to talk openly with your teenager and to make appropriate adjustments to boundaries as you go.

properties.name: How Headspace Care Works for Your Teen

components.text: How Headspace Care Works for Your Teen
Welcome! This overview will explain what you can expect while your teen is receiving care through Headspace Care.
In this card you’ll learn:

items: What types of challenges and concerns Headspace Care can help your teen with;
What information will be shared with you, and what will be kept private;
Your involvement in their care.

components.text: What will my teen’s care look like?

Your child will start out working with a behavioral health coach who will provide them with care via text-based chat. If they need extra support, their coach may recommend adding a therapist to their care team. Generally, your child’s mental health needs will be met with the support of their coach and/or their therapist. If your child needs additional clinical support within the Headspace Care platform, your child’s therapist will reach out to explore the possibility of making a referral to a psychiatrist. Clinicians (in other words, therapists and psychiatrists) provide care through scheduled video sessions. Coaches, therapists, and psychiatrists make up your child’s care team and work together to provide seamless care so your child can pick up right where they left off with each provider.
What areas can Headspace Care help my teen with?
Headspace Care is able to support teens with a wide range of concerns, including but not limited to:

items: Anxiety about relationships with peers
Identity and belonging
Stress about getting into college
Academic issues like time management and building effective study skills
Diagnoses such as major depressive disorder, generalized anxiety disorder, and obsessive-compulsive disorder

components.text: What areas can’t Headspace Care help my teen with?
Headspace Care is not able to provide services for conditions that require close medical monitoring, in-person services, or a high degree of specialization, such as:

items: Treatment for severe eating disorders
Substance use disorders
Active suicidal or homicidal ideation, or high risk self-harm behaviors

components.text: If your teen is experiencing one of these, please check out resources [here](https://www.adolescenthealth.org/Resources/Clinical-Care-Resources/Mental-Health/Mental-Health-Resources-For-Parents-of-Adolescents.aspx)
A note about ADHD

Due to the [Ryan Haight Act](https://www.psychiatry.org/psychiatrists/practice/telepsychiatry/toolkit/ryan-haight-act), we’re unable to prescribe controlled substances such as stimulants, which are frequently used in the treatment of ADHD. If your child has ADHD and is in need of medication, please consult with their Headspace Care care team about options. At times, we’re able to coordinate care with an existing pediatrician, who can prescribe stimulant medication when necessary. Alternatively, some individuals with ADHD benefit from non-stimulant medication, which Headspace Care psychiatrists can prescribe.

If you’re interested in a diagnostic assessment to determine whether your child has ADHD, please schedule an appointment with a Headspace Care psychiatrist. To make such a diagnosis, the psychiatrist will request additional information from your child, your child’s teacher (or other instructor or coach), and you, in order to gain a comprehensive understanding of your child’s current and past functioning in all settings. As a result, a diagnosis of ADHD will not likely be established during the initial evaluation.
How much involvement will I have with my teen’s care?

When your child begins care at Headspace Care, we’ll ask you to complete a survey to get a better sense of how your child is doing, what’s happening at home, and anything you might be concerned about. If your child begins therapy or psychiatry at Headspace Care, we will ask that you join for the first session, and on an as-needed basis subsequently.

We strongly encourage you to communicate directly with your child about questions you may have regarding their care. However, if there is a non-urgent matter, you can contact a Member Support specialist who will relay your message to your child’s coach, therapist, or psychiatrist. Please note that this route should only be used if absolutely necessary. You will also have visibility in the app of your child’s progress.
How will I know how my teen is doing?
