We encourage you to check in with your teen, although we realize teens are not always willing to talk with their parents about how they’re doing. For that reason, you’ll have access in the app to a summary of your child’s Headspace Care usage, including dates that your child engaged with their coach or met with a Headspace Care therapist or psychiatrist.
What about my teen’s privacy?

Adolescent treatment records, including clinical notes and coaching transcripts, will be handled in full compliance with HIPAA, our Notice of Privacy Practices, and the laws in the state in which you reside. When you sign your child up for services at Headspace Care, you and your child will complete consent and acknowledgement forms that outline the health information that will be shared, your rights to access records, and your child’s rights with regard to treatment decisions.
Pursuant to law and best practice, it is Headspace Care policy that our care team will share the following information with parents, when it is discovered or known that your teen is:

items: Engaging in self-harm (e.g., cutting, burning, or hitting themselves) that is of concern
Experiencing active suicidal ideation (e.g., thoughts of killing themselves, accompanied by a plan or intent)
Experiencing active homicidal ideation or intent to inflict serious bodily harm on others (e.g., thoughts of harming others, accompanied by a plan or intent)
Exhibiting signs of grave disability, such as psychosis or mania
Engaging in substance use that is of concern
Engaging in an eating disorder that is of concern

components.text: Please note: In addition to contacting the parent, Headspace Care may be required to notify other parties to prevent harm. For example, in a situation in which an individual may be contemplating harm to others, state law requires that care providers contact law enforcement, as well as the intended victim, to ensure the safety of others. We will also follow state mandates specific to child abuse, sexual assault and sexual activity reporting guidelines.
What should I do if I’m worried about my teen?

It’s normal for teens to want autonomy and privacy. In fact, it’s essential for their development. But, this desire for increased autonomy can be challenging for parents and guardians, particularly if parents are concerned about their child’s safety or welfare.

There are a few ways you can manage this situation. First, we recommend you communicate your concerns or questions directly to your child in a calm and curious manner. Let them know what you’re observing and why you’re concerned, and ask them to explain their perspective.

If this doesn’t work, or if you want to ensure that your child’s provider understands what’s happening at home, we encourage you to let your child know that you’ll be contacting Member Support. You can send a message to Member Support in the Chat tab of the app after completing this activity.

At other times, your child’s coach or clinician may encourage you to obtain your own support, either through Headspace Care or outside our system, in order to ensure you’re able to focus on your own needs, as well as those of your child.
If you believe that your child needs immediate assistance or is in danger or harming themselves or others, please call 911 or the Suicide & Crisis Lifeline for immediate assistance.
We look forward to partnering with you and your child.
Celebrating Single Life

We’re often bombarded on social media with images of happy couples, both with and without children, living seemingly idyllic lives. If we’re single, seeing these pictures can fill us with longing for a partner and make us feel like we’re missing something in our lives. There is plenty to appreciate and celebrate about being single. This activity offers strategies for  shifting your mindset and reflecting on the positive aspects of singlehood.
This activity will:

items: Reflect on the positive parts of being single.
Reframe the negative thoughts around your single identity.
Identify what feeds your belonging needs and incorporate those elements into your daily life to honor your desire for connection.

components.text: Understanding Negative Thoughts About Being Single

When we see seemingly happy couples, we often assume they have it easier or better than we do. Our negative thoughts about being single tend to erase the pride we feel about our accomplishments or the joy we get from our friends and family. The desire to love and be loved is human, but we often lose sight of the fact that there are multiple avenues for love in our lives. We tend to focus on what we perceive to be a missing piece in our lives — the presence of a partner — and focusing on what we don’t have can stand in the way of our happiness.
Appreciating the Benefits of Being Single

There are a lot of benefits to being single that we tend to take for granted, like ability to spend your time the way you want to and having final say over all decisions in your life. This is a rare and liberating time in your life. Yet, so many of us mourn this state instead of enjoying it. When you find yourself mourning this, try to use the following steps to reflect and reframe:

items: Observe your thoughts, making note of any assumptions you have about other people’s lives. We all fall into social media rabbit holes and we all have pangs of envy around the curated life of someone we know based on what they post on the internet. Recognize that this is not reality but a version they are presenting to highlight the very best parts of their experience.

Determine what is factual vs. what is an assumption. Ask yourself, “Are these facts or feelings? Are my thoughts aligned with facts? Is it possible that my opinions are colored by feelings of longing or a desire for something missing in my life?” For example, a negative thought might be “I am alone and I'll be alone forever,” however that is not a fact — it’s a fear. The fact might be, “I am single at this moment, but I have friends and/or family I can connect with whenever I choose.”

Question your negative thoughts. Ask yourself, “How can I prove my thoughts are NOT true? What is at the root of each fear? Why do I think that?” Understanding how these thoughts originally formed is important to uncovering the underlying need that drives them. Once you acknowledge and question them, you can start to recognize and release some of these limiting beliefs that are not serving you right now.

components.text: Let’s try it out!

Practice reframing your negative thoughts and replace negative self-talk with self-affirming thoughts. Most importantly, filter your narrative through the lens of self-compassion. The best way to do this is to use the same tone and language when you talk to yourself as you would to your best friend or a loved one. Ask yourself how you can be more accepting of yourself and make sure your actions align with that.
Below are some benefits of being single. Choose one to reflect upon and practice self-affirmation to improve how you think and feel about the life you have today.
Flexibility
Step one: Make a list of all the things you do in your life that would require you to account for the opinion of a partner if you were coupled.
Step two: Ask yourself, ”How does having flexibility with these activities benefit me?”
Step three: Reflect on how much you enjoy the freedom to choose how you spend your time, money, and energy.
Step four: If it feels helpful, write it down in a notebook or phone app as a reminder.

items: My time is my own.
I get to choose how I spend my money.
I can rest when I want and for as long as I need without letting anyone down.
I am my worst critic, but I could be my best cheerleader. Today, I pick the latter.

components.text: Exploring a new place
Step one: What is one place, far or near, you've always wanted to visit? It can be as exotic as the beautiful temples of Angkor Wat in Cambodia or as mundane as the local farmers' market.

Step two: Recognize that you don't need to wait to be partnered to take that trip. If you don't feel safe traveling alone, make a list of travel companies that specialize in trips for singles and sign up. If you can’t afford the trip right now, create a plan for how you might save to make it happen or invite a friend or two to split costs and start planning your trip.

Step three: Identify what false beliefs are holding you back from exploring more of the world around you. Often, we have been socialized by our parents, social media, or even through our own repetitive thoughts to delay adventure and experience until we are partnered. While there are good reasons to delay gratification in other facets of life, in this context, putting things off could be deepening your longing for excitement, especially when you have an opportunity to explore.
Below are more examples of local places to explore.

items: Visit your local museum.
Take a trip to the closest body of water — the ocean, a lake, a pond, etc.
Find a trail near you that allows you to commune with nature. It doesn't have to be long, hard, or far away to offer the solace and beauty of nature.
Get a map of the world or pull it up on your phone. Is there a country you would like to visit in the next year or two? Go to the travel section of your library and start planning.

components.text: Mastering a skill

Step one: Research suggests that participating in an activity that engages your brain has many benefits, including improving memory, increasing dopamine and endorphin release, which improves your mood, and decreasing cortisol, the stress hormone. Many couples have similar interests, but the majority of people in relationships have differing levels of fitness or ability to participate in the same task at the same level. As a single person, you can dedicate as much time and as many resources as you choose to developing your hobbies. Often, participating in group activities can be an excellent way to meet like-minded people to date or make new friends. This fosters our sense of belonging and feeds our need for connection. Make a list of activities or hobbies you’d like to get involved with.

Step two: Determine which hobby you wish to prioritize. It may be a sport (team or individual), playing an instrument, dancing, creating art or crafts, learning another language or game. Volunteering with a cause that is meaningful to you is a great way to invest your energy. You are only limited by your imagination and the amount of time available to dedicate to this practice.

Step three: How much time will you spend on your hobby a week? What is your goal for this hobby in terms of improvement, competition, or connection? When will you participate in this hobby? Block the time off on your calendar both as a reminder and to hold yourself accountable to following through!

Step four: Here are some possible ways to develop competence in an arena that piques your interest and might offer an opportunity to connect with others who share your interest(s). Feel free to add to this list as you discover more activities that capture your attention and feed your spirit.

items: Contact your local community theater; they’re often looking for actors, crew, and ushers.
Is there a musical instrument collecting dust in your closet, or one you’d like to purchase or rent? Check out online lessons or classes and give it a go.
Your local YMCA or YWCA will have a list of available classes from woodworking to pickleball. Is there something you’re interested in trying that maybe never crossed your mind before?
Local community colleges also offer classes in a variety of languages and technical and vocational skills. Many are offered online at low or no cost.

components.text: Pick one new hobby that most resonates with you. Commit to dedicating some time to developing it every week for the next month. If you're in the groove, commit to continuing for the rest of the season or the next quarter and see how much you learn. Share your success or joy with friends and family. Invite them to come watch or share videos of your progress on social media.
Great work!

Wonderful job today taking the time to celebrate you and the life you've built! Like any skill, self-affirmation takes practice. When you have a negative thought about your single status, you can come back to this activity card to walk through these steps again and again. Consider bookmarking this card or take some time to write down the steps so that they can be helpful reminders when you find yourself getting pulled back into negative thinking about the amazing life you’re creating for yourself. If you need additional help with recognizing successes in your current life, your coach can also support you in finding customized affirmations that reflect just how fabulous being single can be!
Small Steps to Personal Growth

When you’re feeling down, setting goals for personal growth can fall to the bottom of your to-do list. In fact, feeling down and unmotivated can make it hard to do anything, especially the activities that don’t feel urgent. It can be helpful to remember that even when you don’t think you’re progressing, even just making it from day to day is a triumph.
This activity card will help you:

items: Learn how you can be gentle with yourself;
Create and recognize your forward momentum.

components.text: 1. Talk to Your Inner Child

When you’re having thoughts such as, “I’m not good enough,” “I’m not trying hard enough,” “I should be farther than I am,” ask yourself if you would talk to someone else that way, or if you would talk to a child that way. Likely, you wouldn’t be hard on someone who is struggling, so why do you talk like that to yourself?  The next time you are feeling tempted to be rough on yourself, try talking to the child version of you.
Little you doesn’t deserve to be kicked when you’re already feeling down.
2. Positive Affirmations

One way to make small positive steps in your personal growth is to take just a few moments a day to remind yourself of the messages you need to hear.  When you hear something, whether out loud, in your head, or you read it, you start to believe it more and more. So put good things in your head by being proactive about placing them there yourself. One great affirmation that can work for a lot of people is to remind yourself of the following: “I am doing the best that I can, and that is all I can expect from myself.”
Because it is true: what you’re going through, where you are now in your life, and what your mental health is like, you are always doing your best, and you should remember and celebrate that.
3. Prioritize Where to Put Your Energy
Sometimes it just isn’t possible to do everything. In those moments where there is too much on your plate with not enough motivation, try prioritizing.
Write down everything you need to do, and then look through those items and pick the top few that need to happen right now.

Which of the goals on your list are more immediate? What would make you feel better if you had it off your plate? What can be postponed? When your energy isn’t limitless but your list is, you can choose what’s important to you. When you can’t do it all, what can you do?
Success List
Most of the time we don’t realize what we’ve accomplished in a day.

A lot of what we do is more automatic, and without giving it thought we are also not giving ourselves credit. Instead of not acknowledging all of your accomplishments, take time at the end of each day to note what you’ve done.
Got out of bed? Check.  Ate a meal? Great. Talked to a loved one? Nice! All of these things are successes in your day, so don’t forget them!
Caring for Aging Parents

While aging is a normal part of life it can be scary for both the parent and adult child as the nature of the relationship begins to shift from the parent being the caregiver to the child taking on this role. This can be especially difficult if the adult child also has young children at home, a career to balance, or lives far from their aging parent(s). This activity card will help you recognize common signs of aging and more serious concerns. It will also help you identify ways to start the conversation about age-related changes and provide some self-care tips for both the adult children and parent(s).
This activity card will:

items: Help you identify general signs of aging and more serious concerns
Prepare you for having a conversation about age-related concerns
Provide tips for how to support yourself and your parents with self-care and healthy activities

components.text: Signs of aging

Signs of aging look different for everyone and may include changes in cognition, mental health, and physical health. It’s normal to see changes that affect the mind and body. Usual age-related signs may include forgetfulness, like forgetting a name, forgetting to pay a bill, or forgetting where you placed an object.

While changes in cognition, behavior, or mood are common, they may also point to a more serious medical concern — dementia. Dementia can include changes that may affect cognition, behavior, and mood (psychological state). Changes may be gradual and can vary greatly from person to person. You may notice changes in mood such as anxiety, fear, or depression.
Behavioral changes might include:

items: Changes in hygiene or self-care
Trouble driving
Trouble paying bills
Changes in ability to engage in daily activities like cooking and cleaning

components.text: Cognitive changes may include:

items: Memory loss
Confusion
Trouble communicating.

components.text: When you visit your parents in their home, take notice of the following that may indicate a more serious concern:

items: Do your parents have food in their refrigerator?
Are there noticeable changes in driving habits, appearance, or other noticeable patterns or deviations from normal habits?
Are your parents forgetting to do important tasks like taking the appropriate dose of their medicine?

components.text: Other medical concerns become more common during aging. As you age your risk of developing diabetes, heart related conditions, and stroke all increase. Some medical conditions can mimic signs of dementia and may include side effects from medications, alcohol use, or vitamin deficiencies to name a few.
Talking to your parents about aging
Having a conversation with your parents about their health and well-being can be frustrating to you and your parent(s). Here are a few tips that can help:
First, consider the type of conversation you want to have with your parent(s):

items: Are you noticing general signs of aging and want to start a conversation about planning for the future?
Are you concerned that the changes may point to a larger medical issue?
Do other people notice similar changes?
What do you hope to gain or communicate to your parent(s)?

components.text: Next, prepare for the conversation:

items: Remember that change is hard. Your parents may worry about having these conversations. They may fear a loss of control that could include fear of losing their home, financial control, or driving ability to name a few.

Do your homework before your conversation. This might involve talking with siblings, family members or friends, or getting professional advice from experts including attorneys, medical, and financial experts.

Recognize this is a difficult conversation to have and even harder if dementia and illness are present. If possible, consider having these conversations before dementia or other medical issues become a concern.
Determine how to have this conversation with your parent(s). This might include finding the right time, place, and best person to start this discussion.

components.text: Tips for having this conversation:

items: Start small. Sometimes it is important to start small by introducing one topic of concern at a time or just take a step in opening this topic of conversation with your parent(s).
Be open, honest, and supportive throughout your communication. Remember that empathy and compassion go a long way in having a difficult conversation.

Listen first. Have a general idea of what you would like to share, things you have noticed or concerns you may have. Start the conversation by using healthy communication techniques. Use open ended questions so you can gain a better understanding of what is important to your parents. Listen to their concerns and opinions and respond to them in kind.

Consider having this talk with your loved ones early. Age related topics might include conversations about wills, trusts, medical power of attorney, power of attorney, funeral planning, and living wills.

Allow time for all parties to process the conversation. Your parents may have strong feelings or reactions immediately following the conversation, especially if this is the first time you’re discussing aging with them. Give them time to think about the conversation before having a follow-up conversation.

components.text: Some other factors to consider:

items: Consider ways to support your parents from afar. Many adult children don’t live close to their parents. If this is the case for you, there are still ways you can support them from afar. This might include getting to know their neighbors, members of their religious community, friends, or even finding a local organization that provides in-home care or safety checks. Other ways to support them might include meal delivery services, grocery delivery, or regularly scheduled calls.

Encourage your parent(s) to visit their doctor regularly. You can help them write a list of questions to ask their medical providers or have a trusted family member or friend go to the doctor with them if your parent(s) are open to this idea.

Suggest ways to make their lives easier: Consolidating credit cards, reducing the number of bills that need to be paid, setting up online bill pay or bill pay reminders, and having a trusted person advise or assist in these areas.

components.text: High-level self-care tips for everyone
Encourage your parent(s) (and yourself) to live an optimal life by doing the following:

items: Eat a healthy diet full of vegetables, fruit, grains, and drink plenty of water.
Consider a mindfulness practice like meditation or breathing exercises.
Get enough sleep at night. The daily amount recommended for healthy adults is 7-9 hours each night.
Create a healthy exercise plan that includes cardio, muscle strengthening exercises, and balance exercises.

Connect with others. Research has shown that one of the greatest factors in cognition as we age relates to connections with others. It is important to build and maintain connections with others. A few ideas are joining a book club, online virtual group, or having a weekly lunch or Zoom call with friends.
Talk with your doctor. Make sure you schedule regular annual visits.
The CDC has great resources and recommendations for diet, exercise, sleep, and mindfulness. AARP is another great resource to consider for age-related topics.

components.text: Well done!

Kudos to you for taking the time to learn about how you can care and support your aging parents. As you prepare for this conversation, remember that it can help to be prepared and to set an intention for the conversation. These conversations can be difficult to start and if things don’t go as planned, try to take a few deep breaths to stay calm. Additionally, remember that it is OK (and important!) to take care of yourself and set healthy boundaries. Caring for aging parents, especially those with medical needs or dementia can be exhausting. Consider journaling, taking a mindfulness break such as a walk or some deep breathing, or reaching out to support groups, family, and friends for emotional support. For additional support, you can also reach out to your Headspace Care coach.
Gaslighting in Relationships

Gaslighting is when one person manipulates another into doubting their feelings, thoughts, and perceptions. Gaslighting can be a form of domestic abuse or intimate partner violence (IPV) with one partner being the “gaslighter,” or perpetrator, and the other, the “gaslightee,” or victim. This card will discuss the concept of gaslighting, walk you through some common signs of gaslighting, and offer steps for victims to find support.
This activity will:

items: Introduce the concept of gaslighting
Identify common signs and phrases used in gaslighting
Offer some steps to find support and heal from a gaslighting relationship

components.text: What is gaslighting?

What is gaslighting and how do you know if you're being gaslit? In a relationship where gaslighting is prevalent, there will be a gaslighter (perpetrator) and a gaslightee (victim). At the core, the gaslighter works to undermine and/or discredit the gaslightee. They may try to do this in hidden or direct ways with the ultimate goal of making the gaslightee lose their sense of reality and question themselves. At first the gaslightee may find themselves in disbelief about what they are feeling and later become defensive. The defensiveness can become very exhausting and can lead to a sense of powerlessness, hopelessness, and depression.

Gaslighting also leads to an unequal power distribution in which a gaslighter works to have power and control, desires to be right, and redirects blame onto the gaslightee. This psychological form of abuse can occur on a macro and micro level and does not discriminate between culture, gender, age, and socioeconomic status. Anyone can experience gaslighting.
Signs you may be experiencing gaslighting

Often, the gaslighter will try to frame themselves as the hero or the “good one” and will distort your sense of reality so that you feel as if you're to blame. This can make it even more difficult to identify that you are a victim of gaslighting. Take a moment now to review some of the common signs of gaslighting and reflect on whether these signs apply to the relationships in your life. If not, it can still be helpful to be aware of for the future so that you can identify when gaslighting might be impacting you or someone you care about:

items: You are constantly second guessing yourself
You make excuses for your partner's behavior
You worry about what side of your partner will show up when you get home
You always apologizing to friends and family
You feel as if you can't do anything right no matter how much you try
You feel confused and simple decisions feel extremely difficult
You feel like you need to be cautious about what you do or say around your partner
You are constantly walking on eggshells
You lie in order to avoid our partner's hurtful remarks and put-downs
You feel like you can't seem to do anything right

components.text: It's also helpful to be aware of language that is commonly used by someone who is gaslighting:

items: “You're always making stuff up”
“I never said that”
“Your family thinks your crazy, I'm the only one who loves you”
“You need help”
“Just calm down”
“It's always something with you”
“You're so dramatic”

components.text: Steps to healing
Seeking help when you are being gaslighted can be challenging, but it's an important step to healing. If you suspect that you are being gaslit, below are some steps you can take to get help.

items: Find support: Gaslightees typically feel a lot of guilt and shame for staying in a toxic relationship. There is a natural instinct to want to protect and hide from others when you're in a relationship with intimate domestic abuse, but it's important to trust yourself and to reach out to friends, family, and/or a mental health professional for help to rebuild your self-identity.
Reach out to your coach: Coaches are here at any time to provide judgement-free support and can help you find additional resources.

Rebuild self-compassion and self-trust: Start with affirmations. It can be helpful to write these down in a journal. Also, begin to be aware of your body sensations and try to separate out fact from fiction in your thinking. There are several activities for improving self-confidence and self-compassion in the self-care library in the app.

Set boundaries: Remind yourself that you have rights in any relationship. You have the right to say “no” without feeling guilty, to be treated with respect, to make your needs as important as the other person's needs, and more. You can refer to the “Setting Relationship Boundaries” activity card if you need more tips.

Begin to develop assertive responses: Some examples you can consider using are: “I remember that differently,” “I am not debating my emotions with you,” “I will honor my thoughts and feelings,” and “I know what I am experiencing.”
Call 911 or the National Domestic Hotline at 1-800-799-SAFE (7233): If you are feeling unsafe, contact these resources immediately for support.

components.text: Great work today taking the time to learn about the common signs of gaslighting. Even if you are not experiencing gaslighting right now, being aware of the signs can help you identify this behavior early on and allow you to recognize it if it is impacting someone you care about. If you need additional support with your relationships, consider starting another activity card in the “Relationships” topic in the self-care library. Remember that you can always reach out to a Headspace Care coach for support.
Supporting Loved Ones’ Mental Health

It can be difficult to know how to support a loved one who has mental health challenges. Doing so requires a delicate balance of taking care of yourself and taking care of the other person. Here are some tips to help you strike that balance and give you both what you need.
This activity card will:

items: Discuss the importance of self-care when supporting others
Provide tips for communicating with your loved one
Offer practical suggestions for supporting your loved one struggling with a mental health challenge

components.text: Taking care of yourself is a critical part of taking care of a loved one with mental health challenges.

items: We can’t pour from an empty cup! Make sure to take care of yourself and your own needs so that you have the resources and energy to support your loved one.
Engaging in healthy self-care routines and effective coping will also benefit your loved one. By modeling these healthy behaviors, your loved one can see how they might do them, too.

Reach out for professional support if you are having difficulty managing the stress of taking care of a loved one with mental health challenges. It can be a lot to manage, and sometimes we need additional support.

components.text: Effective communication is a key component of most relationships. It is especially important when navigating difficult conversations with a loved one with mental health challenges.
Be open.

items: Follow your loved one’s lead, but talk about mental health in the open. This will help them know that mental health challenges are not shameful or something they need to hide from others.

components.text: Ask them what they need.

items: We often think we know how best to help loved ones. However, when we really stop and listen to them express what they need, we might be surprised.

components.text: Be dependable, accessible, and responsive.

items: Make sure your loved one knows that they can reach you if they are having a difficult time. Show them consistently that you will be supportive and responsive to their needs.
Encourage positive self-talk by complimenting and pointing out successes when appropriate

components.text: For those who are struggling with a mental health challenge, maintaining health routines and engaging in their own care are important. Here are some practical tips for how to help your loved one on a day-to-day basis.
Stress management and physical health, especially sleep, are important for managing many mental health symptoms. You can support your loved one’s physical health by:

items: Not encouraging or scheduling very late night or very early morning activities to do together.
Choosing healthy foods to eat together.
Going for walks together.
Not engaging in alcohol or substance use when your loved one is with you.

components.text: Some mental health conditions can be complex to manage, and it may be important for your loved one to have a professional care team. Discuss with your loved how you can help them manage their care team?:

items: Can you remind them of appointments or medications?
Can you drive them to appointments?
Can you clear your schedule for 30 minutes after their therapy appointment in case they need extra support?

components.text: Encourage fun! Engaging in activities that are fun or help us feel competent and confident is another part of maintaining mental health. If your loved one struggles with this, see if one of the following might help:

items: Engage in a hobby or activity together.
Ask them to teach you a skill they are really good at.
Plan special outings together.

components.text: It’s natural to want to help when a loved one is struggling with mental health challenges, but it can be difficult to know how to do this. Remember that your own self-care is a part of taking care of others. It is also important to focus on communication and day-to-day support with your loved one. Remember to reach out to a professional for support if you become overwhelmed by supporting your loved one.

properties.name: How to be a Supportive Partner

components.text: How to be a Supportive Partner

Supporting your partner through uncertain times is a big task, especially when you could use support yourself. Providing and receiving support when faced with the unknown can help you learn what your partner needs, teach you how to communicate better, and help you build intimacy and closeness. With effort and intention, you can practice strategies so you’re able to emerge from uncertain times feeling like you can get through anything together.
This activity will:

items: Provide strategies to help you tune into your partner’s needs
Help you identify strategies to support your partner through the unknown
Offer tips for communicating support and support needs

components.text: How to tune in when your partner needs help

items: Pause what you're doing, take a deep breath, and give your partner your full attention.

Listen to them without judgment or interruption. Let them know you’re listening by reflecting back what you hear. (For example: “It sounds like you're upset because you’re not sure if your job is secure.”) Let them correct what you're saying if it doesn't match for them.

Express understanding. Even if you haven't been through that exact experience, try to put yourself in their shoes and understand what it might feel like to be in their situation.  If their reaction feels out of proportion to the situation, don't offer correction just yet. Validate their hurt even if you can't validate their reaction. “I’m sorry you’re feeling so upset by this.”

Ask if they're looking for advice or if they just need to vent. Be direct and ask, “Do you need me to help you solve this?” If they're open to advice, offer it gently and don't try to convince them of something.
Ask, “Is there something tangible I can get you right now? Do you just need a hug? Do you need space?” Try to respect what they need in the moment, even if you may want to discuss it more later.

If you get stuck, ask, “How can I help?” Sometimes we think we know how best to support our partner but we miss the mark or don’t realize that they need something different in this moment. What's helpful to us might not be helpful to them and sometimes we need some guidance.

components.text: How to cope with the unknown together with your partner

items: Be mindful with your partner. Put down your phones, turn off the TV, music, or gaming, and take some time to just be with your partner. Listen to them and really try to hear what they’re saying.
Remind your partner of the things that are stable in your life together, and reassure them that the unknown won’t last forever. With time, those things will become known.
Do something different. Be playful and have fun with each other! Switch up your regular routine and try something new.

Remember that whatever you are both feeling is OK. Sometimes we have to sit with feeling worried, sad, or frustrated in order to move through it. Validate your emotional experience. Validate your partner’s emotional experience.

components.text: We often tend to feel more comfortable when things are settled. The unknown can be scary and intimidating. Remember that working through unknowns with your partner will bring you closer together over time.
Relationship Communication Styles

In all relationships, disagreements are inevitable. How we respond to the conflict can help us move forward. There's a concept called “The Four Horsemen,” developed by John M. Gottman, a psychological researcher and clinician, which identifies four behaviors that are damaging to relationships. Recognizing behaviors is the first step to changing them.
This activity will:

items: Explain the behaviors known as “The Four Horsemen;”
Give example of these communication styles;
Provide solutions for counteracting these behaviors.

components.text: What are The Four Horsemen?
The Critical Horseman

Criticism here refers to attacking your partner’s personality or character rather than the behavior they are demonstrating. By criticizing who they are, rather than their behavior, it implies there’s something wrong with them and can end up being more hurtful.
How can you talk to someone about a behavior of theirs that bothers you?
Rather than criticize them, try a complaint that addresses a specific issue, action or non-action that can bring about change.
For example, let’s say your partner left their dishes in the sink again.
A criticism would be: “Why are you so lazy that you can’t clean a dish or put it in the dishwasher?”
Alternatively, a complaint would be: “There are dishes in the sink again. Could you please clean them when you are finished with them?”

Rather than a criticism, try to uncover what you really want to address behind the criticism, which is typically the behavior you don’t like. Learn to make specific complaints and requests using “I statements.” For example, “When the dishes were left in the sink, I felt frustrated. I would like for you to clean up as you go.” Try to speak from a place of calm rather than judgement.

Be mindful that reacting with criticism makes the other person feel hurt, rejected, and attacked.  It can cause each party in this situation to develop a pattern where criticism shows up with greater frequency and intensity, eventually leading to contempt.
The Horseman of Contempt

Communicating with contempt can include mocking with sarcasm and ridicule, name calling, mimicking or using body language like eye-rolling or scoffing. It can be quite mean and disrespectful. Communicating with contempt is any statement or behavior that attacks the other person with the intention to cause feelings of disrespect and worthlessness.
Creating a habit of appreciation is helpful in combating contempt. Often both participants in the relationship may be feeling unappreciated. Being proactive in changing your mindset can help.
Back to the example where your partner left dirty dishes in the sink. Communicating with contempt, would be a sarcastic comment such as, “Wow, looks like you enjoy living in filth.”

Thinking about what you appreciate that person for can help you avoid these comments. Can you take a moment to appreciate one thing? Can you appreciate the times when they’ve done the dishes? Or when they’ve done the cooking or shopping?

Practice becoming aware of your thoughts, feelings and behaviors through journaling or working with your coach. This will help you discover what is really upsetting you. Once you learn this, you can then be specific about how you address this issue with your partner, rather than turning to passive-aggressive or mean comments. Speak respectfully and learn to let go of that which doesn’t positively serve the situation, such as any stories you have been writing in your own head.
The Defensive Horseman

Defensiveness is a protective action and is often used when you think of yourself as a victim always under attack. You might suspect you're constantly scrutinized and you treat all gestures towards you as potential attacks. Examples of defensive behavior are making excuses, cross-complaining, and sometimes adding a “but” to an explanation.
The key to working with defensiveness is accepting responsibility.

In the dirty dishes example, let’s say you’re the one who left dishes in the sink and your partner asked you to do them. Responding defensively, you might say, “But, I always do all the chores around the house. Why do I have to do the dishes, too.”

Rather than act defensively, take a moment to consider what is being asked. If you do feel like you do more than your share of chores, consider that this might be a side issue to what your partner is asking. Instead of reacting defensively, you might take responsibility by saying, “I realize I left my dishes in the sink. Let’s discuss a way to divide up the chores.”
To counteract an inclination towards defensiveness:

items: Practice active listening. Perhaps what you interpreted isn’t what was said. Check that you have heard it accurately before you rush to defend yourself.
Validate what is being said. Let the other person know that you understand what they are saying.
Pause and determine if you need to accept responsibility for what is being brought to you before dismissing it entirely.
Be more open. Review what rings as truth in the other person’s complaint and take action to address it by asking yourself “What can I learn from this?” or “What can I do about it?”

components.text: The Stonewalling Horseman

Stonewalling is when you distance yourself to avoid conflict. You might avoid eye contact, respond curtly, speak in monotone, or physically separate yourself from the person you’re speaking with. When you stonewall someone else, you’re reluctant to express what you are thinking or feeling.
Stonewalling can lead to someone thinking you don’t care about the problem enough to discuss it, which can cause them to get upset and feel ignored.

To prevent yourself from stonewalling your partner and instead to respond effectively, it can help to calm down. First pause, take a deep breath, and exhale fully. Pick the conversation back up when you are calm and you’ve collected yourself.
The antidote to stonewalling is to learn to calm yourself down actively and then to re-engage in the conversation.

If you’re bothered by your partner’s dirty dishes in the sink and your reaction is to turn away and not talk to your partner for the rest of the night, attempt to calm down and address the issue when you feel like you can discuss it in a respectful manner.
Rather than reacting with stonewalling:

items: Check yourself for feelings of being emotionally overwhelmed. Signs of being overwhelmed can be a flushed feeling in your body or face, an inability to form coherent responses, or possibly tears in your eyes.

Pause and take time out. Let the person you are speaking with know you need a break from the conflict discussion. You can table the discussion by saying something like, “Let’s leave this for another time, when we’re both calmer”.
Set the expectation that you’ll both return to the conversation as it is important.
In your time out, take a moment or two to do something calming such as listening to music or taking several slow, deep breaths.

components.text: Take a moment to reflect
Breaking patterns of destructive behavior in communication like these become easier when you are motivated and committed to change.

Have you seen any of these horsemen rise up in your interactions? Perhaps take out your journal and jot down some instances you can think of where one or more of these have come up for you. Feel free to share this with your coach if you’d like to discuss further.
Recovering from a Break-Up

Heartbreak can have many of the features of grief and trauma: sleeplessness, ruminations, and in some people, measurable clinical depression. So, what’s the cure for a broken heart? How long does it take to heal? There isn’t one remedy or secret formula but there are a few tips that can help you through the heartache of a break-up.
This activity will:

items: Explain why break-ups can affect us so strongly
Explain how break-ups can affect us
Provide tips on how to recover from a break-up

components.text: Oftentimes when we experience a break-up, it's not only the loss of the other person that hurts but the loss of a certain kind of life, with its own distinct experiences and social connections outside of the couple’s relationship. Feeling alone and in pain can temporarily impact our intellectual functioning and even our IQ. According to psychologist Guy Winch, people going through a break-up are likely to engage in highly idealized thinking about the ex-partner and the relationship, which can make healing even harder. But, there are things you can do to alleviate the pain.
Here are a few tips and ideas to help get through a break-up:

items: There is no way around the healing process. You just have to go through it, and experience it. Allow yourself to feel, even if it hurts.

Remind yourself of why the relationship didn’t work. In the aftermath of a break-up, it’s normal to look at the relationship through rose-colored glasses. You remember the good times. But thinking about what led to the decline of the relationship can help you come to terms with it being over.

Get reacquainted with yourself. Especially if you used to do things that your partner was more interested in, you now have the opportunity to do things you love and find inspiring. Even if you’re not really in the mood. Get up and get out!

Take care of your body. Exercise, eat healthy food, and drink water. Yes, you might want to drown yourself in booze, late nights, and chicken fingers, but it won’t make you feel better. A night or two of letting loose with a little unhealthy behavior may be OK, but too much partying or bad food on an emotionally empty stomach is not going to help you recover.

Seek closure within yourself. It’s typical to think that you can’t move on without “closure” from the other person. This is especially true when you haven’t allowed yourself to move on or even grieve the relationship. Only YOU can give yourself the permission to move on. By expecting the other person to validate the end of the relationship you remove yourself from the very personal process of healing. Accept the situation and heal from there. Only you can give that to yourself.

Reach out to see if any of your friends or family need help. A sense of purpose wrapped in love is extremely healing. Helping another person automatically makes you feel better and will give you a break from ruminating unproductively about your break-up.

Take your time. Everyone’s process is different. Give yourself time to heal. The moments after a break-up are incredible opportunities to check in with yourself and reimagine a future that has all sorts of new potential. If you find it difficult to imagine a future without your ex-partner, reach out to your coach for help!

properties.name: How to Turn Conflict into Connection

components.text: How to Turn Conflict into Connection

If you’re afraid to speak up in a relationship about an issue that’s bothering you because you don’t want to cause turmoil, you’re not alone. It’s common to want to avoid conflict. But, developing and practicing how to have a low negativity threshold when it comes to discussing issues with your partner can improve your relationship and help you both avoid resentment.
This activity will:

items: Describe what it means to have low negativity threshold;
Explain how a low negativity threshold can improve your relationship;
Provide you with a sample conversation for how to discuss issues.

components.text: Low negativity threshold
Research has shown that having a low negativity threshold can improve your relationships. So what is a low negativity threshold and how do you implement it?
Having a low negativity threshold means that when an issue arises that bothers you or your partner, you address it sooner rather than later.

Many people assume that ignoring problems in a relationship is better for the relationship than surfacing them. We often tell ourselves that we “shouldn’t sweat the small stuff.”  But according to research, couples who discuss problems soon after they arise are less likely to be resentful and are more resilient in their relationships. Discussing problems isn’t nagging. It’s about communication and making sure the minor issues don’t grow into bigger ones—that they don’t simmer until they bubble over.
How to start addressing issues in a relationship

In her TED Talk, researcher Hannah Fry says, “The most successful couples don’t let anything go unnoticed. They allow each other room to complain.” Successful couples—those less likely to get divorced—continually try to repair their relationship. But that’s easier said than done.
To prepare yourself for discussing an issue, ask yourself these questions:

items: What am I not saying to my partner that I want to discuss?
What am I afraid might happen if I do bring it up?
What do I want to happen by bringing it up?

components.text: It’s not easy to start the conversation. To begin, try using this sample script, or come up with your own.
Sample conversation starter

Hey ______.  There are some things that I’d like to share with you, but I’m afraid/shy/reluctant to because I fear ___________.  Ideally I’d like to be able to _________________________.  What I want to share/ask/discuss is ______________.  Thanks for listening. If you’re ready, is there anything you’d like to say in response to what I just shared?

Changing how you operate in a relationship is challenging, especially when you can’t control how the other person will react. But ignoring issues can make your relationship more difficult. Remember, the more you practice, the easier it’ll become. You may be surprised to learn that there are issues your partner has been wanting to discuss with you, too.
If you feel threatened, contact the National Domestic Violence Hotline at 1-800-799-7233. You can also get help via chat 24/7/365 through their website at https://www.thehotline.org/
Setting Relationship Boundaries

Boundaries are important for any healthy relationship, but there are different types of boundaries and different areas in which those boundaries can exist. Knowing about boundaries will give you the power to create and maintain them in your relationships. Boundaries are not simply about keeping people out—they’re about helping you create conscious connections with the people in your life.
This activity will:

items: Describe four different types of boundaries,
Explain where and how you can set boundaries.
Introduce you to the “Relationship Bill of Rights”

components.text: Healthy Boundaries

In relationships, you may find yourself wondering, “How did I get here?” “Why do I say yes when I want to say no?” and “This is making me feel uncomfortable.” If you do have these thoughts, it might be because you haven’t set healthy boundaries for yourself and the people in your life. When you have healthy boundaries, you’re able to have a clear sense of who you are and are better able to deal with these situations.

Understanding different types of boundaries—both unhealthy and healthy—is the first step towards creating healthy boundaries in your relationships. Next, you’ll also learn about the different types of boundaries, different domains in which to implement your boundaries, and the Relationship Bill of Rights.
Types of Boundaries
Soft Boundaries

Soft boundaries occur when there isn’t a clear definition and assertion of rights and responsibilities. Sharing too much about yourself too soon when you’re getting to know someone, reacting to and feeling responsible for someone else’s strong emotion, or being vulnerable to manipulation are all signs of soft boundaries. Having soft boundaries is like leaving the door to your home unlocked — anyone, including unwelcome guests, can enter whenever they like.
Rigid Boundaries

Not being willing to let someone else get close to you physically or emotionally, or both, signifies rigid boundaries. Often those with a history of unhealthy relationships, trauma, or abuse can have rigid boundaries. Rigid boundaries can lead to isolation and loneliness. It’s like living in a locked-up castle surrounded by a mote. No one can get in, and you can’t get out.
Porous Boundaries

A porous boundary occurs when you’re feeling unsure about what to let in and what to keep out. Porous boundaries are a mix of soft and rigid boundaries. It’s having inconsistent boundaries, which are usually dictated by the desires and needs of others. Having porous boundaries can make it seem like you’re easygoing on the outside, but on the inside you feel insecure about your relationship.
Flexible/Healthy Boundaries

When you have flexible, or healthy boundaries, you’re able to effectively protect yourself. You choose what you share and what you keep to yourself depending on the situation. You’re not easily manipulated either. You have a sense of self and are able to say yes and no on your terms. You have an understanding of the difference between your needs and the needs of others. You understand your commitments, both to yourself and to others. And finally, you have control over your inner world and are able to read situations correctly.
Boundary Domains: Where to set your boundaries
Physical boundaries

Physical boundaries include your body, sense of personal space, sexual orientation, and privacy. These boundaries are expressed through clothing, shelter, noise tolerance, verbal instruction, and body language. Examples of violations of physical boundaries include a close talker; a super loud neighbor, roommate, or family member; inappropriate touching, such as unwanted sexual advances; looking through others’ personal files and emails; and intruding in on other people’s personal space, e.g., someone barging into your office without knocking.
Emotional and Intellectual Boundaries

Emotional and intellectual boundaries protect your sense of self-esteem. Having these boundaries allow you to separate your feelings from someone else’s feelings. Also known as codependency, when you allow your partner’s mood to dictate your mood, it’s a sign of unhealthy emotional boundaries. Other examples include sacrificing your plans, dreams, or goals in order to please others, and blaming someone else for your problems, rather than taking responsibility for yourself.
Your Relationship Bill of Rights

To help you create healthy boundaries in relationships, know your rights! Review these anytime you need a reminder or you find yourself feeling uncomfortable in a relationship. Get inspired! Can you come up with other rights that fit with your own life?

items: I have a right to say no without feeling guilty.
I have a right to be treated with respect.
I have a right to make my needs as important as another person’s needs.
I have a right to accept my mistakes and failures.
I have a right not to meet others’ unreasonable expectations of me.

properties.name: How You Feel in a Relationship

components.text: How You Feel in a Relationship

Traditionally in relationships, we focus on what we “want” in the relationship. But sometimes going after what we want, or getting what we want, can distract us from how we’re feeling in the relationship. When we don’t pay attention to or understand how we feel in a relationship, it can be difficult to assess the relationship itself. Figuring out how you want to feel in a relationship can help you discover what’s working and what isn’t.
In this activity, you’ll

items: Answer a series of questions that will allow you to explore how you want to feel in a relationship.
Use prompts to help you visualize how you want to feel and changes you can make to have those feelings.

components.text: These prompts can help you figure out how you want to feel in a relationship. Be honest with yourself when answering these questions. Feel free to think about the answers, or write them down on a piece of paper. If you choose to write them down, you can save the paper and use it as a check-in every once in a while in a relationship.
How I want to feel in a relationship is __________.
How I have felt in relationships is ______________.
I was raised to think romantic relationships are __________________.
My greatest hope around relationships is ____________________.
My greatest fear around relationships is _____________________.
Visualize feeling how you want to feel

Use your past experiences in relationships, or when you’ve been single, to shape your hopes for the future. For example, if you’ve felt lonely either in a relationship, or outside of one, you may hope to feel more connected in the future. Think of ways that you can create a feeling of connectedness in your next relationship, or changes you could make in your current relationship.
To improve how you feel in a relationship, these questions can help you think about how you might make changes to your current or future relationship:

items: Do you need better boundaries?
Can you change how you look for a partner?
Can you voice your needs differently?
Can you create more time for connection?
Can you be a more attentive partner?

components.text: Getting from where you are to where you want to be usually involves a series of small steps. Figuring out how you want to feel can guide how you set your goals to get there. Chat with your coach for help with this process.

properties.name: The Basics: Building Healthy Relationships of Any Kind
properties.description: The Basics: Building Healthy Relationships of Any Kind

components.text: The Basics: Building Healthy Relationships of Any Kind

Join Headspace Care’s relationship guru and coach Shula as she chats with Headspace Care coach Jeff about building relationships—not just with romantic partners, but with friends, family, and colleagues, too. Plus, learn why healthy relationships can be so challenging, and how to overcome those challenges.
Do you want to listen to the audio or read the transcript?
Building Healthy Relationships of Any Kind
The audio is about to start. Turn up the volume or put on your headphones.
Building Healthy Relationships of Any Kind
Jeff Boyle:

Hello everyone, and welcome to our podcast series on relationships. I'm Boyle and I'm a Behavioral Health Coach here at Headspace Care. And I'm going to be your host today. You know, February is the month of love. It's Valentine's Day and so today we're going to be talking about relationships, not just romantic, but also relationships with families and friends, lovers and professional relationships at work. Relationships really carry a significant importance in our lives. They are the trickiest, sometimes, things for us to manage. So today we're going to be talking with a coach from Headspace Care, Coach Shula Melamed, who is uniquely qualified to talk to us though this topic. And Shula, can you get started today by telling us a little bit about yourself?
Shula Melamed:

Sure. Hi, Jeff. Thank you so much for having me. I'm super excited to talk on this topic and I'm just so passionate about it. I'm a coach here at Headspace Care, but I've also been running my own relationship and wellbeing coaching practice since 2008. Before I actually went to school for psychology or began coaching, I worked for an upscale matchmaker.
Jeff Boyle:
Really!
Shula Melamed:

Yes, it was a total... How I got directed into that, it was random. But apparently I really like working with relationships, because I'm also a wedding officiant, as well, so there's that. I always joke that I help people meet, marry and maintain their relationships. But as you said, we're going to be talking about so much more than just romantic relationships.
Jeff Boyle:

Awesome. Thank you so much, Shula. It sounds like you're just the right person to have this conversation, so interesting. In this episode, we're going to focus on building healthy relationships. When you're ready, Shula, let's dive into some questions.
Shula Melamed:
I'm here. I'm ready. Let's do it.
Jeff Boyle:
Great. Great. Okay. Shula, why do you think that relationships come up so often when we're coaching here at Headspace Care?
Shula Melamed:

Well, I think that one of the things that we talk about with the relationships that come up is how to build healthy relationships. That's the thing that comes up so much here. I think that one of the reasons why relationships are such a hot topic and why it's hard to build healthy relationship at times is because we're really not given any relationship education.
Jeff Boyle:
So true, so true.
Shula Melamed:

Right? It's like we're given a relationship socialization. It's what we saw in our environments. It's our caretakers. It's people that we went to school with, people in our community and our peers. These are all people who are giving us that information about how to relate. I often ask folks, what are some of the myths and messages that you got around relationships? I ask them to take a second and think about, what were you taught about what makes a relationship great, good, acceptable? Can you think of things that you were told that were explicit things, that would just pop in your mind when I say that?
Jeff Boyle:
No, not at all. As you're talking about this, I'm thinking it's all by example, observing other people and nothing real structured there.
Shula Melamed:

Sometimes they're explicit and sometimes they're implicit, so treating people a certain way, saying things, not saying things and how creating and keeping those bonds are dependent on something that you're doing or how you're being or how you're treating another person or how they're treating you. We create a relational reality.
Jeff Boyle:
Hmm, gosh. Can you tell me more about that? That sounds really interesting.
Shula Melamed:

I use this term all the time when I'm talking about this, trying to explain the relational socialization piece. The relational reality is really how we think about relationships and what we believe to be true about them. What constitutes a good relationship? What do we avoid and what do we move towards in relationships?
Jeff Boyle:
It's also different for everybody, too.
Shula Melamed:

Yeah, for sure. But some of it can also be, there are some things that can be imposed as norms and some things that can be imposed as standards. They might not be things that are necessarily healthy or anything that is really congruent with what our own experience is or what our own beliefs are and maybe might seem almost hypocritical in what we observe.
Jeff Boyle:
Interesting. Shula, that really takes me to the next question. What would you say are some of the characteristics of healthy relationships?
Shula Melamed:

Some of the things that I would say are characteristics of healthy relationship would be mutual respect, trust, honesty, support, fairness, separate identities, good communication. Also a sense of playfulness and fondness and intimacy and sexuality, if it's an intimate relationship, obviously, is different, as much as you want or as little as you want. All of these take work. Most relationships are most likely a combination of both healthy and unhealthy characteristics. We're all learning and people aren't perfect and everybody has their issues and the relationships need to be maintained. Healthy relationships take work to be really conscious about how people are treating each other. This applies to all relationships, work relationships, friendships, family, romantic.
Jeff Boyle:

Always a lot of effort going into them. I'm wondering about barriers. What are some of the barriers that people have? And what are some tools and activities that you recommend to help overcome barriers in relationships?
Shula Melamed:

Well, I think one of the barriers that people have for having a hard time being in healthy relationships or building healthy relationships is that a lot of people, they tend to forget to check in with themselves on how they are feeling in their relationship. How do you feel in this relationship? We could talk about what's going on and this person did this and I didn't do that and they did this and there was this thing and then they said this and they talked to... It could be all of this stuff. But the whole object of relating is considering yourself and another person or persons at the same time. It's something that takes a lot of awareness. It can slip into an unhealthy dynamic if we're not paying attention or the... It's something that needs nurturing.
Jeff Boyle:
A lot of reflection involved, too.
Shula Melamed:

Absolutely. Reflecting on yourself. Then also putting yourself in the other person's shoes and understanding why they may be behaving in a certain way. So checking in with yourself and be like, “How am I feeling right now?” Not, what are they doing, what am I doing? How am I feeling? And is that feeling something that's created from this dynamic? Is it from something that I need to work on in myself? Is it because my partner or the other person hasn't worked through certain things and it's being projected upon me?
Shula Melamed:

If it gets a bit lopsided one way or another, those are the moments when it's important to check in with yourself and see where you're placing yourself and others in your life and to zoom out and give yourself a chance, do a little grounding to see where you are with the other, or what is your part in this disagreement. Are you taking on too much? Or are you projecting onto the other person? We have an amazing activity in the app. I'm not just saying this because I created it. It's a how-do-you-want-to-feel-in-a-relationship activity card, which has been really illuminating for a lot of folks.
Jeff Boyle:
It's definitely one that I send to members frequently. Those lopsided moments that you were talking about just sound like real learning opportunities and when things get really interesting.
Shula Melamed:

Exactly. If we can see that relationships are learning activities and there are places that we can better ourselves and learn... It's part of coaching. It's part of the whole life, overall wellbeing, relationships and learning from them. It's so important. I love that you said that. It's key.
Jeff Boyle:

I have one last question before we wrap up. Basically, when do you think it's time for someone to relieve a relationship or possibly to maybe reestablish the rules of engagements with the people in their lives?
Shula Melamed:

It's a very personal thing. I mean, I would say, first of all, if you are unsafe, if you feel like you are in danger, if you feel that there is something that's really, really wrong and you feel threatened physically, emotionally, et cetera, definitely there are a lot of resources to reach out and look for help. There is help for you. There's no situation that is too sticky that you can't find a resource. I just want to put that out if there's any DV and domestic violence and all that.
Shula Melamed:

In general, in a situation that might not be as extreme as that, just checking in with yourself. If you recognize that there's some conflicts or inconsistency with how you would like to feel and what is happening in your relationship, when you realize that you might be having an issue speaking up for yourself, or you're having a hard time being open with your partner, friend, colleague, family member, if you're having an issue of what they're bringing forward, checking in with yourself and be like, why is it so hard for me to take what they're saying right now or to acknowledge our need? That's the time that you really need to have those healthy relationship skills and the confidence to step outside of what you might be used to, to get curious. And like you were saying, learn from the situation.
Jeff Boyle:

Thank you. So, Shula, thank you so much today for sharing some really good insight on building healthy relationships. For everyone who's listening, remember, that if you're looking for support, you can always reach out to a professional for help. If your company or health plan offers Headspace Care, we encourage you to download the Headspace Care emotional support app, enter your email address or personal information to get started and then keep an eye out on your inbox for an email so you can complete your signup process. It's super easy to connect with a Headspace Care behavioral health coach, just like Shula, who will be able to help you navigate challenges and share strategies with you based on your needs. Once again, thanks for joining us today and thank you to Coach Shula.
Shula Melamed:
Thanks, Jeff.

properties.name: Give a Little Love: Nurturing Existing Relationships
properties.description: Give a Little Love: Nurturing Existing Relationships

components.text: Give a Little Love: Nurturing Existing Relationships

Listen to Headspace Care’s relationship guru and coach Shula chat with Headspace Care coach Jeff in this fun discussion about strategies to nurture and maintain relationships of any kind, from romantic partners and family to colleagues, friends, and others.
Do you want to listen to the audio or read the transcript?
Nurturing Existing Relationships
The audio is about to start. Turn up the volume or put on your headphones.
Jeff:

Hello everyone and welcome back to our series on relationships. I'm Jeff Boyle and I'm a behavioral health coach here at Headspace Care and your host today. This is part two of our three part series. Last time we spoke a bit about how and why relationships are such a hot topic, what the characteristics of healthy relationships are, and why is it sometimes hard for folks to build healthy relationships. Today, we are joined once again by our resident relationship expert Shula Melamed, to discover the secrets to nurturing and maintaining healthy relationships. Hey there, Shula.
Shula:
Hi, Jeff. Thanks for having me back.
Jeff:
Oh, you're so welcome. How are you doing today?
Shula:
I'm doing well. Thanks for asking. I hope you're doing well as well.
Jeff:
Yes.
Shula:

So just for those of you who missed last time, I am also a coach here at Headspace Care, and I've also been running my own relationship and wellbeing coaching practice since 2008. And as you know, or as you might find out, if you listened to the first podcast, which I highly recommend, you will know that my passion is speaking on this topic of relationships. So I'm really, really looking forward to continuing the conversation.
Jeff:

Oh, me too Shula. Thank you so much for coming back to talk with us. So let's jump right into some questions. My first question is, once you have a healthy relationship or if you want to make your relationship even healthier, what are some important skills that we need to have to help us maintain and nurture our relationships?
Shula:

Great question. And I absolutely love the framing of it as a skill and the image of nurturing. I really, really love the phrase, the grass is greener where it's watered, because to me, there's the other phrase obviously, the grass is greener on the other side, but-
Jeff:
Yeah, I've heard that one.
Shula:

Yeah, yeah. That's one that people use often, but I love where it's watered, because it's all about, it's a vibrant image about the wonders of maintenance, right? Like what happened to that little piece of lawn if you just took care of it and loved it and nurtured it.
Jeff:
Right.
Shula:

So I know that might sound really agricultural or whatever, but I do believe that relationships are living, breathing, dynamic ecosystems. So a few of the things that come to mind, as far as the skills go, there are many skills, but I guess the top three would be communication, conflict management, and conscious connection, or what's ordinarily referred to as healthy boundaries. So the three C's.
Jeff:

That's interesting. So the three C's of relationships. I really love that. Helps us keep it top of mind. I'd love to dive into each one of those, a little deeper, if that's okay. Can we start with conscious connection? What you were talking about with healthy boundaries. Can you expand on that a little bit more?
Shula:

Absolutely. So boundaries are guidelines, rules, and limits that a person sets to let other people know what behavior is acceptable to them and what they have to offer. So it's a personal limit that allows others to know how, and in what ways another person is okay with being treated. So a lot of times when people say boundaries, they think, boom, let's set up the moat, let's close the door, push everyone away. People who are avoidant, they love to interpret it that way. But that's not really what it's about. It's really about consciously connecting with another person.
Jeff:
Really being mindful about it.
Shula:

Exactly. And knowing that there are agreements there, so there are physical boundaries that are your body, sense of personal space, sexual orientation, privacy, even your phone is something that is a physical boundary, right.
Jeff:
Sure, sure.
Shula:

Yeah, which is surprising for some people because like, “Oh how is that a physical boundary?” That's going into to your stuff. And then emotional, intellectual boundaries are your sense of self-esteem and your ability to separate your feelings from another person. So flexible or healthy boundaries effectively protect the person who has them and allows a person who's engaging with them to know what's okay. And the person chooses what to let in and what to keep out and it's situation specific. When you have a healthy sense of boundaries, you're able to navigate different situations and check in with yourself.
Jeff:
Seems super important.
Shula:

Exactly because it's not just one size fits, right. It really asks you to be in touch with what you want in relationships, how you want to be treated, and how you want to feel. It's deeply personal. And it's all about giving yourself permission to stand in your yeses and your nos. And it's a practice.
Jeff:
It is the practice, that's for sure.
Shula:

And we also have an amazing in app exercise that I just so happened to design that we're sharing here, setting relationship boundaries. So if you're not really sure how to do it, you can work on that.
Jeff:

Oh, that's really good to know. It seems like this is a great transition to talk about communication next, another one of the three C's, since the most effective way to set those really important boundaries is actually to say them out loud, to state them.
Shula:
Yes. Imagine that. How many times have you heard that from your members or from people in your life about expecting another person to know exactly what they're thinking?
Jeff:
Mind reading.
Shula:
Exactly. I don't know about you, but I'm not a mind-reader, I'm a coach.
Jeff:
Exactly.
Shula:

And it's probably very likely that your family, friends and colleagues are not mind readers either or might not really have a sense of what you need, especially if you don't come out with it and say what it is that you need. There's a great quote about communication that is largely attributed to George Bernard Shaw, but it could be anyone. These quotes tend to get recycled.
Jeff:
Sure.
Shula:
But it's a great quote, regardless. Whoever you are, thank you. And it's, “the single biggest problem in communication is the illusion that it has taken place.”
Jeff:
Ah, that's powerful.
Shula:

Yeah. So, people feel like something has been communicated and it hasn't. So use your words, speaking up. And the great thing about having worked on your boundaries and acknowledging them is that you have a sense of what you'd like to express. And the reasons why you're not able to communicate or why it's difficult for some people, it's something that we're not necessarily taught at times. We don't often get a relationship education, we get a relationship socialization. So you might've learned somewhere that advocating for your own desires and needs is unacceptable in some way.
Jeff:
Right.
Shula:

Or you might have been conditioned by partners or loved ones to be low maintenance in order to be lovable. And in some cases, people might feel like their needs are overwhelming to them and they might need help discerning what is actually a basic relational right. So there's a lot to this. So it's something, getting right with your communication style and understanding it and understanding if you're not communicating is really important. There's a great in-app exercise called communication and relationships. It's geared more towards work, but it's applicable across the board and it's a skill you can build. That's the awesome thing about it.
Jeff:

Those in-app exercises sound really helpful too. Shula, what are some of the biggest barriers to communication? Most people don't really enjoy confrontation. So conflict, the last of the three C's of relationships, seems like a good next point for us to talk about.
Shula:

Yes, indeed. Yes. So conflict management is a huge part of having healthy relationships of any kind. Yes, many people are conflict averse and sometimes to the point of never really saying anything or standing up for themselves. So it can create issues for them in expressing themselves and communicating their needs. And this can be present again for a number of reasons. Many people have been in or witnessed relationships where conflict was extremely unhealthy, toxic, and destructive. So when I talk about conflict being an important part of healthy relationships, it's very important that we recognize that it's healthy conflict, not something where you're feeling unsafe, or if you're in a situation where it's a toxic situation. And we have resources here on the page that you can go to if you feel that you're in a situation like that.
Jeff:
Sure, sure.
Shula:

But a lot of times where it's just general conflict or where you're bumping up against each other, some people feel like it's the end of a relationship and will do anything to safeguard that relationship, including abandoning themselves. And this is because, for some reason, they have started using this as a survival strategy. And perhaps you don't need to do that in the relationship you're in. Or if you want to work on your skills, it's something to look into. Some people feel that letting things slide to keep the peace is something that is a very good skill to have, but often it creates issues down the line. So it's important to normalize a skill around conflict and understanding your relationship to conflict, normalize disagreements as part of the relational landscape and being able to-
Jeff:
And addressing as they go.
Shula:

Exactly. Speaking of addressing it as it goes, there's a concept that I like to share, which is called the low negativity threshold theory. And it posits that the most successful relationships are ones where couples allow each other to complain and to work together to constantly repair the tiny issues between them, as opposed to bottling feelings up and exploding later. And again, this can be applied to any kind of relationship, not nagging and nitpicking and all that stuff, but just being like, “Hey, that's not okay,” or, “Hey”-
Jeff:
That sounds like such a useful approach to address the small things as they come up and not let them build up into something big that's going to explode.
Shula:
