Exactly. And also when you work on things together as any kind of diet, whether it's a couple or friends or colleagues or whatever it is. When you work through the conflict together can actually bring you closer and it can create greater understanding or intimacy and communication with the other person.
Jeff:
That makes sense.
Shula:
We have another in-app exercise that I just so happen to design. It's how to turn conflict into connection and it gives you a template in how to start approaching these conversations.
Jeff:

Awesome. That sounds great. And I've got one last question for today and it's this, how would you say nurturing relationships in the areas of family and friends, romantic and professional are aligned? What are some of the unique distinctions or considerations there?
Shula:

I think the three C's can be applied to any relationship. I think that every relationship can benefit from having those three skills in place and to really understand your relationship to those three skills and understand where you need to get some help. And also understanding the other person's and understanding that they might have issues in those areas as well. The unique di-
Jeff:
Oh my gosh. Thank you-
Shula:
That's it?
Jeff:
Thank you for that.
Shula:
Oh yeah.
Jeff:
Thank you for that.
Shula:

You're so welcome. Yeah. And the unique distinctions are just, obviously when you're talking about work and you're talking about romance and you're talking about parenting, all of those things have their own unique considerations. And so, those are just unique for each of those. So...
Jeff:

Wow. Well, thank you Shula, for talking about the three C's of relationships. Communication, conflict management, and conscious connection, that boundary setting that you talked about. And also for sharing really practical strategies for nurturing and maintaining relationships. And for everyone who's listening, remember that if you're looking for support, you can always reach out to a professional for help. If your company or health plan offers Headspace Care, we encourage you to download the Headspace Care emotional support app, enter your email address or personal information to get started, and then keep an eye out on your inbox for the email to help you complete your signup process. It's super easy to connect with a Headspace Care behavioral health coach just like Shula, who would be able to help you navigate your challenges and share strategies with you based on your needs. Once again, thank you for joining us today and thank you to coach Shula.
Shula:
Thanks Jeff.

components.text: Taking Care: How Relationships Can Affect Your Mental Health

Listen to Headspace Care’s relationship guru and coach Shula chat with Headspace Care coach Jeff in this discussion about the effect that some relationships can have on our mental health, for better or worse.
Do you want to listen to the audio or read the transcript?
How Relationships Can Affect Your Mental Health
The audio is about to start. Turn up the volume or put on your headphones.
Jeff Boyle:

Hello, and welcome back to part three of our relationship series. Once again, I'm Jeff Boyle, your host for today and a behavioral health coach here at Headspace Care. In part one of this series, we talked about building healthy relationships. And then last time in part two, coach Shula shared really practical strategies for nurturing and maintaining relationships. So today, we're going to talk about why good relationships are so important for our overall health and well-being, and this is super interesting. We're joined again today by our relationship guru, Shula Melamed. And welcome back, Shula. How are you doing today?
Shula Melamed:
I'm doing well, Jeff. Thank you so much once again for having me. How are you today?
Jeff Boyle:
Sure. So great to have you back. I'm doing great and really looking forward to this topic on overall health and well-being and how relationships are so important to that.
Shula Melamed:

Yeah. I've had such a great time talking about all things relationships with you. As you know, we're always trying to hit every single part of the wellness wheel and relationships are definitely part of it. So if any of you were listening for the first time, I would recommend that you listen to one and two, but if you're here, great. I am also a coach here at Headspace Care and I've been running my own relationship and well-being coaching practice since 2008. Relationships are definitely a passion of mine, and it has been an honor to have this conversation with you, Jeff.
Jeff Boyle:
Oh, Shula, thank you. Really, the pleasure has been all mine. So let's get started today. My first question is, what are some of the general benefits of relationships?
Shula Melamed:

Well, while relating to others is crucial, how we relate to them is the biggest factor in our overall well-being. So everything's like, “Oh, if you're married, then you live longer,” and, “If you do this...” and it's not just being in a relationship or having relationships with your family, your friends or colleagues. It's the kind of relationships you have. So relationships can add to your overall health and well-being, but they can also be harmful to your overall well-being.
Jeff Boyle:
Interesting. Thank you for that distinction. Can you tell us a little bit more about how healthy relationships can improve our overall well-being?
Shula Melamed:

Absolutely. These effects can be psychological. They can be physiological as well. So it's very interesting. There was one study that found that midlife women who were in highly satisfying marriages and marital type relationships, long term relationships, had a lower risk for cardiovascular disease compared those in less satisfying marriages.
Jeff Boyle:
Really?
Shula Melamed:

Yeah, literally their heart and all of that was affected by having less satisfying relationships. There's so many benefits to connecting with others. We've talked so much about loneliness, especially in the last year, but this is something that is absolutely true. They have found that it helps to relieve harmful levels of stress to connect with other people. That level of stress can adversely affect coronary arteries, gut function, insulin regulation and the immune system.
Jeff Boyle:
Kind of all encompassing there.
Shula Melamed:

Exactly. Another line of research suggests that caring behaviors, so caring for other people, can trigger the release of stress reducing hormones. So not only is it good to receive affection and have positive regard from your [inaudible 00:04:00] ... partners and everything, but it's also really good for you to express and care for others. It can actually help reduce your stress.
Jeff Boyle:

Thank you for sharing that. That's that sounds really amazing. How healthy relationships positively impact our physical health is so interesting, and I'm wondering about the opposite: unhealthy relationships. How can they compromise our well-being and affect our overall health? What are some of the potential signs or risk factors?
Shula Melamed:

Yeah. Yeah. So a relative lack of social ties is associated with depression and also, with later life cognitive declined, as well as with increased mortality even. So one study, which examined data for more than 300000 people found that a lack of strong relationships increase the risk of premature death from all causes by 50%.
Jeff Boyle:
Wow.
Shula Melamed:

Yeah, it's huge and it's an effect on mortality risk roughly comparable to smoking up to 15 cigarettes a day and greater than obesity and physical inactivity. Socialization or community or anything is outside of what you would normally think of the wellness wheel or for overall health, but [inaudible 00:05:26]. Other studies have linked disappointing or negative interactions with family and friends with poor health. One line of research has found signs of reduced immunity in couples, especially during hostile marital spats. So it kind of comes back to that study that I referenced before.
Jeff Boyle:

Shula, this is such valuable information and just a lot to grasp. Thank you for sharing it. I'm wondering how can we shift things in our relationships when we feel that they might be affecting our overall well-being? How can we kind of turn that around?
Shula Melamed:

Well, first, by checking in with ourselves and how we're feeling in our relationships. So we discussed that a little bit, the importance of that in the first podcast and we discuss the how I want to feel in relationship exercise. So trying to figure out how are you feeling in your relationships right now and what would you like to see change? Where do you need to spend more time? Where do you need to pull back? Where do you need to possibly come to grips with some tough questions like, “Am I lonely? Do I need to reach out to people more? How does that make me feel?”
Jeff Boyle:
That self-reflection.
Shula Melamed:

Yeah, so self-reflection and understanding where you are and if you need to engage more socially or to improve the quality of your relationships. Then also, by calling on the three Cs as we discussed in the last podcast, so really creating a space to communicate, to approach conflict and manage it in a healthy way and to create conscious connection. So those three skills that we discussed in podcast number two can apply them to your relationships and see what relationships can be nurtured and can be expanded on and that are, if the other people, persons, or people or persons are able to meet you halfway and to work on that with you, that's a healthy relationship. And if not, seeing if there really is a place in your life for that relationship and if it's actually improving the quality of your life or if it's not.
Jeff Boyle:
That's completely up to you and your decisions.
Shula Melamed:
Yes. Yeah.
Jeff Boyle:

Very interesting. For everyone, really to learn more about those three Cs of healthy relationships, communication, conflict management and conscious connection, that boundary setting, please check out part two of this series. Shula, any final thoughts as we close out our discussion about relationships?
Shula Melamed:

Absolutely. I would really like to emphasize that healthy relationships are built, and these skills can be acquired if one is willing and given the opportunity to expand on what one originally has thought is possible for them in relationships. So if you're frustrated with being able to express herself, if you're frustrated with how other people are approaching you, if you're frustrated with... If you want to expand your social circle, just know that connecting with other people is something that we learn to do along the lifespan and it shifts and it changes. Focusing on having healthy relationships is as worthwhile and as important as a healthy diet, as moving, as stimulating yourself intellectually and spiritually and everything. So I would really encourage people to go out and work on those things and really have and build better relationships.
Jeff Boyle:
And know that those are skills that you can build.
Shula Melamed:
Absolutely.
Jeff Boyle:

Shula, I have to say it's been a joy, really being able to talk to you throughout this series about relationships from building healthy ones to nurturing them and understanding the effects and impacts of relationships in our lives. For everyone who's listening, remember that if you're looking for support, you can always reach out to a professional for help. If your company or healthcare offers Headspace Care, we really encourage you to download the Headspace Care emotional support app. Enter in your email address or your personal information to get started and then keep an eye out on your inbox for an email so that you can complete your signup process. It's super easy to connect with a Headspace Care behavioral health coach, just like Shula, who would be able to help you navigate challenges that you have and share strategies with you based on your individual needs. Thanks once again for joining us today and thank you to coach Shula.
Shula Melamed:
Thanks, Jeff.
Creating and Honoring Boundaries
This video class will help you learn what boundaries are and the role they play in relationships, and get tips on creating and honoring boundaries.
Cracking the Communication Code
This video class will help you understand how you communicate with others and get tips on honing your communication skills.
Back to School Thriving

Learn how you can shape your family’s approach to this new school season and survive the challenges of this unfamiliar journey. For non-parents, learn how you can tangibly support the parents in your life.
Meaningful Connections

Meaningful connections don’t happen without effort. But when you’re feeling lonely, finding the confidence and motivation to put in the work can be daunting. Learn strategies that can help you dig out from your feelings of loneliness to start building relationships that energize you.
Square Breathing to Relax
"Square Breathing has 4 easy steps:

items: Inhale through the nose
Hold your breath
Exhale through mouth
Hold your breath

components.text: Repeat for as long as you need it.  It usually takes around 2 minutes for someone to feel relaxed.
Counting Breaths

Counting breaths slows your heart rate, your breathing, and can lower your blood pressure, all of which can ease your fight-or-flight response. Counting adds a meditative quality to this technique, which can be particularly helpful for quieting persistent worried thoughts.
In this audio activity you’ll:

items: Learn a new technique to calm down in moments of high stress.

components.text: Here's how to count your breaths:

items: Inhale, filling your lungs with air.
Take a long exhale, and count one.
Inhale again, then exhale and count two.
Repeat, counting all the way up to five.
Start from the beginning and repeat for 5-10 minutes.

components.text: It’s helpful to find somewhere comfortable to sit or lie down where you won't be interrupted. When you're ready to begin, audio guidance will walk you through the whole technique.
Your Current Stress Level
How stressed are you feeling right now?
Counting Breaths
Grab your headphones and let's get to it.
Your Current Stress Level
How stressed are you feeling right now?

decreased.title: Glad you're feeling better.
decreased.body: You just completed Counting Breaths and it seems to have worked for you. Nice! You can continue to do this sort of exercise to help you calm down the next time you’re feeling stressed.

same.title: Your stress level stayed the same.
same.body: You just completed Counting Breaths, and it doesn’t look like it affected your stress level. It’s OK—it doesn’t work for everyone every time. You can try to do this sort of exercise next time you’re feeling stressed to see if it works better for you with more practice. Or, talk to your coach to find another activity that fits your needs better.

increased.title: Your stress level increased.
increased.body: You just completed Counting Breaths, and it doesn’t look like it helped your stress levels. It’s OK. It doesn’t work for everyone every time. You can try to do this sort of exercise next time you’re feeling stressed to see if it works better for you with more practice. Or, talk to your coach to find another activity that fits your needs better.

components.text: Counting Breaths to Reduce Anxiety
Relax with some deep breathing.
Deep breathing can have immediate benefits. It can relax your muscles, slow your heart rate, and decrease your blood pressure. Use this breathing exercise anytime you need.
This two-minute audio exercise will guide you through the deep breathing.
How anxious are you feeling right now?
The audio is about to begin. Make sure you’ve got your headphones if you need them and your volume is up.  Feel free to close your eyes while you listen.
How anxious are you feeling right now?
Nice work trying a skill. Give this a try the next time you’re feeling anxious. The more you practice the better it will work.
Focus Your Energy

With so much going on in life, figuring out where to devote your time and energy can be overwhelming. When you’re able to focus your energy, you can feel more engaged, less stressed and productive. Over time, you'll start to feel like you have more direction and purpose.
In this activity you'll:

items: Recall times when you were happy, proud, and engaged.
Define and prioritize your values.
Create some long-term goals.
Craft your own personal vision statement to help you understand where you should be focusing your energy.

components.text: This activity requires some deep thought and evaluation. It may help to find a quiet place where you can fully engage.
Define Your Values

Your values -- in other words, what’s important to you -- can help guide you in many ways. Knowing your values will help you prioritize your tasks, which will help you know when to say no and when you can dive into something. Living a life according to your values helps you feel more engaged and content.
So, let's get started defining your values. We have a few questions that will help you get there. Write down your answers in a piece of paper.
Think of a time you were really happy. What were you doing?  e.g. I was eating a delicious meal with my good friends.
During this happy time, who were you with? e.g. I was with my partner, and my friends Justin, Jill, Alex, and Andrew.
Where were you? e.g. We were in my backyard, grilling.
Now, think of a time you've been proud.
Tell us about a time that you've felt really proud of yourself. e.g. I felt really proud when I was able to complete my first 5K.
During this proud time, who were you with? e.g. I wasn't with anyone I knew. It was just me, the other runners, and the road.
And where were you during this proud time? e.g. It was a race downtown.
And, lastly, what's a time when you felt really engaged?

Tell us about a time when you felt really engaged in what you were doing. e.g. The other day at work I was tutoring Daniel and I felt like he and I had a conversation that was a real breakthrough toward getting him motivated to complete his homework.
Who were you with when you were feeling engaged? e.g. Just me and my student, Daniel.
And where were you? e.g. In my classroom.

Reviewing your answers to the previews questions, you may see some patterns, which could be clues to what you value in life. If you don’t see any patterns, it may mean that there are many moments that you value. Now, select your top five values from the list below. The moments you've been happy, proud, and engaged will help guide you. If you're having trouble choosing just five, try asking yourself “why?” until you get to a value.
For instance, if I wrote that I was happy when I was having lunch with a friend, then I'd ask myself:

items: Why? Because I enjoy getting lunch with my friends.
Why? Because my friendships are important to me.
Why? Because I value having close relationships.

components.text: Now, select your top five values from the list below. The moments you've been happy, proud, and engaged will help guide you. If you're having trouble choosing just five, try asking yourself “why?” until you get to a value.
Review the list of values below and choose your top five values:

items: Balance
Community
Compassion
Courage
Creativity
Empathy
Enjoyment
Faith
Fairness
Family
Friendship
Health
Humility
Independence
Integrity
Leadership
Location
Loyalty
Perseverance
Power
Prestige
Respect
Security
Self-improvement
Service
Success
Tolerance
Wealth
Wisdom

components.text: Now it’s time to prioritize your values.(This is challenging for a lot of people!)

You might already prioritize them all the time, often without realizing it. When you’re really busy, you have to make a choice about what to do next. You might ask yourself, “What’s the most important thing that needs to happen?” When you do that, you’re prioritizing your values.

Knowing your values and their relative ranks will help you when your values come in conflict with each other. For example, if your child’s dance recital conflicts with your weekly yoga class, but you’ve ranked “Family” as your most important value and “Health” as your third most important, then your answer about your priority becomes clear: attending the dance recital.

From the list of your top values, choose your most important value and write it down. Feel free to change the wording of it to be more specific or general if that will help. If these values were in conflict with each other, which would win?
Now, write your second most important value.
Choose and write your third most important value. If you realize it differs from the list above or you want to change the word, that's fine. Write whatever you want.
What's your fourth most important value?
And what's fifth most important? There's likely a long list of other values that didn't even make it to this list.
Next, you’ll define your goals. You’ll get to see the final ranked list of values at the end of this activity.
Thinking about your long-term goals
Taking some time to think about some of your life goals can help you know where to focus your energy.
Take some time first to reflect on a long-term goal for this area of your life. Say ten years in the future, or some distant amount of time that works for you.
What's a ten-year goal around the goal you chose?
Now, take a moment to reflect on where you'd like to be in five years. What's a five-year goal?
What goal could you accomplish in the next three months?
And, finally, is there anything that you could do today to move toward your goal? If yes, what?
Your Personal Mission Statement

Most organizations have mission statements that help guide the priorities and efforts of the company and employees. Try creating a personal mission or values statement that could serve to guide you as you try to focus your energy.
Now that you know your priorities, your values, and some of your goals, creating a mission statement should be easier.
To get you started, we've created a draft for you based on what you've told us so far.
A DRAFT OF YOUR PERSONAL MISSION STATEMENT
The things I value most are ... I have many goals in life, but one of them is ...

Feel free to add to this statement, take something away, or completely rewrite it. The point of a personal mission statement is that the words hold meaning for you and help you focus your energy toward your goals and what you really value in life.

If you found any part of this activity useful, try writing it down and putting it in a visible place, like a sticky note on your computer, your calendar, or share it with a loved one and encourage them to write one, too. Feel free to return to this activity card any time you find yourself feeling like you don't know where to focus your energy.
Go for a Walk
Try to walk around for at least 5 minutes.  For example, walk around the block or to a nearby park.
If you can't get outside, walk up and down the stairs, or walk around your office for a few minutes.
Stress 101

Many people think that stress is a feeling of being overwhelmed by responsibilities and demands on our energy and time, that stress is something that happens to you. But it turns out that stress is your body responding to change. So how can you reduce stress when it happens? This activity will explain.
In this activity you’ll learn all about:

items: What stress is.
Why stress happens and how it can get out of control.
Why your thoughts, feelings, and behaviors are key to getting stress under control.

components.text: What is stress?

In 1936 an Austrian physician, Hans Selye, discovered the body stress response and defined stress as: the body’s nonspecific response to any demand for change. Stress is commonly thought of as a feeling, but it’s original definition is that it’s a response, not a feeling.

Stress is made up of many emotions. The mix of emotions that make up someone’s stress is different for everyone. Stress usually involves a combination of nervousness, worry, irritability, sadness, frustration, anger, resentment, and being overwhelmed. So when Dr. Selye said stress is “nonspecific,” he meant that stress can and does look and feel different for different people. It elicits different emotions and different behaviors.
Stress is a response

People often say that they wouldn’t be stressed if they didn’t have other people or circumstances demanding change and causing them stress. The problem with that statement is that life is full of demands for change, full of uncertainty, and full of stressors. We all often have things to be stressed about. For some, these stressors are about survival, like having enough to eat, or battling an illness. And for some, the stressors are less concrete, such as stress about aging, or about the future. These are all real challenges that we can’t avoid.
The Myth of a Stress-Free Life

The idea that we can eliminate stressors from our life is, unfortunately, a fantasy. But eliminating stressors isn’t the answer anyway. Since stress is our response to stressors, we need to change our response, rather than change the things that cause us stress.
Put another way, managing stress isn’t about trying to control what’s happening to us in our lives. It’s about gaining skills to help manage our own thoughts, feelings, and behaviors.

Of course we can still try to do something about the stressors in our lives. In a lot of cases, we have to re-prioritize. We need to spend less energy on some people or some responsibilities, and cut other things loose from our lives. But the emphasis here is still on our response—on what we can do for ourselves, rather than on what happens to us.
Managing stress isn’t about getting rid of your stress response either. Just like we can’t avoid all of our stressors, we also can’t get rid of our feelings of stress. And we really wouldn’t want to.
The Benefits (and Downsides) of Stress
Our stress actually has some benefits. It helps us concentrate when we have to get work done and it motivates us to make big moves in our lives.

Think about all the good times in your life that have been pushed forward by some kind of stress. Stress can help you ask someone out on a date. It can inspire you to make life-altering decisions, and it can stoke a fire in you to pursue the things you really want. In fact, it would be really difficult to do any of those things without some stress. So, stress isn’t inherently bad.

Yet, stress can also make it hard to accomplish things. It can make life feel like a chore, put a strain on relationships, put our health at risk, and make us unhappy. Stress is a problem when it doesn’t lead us to take action in the face of stressors, when the stressors are too overwhelming that they don’t motivate us to act. This is why it’s helpful to have more control over your response to stress. In fact, the foundation of cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) is about mastering your response to stress.
The Stress Cycle
Stress is caused by a trigger—a thought, a physical feeling in our body, or something someone says to us.

So, for example, say that you have to give a presentation. You feel nervous. (That’s a feeling). The night before the presentation, you start thinking of all the ways the presentation could go wrong. Your mind is racing with terrible thoughts. (Those are your thoughts). You don’t get any sleep. (That’s the behavior). The day of the presentation, you’re feeling tired and nervous as you start the presentation. Your voice shakes and you have to keep clearing your throat. (Another feeling). After the presentation, you tell yourself you did terribly, and that you will never be good at giving presentations. (Your thoughts again). The next time your boss asks you to give a presentation, the whole cycle starts again.

This is what we call the stress cycle. Our thoughts affect our behaviors, which affect our feelings and so on and so forth. If this example doesn't resonate for you, that's OK. It might take some time for you to figure out exactly what your stress cycle looks like.
And now for some good news. Once you understand how your thoughts and behaviors influence our feelings, we can start to make new thoughts and choose new behaviors. We can interrupt the cycle.

We can use logic and reasoning and conditioning to change our thoughts, feelings, and behaviors to interrupt the stress cycle before we get caught in it. It takes work and dedication to change your thoughts and behaviors. Talk to your coach to come up with a plan for what will work for your needs. We’re here for you!
Mindful Walking
Walking is an incredible way to slow down and be more mindful of things we do and see every day. While walking is something that we do naturally, walking mindfully takes a bit of practice.
In this activity, you’ll learn:

items: How to focus your attention in a new way.
How to get more out of your daily routines.

components.text: While you walk:

items: Pay close attention to your breathing.
Observe your physical sensations, like how your toes feel in your shoes as they hit the ground.
Notice and accept the way you walk, without trying to alter anything.

components.text: The walk can be inside or outside. If now is not a good time for you to take a walk, set up a reminder.
Let's get started.
How stressed are you feeling right now?
Mindful Walking Meditation
Grab your headphones and let's get to it.
Your Current Stress Level
And now how's your stress level?

decreased.title: Glad you're feeling better.
decreased.body: You just completed Mindful Walking and it seems to have lowered your stress level. Nice! Try this exercise next time you are feeling stressed or anxious to help you calm down.

same.title: Your stress level stayed the same.
same.body: You just completed Mindful Walking, and your stress level stayed the same. Mindful walking doesn’t work every time for everyone. Try this exercise the next time you’re feeling stressed and see if it decreases your stress levels. Or, talk to your coach to find another activity that’s better for you.

increased.title: Your stress level increased.
increased.body: You just completed Mindful Walking, and your stress level increased. Mindful walking doesn’t work every time for everyone. Try it again the next time you’re feeling stressed and see if it decreases your stress levels. Or, talk to your coach to find another activity that’s better for you.

components.text: Relaxed Muscles = Relaxed Mind
Calm your mind by relaxing your muscles. Try this quick relaxation technique to reduce stress and anxiety anytime, anywhere.

Progressive muscle relaxation is an exercise that relaxes your mind and body by progressively tensing and relaxation muscle groups throughout your entire body.You will tense each muscle group vigorously, but without straining, and then suddenly release the tension and feel the muscle relax. You will tense each muscle for about 5 seconds. If you have any pain or discomfort at any of the targeted muscle groups feel free to omit that step. Throughout this exercise you may visualize the muscles tensing and a wave of relaxation flowing over them as you release that tension. It is important that you keep breathing throughout the exercise. Now let’s begin.
Begin by finding a comfortable position either sitting or lying down in a location where you will not be interrupted.
Allow your attention to focus only on your body. If you begin to notice your mind wandering, bring it back to the muscle you are working on.
Take a deep breath through your abdomen, hold for a few second, and exhale slowly. Again, as you breathe notice your stomach rising and your lungs filling with air.
As you exhale, imagine the tension in your body being released and flowing out of your body. And again inhale…..and exhale. Feel your body already relaxing.
As you go through each step, remember to keep breathing. Now let’s begin.
Tighten the muscles in your forehead by raising your eyebrows as high as you can. Hold for about five seconds. And abruptly release feeling that tension fall away. Pause for about 10 seconds.
Now smile widely, feeling your mouth and cheeks tense. Hold for about 5 seconds, and release, appreciating the softness in your face. Pause for about 10 seconds.
Next, tighten your eye muscles by squinting your eyelids tightly shut. Hold for about 5 seconds, and release. Pause for about 10 seconds.
Gently pull your head back as if to look at the ceiling. Hold for about 5 seconds, and release, feeling the tension melting away. Pause for about 10 seconds.
Now feel the weight of your relaxed head and neck sink. Breath in…and out.In…and out.Let go of all the stress In…and out.
Now, tightly, but without straining, clench your fists and hold this position until I say stop. Hold for about 5 seconds, and release. Pause for about 10 seconds.
Now, flex your biceps. Feel that buildup of tension. You may even visualize that muscle tightening. Hold for about 5 seconds, and release, enjoying that feeling of limpness. Breath in...and out.
Now tighten your triceps by extending your arms out and locking your elbows. Hold for about 5 seconds, and release. Pause for about 10 seconds.
Now lift your shoulders up as if they could touch your ears. Hold for about 5 seconds, and quickly release, feeling their heaviness. Pause for about 10 seconds.
Tense your upper back by pulling your shoulders back trying to make your shoulder blades touch. Hold for about 5 seconds, and release. Pause for about 10 seconds.
Tighten your chest by taking a deep breath in, hold for about 5 seconds, and exhale, blowing out all the tension.
Now tighten the muscles in your stomach by sucking in. Hold for about 5 seconds, and release. Pause for about 10 seconds.
Gently arch your lower back. Hold for about 5 seconds, relax. Pause for about 10 seconds.

Feel the limpness in your upper body letting go of the tension and stress, hold for about 5 seconds, and relax. Tighten your buttocks. Hold for about 5 seconds…, release, imagine your hips falling loose. Pause for about 10 second
Tighten your thighs by pressing your knees together, as if you were holding a penny between them. Hold for about 5 seconds…and release. Pause for about 10 seconds.
Now flex your feet, pulling your toes towards you and feeling the tension in your calves. Hold for about 5 seconds, and relax, feel the weight of your legs sinking down. Pause for about 10 seconds.
Curl your toes under tensing your feet. Hold for about 5 seconds, release. Pause for about 10 seconds.

Now imagine a wave of relaxation slowly spreading through your body beginning at your head and going all the way down to your feet. Feel the weight of your relaxed body. Breathe in…and out…in…out….in…out.
That’s it!

When you’re stressed, it’s easy to forget what it physically feels like to be relaxed. By practicing PMR, you'll learn (or relearn) how to relax your body. Whenever you notice your muscles tensing throughout the day, PMR can help counter that tension. In addition to helping you relax your muscles, PMR can also help reduce stomach aches, headaches, and improve your sleep.
Readiness to Change
To make a change to your life that sticks, it helps to be ready for that change. Being ready can mean wanting to change, having the confidence to change and understanding the benefits of change.
This activity will teach you about:

items: The importance of being ready.
Factors that might be preventing you from being ready to change.

components.text: Since you’re here, chances are you want to make a change. Maybe you want to reduce your stress, learn to get better sleep or stop procrastinating. But being ready to make a positive change depends on several factors:

items: Your confidence in your own ability to change affects whether you can make a change, and if you can stick to that change. If you’ve tried to make changes in the past but haven’t been successful, your confidence might be low for the next attempt. Low confidence might affect how committed you feel to make the change.

The second factor that can determine your readiness for change is how much you want to reap the benefits of the change. For example, how would your life be different if you got more sleep? What would that look like and how much do you really want that? If you're unclear how your life will be better after putting in the effort to change, you might not have enough motivation to get through challenging situations.

If you fear changing, or you fear the outcome of a change, you might not be ready. Sometimes we've convinced ourselves that our unhealthy behaviors help us in some way. It can be hard to change if it means giving up habits that you think might be helping. Doing something new is not only difficult, it can be scary, too.

components.text: How ready are you to change your current experience of stress?
How ready were you six months ago?

decreased.title: You are more ready now
decreased.body: You're more ready to change now than you were six months ago. That's a trend in the right direction. You're willing to learn about what might help you ease your stress. In short, you're already on your way to succeeding in a way that you haven't before.Think about what’s changed for you in the past six months to make you feel more ready to tackle your stress.

same.title: Your readiness to change hasn't changed.
same.body: And your readiness to change is low. It’s OK. Even if you’re not feeling ready, you're setting up goals, and you're willing to explore what it means to change. In short, you're already on your way to succeeding in a way that you haven't before.Think about what you would need to change for you to move higher on the scale and to feel more ready.

increased.title: You're feeling less ready.
increased.body: Six months ago you were feeling more ready to change than you are today. Even though you’re feeling less ready, you're exploring what it means to change. Keep going with relaxation techniques. You’re on your way to succeeding in a way that you haven't before.

components.text: Anxiety Cues: Becoming Aware
Understanding how your body and mind react to anxiety can help you become aware of when you’re feeling anxious and what triggers the anxiety.
This activity will explain:

items: What anxiety cues are
How to track anxiety cues
Why tracking can help reduce anxiety

components.text: You can choose to listen or read along:
The audio is about to start. Make sure you’ve got your headphones if you need them and your volume is up
How You Experience Anxiety
How do you know that you’re anxious? What clues or signs let you know when you’re anxious?
Maybe you have physical reactions. You may start to sweat, your hands shake, or your heart races. Or, maybe your mind spirals into worried thinking, or your mood or behaviors change.
To understand what triggers your anxiety, it’s helpful to track it throughout the day. Make a log of each time you're anxious and write down any cues that made you aware of your anxiety at the time.
Why tracking anxiety cues helps:

items: The more you track your anxiety, the quicker you’ll become at noticing it at its onset. The earlier you become aware that you’re feeling anxious, the earlier you can make changes to prevent and reduce your anxiety. A small brush fire is easier to put out than a forest fire.
You’ll start to see the effects of anxiety—how it influences your thoughts, feelings, and behaviors.

You’ll notice patterns. For example, you might notice that your pulse always starts to race when you have to talk to your boss. This pattern can help you see that talking to your boss triggers your anxiety.

You’ll start to learn what you can change. Once you understand both your cues and what triggers them, you can take action. So, the next time you need to talk to your boss, you could try doing a technique like a breathing exercise to reduce your anxiety.

You’ll see that your anxiety is limited. Tracking your cues will help you understand that your anxiety isn't as constant as it might seem. You might not that you’re not as anxious in the morning as you are in the afternoon. And you might see that when you’re done with work, or you finish a task, you're more relieved than at other times of the day.

components.text: It’s helpful to keep in mind that tracking your cues could at first make you more aware of your anxiety. Being aware that you're anxious might not feel great. So, it’s important to remember that you’re doing it for a reason—so you can gain control over it whenever it arises.

Anxiety cue tracking only takes a few minutes throughout the day. It might feel inefficient to stop and write down every time you feel anxious, but remember that anxiety itself is inefficient. Taking time to track it will save you time in the long-run as your anxiety begins to improve.
How to track your cues.
When you notice yourself feeling anxious, write down the feeling and what triggered it. The more you track, the more you’ll be able to see patterns in your cues and what triggered them.

We recommend tracking your cues at least 12 times. You might be surprised by what you learn about yourself. You might already be aware of some of your cues, like you know you tend to worry or you tend to lash out when you’re anxious. Through tracking, you might learn that your first anxiety cue is actually more subtle. Maybe your palms start to sweat or you become fidgety.
Take time to track your cues. You might learn something about yourself you didn't know. And make sure to check in with your coach if you run into any problems.
Grounding: 5-4-3-2-1
This grounding practice is meant to be used for times of high anxiety or emotional distress. It can help you feel grounded in the moment
This audio-guided activity may help you:

items: Find a moment of calm during the day.
Take a break from a stressful situation.
Fall asleep.
Shake an ongoing feeling of stress or anxiety.
Focus.

components.text: This activity involves identifying things you can see, hear, and touch, so you can practice it just about anywhere.
Your Current Anxiety Level
How anxious are you feeling right now?
The audio is about to start. Turn up the volume or put on headphones.
Your Current Anxiety Level
How anxious are you feeling right now?
Nice work! The more you practice this grounding technique, the more comfortable you’ll be with it, and the more likely it is to help you.
Deep Breathing

Deep breathing slows your heart rate and can soothe some of the physical symptoms associated with stressful situations. It can help you feel better and more relaxed. This is a classic relaxation technique. It’s simple, quick, and doable just about anywhere.
Here’s how it’ll works:

items: Place one hand on your chest and the other hand on your abdomen.
Breathe slowly but not too deeply into your abdomen so that only the hand on your abdomen raises and lowers.
Repeat five times.

components.text: You can use this technique anywhere, anytime. When you’re ready to begin, audio instructions will guide you through the whole thing.
Also, don't worry if you can't keep up with the breathing pace of the audio instructions. Feel free to go at your own pace.
Your Current Anxiety Level
How anxious are you feeling right now?
Deep Breathing
Time to turn up the volume or put on headphones. Audio guidance is about to begin.
How anxious are you feeling right now?
You just completed Deep Breathing. Next time you are feeling anxious give it a try. The more you practice the better it will work.
Relaxation 101

An appropriate amount of fear is important, but too much fear can have detrimental effects on our physical and mental health. Listen or read about the benefits of just the right amount of fear and learn to calm your fear when it gets to be too much.
This activity will discuss:

items: The physiology of fear
Why we need fear
How to relax even when we can’t take a vacation.

components.text: You can choose to listen or read along:
Making Room for Relaxation
The audio is about to start. Turn up the volume or put on headphones.
An Appropriate Amount of Fear
Our fight-or-flight response is an evolutionary advantage. It helps us react appropriately to danger. It helps us know when not to trust people and when we should keep our guard up.

It’s a good thing that your fight-or-flight response reacts when you’re in real danger. However, when your body stays in a constant state of stress due to situations that aren’t physically dangerous (such as traffic jams, job interviews, financial problems, or social situations), our response can be a problem.
Constantly experiencing the fight-or-flight response isn’t healthy for us. It can lead to high blood pressure, a weakened immune system, depression, and can conflict in relationships.
So, how can we make ourselves less fearful when we don’t need our fight-or-flight response? How can we be less anxious in our daily lives while also reacting appropriately to real danger?
Fortunately, researchers have found a surprisingly simple way to put a stop to the fight-or-flight response: relaxation techniques.
Relaxation Practices are a Big Deal

A relaxation technique is an activity where your attention is centered on something calming while you’re consciously bringing more awareness to your body. These include muscle relaxation techniques, meditation, deep breathing, yoga, and more. And they can counteract our fight-or-flight reaction

The fight-or-flight response increases your blood pressure, your breathing, and your heart rate. A good relaxation technique does the opposite of all that by prompting your body’s natural relaxation response. So your heart rate and breathing slow and your blood pressure lowers.

Practicing relaxation techniques can reduce chronic pain, lessen your fatigue, improve your concentration and mood, reduce any anger or frustration you may be feeling, and boost your confidence. In short, they’re great for you.
Relaxation techniques are worth the effort

Relaxation techniques can be challenging. It can feel strange to relax your stomach muscles or just to let go and relax at all. There are plenty of types of techniques to choose from, so try out a few to find one that works for you.
You can adapt any of these techniques to your situation. These techniques can become your sanctuary.
The goal is to prepare yourself to handle any moment that comes–and the best way to be ready is to be relaxed and to breathe through it
Deep Breathing with Counting

This deep breathing technique eases the fight-or-flight response by slowing your heart rate, calming your and breathing, and lowering your blood pressure. Counting adds a meditative quality to this technique, which can be particularly helpful for quieting persistent worried thoughts.
Here's how the breathing technique works:

items: Inhale, filling your lungs with air.
Take a long exhale, then count to one.
Inhale again, then exhale and count two.
Repeat, counting all the way up to five.
Start again, repeating for five to ten minutes.

components.text: For this technique, find a comfortable place to sit or lie down where you won't be interrupted.
When you're ready to begin, audio guidance will walk you through the whole technique.
Your Current Anxiety Level
How anxious are you feeling right now?
Deep Breathing with Counting
Time to turn up the volume or put on headphones. Audio guidance is about to begin.
Let's re-check your anxiety level.
How anxious are you feeling right now?

You can try to do this sort of breathing next time you are feeling anxious and see if it works then to calm you down. The more you practice, the more comfortable you’ll feel using this technique when you need it.
Celebrate Small Things
Reward your small accomplishments
Do you sometimes find even showering or dressing may feel like a chore? But the more we avoid our daily responsibilities, the worse we often feel about ourselves in the long term.
INSTRUCTIONS
Schedule a time each day to do one small task you've avoided, like dishes, laundry, or buying groceries
WHAT'S NEXT?
Acknowledge and reward the success of completing each daily task. Try pairing them with a pleasurable activity immediately after—like taking yourself out to a favorite cafe after you buy groceries.
WHY
Increasing the sense of mastery is another core component in behavioral activation. Studies show behavioral activation is very effective in treating even severe presentations of depression.

properties.name: Savor the Good
properties.description: Take time to cherish the good moments in life to boost your mood. It can be hard to remember the good parts of your life when you're down or anxious, but we all have experienced good moments. The trick is to remember them and spend some time cherishing them.

components.text: Savor the Good

Research has found that savoring the good things in your life helps you feel happier and less stressed. Those who make time to savor good experiences are more likely to be optimistic, happy and satisfied with life, as well as less depressed.
In this activity you’ll learn:

items: How to recall good memories in your life.
How savoring the good can help your mood.
New ways to cherish the good moments.

components.text: Cherishing the good moments in life can actually boost your mood. When you’re feeling down or anxious, it can be hard to remember all the good in your life. And there are good moments. You just have to remember them and then spend some time cherishing them.
How to savor the good moments

In order to savor the good moments in your life, you need to know what they are. Start by looking at your day. Maybe it was the feeling of entering a warm home after being out in the cold, or your first sip of coffee in the morning.
You can also look for pleasant memories, parts of your life that you’re grateful for, or plans you’re excited about. Those count as good moments, too.

While thinking about each good time, spend a few moments savoring the sensation of being warm, or satisfied, or grateful. Keep a journal and write notes about these moments. Being aware and paying attention to the good times can have a big impact on your overall mood.
Here are four different ways to cherish the good moments:

items: Luxuriating: When absorbed in physical pleasure, such as receiving a massage, or through eating delicious food slowly and mindfully.
Giving Thanks: When feeling gratitude for a positive experience, like a great day out with friends or the company of your pet.
Basking: When immersing yourself in the pride of an accomplishment, like completing a 5K run, or finishing a work project.
Marveling: When being amazed by the beauty of the world, such as a beautiful sunset, or the way the city sparkles at night.

components.text: Remember the good moments
Savoring the good is a quick and simple way to boost your mood and increase feelings of positivity and well-being.
We looked at four different styles of savoring: luxuriating, giving thanks, basking, and marvelling.
Try to remember to find the good, small moments in your life and apply any of the styles of savoring to those moments.
Date for One
Recharge by taking time just for you.
INSTRUCTIONS

Being constantly surrounded by others may wear your mood down. Plan a solo "date" in which you do one small, pleasurable activity alone. Read, cook, sing—or look for more ideas in the other health tips!
WHAT'S NEXT
If this feels good, try scheduling hour-long "dates" a few times a week, maybe even every day.
WHY
Spending time alone can rejuvanate you. It's important to take a break and give your mind the time it needs.
Define Your Values: Personal Compass

Defining your values—what’s important to you—can help guide your behavior. Unlike goals, values are aspirational qualities that aren't meant to have a finish line. A value is something you’re constantly working towards, such as being a good parent, a supportive partner, or a more spiritual person
What to do?

Spend time clarifying what your values are. It may be helpful to write them down so you have them as a reminder for another time. Remembering and returning to your values can be useful for your mental health, especially when you're feeling depressed.
Why define your values?

Clear values can help you respond better to stress. In a research study, one group of subjects spent time thinking about and affirming their values, while the other didn't. Both groups then were given a test that was meant to be stressful. The group that had affirmed their values showed less psychological stress.
Good Distractions
Distract yourself to move on from intensely negative emotions.
INSTRUCTIONS

Brainstorm distractions that you can use in anytime, anywhere, in moments of extreme anxiety or upset. Examples include: doodling, playing a game on your phone, tearing pieces of paper, blowing bubbles, going on a walk.
WHAT'S NEXT?
Engage in a distraction activity the next time you feel your emotional state is triggered.
WHY
Distraction is an evidence-based DBT skill that lets you get out of your head. After engaging in a different activity, you might find yourself less angry, anxious, or sad.
Go with the Flow
Accept the facts and flow past them
INSTRUCTIONS
Rather than resisting a negative situation, accept it. Remember that what's done is done, and take the good with the bad. Instead, focus on changing the future.
WHAT'S NEXT?
Fighting the circumstances only prolongs your upset. Don't focus on regrets!
WHY

These ideas are part of radical acceptance, a key concept in DBT (Dialectical Behavior Therapy). Research shows DBT skills are effective for depression, bipolar disorder, substance use disorders, eating disorders, and physical conditions.
Kindness Meditation
Think compassionately about yourself and others with this daily exercise.
INSTRUCTIONS
Close your eyes and picture a loved one. Slowly say the following to yourself: "May they be free from suffering. May they be safe. May they be healthy. May they be peaceful and at ease."
Next, picture yourself in your mind's eye. Repeat the phrases again, to yourself.
WHY
Loving kindness meditation has been shown in research to build positive emotions and a sense of connectedness. It's increasingly used in treatments for depression.
Unplug from Technology
Unplug for an hour each day to feel more grounded
INSTRUCTIONS
Find an hour of the day to silence your electronic devices and put them out of sight. (Try this at home after the workday.) Enjoy the experience of freedom from pings, call, and distractions.
WHAT'S NEXT?
If you can, build up to unplugging for two or three hours a day.
WHY
While technology has wonderful uses, it can also lead to distraction and anxiety over keeping "up to date." This exercise can help ground you and decrease distractions.
Activities to Enjoy
Learn what the Headspace Care community does to combat depression!
One health strategy is to find something you enjoy doing daily. Here are some of the activities Headspace Care members have shared with us. You might find inspiration in them:

items: Watching YouTube videos of rap battles or make-up tutorials.
Taking a walk while listening to music.
Writing in a journal (or in the Notes section of Headspace Care).
Gardening.
Reading manga or comics.
Playing and watching movies with their child.
Making a yummy drink, like special tea or hot chocolate, and sitting down to enjoy it.
Going for long walks with a pet.
Playing Dance Central on the X Box.
Watching a favorite show.
Cooking.
Walking around the park.
Playing Candy Crush.
Listening to calm music or rain.
Exercise and meditation.

components.text: If there's something you enjoy doing that helps you deal with your depression, please let us know by sending an email!

items: Listening to the sound of the ocean or thunderstorms

Here are some additional activities Headspace Care members have shared with us. You might find inspiration in them:

items: Dancing with family members
Making smores
Watching fish in a tank
Spending time with friends and just hanging out without a plan
Walking on the beach at night, when it's less hectic
Listening to kids play
Reading medical studies

Making a ""happy book"" by cutting pictures out of magazines, for bad times
Making wire-wrapped pendants
Playing computer games
Listening to music while cleaning
Sharing ideas with supportive people
Talking to a loved one on the phone
Painting
Getting lost in music
Spending time at your church, synagogue, mosque, or place of worship
Bubble baths
Coaching children's sports teams

components.text: If there's something you enjoy doing that helps you deal with your depression, please let us know by sending an email!
ADHD & Self-Esteem

If you have ADHD, it can often feel like you just don’t measure up to your peers or co-workers. It can take you longer to complete tasks and make you more likely to make careless mistakes. It can be easy to feel bad about yourself and feel like you just can’t get it right, even though you try so hard. The good news is that there are strategies you can use to help boost your self-esteem.
This activity will:

items: Guide you through three categories of tools that you can use to help build your self-esteem
Introduce tactical tips to improve how you feel about yourself

components.text: Be the captain of your own ship

A captain of a ship often faces different setbacks along their journey that they need to plan and adjust for. Similarly, we are all on our own unique journeys and will face setbacks. When these challenges arise, it’s important to take time to reassess and identify key steps that will help us to get back on track on our journey.
If you’re having trouble completing your tasks, consider trying one of the following tips:

items: Take time to organize your workspace. Try setting aside just 5-10 minutes each morning to clean up your workspace by removing clutter and only keeping the things that you need for work in front of you. Taking this time before you start work each day can help you stay focused throughout the day.

Review ways to help manage time better and decrease distractions. Consider setting a timer to stay focused on one task at a time. You can try setting a timer for 25 minutes to focus on one task and reward yourself with a 5 minute break to do something that is energizing to you. Also, try putting your phone away, silence alerts, turn off the TV, use noise-cancelling headphones, and dim the lights. Overall, removing these sensory distractions from your area will assist in better time management.

Consider speaking with a supervisor about accommodations. Sometimes it can help to open up to a trusted supervisor when you are struggling with school or work. This can help them to better understand why you might be struggling to get your tasks completed and allow the two of you to work together to find the support you need.

components.text: Be your own best friend

This might feel awkward to do at first, but oftentimes we offer more kindness and support to our friends than we do for ourselves. Shifting your mindset to treat yourself the way you would treat your friend can help you allow more compassion towards yourself.
Below are some tips you can try to help you start to become your own best friend:

items: Don’t compare yourself to others. It can be so easy to compare yourself to others that you might not even notice when you’re doing it. Try to identify these moments as they happen this week and notice these thoughts as they occur.

Recognize what makes you special and unique. Remind yourself that everyone presents their own unique talents and skills.  Recognize all the ways you are measuring up and focus on comparing yourself to your own abilities and improvements you have made in your life.

Make an inventory of your talents and then find ways to express these. Do this by sitting in a quiet spot free from distractions. Take out a piece of paper and pen and think about your accomplishments.  For each accomplishment, consider what went right. Write those down as your skills and talents. If lists are not your thing, try making a bubble map by writing down each accomplishment in a bubble and branching off each “accomplishment bubble” with additional bubbles filled with your skills / talents associated with that accomplishment

Focus on all of your strengths, not weaknesses. Part of being human is having strengths and weaknesses. Being aware of your strengths is just as important as recognizing your weaknesses. Take some time to reflect on how your strengths have helped you or others at home, work, school, or elsewhere.

components.text: Put your oxygen mask on first

Before you can care for others in your life, it is important to care for yourself first. You may have people in your life who depend on you like aging parents, your partner, children, friends, co-workers, team members, etc. It can feel selfish or even like you’re letting them down when you focus on yourself, but prioritizing your own self-care is key to being able to provide effective and sustainable care for others.
If you’re having trouble caring for yourself, below are some tips to consider. Pick one tip to try out this week:

options.name: Concentrate on activities that energize you.
Speak with a coach or therapist about dismantling negative self beliefs.
Consider volunteering or doing something nice for others.
Explore the Headspace Care self-care library.

components.text: You don’t have to do all of these things at the same time. There’s no one-size-fits-all approach to self-care, so make a plan that works for you. Remember to start small — find a regular weekly time where you can focus on one thing to do for yourself.
Great work!

Congratulate yourself for taking time for yourself today to build your self-esteem! When you have ADHD or struggle with attention, it can be easy to feel discouraged. You’ve already taken some important steps by recognizing this and learning some helpful tips and tools. Remember to take this one step at a time. Consider setting up some time this week to try the tip you chose. Good luck! And remember that a coach is always available to provide additional support when you need it.
Practicing Body Kindness

There are countless messages insisting that happiness can be achieved by shrinking or changing our bodies to fit the latest societal trend. These narratives can trap us in a disordered mindset that glorifies weight loss and diet culture. If you find yourself struggling to be kind to your body, there are tips that you can use to help shift your perspective and accept your body — flaws and all.
This activity will:

items: Provide tips to shift your mindset towards body kindness
Guide you through selecting a tip to commit to practicing as a first step

components.text: Tips to practice body kindness (1 / 3)

You are more than your body. While this can feel obvious, it’s not always the easiest to believe because so much of the media we consume and the narratives we are told center around the body and physical appearance. The following tips can help you start to shift from this body-centric perspective towards one that allows you to see all of the other important aspects of life:

items: Rewrite your body narrative. Your body narrative is the story you’ve told yourself about your body from a young age. Taking time to reflect on the origin of your body narrative can help you begin to unravel beliefs that might not be serving you anymore. Ask yourself, “At what age did I start having concerns about my body?” “How did the stories I used to tell myself impact my life at the time?” Recognizing how these patterns formed in your mind is an important step. Once you’re clear, you can start to undo patterns that you’ve held onto from a young age.

Practice intuitive eating. Intuitive eating emphasizes viewing food from a neutral place. Rather than thinking of food as either healthy or unhealthy, which can make you feel guilty and lead to a strained relationship with food, intuitive eating integrates instinct, emotion, and rational thought into food choices. Reminding yourself you’re allowed to feel pleasure through eating can help you adopt a more neutral and kind outlook on food choices.

Question what you hear about diets and exercise. Diet culture promotes the exhausting and consuming worries about what we “should” or “should not” eat. It increases food guilt and body shame, and it manufactures obsessive thinking patterns about food and exercise. It is valid to question these entrenched eating beliefs and give yourself the compassion you deserve.

components.text: Tips to practice body kindness (2 / 3)

items: Use compassionate self-talk. Think about what you would say to a close friend or child when you have unhelpful thoughts about your body or food. Consider both the internal and external language you use when thinking and talking about your body, other people’s bodies, and food.

Ditch the scale. You’re not defined by the number on a scale. If stepping onto a scale causes you to feel overwhelmed or anxious, ask yourself if knowing your weight will benefit you in any way, and then find the courage to walk away. Keep in mind you have the option to decline being weighed during doctor and medical appointments.

Engage in joyful movement. Approach movement and exercise from a place of love, nourishment, fun, pleasure, and joy, rather than as a way to burn off calories or punish yourself. Use exercise and movement as a way to respect and nourish your body.

components.text: Tips to practice body kindness (3 / 3)

items: Set healthy boundaries. If you’re in a discussion with someone who is complaining or criticizing their body or food, you can choose not to participate. If you feel comfortable, let them know that discussing weight loss and diets brings up emotional discomfort. Gently communicating that you’d prefer not to talk about these subjects because of your own personal struggles can be rewarding.

Seek out support. Identify the underlying feelings of your body image or food issues by talking with a therapist, a coach, or a non-diet dietitian, i.e., a practitioner who emphasizes healing your relationship with food rather than dieting.

Follow body-neutral accounts on social media. There are plenty of body image accounts on Instagram that offer amazing content in this area. Do a search for hashtags like #haes (health at every size) or #antidiet to find meaningful content in this area.

components.text: Give it a try

It takes time and practice to shift your body mindset, so try to take this one day at a time. Some tips might be easier for you to start with than others so consider trying one at a time and pick ones that feel most helpful to you.
Take some time to select just one tip you can commit to trying this week:

options.name: Question what you hear about diets and exercise
Follow body-neutral accounts on social media

components.text: Awesome work

Congratulate yourself for taking the time to prioritize yourself by learning some helpful body kindness tips. By practicing these tips over time, you can work towards developing a more peaceful and accepting view of both food and your body. Remember that you are worthy and deserve to live in greater harmony with your entire self. If you’re interested in learning more, consider checking out the other “body image” activity cards in the self-care library or reaching out to your coach for additional support.
Building Self-Confidence

Having been socially distant for so long due to the pandemic, many of us are feeling less confident these days. Whether you could use a self-confidence boost at work, in your social life, with your body image, or in another area of your life, there are strategies that can help you build up your self-confidence.
If you haven’t already, check out the Defining Self-Confidence activity card first for the intro to this series. You can also print out the accompanying workbook to follow along:

[Self-Confidence Workbook](https://gingerio.my.salesforce.com/sfc/p/#f40000002Q1l/a/5G000000UxUX/VeTCeiqCh7M4zXYordOc33pxMkwC61gDpz5R9Vmyy7Y) (this is completely optional!). In this activity, we will focus on the content from pages 2-8.
This activity will:

items: Teach you five strategies for building self-confidence
Discuss why building self-confidence matters

components.text: First, do you want to watch the video or read?
Strategies for Building Self-Confidence
Strategy #1: Collect data about yourself

items: Oftentimes, when we have low self-confidence, it can be easy to have negativity bias and focus more on negative experiences than positive ones.
Noticing and collecting positive information about ourselves that challenges this negativity bias can boost our confidence and self-esteem.
By collecting compliments from yourself or others, you can actively challenge preconceived notions about yourself that might be contributing to low self-confidence.

components.text: Let’s try this out!

On a piece of paper or your phone, write down three compliments that you received today from yourself or others. It’s completely normal to struggle with this at first. If you’re having a tough time thinking of compliments, consider reaching out to your coach who can guide you through identifying these compliments.
Strategy #2: Reframe your mindset

items: A fixed mindset (seeing your qualities as unchangeable and either good or bad) can contribute to low self-confidence.
A growth mindset (believing your abilities can change, develop, and strengthen) can boost self-confidence.
Our mindset is a set of beliefs about ourselves and can be changed. Changing from a fixed mindset to a growth mindset can boost self-confidence and contribute to making positive changes in your life.

components.text: Let’s try this out!
To adopt a growth mindset, begin by questioning your thoughts and ask yourself if they are based on facts or based on beliefs generated from low self-confidence.

items: To start, think about an unfavorable belief about yourself that you currently have and write it down on a piece of paper or on your phone. Try to take just one moment to do this now.

Next, ask yourself: What is the evidence behind my thinking? Is it based on fact or on beliefs generated from low self-confidence? Take a moment to write down your reflections or arguments on the piece of paper or on your phone.

components.text: Strategy #3: Practice positive self-talk

items: We all have a self-talk tape in our heads that can influence our actions. If we have self-talk that tells us we can never progress or improve, then taking the actions needed to build self-confidence might feel impossible.
Healthy self-talk isn’t narcissism, bragging, or boasting. Rather it is an optimistic evaluation of yourself and your abilities and a sense of trust in yourself.

Since confidence is a skill and not a personality trait, we need to be able to take repetitive actions, even if we feel fearful or doubtful, to build that skill. By practicing positive self-talk, taking those actions becomes much easier.

components.text: Below are some ideas to encourage thoughts that build self-confidence:

items: Mirror work. Look in the mirror and say positive things about yourself.

Positive affirmations. These are positive phrases or statements used to challenge negative or unhelpful thoughts about yourself, motive yourself, or boost your self-esteem. Listen to a recording of them, write them down, and practice saying them out loud.

Letter-writing. Write a letter to yourself about the things you are proud of in your life. This will give you confidence for facing new challenges and find similarities between current situations and the past.

components.text: Let’s try this out!
Grab a piece of paper or open up the notes section of your phone and choose one of the activities below to try out right now:

items: Write three positive affirmations to yourself that you can recite today (and every if you’d like!).
Write a short note to yourself about the things from this week or month of which you are proud of.

components.text: Strategy #4: Know your strengths & values

items: Identifying your strengths and values can provide direction, help you make confident decisions, and boost your self-esteem and self-confidence.

Your values about yourself as a person might contrast with how you operate and think on the day-to-day. For example, you might value kindness or honesty, but at the same time have low self-confidence and negative thoughts about your body. However, body size doesn’t contribute to your actual overall life values of kindness or honesty.
If you know your values, you can more confidently choose daily thoughts or actions that support and align with them.

components.text: Let’s try this out!

items: Write down your top three values (e.g., ambition, courage, passion, organization, gratitude, equality, family, loyalty, generosity, success, etc.)

Cross-examine them with your life. Where in your life are you meeting those values? Where are those values not being met? Consider the following areas of wellness: social, emotional, spiritual, intellectual, physical, environmental, financial, occupational.
Identify and write down ways you can practice and more deeply live by your values. If you need help, consider reaching out to your Headspace Care coach to figure this out and create an action plan.

components.text: Strategy #5: Feel the fear and do it anyway

items: This is the biggest and most effective way to build self-confidence: practice whatever it is you want to feel more confident in (even if you feel self-doubting). The action comes first, and the feeling of confidence comes after.
Practice incrementally by starting small and building up to more challenging experiences.
Do not give up at the first signs of adversity or failure. Keep practicing.

components.text: Let’s try this out!

items: Write down three ways you’ve shown confidence or three things that you’re proud of.
Keep this list of items in a place where you can easily access it.
Before you start a challenging activity, read and reflect on these three things to help build up your confidence.

components.text: Well done!
Congrats on completing this self-confidence activity! Self-confidence is an important part of life and provides you with:

items: Better overall health because you have an increased positive attitude and can manage stress and difficult emotions more effectively
More time for family and friends, as self-confidence helps you set healthy boundaries
Improved performance at work or school through better ability to concentrate and greater commitment to tasks
Better ability to influence and persuade others
Increased energy and motivation
Greater levels of happiness
And much more…

components.text: Self-confidence takes practice, so remember to take it one step at a time. You can refer back to these strategies or reach out to your Headspace Care coach for more ideas.
Build Mastery
Practice what you're good at to improve your mood. Getting back to, or beginning a creative endeavor, such as painting, cooking or writing can be therapeutic and fuel self-esteem.
More about mastery

Building mastery is about committing to something and doing it on a daily basis. It might mean reigniting a passion to do something that you once abandoned, or it could be about trying something new. If you’ve always wanted to learn a new language, try yoga, or go hiking, just finding the courage to begin something new is a form of mastery.
If you’ve contemplated doing it and never did, then the act of doing it once, for any length of time is an accomplishment!
Feel more confident and in control
Building mastery is a DBT skill (Dialectical Behavioral Therapy in fancy talk) that helps you feel a sense of confidence and control with your surroundings and within yourself.
Essentially, it means doing things that make you feel accomplished, whether getting better at something you already feel confident about or learning something new.
Mastery is a great DBT skill to use when you want to feel more motivated and confident but just don’t know where to start. It's been proven to improve mood, reduce anxiety and boost self esteem!
Ok, but how do I begin?

You can practice this skill by picking an activity to accomplish. Ideally, it would be something that is challenging but still possible. Go into it with the attitude that you will follow through and succeed. Try not to set the bar too high, but don't worry if you chose something too challenging. Just reduce the difficulty at first by doing a less challenging version of your activity. Each time you practice, allow yourself to do increasingly difficult variations.

When you finish something, do more than cross it off the to-do list. Give yourself a reward! Take a break, or spend some time thinking about what you just did. Let it sink in that you got something done.
Feel free to write your experience in a journal or share with your coach who can help support you in keeping momentum around this.
I did a thing!
Building mastery is the process of doing something new, difficult, or fulfilling and feeling a sense of accomplishment after you do it.
Building mastery doesn’t have to be anything mind-blowing, it simply has to result in that special feeling that can be described as, “I did a thing!“
It's been proven to build confidence, inspire motivation, and even improve your mood!
Compliment Collector
Record the compliments you receive to boost your self-image
INSTRUCTIONS
Every time you receive a compliment — no matter how small — write it down in a piece of paper.
WHAT'S NEXT?
At the end of each day or week, look over the past compliments you've received.
WHY
We often dwell on the negative, especially at night or when alone. This exercise refocuses on the positive. Positive affirmations are a CBT tool that boost self-image and self-esteem.
Four Cornerstones of Self-Worth

Self-development is similar to building a house. Before you build the house, it’s important to prepare by scouting the site and laying a strong foundation. Learning about four key strategies can help you lay the foundation for your self-worth.
This activity will:

items: Walk you through key cornerstones of self-worth
Guide you through identifying your own cornerstone
Start the process for creating your self-worth foundation

components.text: Four Cornerstones of Self-Worth

Before you build a house, it’s important to lay a solid foundation so that your home can stand strong against external forces. Similarly, it’s also important to develop strong self-worth as a foundation to help you navigate through life. We’ll identify four cornerstones to help you establish this foundation. To start, let’s walk through three cornerstones together and then you will have some time to reflect on your fourth cornerstone.
Cornerstone #1: You are awesome

You might be asking, “How can you say that if you don’t know me yet?” Here's the reason: You are awesome because you are the only you on this planet and that makes you one of a kind: Awesome. This doesn’t mean that you are perfect, but you don’t need to be perfect in order to be awesome.  What makes you awesome is that you are unique and it isn’t dependent on anything external. Take some time right now to tell yourself, “I am awesome.” You can repeat it in your mind or if you feel comfortable, try saying it out loud. It might also help to write  “I am awesome” on a post-it note, in your journal, or on your phone to help you come back to this cornerstone throughout the week.
Cornerstone #2: You didn’t come with instructions

Sometimes it can be easy to feel that we are doing things incorrectly or wrong. When you have those thoughts, keep this in mind:  you didn’t come with instructions or a troubleshooting guide, so you can’t be doing “YOU”  wrong.

Your choices and your beliefs are part of your own, unique human experience.
