Rather than comparing yourself to others to determine what’s right for you and what’s wrong for you, remind yourself that you are not them. You were born to be your own person. Try taking a moment now to remind yourself, “I decide who I am,” “I am the mold/pattern and I fashion things around me,” “Other people’s opinions don’t dictate my outcomes.”
Cornerstone #3: You are who you are

Just as you are your own unique individual, the world is filled with different types of people who come from different backgrounds and hold different core beliefs. In the same way that you can’t change things that you dislike about others, how others feel about you doesn’t need to impact or change who you are. Your experiences have made you who you are. Sometimes that might not match with someone else’s experiences, but that doesn’t make your experience any less valid. You must learn to accept yourself, the good, the bad and the indifferent. You may not like all of it, but it is part of you. This is called self-acceptance. Take some time now to repeat to yourself, “I am who I am.”
Cornerstone #4: Choose your own cornerstone

For the final cornerstone, let’s work on picking one together. One way to pick a cornerstone is to ask yourself, “What is something that makes you unique?” On a piece of paper or on your phone, write out “I am….” and try completing that sentence with things that make you unique.

Another method is to ask yourself, “What are some things about yourself that make you smile?” For example, maybe you sing, write, dance, or cook and those are areas about yourself that make you smile. Maybe you’re kind and you encourage others. Think about anything that makes you smile and makes you feel good about being you.

Take some time right now to pick just one of the two methods above and try it out. When you’re done, pick one item from your list and add that as your fourth and final cornerstone. If you need some help thinking through some examples or need guidance selecting your cornerstone, you can also reach out to your coach who can help walk you through this exercise.
Nice work!
Congrats on establishing your cornerstones and taking the first step towards laying your self-worth foundation. Throughout your week today, try to pick one cornerstone to remind yourself of each day.
Count Your Blessings
List the things you're thankful for, and improve positive emotions
INSTRUCTIONS
Depression can make it difficult to appreciate what's going well. For the next two weeks, spend a few minutes at the end of each day writing down five things you're thankful for.

These can be events that occurred during the day, like a stranger letting you go first in line. Or they might be bigger moments of gratitude, like a sibling who's been supportive over many years. You might find that some things appear on the list multiple times — that's okay!
WHY
Research has shown that keeping a list of gratitude improves positive emotions, well-being, and sleep in as little as two weeks.
Defining Self-Confidence

Face masks and life behind a computer screen make it easy to hide from the outside world. Add in awkward socially distanced gatherings and virtual meetings in comfy pants, and it’s no wonder so many people might be feeling less confident these days. Whether you could use a self-confidence boost at work, in your social life, with your body image, or something else, Headspace Care can help. To get started, it helps to understand what self-confidence is and how it applies to your life.
Before you begin, you can also print out the accompanying workbook to follow along:

[Self-Confidence Workbook](https://gingerio.my.salesforce.com/sfc/p/#f40000002Q1l/a/5G000000UxUX/VeTCeiqCh7M4zXYordOc33pxMkwC61gDpz5R9Vmyy7Y) (this is completely optional!). In this activity, we will focus on the content from page 1.
This activity will:

items: Guide you through a reflection of how self-confidence applies to your life
Define and provide the foundations of self-confidence

components.text: First, do you want to watch the video or read?
Defining Self-Confidence
Self-Reflection

Take a moment now to reflect on the questions below. If you printed out the workbook, take some time to write down your answers in the workbook. You can also write down your responses in your journal, phone, or on a piece of paper.

items: What does being more confident mean to me?
In what area of my life would I like to feel more confident? (Ex: Relationships and/or dating, career, socializing, parenting, speaking up, health, independence, etc.)
Is there an area in my life where I feel more confident than others? Why might this be?

components.text: Definitions
lf-confidence, self-esteem, and self-efficacy are often used interchangeably, however they are not the same. Below is a breakdown of each to identify some of the nuances.

items: Self-confidence is a skill that can be built and trained through repetition. We often expect that self-confidence is a characteristic that we either have or don’t have, but in reality we can’t feel that feeling of self-confidence until the task or action that we are doing is no longer new to us.
Self-esteem is how you feel about yourself. It’s possible to have high self-confidence and low self-esteem at the same time.
Self-efficacy is having that strong positive belief and trust in yourself that you have the skills to achieve your goals.

components.text: Remember, you are not alone if you’re facing challenges with self-confidence. Many other Headspace Care members struggle with self-confidence in a wide variety of areas and it’s completely OK to feel this way. Next, we’ll walk through some fundamentals of self confidence to set a foundation for how to boost your self-confidence.
Foundations of Confidence

items: Self-confidence is a skill that can be trained. You can learn and train new skills. With any new skill, it will take repetition, practice, and persistence. Remember to be gentle with yourself in the process.

A common confidence myth is that you need to feel confident before you do something. In reality, the actions of confidence come first and the feeling will come later. You can take action, even when you might not feel confident. Consider taking some time to ask yourself, “What actions do I want to take (what do I want to achieve) and what might get in the way of those actions?”

Confidence is not a lack of fear. It’s about trust in one’s abilities. You may still feel fearful when doing the task or action. Doubts are normal in the process of building confidence. Confidence is rooted in self-acceptance. It accepts the circumstances for what they are and focuses on what is meaningful and relevant.

components.text: Nice work!

Great job today learning about self-confidence!  Remember that self-confidence is a skill that can be developed. The action comes before the feeling and self-doubt is totally normal in the process of building self-confidence.

Check out the “Strategies for Building Self-Confidence” activity card next to learn about some tactical steps you can take to build up your confidence. Remember that you can always reach out to your Headspace Care coach for support.
How to Handle Rejection

Even though rejection is a normal part of life that happens to everyone, it can still hurt. While rejection is often not personal, it can feel very personal and can cause us to make judgements about ourselves. Learning about different ways to handle rejection can help you separate your own identity from the rejection.
This activity will:

items: Guide you through a framework or how rejection can impact the stories we tell about ourselves
Offer coping strategies to manage negatives feelings associated with rejection

components.text: The Ladder of Inference

When you experience rejection, it's easy to internalize it and form conclusions about yourself. In reality, there could be many other reasons and circumstances for the rejection. It's common, however, to allow the rejection to impact your self-identity. This typically occurs through what is referred to as "the ladder of inference." The following are the "steps" of the ladder of inference that lead us to letting a rejection impact our self-worth.

items: The rejection event occurs: This is the bottom step of the ladder and the initial triggering event (e.g., you didn't receive a job offer).

You start creating a story: The next steps are the negative thoughts that form as a result of the rejection (e.g., "I'm not good enough"). Negative thoughts can often build on top of the other. Each thought is another step up the ladder (e.g., "I'm not as good as other people," escalates to, "I'm a failure").

You make conclusions: All of your negative thoughts lead to the top of the ladder, where you form a conclusion about yourself that can impact your future actions (e.g., You don't apply for future roles because you feel like you're unqualified).

components.text: The good news is that YOU get to decide how you get to the top of the ladder. When a rejection occurs, being aware of the thoughts that come up as a result of the event can help you to neutralize the impact of rejection.

Next, we'll walk through some strategies that you can use when you find yourself having negative thoughts as a result of rejection. These strategies can help you form balanced and healthy stories about yourself and help you remain resilient in the face of rejection.
How are you currently feeling?
Take some time now to identify a rejection that you're either currently experiencing or have experienced in the past.
How much does this rejection negatively impact how you feel about yourself?
Coping strategies that can help
Now that you've identified the event, let's walk through some strategies to help you neutralize the negative effects of rejection:

items: Affirmations: Balancing the negative thoughts with positive affirmations can help you to find a middle ground. For example, "I am qualified," "I am enough," and "I believe in myself."

The power of "yet": Rejection isn't necessarily permanent. Just because you've experienced rejection now doesn't mean that the opportunity is out of reach in the future. Using "yet" can help you remember that rejection is temporary. For example, "I have not been accepted to college, yet,"  "I have not been promoted, yet," or "I have not found a partner, yet."

Neutralizing thoughts: Consider some of the unexpected positive impacts of this rejection to help balance out the negative. For example, ask yourself, "What have I learned from this rejection?" and, "Perhaps this "no" creates space for a "yes" somewhere else."

components.text: How are you currently feeling?

Practicing these strategies when you find yourself experiencing negative thoughts after being rejected can help you to proactively prevent yourself from forming negative conclusions about yourself. Now that you've tried it out, take a moment to reflect on how you feel about the rejection.
How much does this rejection negatively impact how you feel about yourself?
Wonderful work

Kudos to you for taking the time today to learn about how you can handle rejection. In the next few weeks, try to notice any negative thoughts that you have that are related to instances of rejection. Then, practice these strategies to help you form healthier and more balanced stories about yourself.

If you need additional support, check out the "Kindness Meditation" and "Challenging Your Automatic Thoughts" activity cards in the self-care library. You can also reach out to a coach for additional support.
Reframing Body Image

“Body image” often implies that the body is something that is viewed. By reframing “body image” as “body acceptance,” you can start to recognize and appreciate your own body as it is, without judgement or criticism. Body acceptance can help you feel more confident, powerful, attractive, loving, happy, and free.
This activity will:

items: Introduce the concept of reframing as a tool towards body acceptance
Provide steps to reframe negative thoughts about your body
Allow you to practice reframing common negative thoughts to build up this skill

components.text: Reframing your thoughts

Cultivating body acceptance has more to do with your mind than your mirror. You can begin making small, daily changes by challenging and reframing your thoughts. Reframing does not mean seeing only a shiny, positive side to everything. It’s simply a way to challenge your thoughts by applying a different point of view. It is an inside job and can take time. Here are some steps to begin:

items: Observe your thoughts, making note of any automatic thoughts. Automatic thoughts are assumptions or opinions about your body. They affect how you feel about yourself. When you make negative assumptions about your body, it can make you feel bad.

Begin to determine what is fact, and what isn’t. Ask yourself: What are the facts? Are my unhelpful thoughts backed up with facts? Is it possible that my unhelpful thoughts are opinions, rather than facts? For example, an unhelpful thought might be “I am useless and lazy”, however that is not a fact; it’s an opinion. The fact might be, “I am choosing to sit on my couch at this moment.”

Question everything you think. Ask yourself: What facts do I have that prove that my unhelpful thoughts are NOT true? Where did each thought come from originally? Why do I think that? Understanding how these thoughts and beliefs formed is an important step. Once you acknowledge and question them, you can start to undo patterns and non-supportive beliefs that you’ve held onto, possibly from a young age.

Change your inner narrative by reframing and rewriting thoughts that no longer serve you. Our thoughts are often just based on our beliefs and beliefs can be changed, which means you can also change the way you feel about your body. Ask yourself: What’s the bigger picture? Is there another way of seeing it? What advice would I give someone else? Is this really as important as it seems?

components.text: Let’s try it out

Practice reframing your thoughts and repeat body-affirming thoughts as often as possible. Most importantly, filter your self-talk, words, and actions through the lens of compassion. Ask yourself what choices most align with your body acceptance desires.
Here are some thought examples you can use to practice reframing. Choose a thought from below that most resonates with you to see how you might reframe it.

options.name: My legs are ugly; I hate the cellulite on them and can’t wear shorts because of it.
I’m too fat. I’m too overweight.
Other people are more beautiful than me.
I am not pretty enough to be attractive or desirable. I am not attractive enough to find love.
If I change my appearance, I’ll be more successful. I'd be a better person, get more job offers, and be better liked if I was thinner.
I don’t like how I look. I have to cover parts of myself up. I look bad in my clothes.

components.text: My legs are ugly; I hate the cellulite on them and can’t wear shorts because of it.
Step one: Observe the thought as a thought, and nothing more.

Step two: Ask yourself, ”What part of this thought is fact?” An opinion is that your legs are “ugly” or that you can’t wear shorts. Ugly is based on opinion and is not fact, Wearing or not wearing shorts is a choice. Neither are facts.

Step three: Inquire about your opinions and assumptions. Why do you feel hate for cellulite? How did the belief that it is bad come to be? Why do you believe you cannot wear shorts? Where and why did you learn that belief? Is it necessary? How is it serving you?

Step four: Practice reframing your thoughts. A fact might sound like “I observe cellulite on my legs”. Then refrain from labeling the facts as “good or bad” which may be opinions based on past experiences and assumptions.
Next, choose new thoughts. Below is a list of examples. Pick one new thought that most resonates with you. If it feels helpful, write it down in a notebook or phone app as a reminder.

items: “I love the feeling of sunlight on my legs and I am grateful for their ability to help me be mobile.”
“I can choose to wear shorts if I desire to”
“These legs were made for my body to use, not for other people to look at”
“My legs are healthy. I appreciate all they do for me and I think they are beautiful as they are”

components.text: I’m too fat. I’m too overweight.

Step one: Question your thought. Where did it come from? Who has determined what “too fat” is for you, and why? Is thinking and believing this helping or hurting you? By whose standards are you basing this belief? Keep in mind that everybody has different sizes and shapes, resulting in different natural weights.

Step two: Reframe the thought to be factual. That might sound like “My body weighs more than I did on [prior date]” or “I desire to take loving care of my body so it can feel its best”. Try not to label the factual thought as good or bad.

Step three: Choose a new thought that may be more aligned with your life values. If your life values are kindness and honesty, body size does not contribute to those. Instead, you might choose a thought such as “my body helps me be mobile so I can be kind to others” or “my body is what gives me the ability to speak with honesty”.

Below are more examples of possible new thoughts. Pick one new  thought that most resonates with you. If it feels helpful, write it down in a notebook or phone app as a reminder and practice using it.

items: “My body is my own. No matter what it looks like or feels like, it is always mine and I can appreciate it through all its forms and abilities.”
“I am not what I weigh. I am unique and loved and special simply for being me.”
“I love me for who I am, in all ways. I can learn what my body needs so I can do all I want to do in my life.”

components.text: Other people are more beautiful than me.
Step one: Observe your thought. Notice where it comes from. Does it come from a comparison to someone you’ve seen on TV or social media?
Step two: Determine what is fact. There is not a standard for beauty, and beauty is subjective. A fact instead might sound like, “The person has brown eyes and I have blue eyes”.

Step three: Question what you think. Most of the images we see online, in magazines, and on TV are highly edited, filtered, and not real. In reality, those people do not look like that. Instead of thinking, “I should look like that,” you could change it to, “that person does not actually look like that and that image has been edited.”
Step four: Choose a new thought. You can replace your original thought with fact and with positive affirmations. A positive affirmation might sound like:

items: “I love and accept myself.”
“I am perfect and complete just the way I am.”
“My body can do awesome things.”

components.text: Pick one new thought that most resonates with you. If it feels helpful, write it down in a notebook or phone app as a reminder and practice using it.
I am not pretty enough to be attractive or desirable. I am not attractive enough to find love.

Step one: Find the fact versus opinion in your thought. There is not a standard for “pretty,” and beauty is subjective. A fact regarding how a person looks might instead might sound like, “That person has brown eyes and I have blue eyes.” You have no idea what another person might feel attracted to. Your appearance has nothing to do with your ability to find love.
Step two: Change your inner narrative. Some examples might be:

items: “I deserve love and affection.”
“I am attracting the right person(s) for me.”
“I am worthy of healthy loving relationships.”
“I am open to love.”
“I am perfect and complete just the way I am.”
“My body can do awesome things.”

components.text: Pick one new thought that most resonates with you. If it feels helpful, write it down in a notebook or phone app as a reminder and practice using it.
If I change my appearance, I’ll be more successful. I'd be a better person, get more job offers, and be better liked if I was thinner.

Step one: Observe what is fact and what is opinion in your thought. We cannot know the future, so future predictions cannot be fact. A person’s ability to be successful or intelligent does not depend on their looks. How we look does not contribute to our worth.
Step two: Change your inner narrative. Some examples might be:

items: “I am the architect of my life. I build its foundation and create its contents.”
“My ability to conquer challenges is limitless. My ability to succeed is infinite.”
“I can achieve greatness.”
“I am perfect and complete just the way I am.”
“I love and accept myself.”

components.text: Now pick one new thought that most resonates with you. If it feels helpful, write it down in a notebook or phone app as a reminder and practice using it.
I don’t like how I look. I have to cover parts of myself up. I look bad in my clothes.

Step one: Question what is fact and what is opinion in your thought. You might not like how you look. Why is that? Are those thoughts based on fact or on feelings generated from low self-esteem or highly edited images? How is that thought serving you? Having to cover parts of yourself is a choice or opinion, not a fact. How you look in clothes is subjective, and there is no single standard for what is good or bad in clothing. Your clothes were made to fit you, not the other way around.
Step two: Change your thought by challenging it, and choosing something new. You might change it to a fact or a positive thought.
Facts might sound like:

items: “Currently I do not feel love for my body and that is a choice I can change.”
“I choose to hide parts of my body, even though my body does not determine my worth.”
“I am grateful to wear clothes. What other people think of me is none of my business.”

components.text: Positive thoughts might sound like:

items: “I love and respect myself.”
“My appearance is not my identity. I am a loving and wonderful person.”
“My opinion of myself is the only one that counts.”

components.text: Now pick one new thought that most resonates with you. If it feels helpful, write it down in a notebook or phone app as a reminder and practice using it.
Nice work!

Great job today taking the time to reframe your thoughts! Like any skill, reframing takes practice. When you have a negative thought about your body, you can come back to this activity card to walk through the steps. Consider bookmarking this card to make it easy to find or take some time to write down the steps so that they can be helpful reminders throughout your week. If you need additional help with reframing your thoughts, your coach can also support you through these steps.
5 Tips to Tame Financial Anxiety

It’s good to care about your financial security, but worrying about it can take a toll on your mental and physical health. Here are five ways to tame financial anxiety and get it to work in your favor.
In this activity card, you’ll learn:

items: About resources that can help you manage your finances;
Strategies to help you feel less anxious about your finances;
Why those strategies can work

components.text: Try some or all of these strategies:
1. Realize that financial anxiety is normal.

If you worry about money, you are not alone. According to the American Psychological Association’s latest Stress in America survey, 72% of Americans have felt stressed about money at some point in the past month. This stress isn’t limited to Americans, either; people around the world struggle with financial anxiety
2. Discuss your financial concerns with someone you trust.

Sharing some of your financial concerns with a trusted friend or family member can lighten the emotional load you’re carrying. It can also prevent you from feeling alone in managing the issue. You don’t have to share every detail about your financial situation, but do consider expressing a few key points about what is bothering you the most.
3. Consider working with a financial counselor.

In addition to listening to your financial concerns, a financial counselor can help you learn about money management, make sense of your credit score, manage debt and understand how money can affect relationships and self-confidence. Some financial counselors will help you build financial goals and a personalized plan for working toward them, and some can help you determine if you’re eligible for certain tax credits or public assistance programs. To make sure you are working with someone with adequate training and experience, look for a counselor certified by the Association for Financial Counseling & Planning Education. Many banks, credit unions and nonprofits like GreenPath Financial Wellness also offer reliable financial counseling.
4. Prioritize your mental health.

A clear mind and a calm emotional state can help you make strong financial decisions. They can also help you ease stress from your finances and other sources. Yoga, meditation and other mindfulness practices can strengthen your ability to calm yourself and push stressful thoughts to the sidelines. Working with a mental health professional like a coach or a therapist is another way to manage anxiety and build the future you want for yourself. Also make sure you’re getting enough rest and exercise, both of which support your overall health and can help regulate your mood. Remember, good health is a valuable asset: It’s worth the extra effort to achieve it.
5. Find financial inspiration.

Even if you’re swimming in debt or struggling to fill an empty bank account, you are not destined to face this barrier forever. First, remember that this too shall pass. Second, find a few sources of financial inspiration that help you maintain a positive attitude about money and take steps toward improving your situation. This could be a blog that shares personal finance tips, stories of people who overcame daunting financial obstacles or even an app that helps you track how much money you’re saving each time you stick to a budget.
Sources:
https://www.apa.org/research/action/speaking-of-psychology/financial-stress
https://www.nerdwallet.com/article/investing/financial-counselor
A Mindful Approach to Parenting

Parenting can be challenging at times no matter what stage your child is in. By taking a mindful approach, parents can learn how to manage stressors and cope with the day-to-day challenges of parenting.
In this activity you will:

items: Learn about mindfulness and its positive benefits
Understand ways to apply mindfulness to parenting
Learn tips and tools to apply for all stages of your parenting journey

components.text: Common Stressors That Parents Face
Parenting can bring a variety of stress to one's household. Some of the most common challenges include:

items: Navigating life as a new parent
Managing time with work and family
Helping children who have issues at school or home
Managing one's own emotions
Helping children through tough emotions
Balancing responsibilities
Pandemic Stress
And more…

components.text: If those stressors affect your life, you are not alone! It's normal to feel stressed as a parent. Practicing mindfulness can be a helpful tool to manage your stress. We'll walk through some specific strategies for how you can take some of the fundamentals of mindfulness and apply them to parenting.
What exactly is mindfulness?

According to the American Psychological Association, mindfulness is: “…a moment-to-moment awareness of one's experience without judgment.” Mindfulness asks that we observe our physical, mental, and emotional experiences. Mindfulness can be achieved during a meditation session, taking a thoughtful break, and practicing yoga, and other forms of exercise.

Mindfulness can be beneficial in parenting in so many ways. One of the biggest benefits of mindful parenting is learning to manage your emotions and modeling that for your children. In times of distress, being mindful may seem unrealistic, but with a little practice, mindfulness is achievable, even in the most stressful circumstances. Below are three tactical ways to practice mindful parenting:

items: Practice Conscious awareness: Mindful parenting may look like bringing conscious awareness to the current situation instead of letting your emotions hijack the situation. For example, imagine that your three-year-old is throwing a tantrum at the dinner table and refusing to eat their vegetables. In this situation, you might acknowledge that when your child throws a tantrum, it is really frustrating. Naming the emotion allows you to pause and acknowledge what's currently happening.

Let go of guilt and shame: Mindful parenting can include letting go of guilt and shame about the past, and focusing on the present. For example, perhaps you’re feeling guilty about having to travel for work and being away from your children. In this situation, you might experience feelings of guilt. That's OK. Instead of trying to change or avoid those feelings, practice acceptance.

Pause before responding: Mindful parenting teaches us how to pause before responding. For example, instead of lashing out in anger and frustration when your child is upset, mindful parenting might mean taking five minutes to practice deep breathing or affirmations to get through the tough moment. Taking this moment to pause can help you choose the best way to respond to your child’s behavior.

components.text: Consider Your Own Wellness Needs

To help you practice mindful parenting, consider evaluating whether your needs are being met as an individual. In order to take care of others, we must ensure that we are taking care of ourselves. Consider some areas in your life that are challenging right now and take some time to write them down. Take a moment to read the wellness wheel below. Which of the eight areas of wellness do your challenges fall under — social, emotional, spiritual, intellectual, physical, environmental, financial, or occupational?
Now take some time to read mindful affirmations for the areas that you've identified:

items: Social: “I am supported by those who celebrate me, support me, and point me in the right direction.”
Emotional: “I share my emotions openly, releasing that energy from my body.”
Spiritual: “I am a special soul who is here in this world to be fully expressed.”
Intellectual: “My thoughts are my sacred territory and I get to choose which direction I focus them, and they are powerful.”
Physical: “I courageously choose balance in my life for my mind, body, and soul.”
Environmental: “I am creating an environment that makes sense for me to thrive.”
Financial: “I give my attention to a future scenario I want, one that inspires me and represents my fullest potential.”
Occupational: “I am using my full potential to cultivate a life where I am satisfied with my career in fun and fulfilling ways.”

components.text: Tips on Becoming a Mindful Parent
You don't need to wait for a frustrating parenting moment to happen in order to practice mindfulness. Pick one tip to try out this week to practice mindfulness ahead of time.

options.name: Create a meditation practice to do 3-4 times a week. Carve out 20 minutes of your time (either day or night) to create a sacred meditation practice. Use this time to let go of frustrations, anxieties, and stressors.

Set boundaries with work. Whether working from home or in person, set boundaries with your work schedule so you can actively be present during family time. You might also consider putting a family activity on the calendar if your work schedule is demanding.
Have a mantra for tough moments. Sometimes repeating a comforting mantra helps with grounding and patience. Try this time-tested favorite: “I am doing the best I can with what I have at this moment.”
Learn your triggers. As a parent, what negative behavior from your child sends you from 0 to 100? Figure out why this triggers you by exploring your inner child.
Be open minded. Some battles are not worth the power struggle. Figure out where you can be flexible and come to a solution with your child.

Set a limit on your screen time. Sometimes we can become too hooked into social media and our phones. Try to practice mindful awareness and being present by spending an hour (or more) a day without the screens. During this time, you can practice self-care, journaling, or relaxation.

components.text: Great work!

Congrats on taking the time today to learn more about mindful parenting. You are doing great! Keep in mind that any new skill takes time to practice, so it's completely normal if the tip doesn't work right away. Consistent practice is best. If you’d like, you can also come back to this activity next week and try another tip.
If you need additional ideas or support, check out the self-care library for some more tips and tools to help you stay focused. You can also reach out to a coach for additional support.
Building Resilience

Roadblocks are inevitable, but with the right skills and an open mind, you may find that a new route can lead to somewhere wonderful. In this activity card, coach Phoebe Jenkins will provide you with tools to help build healthy habits, change your mindset, practice self-care, and strengthen relationships so you can learn to thrive when challenges arise.

If you haven’t already, check out the “Defining Resilience” activity card first for the intro to this series. You can also print out the accompanying workbook,  [Resilience Workbook](https://gingerio.my.salesforce.com/sfc/p/#f40000002Q1l/a/5G000000RJfC/3hXG13hB8DNvv7.hgq46136vt_2Sy7_aHcqQ1FmIlr8), to follow along — both for this activity, “Building Resilience,” and for “Defining Resilience.” In this activity, “Building Resilience,” we will focus on the content from pages 3-11 from the workbook.
This activity will:

items: Explain the four pillars of resilience
Discuss strategies for building these four pillars
Guide you through ways to build your own resilience toolkit

components.text: First, do you want to watch the 28-minute video or read the content?
Building Resilience
Pillar #1: Purpose

Having purpose and meaning in your life can help you focus on the bigger picture rather than the immediate challenges at hand. Staying connected to your purpose can help you to stay grounded and present when dealing with hardships. Here are two strategies that can help you build your purpose:

Tip #1 - Collect and build wisdom: The wisdom and insight that helped you overcome difficulties in the past can be useful to collect and put into your resilience plan. It might be song lyrics, novels, poetry, spiritual writings, quotes, the sayings of your grandparents or your own experiences. To collect this wisdom, create a list or box in which you highlight all things you’ve used before in life that helped you reconnect with your greater values and purpose and get through difficult times. Refer to this list or box when you experience hardships and add to it when you can. What’s one piece of wisdom or insight that you can refer to when faced with a challenge?

Tip #2 - Move toward your goals: Staying connected to your goals and making progress can help boost your resilience and keep you rooted in your purpose, even when facing hardships. To do this, it can help to clarify your long-term goals and focus on small steps to make progress towards those goals. Take some time to reflect on the following questions, which can help you to focus on your purpose regardless of what life throws at you:

items: What will make your life a good one?
What is one long-term goal you can set based on your answer above?
What are three SMART (specific, measurable, attainable, realistic, and time-bound) short-term goals you can set that will help you achieve your long-term goal?

components.text: Pillar #2: Thoughts

How you think can impact your resilience when facing obstacles. Healthy thoughts support you and help you face greater challenges. By adopting balanced and realistic thinking patterns, you can build resilience. You may not be able to change a highly stressful event, but you can change how you interpret and respond to it. Below are three strategies that can help you build your purpose:

Tip #1 - Practice adaptability: Adaptability = flexibility + creativity. When you are adaptable, you are more likely to feel in control of your situation, boosting your sense of resilience. You can build your adaptability by practicing creative thinking and brainstorming. The act of generating new ideas can prepare you for coming up with solutions during a hardship instead of feeling stuck in black-or-white, all-or-nothing thinking. To do this, you can try an activity called “10 New Ideas.”

items: Pick a length of time (e.g., one week) and every day during that time frame, create ten new ideas for a specific topic  (e.g., new ideas for a book topic, date idea, business, etc.)
Schedule a specific time and place to do this exercise and add it to your calendar daily for the allotted time.
Write your ideas in a notebook or on your phone or computer rather than doing it in your head.
Consider trying it out now. Take a few minutes to write down ten new vacation locations you’d like to visit if you had a chance to leave tomorrow.

components.text: Remember that the point of this exercise isn’t to come up with particularly creative or unique ideas! Rather, this exercise trains your brain for the process of generating many different ideas. For this reason, see if you can avoid judging or censoring your ideas; being creative can be challenging at first.
Pillar #2: Thoughts (continued)

Tip #2 - Widen your window of tolerance: Inside your window of tolerance is when you feel calm and receptive. Outside your window of tolerance you feel reactive and stressed. For example, some days an annoyance might feel like an insignificant blip. Other days, it leaves you feeling angry and frustrated. The difference is if you were inside or outside your window of tolerance. Staying inside your window of tolerance can help you be more resilient and deal with difficulties. To more frequently stay in your window of tolerance, bring awareness to your thoughts in response to a stressor. Practice questioning them and generating alternative thoughts. When faced with a situation, see if your automatic thought is based on assumption or fact, rather than immediately reacting to the situation based on your initial thoughts.

Imagine the following scenario: You’re going for a walk in your neighborhood and see a new family moving into the house down the street. Since they’re outside, you give them a friendly wave and say “hi.” They look at you, but don’t respond or smile back. What are your initial reactions and thoughts?

items: One reaction might be, “They just stared at me - do they think I’m weird? Do they not like me?” or “Wow, how rude! They must be an unfriendly family.” These might be some of your automatic thoughts.

Now, instead of staying in that assumption, try generating alternative thoughts. What else could be the reason the family did not respond? Perhaps they’ve been moving all day and were too tired to process a new person greeting them. They could be adjusting to a new environment or you might not know the reason at all and could return another day and try engaging them again.

components.text: Questioning your automatic thoughts, coming up with alternatives, and practicing positive self-talk will help you remain in your window of tolerance.
Pillar #2: Thoughts (continued)

Tips #3 - Identify what’s in and out of your control: The key to resilience is focusing on what’s in your control and letting go of what isn’t. You may not be able to control certain things that happen. But, you can deal with the emotions that result from the experience, and reframe the meaning of the situation or engage in other activities that help you cope with the consequences of the situation.
To put this into practice, when you are experiencing hardship:

items: Make a list of what’s in your personal control, especially what actions are fully within your power and don’t rely on other people or circumstances to be effective. Listing what is within your control can help you think of what action you can take to deal with those things.
Then, make a list of things that are out of your control. Listing what is out of your control can help you acknowledge them, then work on letting them go.

components.text: Distinguishing between what is in and out of your control can help you to approach hardship from a rational perspective rather than feeling overwhelmed.
Pillar #3: Connection

All forms of social support matter in helping us face challenges because they help us feel less stressed and less alone when we are suffering. Relationships that create love and trust, provide role models, and offer encouragement and reassurance can help bolster our resilience.

Tip - Build healthy social connections: Having a healthy support system enables you to tap into that resource in times of hardship and help boost your resilience. Below are ways to build and nurture this support system:

items: Build a support system by finding trustworthy and compassionate individuals who validate your feelings. This process could mean that you may have to set boundaries with individuals who disrespect you and your feelings, or that are detrimental to your emotional wellbeing.

Nurture your existing support system. One way you can do this is by using a tool called “One Kind Thing” daily. This involves doing one form of “outreach” per day (e.g., sending a text message letting someone know why you’re thankful for them, doing something kind for a friend, or buying a meal for someone in need). This practice helps you to create more meaningful connections which can help you feel more resilience.

components.text: Take some time now to reflect on your own support system. Consider writing down your responses in your workbook or on a piece of paper, your phone, or computer:

items: What “supportive people” in your life kept you standing when it would have been easier to fall down? For instance, did you call an old friend, ask a teacher for advice, or have a parent or grandparent give you a pep talk? If there aren’t people that come to mind, consider taking the steps suggested above to begin building new connections.
Whether or not you have an existing support system, what are some ways you can build or nurture healthy relationships?

components.text: Pillar #4: Self-Care

Our physical health provides mental and physical energy to deal with challenging situations. Proper nutrition, sleep, hydration, and exercise can strengthen your mind and body, which is important for tackling challenging situations. Self-care practices can also help you feel more hopeful and stay centered during difficult times.

Tip #1 - Create constants: Having routine or constants in your life during times of crisis can help you feel like some things are still in your control. You can turn to things like regular exercise, consistent meals, a daily meditation, or a regular bedtime for purpose and stability. To start, pick one small self-care habit to start with. It may be helpful to write it out and create a schedule for yourself. You might also find it helpful to have a visual reminder (e.g., post-it notes or setting a phone reminder) and incorporate it into your daily routine. Take some time now to reflect on the question below:

items: Do you have constants in your life you can rely on, especially during times of crisis or change? If not, what are some ways you can introduce constants into your life? If you need support, your Headspace Care coach can help you create a plan to form these constants and hold you accountable.

components.text: Tip #2 - Engage in movement: Regular movement (especially regular exercise) lessens stress, boosts mood, and improves sleep. Movement can also improve your concentration and planning which are important tools for dealing with difficult situations. Physical movement can also train you for mental resilience. For example, a workout class might be physically and mentally demanding, pushing you to your limits; however, at the same time, you are practicing getting through it until the end of class without giving up. Try out the following to bring more movement into your life:

items: Identify what kind of movement you want to do. Start small and easy so that you can’t say “no” to it. This might mean just committing to one push up or a two-minute stretch, or five minutes of gardening a day. Set aside time for yourself, schedule it, and try to stick to it.
Ask yourself what wellness and self-care strategies you’ve used in the past that have helped you cope with difficulties and stay resilient. How might you schedule these more consistently?

components.text: Well done!

Congrats on taking the time to learn about resilience! In this activity, you’ve learned four pillars of resilience and strategies for building each pillar. Remember that it takes small steps over time to build resilience. Take your first step towards building your resilience toolkit now by picking one pillar that you want to focus on:

options.name: Purpose (collect & build wisdom, move towards your goals)
Thoughts (practice adaptability, widen your window of tolerance, identify what’s in & out of your control)

components.text: As you start to practice the strategies in your pillar, it can help to write down some actionable steps you can take to strengthen this pillar. When you’re ready (or if you need a fresh start), you can always come back to this activity card to try out a new pillar.
Defining Resilience

Unexpected detours are part of life. How you navigate those detours can make all the difference for your well-being and personal growth. Getting off course may feel stressful, but learning how to cope can make you emotionally stronger. To get started, it helps to understand what resilience is and how it can help you to thrive when challenges arise.

Before you begin, you can also print out the accompanying workbook to follow along: [Resilience Workbook](https://gingerio.my.salesforce.com/sfc/p/#f40000002Q1l/a/5G000000RJfC/3hXG13hB8DNvv7.hgq46136vt_2Sy7_aHcqQ1FmIlr8). In this activity, we will focus on the content from page 2 in the workbook, Defining Resilience.
This activity will:

items: Define and explain the foundations of resilience
Discuss common myths about resilience
Guide you through a reflection of your own resilience

components.text: First, do you want to watch the 5-minute video or read?
Defining Resilience
What is resilience?

Resilience is both a mindset and a series of tools and actions that can help people boost their ability to bounce back from hardships and challenges, both big and small. It’s the process of adaptation in the face of adversity, trauma, tragedy, threats, or significant sources of stress.
Take some time now to reflect on your own experience. Ask yourself:

items: Have I gone through a big change in the past year?
In what area(s) of my life has this change impacted me? (E.g., health, finances, relationships, social life, career, education, happiness, etc.)
How do I usually face challenges as they arise?
Do I find my current methods effective?

components.text: Resilience Myths

There are common misconceptions about resilience that can make the idea of being resilient feel daunting or unachievable. Resilience sometimes can often be misrepresented as being strong at all times and in all circumstances. However, it’s something that anyone can practice, often in small ways. Below are three myths about resilience that can get you started reflecting on how you’ve used resilience in your life:

items: Resilience is something you either have or don’t have: While some people might naturally be able to adapt more quickly to new situations or challenges, resilience is a still that involves thoughts and actions that can be developed or learned by anyone. You can learn more about these strategies in the “Building Resilience” activity card.

Being resilient means you won’t experience difficulty or distress: Resilience is about your ability to react and cope with challenges and not the absence of difficulty or distress. In fact, the road to resilience is likely to involve trial and error, which is completely normal and all part of building your resilience over time.

Acts of resilience must be “grand”: Resilience often happens every day in small ways. Over time, these small acts of resilience build and can help you feel prepared if and when something more challenging comes around.

components.text: Reflecting on your own resilience

Take a moment now to reflect on the questions below to consider ways you’ve been resilient in your own life. Consider writing your response in your workbook or on a piece of paper as a helpful reminder this week:

items: When did I overcome hardship in my life?
How might resilience help me in my life? Why do I want to build resilience?

components.text: Well done!

Nice job today learning about resilience! Remember that anyone can develop resilience. By taking small steps in your everyday life, you can build up this skill. When you take some time to reflect on your own past experiences, you’re likely to find examples of how you’ve already practiced resilience. Check out the “Building Resilience” activity card next to learn about some tactical steps you can take to continue building your resilience. Remember that you can always reach out to your Headspace Care coach for support.
Track & Challenge Automatic Thoughts

An automatic thought is the first thought that comes to mind after an experience, big or small. Typically automatic thoughts can be uncomfortable, and sometimes they’re not based in reality. They can lead you to a conclusion that may not be true. Tracking your automatic thoughts can help you understand what triggers them and how to manage them.
This activity will help you track a recent automatic thought and help you challenge it.
1. What was your most recent automatic thought?
E.g. “Everything in my life is falling apart.”
2. When did you have the thought?
E.g. In the morning, just before breakfast.
3. Where were you when you had the thought?
E.g. “At home, on my computer.”
4. What happened and how did you feel?
E.g., “I'd just had a big fight with Sam. I felt totally out of control and ashamed that I'd said things I didn't mean.”
5. Can you come up with an alternative to your automatic thought?
E.g. “Just because I felt out of control in my fight does not mean that ‘Everything is falling apart.’”
6. Write a question to challenge your automatic thought.
E.g. “Is everything actually falling apart or could it be in just this one part of my life with Sam? Are there parts of my life that are going well?”
Write a more reasonable alternative explanation to your automatic thought.
E.g. “My relationship with Sam has been rocky, but I'm doing really well at work. Some things actually are going well.”
Nice work! You just practiced rewriting an automatic thought.  Tracking your automatic thoughts helps you understand what triggers them and provides a way to manage them.
Common Challenges of Tracking Automatic Thoughts
The Trouble with Automatic Thoughts

The first thought that comes to mind after an experience, regardless of whether the experience was big or small, is called an automatic thought. Automatic thoughts can be uncomfortable or make us feel anxious, or they can add to already existing anxiety. Here’s the good news about automatic thoughts: They’re usually not based in fact.

Keeping track of when automatic thoughts occur and what triggers them can help you prepare for and manage them when they arise. It can also help you understand when they’re true and when they’re not. But tracking automatic thoughts can be challenging.
Here are a few of the common challenges people face when trying to track automatic thoughts, along with some explanations.
Common challenge #1:
“My automatic thoughts ARE true.”
Explanation:

When we talk about automatic thoughts, we usually say that they’re not true. But what does that mean? And what if your thought is true? You indeed had a real experience, and your feelings about that experience are true, too. As an example, let’s say you lost your new sunglasses and you’re frustrated about that. It’s true that you lost your sunglasses and it’s true that you’re frustrated.

But, when you take it a step further, you may make an assumption that’s not true. Sticking with the same example, you might think, “I lost my sunglasses. I’m frustrated. Nothing ever goes right for me.” That last part, that nothing ever goes right for you, is an assumption. It’s your automatic thought and you can challenge that thought because it’s debatable. In this example you would try to think of things that do go right for you.
Common challenge #2:
“I don’t know when I have an automatic thought.”

It’s sometimes difficult to notice when automatic thoughts arise. If that’s the case, it may be helpful to pay attention to your physical feelings of stress or other behaviors. When you notice physical signs of stress, stop and think what may be causing those signs. It might be a stressful automatic thought.
Behavior Chain
Here's what you can expect to take away from today's activity: Gain a short introduction to several different types of mindfulness practices.

items: Understand how one stressful 'trigger' event might set off a series of reactions from you.
Learn how to identify when you’re being 'triggered'.
Learn about ways to change your reactions and limit the effect of stress.

components.text: The bad news about stress is that you can't avoid all of the things that trigger it– it's just not possible.

You don't control the universe, and sometimes the universe is going to make you sad, sometimes it's going to make you feel angry towards your partner, and sometimes it will disrupt your healthy habits.
Even though you can't avoid these triggers altogether, you can make yourself less vulnerable to them.
That means you can help yourself be less reactive to them when they happen. Instead of reacting to your trigger with a problematic behavior , you can find different, better responses.

But finding new ways to respond to your triggers is the tricky part. You may have noticed that often times it seems like problem behaviors just sort of happen to you. Your trigger happens, and the next thing you know, you're reacting emotionally or feeling completely overwhelmed. This makes it feel impossible to know what you can do differently the next time around.
And that's where The Behavior Chain comes in.
The Behavior Chain helps make sense of the whole chain of events associated with your problem behavior.
There are six basic links to The Behavior Chain. Here's what they are.

items: Vulnerability: This is anything that might have made you vulnerable before your problem behavior happened. Vulnerabilities might be a stressful event, lack of sleep, physical pain, drinking, drug use, etc.
Prompting Event: This is the event that led directly to your problem behavior. What happened?
Thoughts & Feelings: These are the many thoughts and feelings that happen as a result of the prompting event.

Actions: Any actions you took right after the prompting event. It helps here to consider in detail what happened right after the prompting event took place? What happened after that? And then what happened after that? And so on.
Problem behavior: This is the behavior you're trying to change.
Consequences: This is how your problem behavior affects you and others after you've done it. How do you feel afterward? What do you think about yourself?

components.text: Take Jamie, for example.

items: Vulnerability: She barely slept.
Precipitating event: She got a bad evaluation at work.
Thoughts and feelings: She felt overwhelmed, terrified of losing her job, and had lots of negative thoughts about her self-worth.
Actions: She went to the bar with coworkers after work. She had one more drink than she usually does
Problem behavior: She stopped for fast food, breaking her commitment to herself to eat healthy.
Consequences: She felt ashamed and disgusted with herself.

components.text: So what?
What's important to know about the behavior chain is this:
Each link in the chain represents an opportunity for you to do something different.
Somewhere in that chain, there's a place you might have made a different decision that would have made you less vulnerable to your unwanted behavior.
Considering the chain as a whole gives you a chance to step back and find where that place might have been.

Jamie might have broken her behavior chain at the bar, for example. Her lowered inhibitions made her extra vulnerable to making unhealthy food choices, so she could have chosen not to have that extra drink. Or, she could have skipped drinking altogether and stuck to water that night.

The more you create and analyze behavior chains, the more information you'll have about how and when to take care of yourself. And when you train yourself to recognize and take action early in the chain, the less reactive you'll be to your triggers.
That's how it works. Now you'll give it a try on your own. Afterward, you can talk to your coach about your experience.
Guided Productivity Meditation
10 minutes
Here's what you can expect to take away from today's activity:

items: Get help focusing on your intention to get something done.
Learn how to tackle a task you've been dreading or attempted multiple times but keep being unable to finish.

components.text: Mindfulness practices work like this:

items: Find a place to sit or lay down where you won't be interrupted.
Have your headphones ready, and audio guidance will walk you through the whole practice.

components.text: Your current skill level
How focused and able to complete your task do you feel? 0=Not at all, 10= Completely
Grab your headphones and let's get to it.
Your current skill level
How focused and able to complete your task do you feel? 0=Not at all, 10= Completely

increased.title: Your focus level increased.
increased.body: Continue to practice this skill and use it when it will be helpful to you.

same.title: Your focus stayed the same.
same.body: This meditation doesn’t seem to have affected your focus for the task at hand. You can try this activity again and see if it works better for you with practice.

decreased.title: Your focus went down.
decreased.body: This meditation seems to have made it more difficult to focus on the task at hand. You can try this activity again and see if it works better for you with practice

components.text: How I Practice Self-Care

Mason, a teenager from the San Francisco Bay Area, was a member of Headspace Care’s first Teen Advisory Council. Mason enjoys running, doing math problems, and cooking, and is interested in psychology and neuroscience. He loves hanging out with his family and his cat named Pillow. In this video, he shares his self-care practices that helped him cope with isolation and loneliness during the pandemic.
Headspace Care activity cards that can help:

items: “Practicing Self-Care”
“Celebrate Small Things”
“Activities to Enjoy”
“Savor the Good”

components.text: Reach out to your Headspace Care care team any time for judgement-free support and help finding additional resources.
Improve the Moment
The IMPROVE strategy helps you relax in stressful situations.
INSTRUCTIONS
Let's start with the I in the IMPROVE strategy.
When stressed, imagine relaxing moments, good experiences from the past, and anything that has made you feel good.
Start trying to put this technique into action. Practice in a low-stress situation first, so it'll come naturally when you need it in times of stress.
WHY
This technique can help you be more grounded, calm, and lucid.
Improve the Moment (Part 2)
The IMPROVE strategy helps you relax in stressful situations
INSTRUCTIONS
The M in the IMPROVE strategy is Meaning.

When stressed, look for the meaning or purpose in what you're currently feeling. For example, if a good friend's actions upset you, maybe your feelings help you realize how much you value them, and how hard you're willing to work on that friendship.
Start putting the Meaning technique into action. Practice in a low-stress situation first, so it'll come naturally when you need it in times of stress.
WHY
This technique can help you be more grounded, calm, and lucid.
Improve the Moment (Part 3)
The IMPROVE strategy helps you relax in stressful situations.
INSTRUCTIONS
The P in the IMPROVE strategy is Prayer.
Prayer doesn't require religion! When stressed, try praying either in the traditional religious sense, or by simply creating a positive saying for yourself.
Start putting the Prayer technique into action. Practice in a low-stress situation first, so it'll come naturally when you need it in times of stress.
WHY
This technique can help you be more grounded, calm, and lucid.
Improve the Moment (Part 4)
The IMPROVE strategy helps you relax in stressful situations.
INSTRUCTIONS
The R in the IMPROVE strategy is Relax.
When stressed, use a relaxation technique that works for you. Refer to our health tips for more ideas.
Start putting the Relax technique into action. Practice in a low-stress situation first, so it'll come naturally when you need it in times of stress.
WHY
This technique can help you be more grounded, calm, and lucid.
Improve the Moment (Part 5)
The IMPROVE strategy helps you relax in stressful situations.
INSTRUCTIONS
The O in the IMPROVE strategy is One.
When stressed, focus on one thing in the current moment. Fixate on a color in the room, a cloud or a plant. Stay in the present.
Start putting the One technique into action. Practice in a low-stress situation first, so it'll come naturally when you need it in times of stress.
WHY
This technique can help you be more grounded, calm, and lucid.
Improve the Moment (Part 6)
The IMPROVE strategy helps you relax in stressful situations.
INSTRUCTIONS
The V in the IMPROVE strategy is Vacation.
When stressed, take a mini-vacation that removes you whatever's causing the stress. This might we a walk or a trip to a friend's house.
Start putting the Vacation technique into action. Practice in a low-stress situation first, so it'll come naturally when you need it in times of stress.
WHY
This technique can help you be more grounded, calm, and lucid.
Improve the Moment (Part 7)
The IMPROVE strategy helps you relax in stressful situations.
INSTRUCTIONS
The E in the IMPROVE strategy is Encouragement.
When stressed, give yourself some encouragement! Remind yourself of what you're doing right. List examples of how you've succeeded in the past.
Start putting the Encouragement technique into action. Practice in a low-stress situation first, so it'll come naturally when you need it in times of stress.
WHY
This technique can help you be more grounded, calm, and lucid.

properties.name: Knowing When to Ask for Help
properties.description: Knowing When to Ask for Help

components.text: Knowing When to Ask for Help
Daisy’s story about asking for help and support when she felt overwhelmed by responsibilities at home.
Video: selfsea/Peer Health Exchange
Headspace Care activity cards that can help:

items: “Preventing Burnout”
“Managing Family Relationships”
“Supporting Loved Ones’ Mental Health”
“Grounding Your Stress”
“Asking for What Your Need”

components.text: Reach out to your Headspace Care care team any time for judgement-free support and help finding additional resources.
The Myth of Multitasking
This activity will discuss some of the research on multitasking and how it affects productivity. Hint: multitasking can actually make you less productive.
First, do you want to listen to the audio or read along?
Grab your headphones and let's get to it.
We all have lots of demands on our attention: tasks we have to do, and things we want to do.

With all there is to do, it’s hard to stay focused. So, we try to multitask -- we try to do more than one thing at time. But multitasking is a myth. We can’t actually focus our attention on more than one task at a time. What people refer to as multitasking is actually switching from one task to the other and back again.
The Evidence

For example, let’s say you have several tabs open on your browser window. In one, you’re drafting an email. In another, you’re researching mattresses. In another, you’re chatting with your partner about your dinner plans. You might feel like you’re engaged in all of those tabs, but you’re actually only focusing on whichever tab is open. You’re switching between tasks. Another (more dangerous example) is driving while glancing at your phone. You may think you’re able to multitask, but your attention can’t be on both the road and your phone at once.

Research shows that task-switching is quite common. In one study of office workers, researchers found that most employees only spent an average of 11 minutes on a task before they were interrupted. It then took them an average of 25 minutes to get back to the original task. Why so long? Well, because getting interrupted affects our short-term memory. Basically, the employees forgot what they were doing originally. They got distracted by a new project or task, and started working on it instead.

Those interruptions, however, are part of modern worklife. The same researchers found that most employees felt the interruptions were important for their work. The interruptions were either for urgent items that came up, or were helpful to what the employees were working on.
So, what’s so bad about interruptions? According to this one study, they make doing a single task take a lot longer than it normally would.
Want to see for yourself? Try this:
Start a timer. Then, draw two horizontal lines. On the first line, write the phrase “I’m great at multitasking.” On the second line, write out the numbers 1 through 20 in order.
On average, this takes about 20 seconds to do.

Next, draw two horizontal lines. This time, you’ll switch back and forth between writing the letters of “I’m great at multitasking” on the first line and the number 1-20 on the second line. So, you’ll start by writing “I” on the first line. Then switch and write “1” on the second line. Then switch back to the first line and write “m” in the I’m. Then you’ll switch back to the second line and write the number 2. And so on until you have the full sentence and all 20 numbers written.
As you can imagine, it takes most people at least double the amount of time to complete the second task even though the outcome is identical.
All that switching of focus takes mental energy. And it takes double the time.
Your Next Steps

Given that multitasking is actually rapid task-switching, and that rapid task-switching takes a whole lot more time and energy than focusing on one task at a time, what should you do? The trick is to find longer blocks of uninterrupted time to spend working on a single task.

It’s easier said than done and how to get that time will differ with everyone. If you work in an office, it might be useful to come in work earlier or to leave later than most people, so you have more alone time. Or, you might find it helpful to block out an hour on your calendar to work on a specific task. If being interrupted by emails or instant messages is your problem, close out everything on your computer except what you’re currently working on.
While those examples are specific for office workers, the principles behind them apply to any situation:

items: Find time to be alone so you can focus.
Plan out your day so that you have specific blocks dedicated to each of your tasks.
Try to minimize any distractions during those times.

components.text: The ability to focus your attention on the task at hand, dismiss distractions that come your way, and quiet your mind is something you can learn. It just takes intention and practice
Preventing Burnout

Burnout is the feeling you get when you’re no longer able to cope with all that is demanded of you. Some people describe it as feeling like a dry sponge that is still being wrung out for any last drops of water. Preventing or dealing with burnout doesn’t just mean taking a vacation. There are other ways to help you avoid feeling like that dry sponge.
In this activity you’ll learn:

items: What burnout is and why it matters for you.
How to identify the signs of burnout.
How to prevent burnout.
How to cope with burnout.

components.text: How to tell if you’re burnt out
These physical manifestations could be signs of burnout:

items: You have less energy than usual.
You seem to catch every cold or flu that comes along
You feel constantly tired even after getting plenty of sleep

components.text: Burnout can also manifest as emotions, too, such as:

items: You feel helpless or hopeless.
You get little satisfaction from what you do every day.
You neglect your needs because you don’t care anymore.

components.text: What causes burnout?

Burnout is the gap between our expectations and the actual rewards. It’s the difference between what we want and what we actually get. This might explain why young people often burn out more than their older coworkers. Younger people often have high and idealistic expectations when they first start working. But, once they’re into the daily grind, they find the rewards are often far less than what they expected.

Burnout doesn’t just happen in the workplace. A lot of caregivers of elderly parents or of special needs children experience burnout too. Again, any time the demands are more than you can cope with, you’re likely to burn out.

Researchers from the University of California, Berkeley did a study on burnout. They looked at employees from one insurance company. Some experienced burnout while others were able to resist it. The difference was that those who weren’t burnt out had had a positive experience with insurance during their childhood—maybe an insurance company helped their family recover financially from a house fire. Employees with these personal experiences were engaged in their work. Some even felt their career choice was a calling.
Preventing Burnout by Building Engagement

Many people might think that relaxing more or taking a vacation will prevent burnout. But, as we learned from the insurance industry study, building engagement with what you’re doing is the best approach to preventing burnout. Deriving meaning from and feeling personally invested in what you do can help you cope with challenges and more quickly recover from stress. While a career change may be possible for some people, it’s unrealistic for others. You don’t have to change jobs to find something you can engage with; you might just need to change how you think about it.
Where do you want to engage?
Aligning your energy with your values will help you stay engaged instead of burned out.sssssss

The concept of “giving your all” to everything you do isn’t necessarily healthy or helpful. Focusing your energy on something you care about can help prevent you from spreading yourself too thin. So, while you still have to work every day, pay the bills, and run errands, you can still find ways to incorporate meaning into those activities. For example, if you value alone time, maybe you can reframe your errands as “me time” and listen to your favorite music in the car or while you wait in line.
If you can find a part of your day that you can make more meaningful, you can start to turn your exhaustion into engagement and your hopelessness into hopefulness.
Ways I Handle Stress

Ruscia (pronounced like the country) is a teenager from Detroit and was a member of Headspace Care’s first Teen Advisory Council.  She loves reading, making art, and trying new foods. She’s also learning American Sign Language. In this video, she shares four tips for how she manages stress.
Headspace Care activity cards that can help:

items: “Activities to Enjoy”
“Grounding Your Stress”
“Stress 101”

components.text: Reach out to your Headspace Care care team any time for judgement-free support and help finding additional resources.
Adaptability Check-In
What is this?
A short survey to measure your ability to bounce back from challenges, also known as resilience. Being resilient means you have confidence and can handle whatever comes your way.
Why am I doing this?
So you and your care team can understand your strengths and areas of improvement. You'll see your results at the end.
How do I start?
Tap Begin. Choose the answer that best describes how much, in the past month you agree with the statements.
Over the last month, how much do you agree with the following statement:
I am able to adapt when changes occur.
Over the last month, how much do you agree with the following statement:
I can deal with whatever comes my way.
Over the last month, how much do you agree with the following statement:
I try to see the humorous side of things when I am faced with problems.
Over the last month, how much do you agree with the following statement:
Having to cope with stress can make me stronger.
Over the last month, how much do you agree with the following statement:
I tend to bounce back after illness, injury, or other hardships.
Over the last month, how much do you agree with the following statement:
I believe I can achieve my goals, even if there are obstacles.
Over the last month, how much do you agree with the following statement:
Under pressure, I stay focused and think clearly.
Over the last month, how much do you agree with the following statement:
I am not easily discouraged by failure.
Over the last month, how much do you agree with the following statement:
I think of myself as a strong person when dealing with life’s challenges and difficulties.
Over the last month, how much do you agree with the following statement:
I am able to handle unpleasant or painful feelings like sadness, fear, and anger.
All done!

Thank you for taking the time to let us
know how you’re doing.

components.text: Questions for You About Your Teen
Your teen's coaches will use your answers to gain an understanding of what your teen may be going through from your perspective and why you’re referring your teen to Headspace Care.
This survey should not be used to communicate urgent or emergent matters, as it won’t be reviewed immediately.
If your teen is experiencing an emergency or needs immediate assistance, please contact the National Suicide Hotline at 988, call 911, or go to your nearest emergency room.
Please tell us why you’re seeking care for your teen.
Please share any concerns you’d like your teen’s care team to know about.
Does your teen have an existing mental health diagnosis?
E.g. Major Depressive Disorder, ADHD, etc.
What is the diagnosis and when was this diagnosis first made?
What are your goals for your teen?
Please clarify what the other goals are for your teen.
How would you rate the relationship with your teen and their family (including siblings, etc)?
On a scale of 0 to 10, with 10 being the most positive and 0 being the least.
What are your teen’s strengths or talents?
Do you believe that your teen may be in danger of harming themself or others?
What leads you to believe they may harm themself or others?
Thank you
Thank you for your answers. We’ll use them to connect your teen with a coach who can help with their specific needs.
If you experience any issues, please reach out to [caresupport@headspace.com](mailto:caresupport@headspace.com).

properties.description: Headspace Care: Escalation for Psychiatry With Previous Consent

components.text: Here’s what to expect for your teen
About Headspace Care psychiatry

Psychiatry sessions take place via video chat. Our psychiatry team is made up of psychiatrists and nurse practitioners specifically trained and certified in comprehensive diagnosis and treatment of mental health conditions. They can prescribe and help manage medications, and work with your teen’s therapist and coach to explore treatment plans.
Your next step

Fill out this intake form before your teen’s first psychiatry session. This will help the psychiatrist better understand what your teen might need, and how to personalize their care. It’ll take about 10 minutes to complete.
If your teen is experiencing an emergency or in need of immediate assistance, text or call the National Suicide Hotline at 988, call 911, or go to your nearest emergency room.
This form should not be used to communicate urgent or emergency matters, as it will not be reviewed right away.
Instructions

Tap the button below to answer a few questions and confirm you have read our policies. If any questions in the form are not relevant to your teen, please indicate that. If you have questions about the form, please reach out to help@headspace.com, or to Member Support through the “Chat” tab.
This form must be filled out at least 24 hours before your teen’s first session.
Review services
These are the service(s) recommended for your teen.
Therapy
components.subtitle:
A state-licensed clinician talks with your teen via video chat. The therapist will help your teen understand patterns and identify ways to create change.
- Therapy sessions are held live over video chat
- Number of sessions covered will vary, depending on your insurance.

components.text: Psychiatry
components.subtitle:
Psychiatrists work with the care team to explore your teen’s diagnosis and treatment plan.
- Psychiatry sessions are held live over video chat.
- Number of sessions covered will vary, depending on your insurance.

components.text: Where would you like your teen's prescriptions to be sent?
Please indicate that you understand your teen will not be prescribed a controlled substance.

Headspace psychiatrists CANNOT prescribe controlled substances including stimulants, benzodiazepines or opiates. These require an in-person visit due to prescribing regulations for telemedicine. However, our clinicians can treat most conditions without these substances.

I consent to my teen’s access to and use of Headspace Care. I selected the services that I would like my teen to access during the referral process.
- Coaching via chats is able to support teens with a wide range of concerns from everyday anxiety and academic issues..
- Clinical services includes therapy and psychiatry services provided via telehealth. Support for clinical diagnoses will require therapy and/or psychiatry services. If I only consented to coaching during the referral process, I may reach out to Member Support in the app to inquire about allowing my teen to access clinical services, and I understand that additional consents may be required in order for my teen to access these services.

I understand text/SMS messages and data rates may apply.
My teen’s treatment records, including coaching transcripts and/or clinical notes, and health care information will be handled in compliance with HIPAA and the laws in the state in which my teen resides.

I understand that Headspace’s policy includes sharing information with a parent or guardian and/or appropriate third parties, including but not limited to if a teen is:
- Engaging in self-harm (e.g. cutting, burning, or hitting themselves)
- Experiencing active suicidal ideation (e.g. thoughts of killing themselves, accompanied by a plan or intent)
- Experiencing active homicidal ideation or intent to inflict serious bodily harm on others (e.g. thoughts of harming others, accompanied by a plan or intent)
- Exhibiting signs of grave disability, such as psychosis or mania
- Engaging in substance use that is of concern

I understand that there are some situations in which a provider is legally obligated to take action to protect my teen or others from harm, even if they have to reveal some information about my teen’s treatment.
