components.text: Help us learn a little more about your teen

Before your teen’s first coaching, therapy, or psychiatry session, please fill out the consent and intake form on the next few screens. To give consent, you must be your teen’s legal parent or guardian. Answering a few questions will help us better understand what your teen needs help with. It’ll take about 15 minutes to complete.
If your teen is experiencing an emergency or in need of immediate assistance, text or call the National Suicide Hotline at 988, call 911, or go to your nearest emergency room.
This form should not be used to communicate urgent or emergency matters, as it will not be reviewed right away.
Instructions

Tap the button below to answer a few questions and confirm you have read our policies. If any questions in the form are not relevant to your teen, please indicate that. If you have questions about the form, please reach out to caresupport@headspace.com, or to Member Support through the “Chat” tab.
This form must be filled out at least 24 hours before your teen’s first session.
Which Headspace Care services would you like your teen to access?
Select all care services you consent to

options.name: Coaching only
options.detail: A coach guides your teen through challenging emotions. Sessions with coaches take place via text chat in the app.

options.name: Coaching & Therapy
options.detail: If needed, a coach can refer your teen to a therapist: a state-licensed clinician who helps your teen understand patterns in their life and find ways to create change. Sessions with therapists take place via video chat.

options.name: Coaching, Therapy & Psychiatry
options.detail: Psychiatrists can prescribe and help manage medications, and work with your teen’s therapist and coach to explore their diagnosis and treatment plan. Sessions with psychiatrists take place via video chat.

components.text: Headspace Care teen  coaching, therapy,  & psychiatry consent
**About the intake form**

Before your teen’s first therapy or psychiatry session, please fill out the consent and intake form on the next few screens. The information you provide will help the coach, therapist, or psychiatrist better understand your teen and provide personalized care. It will take about 15 minutes to complete.

**If your teen is experiencing an emergency or in need of immediate assistance, text or call the National Suicide Hotline at 988. Or, call 911 or go to your nearest emergency room.** This form should not be used to communicate urgent or emergency matters, as it will not be immediately reviewed.
**Instructions**

Tap the button below to answer a few questions and confirm you have read our policies. If any questions in the form are not relevant to your teen, please indicate that. If you have questions about the form, please reach out to caresupport@headspace.com or to a Member Support specialist through the “Chat” tab.
**This form must be filled out at least 24 hours before your teen’s first session.**
Which Headspace Care services would you like your teen to have access to?
**Coaching** takes place via text. A coach guides your teen through challenging emotions, available 24/7.
**Therapy** with a state-licensed clinician takes place via video chat. A therapist helps your teen understand patterns and identify ways to create change.
**Psychiatry** can be added to therapy if the therapist, teen, and guardian agree that it’s needed. Psychiatrists work with the care team to explore your teen’s diagnosis and treatment plan.

options.name: I do not consent to coaching, therapy or psychiatry

components.text: Please review and agree to our Headspace Care Teen Coaching policies:

I have read and understand the parent/guardian overview of Headspace Care Teen Care, which includes the following:
- I am referring my teen to Headspace Care Teen Coaching. For Headspace Care Teen Therapy I may reach out to Member Support in the app to inquire about these services for my teen.
- Headspace Care is able to support teens with a wide range of concerns from anxiety, academic issues, to managing diagnoses like Major Depressive Disorder, Generalized Anxiety Disorder, and Obsessive Compulsive Disorder.
- Headspace Care is not able to provide services for conditions which require close medical monitoring, in-person care, a high degree of specialization, or prescribe stimulant medication often used in the treatment of ADHD.
- I may talk with my teen directly to understand how they’re feeling, and Headspace Care will also provide a weekly summary update with my teen’s usage of services, including dates that my teen engaged w/ the Headspace Care care team.
- I may contact my teen’s Coach and/or Clinician through in-app chat with Member Support.
- I authorize Headspace Care to send email and text/SMS messages to invite my teen to enroll, send service reminders, and encourage my teen to utilize Headspace Care services.
- My teen’s treatment records, including coaching transcripts and/or clinical notes, will be handled in compliance with HIPAA and the laws in the state in which my teen resides.

- I understand Headspace Care’s care policy includes sharing the following information with a parent or guardian when a teen is:
1 - Engaging in self-harm (e.g., cutting, burning, or hitting themselves)
2 - Experiencing active suicidal ideation (e.g., thoughts of killing themselves, accompanied by a plan or intent)
3 - Experiencing active homicidal ideation or intent to inflict serious bodily harm on others (e.g., thoughts of harming others, accompanied by a plan or intent)
- I understand that if my teen needs immediate assistance or is in danger, or harming themselves or others, I will call 911 or the National Suicide Lifeline (988), for immediate assistance.

Stress Check-in
Every month, we'll ask you a few questions about how you're feeling.

We use a science backed survey called the Perceived Stress Scale (PSS). It's the most widely used tool for measuring perception of stress, but it's not a rigid analysis. Just think of it as a benchmark for how you've been feeling.
You'll be able to see how your stress levels change over time, which can help you notice what's working, and when you might want to try something new.

Practice Cognitive Reframing
Here's what you can expect to learn from today's activity:

items: Understand when you can use Cognitive Reframing.
Get practice reframing situations.

components.text: Cognitive Reframing is a technique for revising the stories you tell yourself. It's a way to create new, more realistic thoughts to replace the ones that make you feel awful.
Here's when to use Cognitive Reframing:

items: When you notice yourself worrying.
When you're having a negative thought that you just can't shake.
When you find yourself having many different negative thoughts, spiraling from one to the next.
When you're procrastinating on a task due to negative thoughts or excuses.

components.text: You can do this anywhere on your own, or use this audio-guided technique.
Your Worry
Grab your headphones and let's get to it.
Please write what you are stressed out about on a piece of paper.
Your Automatic Thought:
What is your automatic thought within this worry? Be as concrete and specific as possible.
Please write it down on a piece of paper.
The Logical Error
What is the main logical error in your automatic thought?
Catastrophizing
You’re likely anticipating the worst despite low probabilities. But you can’t take our word that the probabilities are low–you need to prove this by collecting evidence.
Look at what you wrote for your automatic thought previously.
How likely is it that your thought will actually happen?
Black and white thinking
People and situations are complex, so your challenge is to see and understand the shades of gray that make them complex.
First, how much do you believe your automatic thought?

Thinking in percentages can be a concrete way to see the complexities of a situation. If you’re angry with someone, for example, you might think to yourself: “So-and-so is self-centered.” But consider the percentage. Perhaps so-and-so is self-centered 60% of the time, but generous 40% of the time.
Overgeneralization
A broad, sweeping generalization based on a single piece of data is not generally true. Or at least, you don’t yet know if it’s true.

Look for evidence for and against your statement. Then, try to think about the situation with more flexibility. Replacing words like “never, always, all, none, everyone, no one” with “sometime, some, and some people.”
Look at what you wrote for your automatic thought previously.
First, how much do you believe your automatic thought?
Mind reading
You’re making assumptions about someone’s thoughts or feelings.
Treat your statement as a hypothesis. Are there other possible explanations for the person’s behavior?

For example, if someone didn’t say hello back to you, what else could be going on? Maybe she’s upset about something that has nothing to do with you. Maybe she’s concentrating on something else. Maybe she didn’t hear you.
There are usually countless explanations for someone else’s actions, and it won’t help to assume you know the right one. If you really want to know, try asking the person directly.
Look at what you wrote for your automatic thought previously
First, how much do you believe your automatic thought?
Fortune telling
Chances are that your predictions about the future won’t be accurate–at least they won’t be entirely accurate.
Look at what you wrote for your automatic thought previously.
How likely is it that your thought will actually happen?
Personalization
Chances are that your predictions about the future won’t be accurate–at least they won’t be entirely accurate.
Personalization is the tendency to relate everything around you to yourself–like blaming yourself for something you couldn’t have actually caused, or comparing yourself to others.
First, how much do you believe your automatic thought?
Filtering
You're filtering out details from the situation, and missing the positive.
Look at what you wrote for your automatic thought previously.
First, how much do you believe your automatic thought?
To conquer filtering, you can deliberately shift your focus -- look for more positive information from the environment.
Emotional reasoning
Feelings don’t always tell you the truth about the situation you’re in.
Look at what you wrote for your automatic thought previously.
Feelings don’t always tell you the truth about the situation you’re in.

Emotions tend to follow thoughts, but sometimes you notice your feelings before your thoughts, and you search for thoughts to explain or validate your feelings. In that case, your thoughts are a product of your feelings rather than a result of logical, careful reasoning.
First, how much do you believe your automatic thought?
Be skeptical. Is your feeling based on factual evidence, or is it based on opinion?
If you’re not sure whether something or someone actually relates to you in a meaningful way, ask a friend or someone you trust to give you a different perspective.
Gather evidence

items: What evidence supports this thought?
What evidence doesn’t support this thought?
What are some other possibilities?

components.text: Write a more balanced sentence that reframes your worry given the evidence.
Please write your responses down on a piece of paper.
Re-evaluate your automatic thought.
After considering the evidence. How much do you believe your original automatic thought will happen?
Nice work
When you catch yourself thinking in black and white, keep looking for shades of gray.
Try to write a balanced statement about your worry. Write for 30 seconds on a piece of paper.

Tell us why you didn't like cognitive reframing.
Sometimes it takes a few tries to really get it.

options.name: Have you had any difficulty making cognitive reframing work for you?

components.text: A little more motivation for you.
When you start to master cognitive reframing, it helps reduce your stress in the moment. But what you might not know is that research has found it also keeps your stress low for up to 24 hours.
Back in 2012, researchers wanted to test the lasting effects of cognitive reframing.
To do this, they showed a group of research participants photos of snakes or spiders, paired with occasional mild electric shocks, training the participants to associate the images with pain.
So the researchers conditioned the participants to have a fear response to the images. They also measured the participants' stress levels throughout the process.
After this initial conditioning, participants were divided into two groups: one received cognitive reframing training, and the other (the control group) received no follow-up treatment.

A day later, the participants were invited back to the lab to repeat the conditioning experiment: viewing images of snakes and spiders while receiving occasional electric shocks. This time around, the group that had completed cognitive reframing training had a significantly lower stress response than the control group, even though the two groups had nearly identical stress responses the day before.
The takeaway is this: cognitive reframing is scientifically proven to work, and not just for a moment. The benefits of cognitive reframing last through the whole day (if not longer).

So as you return to your cognitive reframing practice this time around, try to notice how you feel throughout the day when you encounter or think about the situation you're reframing. You'll likely find that the relief is still there.
Alright, not a problem.
Is there any particular reason you haven't tried cognitive reframing?
Is there any particular reason you had difficulty with it?

components.text: Fair enough
You may not have a real reason why you haven't tried it, but we have plenty of good reasons why you should.
Remember that the point of cognitive reframing is to manage your stress by mastering your own thoughts.
We understand that you won't be able to whip out your phone to reframe your thoughts whenever you have them, forever and ever. That's not a sustainable habit.
And that's not the habit we're trying to build. What we are trying to build is muscle memory.
Our guided technique will help make this whole cognitive reframing process second-nature to you.

Every time you practice identifying your automatic thoughts in the guided technique, you'll start to become more and more aware of your automatic thoughts as you go about your day. As you encounter different logical errors in your guided technique, you'll be able to recognize those logical errors in more and more of your thinking patterns.

Eventually, the steps of cognitive reframing will flow more naturally for you. Instead of six or eight individual steps, the whole process will feel like one. And you won't need the guided technique anymore.

But cognitive reframing doesn't come naturally to you just yet. So you'll have to put in some time and effort to really change how you understand and interpret your own thoughts. Just remember that it's time well-spent. Once you have it mastered, it's a stress-reduction strategy you'll be able to do anywhere, anytime.
You'll have another chance to give it a try today.
That's totally understandable – you're a busy person.

components.text: Believe it or not, your procrastination might be a sign of stress.
Avoiding things that make you uncomfortable or nervous is a telltale sign of stress. We're not saying this is definitely the case for you right now, but it's worth considering.
Why have you been procrastinating?

If it's because you're worried the technique won't work or you won't do it correctly, or if it's because it seems too time-consuming, or if it all seems too uncertain or unknown to you, it's very possible your procrastination is stress-related.
If you think that's the case, you may want to use your procrastination-thinking about this very technique as your automatic thought when you take the leap and try cognitive reframing today.

That might mean you use an automatic thought like, "If this technique doesn't work for me, I'm hopeless." Then you'll use the guided cognitive reframing process to create a new, more reasonable thought to replace the original one.

If your procrastination isn't stress-related, that's totally normal too. You may just not feel like it, or you might feel like you have more important things to get done. Today's your chance to give it a try.

components.text: Cognitive Reframing does take a little while at first, especially if you're using our version with audio guidance. If you understand cognitive reframing already, you may want to try pausing or muting audio guidance and completing the practice at your own pace.

The good news is that the time you spend working your way through the cognitive reframing technique is temporary. If you practice cognitive reframing enough, it becomes second nature–it won't take you any time at all.

You're not off the hook from your cognitive reframing practice today, but if you're looking for a quicker practice to try on your own, this is a good one that gets at the heart of cognitive reframing.
As soon as you notice yourself having a negative thought, challenge yourself to think of 5 positives related to your negative statement.
Say you walk into a room full of new people and your first thought is "I'm not going to like anyone here." In this situation, you might say think these positives:

items: That woman looks very friendly
I'm hungry and that food looks great
My friend said he might show up later
I'm here because so-and-so invited me and I like so-and-so
It's really nice to be around other people and not at home by myself

components.text: And there it is, your statement, reframed. You can see 5 new possibilities for how the evening will turn out. It's not quite the same as the real thing, but if you're feeling pressed for time, it's a decent replacement.
Yeah, it is complicated.

items: It felt too complicated

components.text: Let’s try to boil cognitive reframing down to a few simple steps:

items: Identify the automatic thought
Find the logical error in your automatic thought
Consider the evidence for and against your automatic thought
Create a new, more balanced statement to replace your automatic thought

components.text: To put it even more simply, cognitive reframing is the process of seeing your own thoughts from a new perspective.
If you don't want to walk through the whole cognitive reframing technique, try thinking of someone whose opinion you trust–someone you consider reasonable and at least a little bit optimistic.
How would that person view the situation you're in? What would they say to the automatic thought you're having?
Cognitive reframing can really be that simple. But you'll still go through the full, guided technique today. Just to get the hang of it.
You're definitely not alone.
You said:

items: I did not believe my new thought.

components.text: Ah, yes. This is one of the most common obstacles to mastering cognitive reframing, so you're in good company, stress.

No matter how much evidence you have against it, your automatic thought still feels right. No matter what we tell you about cognitive reframing's effectiveness, you feel like the exception to the rule. You know your thoughts are right because they feel so right.
If this is your experience, it means you’re struggling to let your rational mind (the one guided by evidence) take over your emotional mind (the one guided by feelings and intuition).

Forgive us for the metaphor, but consider the relationship between your rational and emotional mind to be like an elephant and a human rider. The elephant is your emotional mind, and the rider is your rational mind. The rider can't control the elephant with force–the elephant is much bigger and stronger. Instead, the elephant needs time to learn to trust the rider.

For you, this means that you may need to give yourself permission to stop trusting your emotional mind and start trusting the reframing process. It may take some time to see that your new, reframed thoughts are trustworthy. But the first step is to be open to trusting them.
Oh, but you will (if you practice it now).
You said:

items: I won't remember to do it in real life.

components.text: Our audio guided technique has a bunch of steps that might lead you to believe that whole process takes a bunch of time. And for now, you're right. It does take some time and effort to walk through the whole process whenever you catch yourself with a negative automatic thought.
But it's not like you'll have to do this forever.

But cognitive reframing doesn't come naturally to you just yet. So you'll have to put in some time and effort to really change how you understand and interpret your own thoughts. items: I just don't get the point

components.text: You've got these negative automatic thoughts. When you don't notice these automatic thoughts happening, you tend to believe them. And since you think they're true, you get stressed. The problem is that these automatic thoughts aren't true–they're usually just interpretations of a situation, and they don't take into account all the facts of the situation you're in. They're assumptions. These assumptions are based on logical errors, which are the specific ways your mind mis-interprets information.
Cognitive reframing is the process we use to create new, more reasonable thoughts that can replace the original automatic thought.
At its most simple, the process works like this:

items: Identify the automatic thought
Find the logical error in your automatic thought
Consider the evidence for and against your automatic thought
Create a new, more balanced statement to replace your automatic thought

components.text: Our guided cognitive reframing technique takes you through these steps, one by one. It takes some time and effort, but over time, this process will become second-nature to you. What was once six or eight guided steps will become one big step that you can do on your own.
The point of cognitive reframing is to master the thoughts that cause you discomfort–to cut off the thoughts-feelings-behaviors cycle that keeps you stuck feeling stressed.
Tell us why you didn't like cognitive reframing.
Now's the time to send your coach a message and let them know what you didn't like about cognitive reframing. Once you've done that, you can continue on ahead.
Automatic Thoughts

Cognitive reframing is a technique for challenging the logic of your automatic thoughts and creating new, more realistic thoughts to consider. Cognitive reframing can help you decrease your stress, have more control over your reactions, and ease your anxiety.
In this activity, you’ll:

items: See an example of cognitive reframing.
Learn how and why reframing your thoughts works.
Get some helpful advice before giving it a try for yourself.

components.text: Let’s start with a hypothetical situation…

Let’s say you’re meeting a friend for lunch. The two of you have lunch together nearly every Wednesday and you always text each other on Monday to confirm. You text your friend, as usual, but this time she doesn’t get back to you until late Tuesday. Then, on Wednesday, she’s over fifteen minutes late and doesn’t say anything about it. You eat lunch together, but it feels like she’s distracted, like her attention isn’t really on you and your lunch together. You’re annoyed that she took so long to text you back and then on top of that, she was late to lunch. You’re pretty sure she can tell you’re annoyed. You leave the lunch feeling not sure you want to keep having these Wednesday lunches.
The Stories We Tell Ourselves

There are a couple of stories you could tell yourself about your friend and her behavior. One story is related to your friendship. In this story, your friend doesn’t value you or your time. She didn’t text you back in a timely manner because she takes your friendship for granted. She knows you’ll always be there for her and so she’s taking advantage of that fact. Then, she was late for lunch for the same reason. She doesn’t value your time. And she was distracted at lunch because maybe she doesn’t even like you any more. She finds you boring and is just doing these lunches out of a sense of obligation. It’s no wonder when you tell yourself this story that you’d start questioning your friendship.

But there’s a different story you could tell yourself. In this story, your friend is dealing with a lot of things. In fact, she told you at lunch that she’s worried about her mom. She thinks her mom might be starting to struggle with dementia. On top of that, she’s seen some coworkers laid off recently and she’s worried about her job. In this story, you realize your friend said she took her mother to the doctor on Monday, which might be why she wasn’t able to get back to you until Tuesday. And, when you think about it, you realize that she might be worried about losing her job and so she might be trying to take shorter lunches, which might explain why she was late. While it’s still true that she could have been more sensitive to how her behavior affects you, when you tell yourself this story, you can be a little more forgiving of your friend’s rudeness, and you may even feel compassion for what she’s going through.
Why Stories and Automatic Thoughts Matter

We all tell ourselves stories about our lives. Stories help us make sense of what’s going on with ourselves and other people. They help us see patterns, and can boost our opinion of ourselves and others. It’s important to keep in mind that these stories can be based on facts, but they can also be based on fiction.

Cognitive reframing is a technique that asks you to question the stories that you tell yourself. It asks you to keep track of your thoughts and to check them for accuracy, to see if there’s another way to tell the story. It asks you to see if there are positives or even just another slant to the story that you may have missed when you told it to yourself the first time.

In other words, cognitive reframing asks you to analyze the evidence for and against your automatic thoughts and then it asks you to generate a more balanced explanation, to tell yourself a different and likely more accurate story based on the evidence you’ve gathered.
Some Perspective

To be clear, you won’t always be able to convince yourself entirely of your new, more balanced story. But you will be able to loosen your grip on the automatic thoughts that cause you stress. You’ll start to see new possibilities and new sides, and feel more in control of your reactions.

You are in charge of the stories you tell yourself. No one else is. And that’s freeing. Because just a little bit of doubt about the truth of your automatic thoughts is all you really need to start being able to ease your anxiety. Once you see that you’re able to change your thinking, you can start to approach your life and your problems with more feelings of control.
Thoughts: Fact or Opinion?
Here's what you can expect to take away from today's activity:

items: Learn how to distinguish between fact and opinion as you process thoughts.
See examples of how to avoid treating opinions as facts.

components.text: Scientific Attitude
This activity is about taking in all of the evidence and trying to figure out the truth. Here's what that means, with some examples to drive it all home.
Distinguish between fact and opinion.

items.body: Fearing elevators is a fact; believing that elevators cause fear is an opinion.

components.text: Accept facts even if they directly contradict your feelings. That means you may have to work on changing your feelings rather than twisting facts to fit your feelings.

items.body: Accepting that your present frustration may be because you didn’t get your way, even though you don’t like thinking of yourself as being demanding or needy.

components.text: Don't jump to conclusions based on too little evidence, or evidence from someone else's life.

items.body: Jumping to conclusions might sound something like this: “My marriage conflicts cause my stress. My friend got over her stress when she got divorced.

components.text: Be comfortable with uncertainty when you don't have the answer. Be willing to tell yourself that you don’t know.

items.body: I don’t know why I lose my temper all the time, but I think it is because I do more than my share of work around the house.”

components.text: Don't accept your own theories too soon, or with too much certainty. Know that every theory can change in the face of new evidence. Be willing to accept new evidence.

items.body: “The reason I have never given a speech in public is because I know I’ll always do a terrible job.”

components.text: At the same time, don't reject any theory too soon.

items.body: It can’t be my thoughts causing problems because I don’t remember thinking anything.” This theory, too, is subject to change on the basis of evidence.

components.text: Notice when you search for evidence to confirm your own theories. Then search for evidence against it.

items.body: Find evidence to support the idea that emotions can cause attitudes, as well as the view that attitudes can cause emotions.

components.text: If it's not productive or possible to test your theory, abandon your theory.

items.body: It may not be possible to test such hypotheses as, “If I only had more money, I would be happier,” or productive to test, “Stress is caused by my job so I should quit.”

components.text: Cognitive Reframing Deep Dive

One of the biggest challenges people face when learning how cognitive reframing can help with automatic thoughts and logical errors, is trusting in the reframing process. This activity card will help explain why cognitive reframing can be so difficult.

It’s common to feel that regardless of how much evidence you have to explain away your automatic thought logically, it still feels right and true. Perhaps you feel like reframing might work for other people’s thoughts, but yours is the exception to the rule. You know your thoughts are right because they feel right.
It’s difficult to let your rational mind, which uses logic and evidence, guide your emotional mind, which relies on feelings and intuition.

Here’s another way to think about it: Imagine your rational mind is an elephant and your emotional mind is a person riding the elephant. Because the elephant is much bigger and stronger than the person, the person won’t be able to control the elephant with force. Instead, the person needs to gain the elephant’s trust in order to get it to move.

In other words, in order to reframe your automatic thoughts, you may need to give yourself permission to trust your rational mind and the reframing process. It may take some time to trust your new reframed thoughts, but the first step is being open to trusting them.
Keep this in mind as you practice cognitive reframing.
Why Cognitive Reframing is Useful

Cognitive reframing is a technique that helps challenge our automatic thoughts and logical errors. It’s a way to help us think clearly and objectively when automatic thoughts make it difficult to do so. But, why do we have automatic thoughts and make logical errors in the first place? Read on for an explanation.
Our brains have a natural way of making decisions quickly using shortcuts.
These shortcuts are called heuristics. Heuristics often rely on previous experience to help us make decisions, often without complete information.
Most of the time, heuristics are really helpful

For example, let’s say you’re in the pasta aisle trying to pick out a new type of pasta. You choose a brand that you’ve had before because you’ve liked that brand in the past. You don’t need to read the ingredients list. You’re still likely to end up with a pasta that you enjoy. That’s your brain using heuristics to make a decision.
But, heuristics can also lead us to make decisions that are not helpful

For example, you see a news story that there’s been an increase in shark attacks in California. Then, while on vacation in Florida you refuse to get in the water. Or, after a news story about a plane crash, you’d rather take a car than fly, even though getting in a car puts you at higher risk of an accident than a plane. These logical errors are examples of when heuristics are not helpful.
When your mind makes these unhelpful judgments or decisions with incomplete information cognitive reframing can help.
Cognitive reframing forces your brain to go through the logical decision making process that it originally skipped.
Identifying Automatic Thoughts

You have automatic thoughts all the time, but you probably don’t notice them because they’re so automatic. Your automatic thoughts are the assumptions you make throughout your day about a variety of situations. They affect how you feel from one moment to the next, and how you feel about yourself in general. When you make negative assumptions about yourself and the world, you feel bad. And of course, when you make positive assumptions, you can feel better.
In this activity you’ll:

items: Learn about the assumptions you make every day.
Identify your automatic thoughts in order to see your world from a new perspective so you can prevent your unhelpful automatic thoughts.

components.text: The good news is that you can change the way you think, which means that you can change the way you feel. That’s why it’s important to start noticing and identifying your automatic thoughts. Let’s get started.
Choose one of these automatic thoughts that you've had.

options.name: That person must not like me

components.text: Imagine
You’ve applied for a new job. You’ve written your cover letter, prepared your resume, interviewed with the manager, and now you’re waiting.

You’re cautiously anticipating all the awesome ways your life will change if you’re offered the job. You’ll have co-workers you like, better hours, less time commuting. You’ve got your phone in your hand at all times in case they call.
And then the call comes. With a deep breath, you answer your phone. From the tone of the manager’s voice, you can tell right away that it’s not the news you wanted.
You didn’t get the job.
That’s when that tiny voice in your head makes its entrance.

items: “My life is a mess.”

components.text: The voice in your head loves to make assumptions.

It assumes that your life is a mess because you didn’t get the job you applied for. It could have instead reasonably assumed that your life is better off without that job, because if it was the right match for you, you would have been offered it.
But, it used one brief experience to make generalizations about the state of your life. And it made you feel awful.
That’s why your automatic thoughts are worth noticing. They can affect how you feel, but if you change your automatic thoughts, you have the power to change how you feel.
You’re supposed to have coffee with an old friend.
Actually, she was supposed to show up for coffee 20 minutes ago, but she’s nowhere to be found.
You check your phone for a text message every couple of minutes, but no updates. You’re getting irritated and stressed.
That’s when the voice in your head makes its entrance:

items: “She must not like me.”

components.text: The voice in your head loves to make assumptions.

It assumes that your friend is late because she doesn’t respect you or care about you enough to be on time. It could have instead reasonably assumed that your friend was late because she was stuck in traffic, had a family emergency, or got distracted.
But, your automatic thoughts took one brief experience and made generalizations about your worth as a friend and your friend’s motivations. Your automatic thoughts made you feel awful.
That’s why your automatic thoughts are worth noticing. They can affect how you feel, but if you change your automatic thoughts, you have the power to change how you feel.
You’re studying at a coffee shop and you spot a cute stranger.
You smile. You make eye contact. You name the puppy you’ll raise together.
Then your stranger gets up and leaves, without even so much as a “Hello“. That’s when that tiny voice in your head makes its entrance.

items: “I’ll never find someone.”

components.text: The voice in your head loves to make assumptions.

It assumes that your stranger left the coffee shop because of you, or at least because they weren’t interested enough in you. It could have instead reasonably assumed that your stranger had an appointment to go to.
But, your automatic thoughts used one brief experience to make huge generalizations about your worth and your attractiveness and it made you feel awful.
That’s why your automatic thoughts are worth noticing. They can affect how you feel, but if you change your automatic thoughts, you have the power to change how you feel."
You’ve applied for a new job. You’ve written your cover letter, prepared your resume, interviewed with the manager, and now you’re waiting.

You’re cautiously anticipating all the awesome ways your life will change if you’re offered the job. You’ll have co-workers you like, better hours, less time commuting. You’ve got your phone in your hand at all times in case they call.
And then the call comes. With a deep breath, you answer your phone. From the tone of the manager’s voice, you can tell right away that it’s not the news you wanted.
You didn’t get the job.
That’s when that tiny voice in your head makes its entrance.

items: “I’m a failure.”

components.text: The voice in your head loves to make assumptions.

It assumes that the reason you didn’t get the job was your fault—that it had to do with your own personal failing. Maybe it even reminds you of all the other jobs you haven’t been offered in the past. It could have instead reasonably assumed that you didn’t get the job because there was another candidate with the perfect experience, or because the manager changed the job description during the hiring process.
Instead, your automatic thoughts used one brief experience to make huge generalizations about your worth and you ended up feeling awful.
That’s why your automatic thoughts are worth noticing. They can affect how you feel, but if you change your automatic thoughts, you have the power to change how you feel.
You’re on the phone with a friend, and you’re telling her about your terrible day.

You’ve just told her everything: how much traffic there was in the morning, how you spilled water on your keyboard before lunch, how you had an argument with a coworker, and how you forgot about dinner plans at the end of the day. Now you’re waiting for her to respond.sssss
“Oh,” she says. “That’s too bad.” Then she changes the subject.
That’s when the voice in your head makes its entrance:

items: “No one understands me.”

components.text: The voice in your head loves to make assumptions.
It assumes that your friend gave you a short reply because she doesn’t understand why you’re so upset about your day.

Your automatic thoughts could have instead reasonably assumed that your friend was short with you because she was distracted by something on her end of the phone, or because she also had a bad day and wanted to talk about something more upbeat.
Instead, your automatic thoughts used one brief experience to make huge generalizations about your social life.
That’s why your automatic thoughts are worth noticing. They can affect how you feel, but if you change your automatic thoughts, you have the power to change how you feel.
Tracking Automatic Thoughts
Here’s a quick way to notice and keep track of your automatic thoughts. Start by identifying three things:

items: The emotion
The why
The ”what-it-means”

components.text: The “what-it-means” is key here. That’s your automatic thought.

It’s a fact that you’re feeling sad, and it’s a fact that your friend is late. But it’s an assumption that your friend doesn’t care about having dinner. It’s an assumption you’ve made based on what you think your friend’s behavior means.
When you track your automatic thoughts, remember to track the what-it-means instead of the whys.
Identifying automatic thoughts is just the first step in a longer process, so by practicing this part, you’ll be on your way to changing them.
Observing Your Thoughts?
Cognitive defusion is the process of observing thoughts for what they are -- just thoughts. Cognitive defusion lets you see your thoughts from a new perspective and helps make them less stressful.
This activity card will teach you:

items: what cognitive defusion is.
how to separate yourself from your thoughts.
to consider your thoughts in new ways that can reduce your stress.

components.text: Write down a recent thought that has caused you stress or anxiety. E.g My boss hates me
How stressful is this thought?
Cognitive defusion may seem challenging, but we’ll walk you through it. It takes a little bit of concentration, so try to find a quiet and comfortable place where you can focus.
Cognitive Defusion
First, choose a technique to try. (You'll have a chance to do them all).
Visualization
Choose a few words to describe how this thought feels. E.g. painful, sharp
Now, consider the words you used to describe your thought.
Try to imagine an object that has some of the same characteristics.
For example, if you described your thought as 'sharp,' then you might imagine a needle. Or, if you said 'overwhelming,' you might imagine a tidal wave.
What is an object that shares some of the same characteristics as how your thought feels to you?  E.g. a jagged rock.
Leave the Object Behind
Now, for the visualization part.
Imagine how you, someone else, or a force of nature could make the object less threatening.
For example, if you chose a jagged rock, you could imagine giving it to a professional baseball pitcher who then throws it far into the middle of a lake.
Or, let’s say you chose a tidal wave. You could visualize the wave in a bathtub where you could pull out the stopper and watch it go down the drain.
Take a moment to imagine how the object can be less threatening.
E.g. “I imagine a needle being lost in a football-sized field of haystacks.” Next time you experience this automatic thought, try the visualization you just came up with.
Now What
Make a plan
Sometimes when we are having a stressful thought, it can feel liberating to accept the possibility that the thought is true, and then create a plan of action to help diminish the thought.
This thought may or may not be completely true. But let’s pretend for a moment that it is. How do you move forward?
This is your time and space to make a plan for what to do about your thought.
We recommend taking five or more minutes to make a plan for how to move forward. (Setting a timer can be helpful). Go ahead and write down your plan now.
Order in the Court
Pretend your stressful thought is on trial and the jury must determine if the thought is true (innocent) or false (guilty).
Here’s the catch: You must argue for both sides -- the prosecution and the defense -- that it’s true and false.
First, consider a defense for your thought, stating the reasons it is true:
Why is your thought true?
Now, write down the possible reasons your thought is false. This can be more difficult.
How or why might your thought be false?
The Prosecution
So, what's the verdict? Is your thought guilty (false) or innocent (true)?
Here’s the good news. Unlike a real court, the verdict is not what’s important. What is important is considering all the evidence before deciding whether a thought is true.
Mental Appreciation

Our brains are very good at thinking and worrying about all of the worst possible outcomes. That’s our natural evolutionarily flight-or-fight reaction that protects us from possible harm. By worrying, our brains are just trying to help.
Given that, can you express gratitude to your brain? Can you write your brain a thank you note?
The first step is to recognize the good intention behind your stressful thought.
What was the good, or protective intention behind this thought?
E.g.: My automatic thought was “My boyfriend is going to break up with me“, so the good intention might be that my brain is trying to prepare me so that my heart won't get broken.
The Good Intention
So now, let's say thanks.
Write a short note to your brain, thanking it for its good intentions.
Now, give your brain a gentle suggestion about what you’d like it to do the next time you feel stressed or worried.
What would you ask your brain to do differently next time to create less stress?
Appreciating the way your mind works is a first step toward realizing how capable it is. Once you understand how amazing it is, you can start to realize how it can change and grow for the better.
You've just learned a new technique! Let's check in again:
Your Current Stress Level
How stressed are you feeling right now?

decreased.title: Your stress level decreased.
decreased.body: This technique helped lower your stress level. Sometimes thinking through solutions can help reduce anxiety or stress in the moment. Even better is that this technique is more about the long-term than the short-term. Doing this technique now will help you prepare for how to cope with your stress in the future.

same.title: Your stress level stayed the same.
same.body: Your stress stayed the same before and after this technique. Sometimes the simple act of coming up with solutions can help reduce anxiety or stress in the moment. But this technique is more about the long-term than the short-term.

increased.title: Your stress level increased.
increased.body: Although your stress level increased, stick with it. Sometimes cognitive defusion brings up stressful thoughts or feelings. The technique is more about reducing your stress for the long-term rather than right now.

components.text: Give Your Mind a Break

When your past is bothering you, getting your mind off of it can be tough. Rehashing negative thoughts over and over in your head can be unpleasant and counterproductive—and sometimes can lead to chronic depression. Let's learn a few tricks to help get your mind off unproductive thinking behaviors.
When your beautiful mind is working against you.
We're going to take a look at some distraction techniques that can break us out of our thoughts and help us get out of our heads.
They help interrupt the repetitive cycles of fear or negative thinking, and especially helpful if past traumas or fears overtake you.
Freeing your mind
If you find your mind cycling around regretful, unproductive thoughts about the past, try these distraction strategies:

items: Work on a puzzle like a crossword or jigsaw
Count the number of leaves on a plant, or petals on a flower
Name everything you see that's blue
List the sounds you hear (cars driving by, leaves rustling on trees, etc...)
If you're sitting, pay attention to how your feet feel on the floor and how the chair supports your back
Take a shower and note the water flowing over you
Put music and try to hear each instrument separately

components.text: If your thinking drifts back to the past, that's okay. Note it, then refocus on a present activity.
It's ok to get distracted
Our minds can ruminate (rehashing negative thoughts over and over again) on unhelpful or unproductive thinking patterns. We've all been there - it's normal.
Using a few of the strategies here can help distract your mind from the constant rumination.
Remember, if your thinking drifts back to ruminating thoughts, it's okay. Take note and then regain your focus on your activity.
Investigate Your Fears
Battle anxiety by questioning the likelihood of your fears.

When you're feeling worried or anxious, it's common to overestimate the likelihood of events that you fear. This type of fear or worry has the tendency to overwhelm us, but a reality check often reveals these fears are scarier in theory than they are in real life.
Most things you worry about won't actually happen

Once you start examining your anxious or worried thoughts, you’ll probably be surprised by how much of your thinking is inaccurate, exaggerated, or focused on the negatives of the situation. You might, for example, be terrified of giving presentation to your company, or getting an injection for health reasons.
Hold those fears up to the light and try to challenge them. Challenging exaggerated or fearful thoughts helps you see things from a different, more balanced perspective.
This can reduce anxiety and worry and help you feel better in your decision making.
Write your cares away

Keeping a journal helps you establish order when your world feels like it’s in chaos. It helps you get to know yourself by revealing your innermost fears, thoughts, and feelings. Look at your writing time as personal relaxation time, a time when you de-stress and wind down. Look forward to your journaling time, and know that you're doing something good for your mind and body.
Challenging Your Automatic Thoughts
Here's what you can expect to take away from today's activity:

items: Learn about how your brain might jump to conclusions.
Learn to catch errors in logic before you go down a path of conclusions.

components.text: Challenging automatic thoughts

Now that you have a sense for what some of your automatic thoughts look like, it’s time to talk about how to challenge them. It’s important to remember that your automatic thoughts are assumptions. Your brain uses all kinds of twisted logic to make these assumptions, which we call logical errors.
These logical errors keep you from seeing all the complexity and possibilities in a situation. Instead, they convince you that your automatic thoughts are the truth.

So the first step to untangling your automatic thoughts is to understand all the possible types of logical errors your brain might be making. Once you can identify these logical errors, it’s much easier to challenge them.

When you’re ready to begin, audio instructions will guide you through the exercise. You don’t have to take any extra time out of your day to practice it–just make it part of your usual meal time routine.
Logical Errors
What is an error in logic? There are  some common techniques your mind uses to interpret situations automatically

items.body: Believing something is a lot worse than it actually is.

items: You can catastrophize the outcome of current situations (thinking that a small mistake at work will get you fired, for example), or you can catastrophize he future (thinking that everything is bound to go wrong for you).

items.body: Perceiving situations only in extremes.

items: After eating a bag of potato chips at lunch, you might think to yourself, “I completely failed my diet.” When thinking in black and white like this, you don’t see the middle ground in situations. You think in absolute extremes instead of perceiving things on a spectrum.

items.body: Viewing a negative event or situation as a never-ending pattern.

items: You might overgeneralize a job rejection to mean that you will always fail. After your significant other breaks up with you, you may feel that you will never find the right partner. Overgeneralization is at fault–it makes you perceive a negative experience as a lifelong pattern.

items.body: Making judgments about how other people think and feel about you.

items: While talking to an acquaintance, you notice that she is looking elsewhere as you are talking to her, so you assume she is bored and wants to get away from you. This is an example of mind reading. Without direct evidence, you assume what others’ intentions are by “reading their minds.”

items.body: Predicting that things will turn out badly before they happen.

items: When fortune telling, you might turn down an invitation to an event because you think that no one would be interested in talking to you anyway. You assume that you already know things will not go well in the future without any evidence to support that assumption.

items.body: Assuming that you (or others) have directly caused something to happen.

items: When personalizing a situation, you mistakenly consider an event to have occurred because you or someone else played a role in it. Personalization makes you feel as though you made something happen even though you may not have had any control over the situation

items.body: Focusing on negative details and filtering out positive details.

items: Filtering causes people to dwell on unhappy experiences and ignore rewarding ones. You might insist that your accomplishments don’t count and overemphasize your failures.

items.body: Believing that what you feel must be true.

items: Emotional reasoning causes you to reach conclusions based on how you feel instead of using logical reasoning. You may feel suspicious because your significant other hasn’t returned your call yet, but you reach this conclusion based on your feelings rather than supporting evidence.

components.text: Find the logical error.
As best you can, choose the cognitive distortion that you think describes each of these automatic thoughts.

options.name: That person must not like me

components.text: Find the logical error.

items.header: That person must not like me

components.text: A few possible answers

Depending on the context of the situation, many of the logical errors we listed may be applicable. Most people consider 'My life is a mess' to be an example of filtering, overgeneralizing, black & white thinking, or catastrophizing.
For example, the individual who says her life is a mess is focusing on negative details and filtering out positive details.
She could also be overgeneralizing: perhaps she has recently been through a negative event and has let herself believe that it is representative of her whole messy life.
Similarly, black & white thinking could lead her to see her situation in only extremes, causing her to feel that her life is a mess rather than seeing it in a more balanced and nuanced light.
Lastly, she could have a tendency to catastrophize–perhaps she made a small mistake and now feels that her whole life is a mess as a result.
Probably Mind Reading
For this one, most people choose mind reading.

Mind reading is just what it sounds like–believing you know what other people are thinking without them having told you. Thinking that someone doesn't like you without them having told you so is a perfect example of mind reading.
Again, it's possible you chose a different logical error that could make sense depending on the context you imagined. Feel free to chat with your coach if you have any questions.
Again, a few possibilities
For the statement, 'I'll never find someone,'' there are a few possible logical errors happening.
The most obvious is fortune telling. The individual who thinks he'll never find someone is looking into an unknown future and thinking something negative will happen when he cannot possibly know.
Catastrophizing may also be at play. This guy might have a tendency to think that everything will always go wrong for him.
Some of the other logical errors–especially black and white thinking and filtering–also make sense here.
And, again, depending on the context you imagined, the other logical errors may make sense.
Nice job
It might be helpful to discuss your thoughts on this topic further with your coach.

In the meantime, keep practicing. For the next few days, you’ll continue tracking your automatic thoughts, but now you’ll also identify the logical error in each thought. We’ll keep your reminder preferences the same unless you choose to change them.
Keep in mind that this is just the first step in challenging your automatic thoughts.
Managing Worry
Did you know worrying can actually be helpful sometimes? While worrying might feel uncomfortable, it can serve a purpose. Worrying can help you figure out a solution to a problem.
This exercise will help you learn:

items: When your worry is helpful and when it’s not.
How to manage your worry when it arises.

components.text: Usually, we think of worry as an unhelpful feeling. We wish we could just turn it off, like flipping a light switch. But sometimes, worry can actually be helpful.

Worry can help us figure out a solution to a problem or fix a situation. Figuring out when worry is helpful or unhelpful is key to managing our worry and has a lot to do with what we can or can't control.

For example, let's say there's a big storm headed towards your home. You're worried you won't be able to get to the grocery store and that your basement will flood. Basically, you're just really worried about this storm.

There are some things you can do to feel better and manage your worry, like buying extra food or moving stuff out of the basement. There are a few elements of this worry, or this situation, that you have some control over. Taking these steps are positive, productive outcomes of worry. Ultimately, this helps you.

But, at the end of the day, the storm's still coming. Who knows how extreme it might be, or what will happen once it hits? There's nothing you can do about the intensity of the storm. And, there aren't any positive outcomes of worrying about this. So, worry can't really help you here. This is out of your control.

So, it pretty much comes down to asking yourself two questions. First, is this worry totally out of my control - am I just spinning my wheels here? Or, do I have some control here? Is there a step I could take that might help me handle this?
Worry is Sticky
While it's helpful to evaluate each worry, and figure out when we have control or not, it might not prevent us from feeling like we're constantly worrying.

Have you ever heard a song you used to really love? When you hear it, suddenly, it’s like you’re back to that time in your life, maybe months or years ago. You may remember where you were living, what you were doing, and who you were with.

Worry works in a similar way. When you worry throughout the day, those worries become attached to the things you’re doing, places you’re going, and situations you’re in. When you do these things, visit these places, or are back in a similar situation at a later date, the same worries come back to you, like the memories you have when you hear that old favorite song. Being reminded of your worries from a day, week, month, or year ago, isn’t all that helpful to you.

Here’s another example. Let’s say you worry when you’re showering in the morning, commuting to work, or scrolling through your Facebook newsfeed. You begin to associate your worries and the act of worrying with these activities or times of the day. It becomes really difficult to stop worrying because these activities are ingrained into your routines. Thus, worrying is ingrained into your routine.
The Worry Tool

As you know, it’s really hard to quit worrying. Has anyone ever told you to just “stop worrying”? Usually, this suggestion doesn’t work. But, that doesn’t mean you can’t better control the amount of time you spend worrying. It turns out that postponing worrying can really help with the total amount of time you spend worrying.

When you worry throughout the day, you attach your worries and the act of worrying to whatever you’re doing. If we’re constantly or frequently worried, then we end up linking most of our routines, days, even our lives, to the act of worrying and to our worries. Since preventing worry completely is a little unrealistic, it helps to dedicate just one place and time of day to worry for 30 minutes. If you notice yourself worrying about something at another time or place, you postpone the worry. One technique, called the “The Worry Tool” helps you have a set, specific place and time to worry about something later. This time and place is now the only one you’ll connect your worries with. After a lot of practice, you’ll be able to postpone worrying.
Some Things To Keep In Mind

Using the Worry Tool might not be easy. It may seem counterintuitive to just sit and process your worries for 30 minutes each day. But, because you have a set time and place for worry, you don’t need to worry at other times during the day. You prevent yourself from associating worry with the positive, or just the regular, activities in your life. This means, ultimately, you can enjoy and be free of your worry during those other times.

Try your best to use the Worry Tool for 30 minutes each day at the same time and place. Keeping the time and place consistent is really important. At first, it may be hard to postpone your worries to when it’s time to use the Worry Tool. That’s OK.

Here are a few other ideas that can help when using the Worry Tool. Jot your worries down in a notebook or in your phone as they pop up throughout the day so you won’t forget about them when it’s time to use the Worry Tool. Or, grab an empty envelope and write “Worry” on it. Each time you have a worry, write it down on a piece of paper and stick it in your new worry envelope. Don’t open it until you’re ready to use the Worry Tool, at the same time and place each day.
It’s helpful to set a reminder in your phone for the time that will work best for you to use the Worry Tool.
The Impact of Worrying
Here's what you can expect to take away from today's activity:

items: Learn about the research behind worrying.
Learn the consequences of worrying.

components.text: The Science:

Have you ever felt that by worrying, you're preparing for the things that scare you? In some ways, worrying about the future can feel like self-protection. Your instincts tell you that if you worry, bad things won’t happen, or you’ll be better prepared for them if they do.

And worrying is often reinforced by the act of worrying. Very few of the things that we worry about will actually happen. So it's easy to tell ourselves we somehow prevented the bad event from happening in the way we worried about. It’s a kind of superstition. And, like most superstitions, it’s not backed by the research.

Researchers have found that worrying is actually unlikely to help worriers find good, concrete solutions for coping. Without a good coping strategy, the problems still exist, and the worrying continues.
Worrying so much has other real consequences. People who worry are more likely to be aware of threats and find more things threatening. In other words, they’re more likely to lead fearful lives.

Worriers are also more likely to procrastinate: worry affects decision-making speed. So, worriers put off tasks and really try to get things right because they’re very concerned they might be making mistakes; they second-guess themselves a lot.

And worrying makes people think less flexibly. Worriers tend to see only a few possible outcomes rather than all the possibilities. They get stuck on one aspect of a situation they find troubling and are less able to let it go and move on to another idea.

It’s in your best interest to contain your worries, but not just because it will make you feel better. It’s also about keeping your brain productive and functioning at high levels. That’s why learning strategies to contain your worries is well worth the effort it takes to get used to them. Figuring out how to separate ourselves from our worries, or our thoughts, and trying to take a new perspective on them can be helpful. Because worries are, after all, just thoughts.
It might be helpful to discuss your thoughts on this topic further with your coach
The Worry Tool
The Worry Tool is a step-by-step technique to help you manage your worries whenever they arise.
The Worry Tool will help you:

items: Recall a worry you've had over the past 24 hours.
Evaluate your worry.
Develop a solution for how to cope with this worry.

components.text: Before using the Worry Tool, try to find a quiet place where you won’t be disturbed. If possible, try to practice this technique in the same place and same time of day, ideally not right before bedtime.
The Worry Tool is a structured way to process your worries, but if you prefer you can use it as a loose guide, or just process your worries in your own way whenever you have the time to do so.
Note: The Worry Tool might not be the best technique if you’ve experienced panic attacks in the past.
The Worry Tool

There are two options for using the Worry Tool. Whichever option you choose, it's ideal to make sure you're using the Worry Tool at the same time and place each day, but if you can’t, that’s OK, too. Try to plan a time and place each day, even if it’s not the same every day. The goal is to learn to delay engaging with our worries.

Time to get started. Spend the next half hour or so giving yourself permission to worry about whatever you've postponed worrying about. Let your worry reign free. If you have trouble with just thinking through your worries, try saying your worries out loud or writing them down. Ready? Go. (If now is not a good time, feel free to pick another time to spend 30 minutes doing this).
Want more structure? Tell us about a worry you’ve experienced over the past 24 hours. Write it down in a piece of paper. We'll guide you through processing it.
What type of worry do you think this is?

options.name: A worry I can do something about
A worry I can't do anything about

components.text: You said: A worry I can do something about
Since you've got some control here, let's figure out exactly what you can do to help solve this worry.

Now, try your best to come up with five solutions to this worry. Write them down in a piece of paper. They can be small steps that might not completely solve the problem. Don't judge these solutions. Just let yourself write.

items: Solution 1 E.g. I can do a deep breathing technique.
Solution 2 E.g. I can make a list to help me prioritize.
Solution 3 E.g. I can set my alarm an hour earlier.
Solution 4 E.g. I can try a new activity.
Solution 5 E.g. I can schedule a meeting with my boss.

components.text: You said: A worry I can't do anything about
Let's spend some time evaluating this worry.
What's some evidence that this worry is true, or might happen?
What's some evidence that this worry is false, or might not happen?
Worst case scenario
Ok, now just for a minute, let's say this worry is true, or that it will happen. What is the worst case scenario? What's the absolute worst possible thing it could happen?
Write down your answers in a piece of paper
You've got this.
You have a solution. So, you can cross this worry off the list for now.

It's OK if you're still worried. The idea isn't to completely stop worrying or for the worry to suddenly disappear. That's a little unrealistic. But, evaluating the worry and brainstorming solutions can help you feel more in control. It can give you a sense of relief. You've created a path to help you tackle this worry.
Brainstorming Solutions

Let's brainstorm some ways you could manage this worst-case scenario. By coming up with a few solutions or strategies, you’ll be prepared for whatever might happen. Try to think of four possible solutions.
These solutions don't necessarily have to solve or fix anything. These can be small steps you can take. Or little things you can do to feel better, if the worst-case scenario does actually happen.
Brainstorming Solutions

items: Solution 1 E.g. I can do a deep breathing technique.
Solution 2 E.g. I can call a friend to talk.
Solution 3 E.g. I can go for a long walk.
Solution 4 E.g. I can exercise or take a long bath.

components.text: The good news is that you just came up with some solutions to help you manage the very worst-case scenario. By preparing for this extreme, you'll also be able to manage anything else that could happen.
Don't forget.
Sure, it's helpful to prepare for the worst-case scenario. But don't forget, you also came up with some evidence that this worry might not happen, or could even be false.
While you're now prepared for the worst-case scenario, it's important to really consider the evidence you created against your worry, too
You've got this.
Now that you've evaluated your worry and prepared for the worst-case scenario, you can cross this worry off the list for now.

It's okay if you're still worried. The idea isn't to completely stop worrying, or for the worry to suddenly disappear. That's a little unrealistic. But, evaluating the worry and brainstorming solutions to the worst-case scenario can help you feel more in control. It can give you a sense of relief. You've created a path to help you tackle this worry.

Next time you decide to use the Worry Tool, try to do it at the same time and place as you did today. If that's not possible, try planning ahead to specific time and place you'd like to use the Worry Tool next time.
What's next?
You can start the Worry Tool again with another worry, or use the same one again. Or, you can wrap up your Worry Tool practice for today.
Keep in mind, it's best to practice the Worry Tool for 30 minutes each day.
Tracking Automatic Thoughts
An automatic thought is the first thought that comes to mind after an experience. Automatic thoughts might not be based in fact and might make you feel worried or anxious.
This activity will teach you how to keep track of your automatic thoughts so you can better manage them:
Tracking automatic thoughts allows you to figure what triggers them and how to manage them in the future. Let’s start tracking them.

items: What was your most recent automatic thought? E.g. Sam is angry at me for being late.
When did you have the automatic thought?
Where were you? E.g. At lunch in the cafe.
What happened and how did you feel? E.g. I walked in a few minutes late and saw Sam talking with someone else and laughing, which made me feel hurt and anxious.
